fields.trailText: Bayer Leverkusen's coach Christoph Daum said yesterday he would take up the post with German national team next year despite the launch of a fraud probe into his finances. Daum said he would sign a three-year contract with the German FA in the next few weeks. "I am looking forward to the job. Everything is sorted out," he told a German news agency.

Daum said he would sign a three-year contract with the German FA in the next few weeks. "I am looking forward to the job. Everything is sorted out," he told a German news agency.

 Saudi Arabia are to calling for the release of the Wolverhampton Wanderers striker Sami Al Jaber 14 days before the start of the Asian Cup in Lebanon. The Saudi coach Milan Macala wants Wolves to release Al Jaber following the First Division match against Nottingham Forest on Saturday.

Al Jaber joined Wolves at the start of September, but only made his full debut in the 3-2 defeat by Grimsby Town in the League Cup on Tuesday night. He became the first Saudi to sign for an English side when he joined on a four-year contract after leaving Riyadh club Al Hilal.

webTitle: Rapid chance for Fowler to deliver

fields.headline: Rapid chance for Fowler to deliver
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler will line up at Anfield tonight for his first start alongside Michael Owen in more than 12 months.
fields.body:
Liverpool's Robbie Fowler will emerge from one of the bleakest periods of his fractured career against Rapid Bucharest this evening having been reminded that, despite his pedigree and his goals, he is still some way from realising his rich potential.

Having finally recovered from the after-effects of an ankle injury sustained during pre-season, the England international striker will line up in the first-round second-leg tie at Anfield for his first start alongside Michael Owen in more than 12 months.

"This is a most important season for Robbie, and he knows it," said Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier, who is also expected to recall the Finnish defender Sami Hyypia after injury. "He has had so many unfortunate setbacks over the past couple of years but now is the moment when he must prove what he is worth, when the potential must be fulfilled.

"He is now 25 years old and what we do not want is Robbie just to remain an outstanding prospect. I do not want people to say of him, 'he's a good player but...' I want him to show what he can do. If he is to achieve what I believe he can achieve there are certain sacrifices which have to be made. I think that he is now ready to deliver."

Fowler will replace Emile Heskey, who could be absent for up to six weeks if, as is now thought likely, he is forced to undergo corrective surgery on a damaged knee.

Although Liverpool won the first leg in Bucharest 1-0, Houllier is not taking anything for granted. After that victory he spent more time pointing out the possible return-leg pit-falls than he did celebrating victory.

He is acutely aware that tonight the great enemy to be conquered will be complacency and not the fighting spirit of opponents who were led meekly and compliantly to their fate earlier this month.

In many respects Liverpool's poor performance against Sunderland in the Premiership last Saturday may be a blessing in disguise because, having angered their manager once, only the more foolish of Houllier's squad would consider doing it for a second time.

"I was happy with the result in Bucharest, because any win away from home in a European competition is tremendous," he said. "But we musn't go into the second meeting with Rapid believing that the tie is over."

webTitle: Uefa Cup preview: HJK Helsinki v Celtic

fields.headline: Celtic silent over Collymore
fields.trailText: With the rehabilitation of one misfit striker a fait accompli during Martin O'Neill's tenure at Celtic, speculation about the arrival of another, Chris Sutton, dominated the build-up to tonight's tie in the Finnish capital.
fields.body:
With the rehabilitation of one misfit striker a fait accompli during Martin O'Neill's tenure at Celtic, speculation about the arrival of another dominated the build-up to the Scottish club's Uefa Cup second-leg tie against HJK Helsinki in the Finnish capital tonight.

Chris Sutton's form and strike rate have more than justified the manager's gamble in ending his incarceration at Chelsea, and after Stan Collymore's latest P45 from Leicester City, where he was signed by O'Neill last season, the prospect of a move north for one of football's more enduring sideshows does not require a leap of imagination.

But fanciful it may be. Collymore's homesickness when more than a bicycle ride from his native midlands is well documented, as Liverpool will testify, and O'Neill's faith in his current striking resources has been sufficient to allow the talented Mark Burchill to go on loan to Birmingham City. The club have so far refused comment on Collymore.

Tonight's opponents, meanwhile, have their own striker problems with the Brazilian Rafael offloaded to the Dutch side Heerenveen this week. HJK present a modest threat in his absence and have a 2-0 deficit to overcome from the first leg courtesy of a Henrik Larsson double in Glasgow.

They expect a crowd of 10,000 for the game, more than double the usual gate, but according to the coach Jyrki Heliskoski a partisan wall of noise from the normally reserved Finns is unlikely. "If we are leading 1-0 with a minute to go they might get excited," he said.

 Hearts face an injury crisis before tonight's second leg against Stuttgart at Tynecastle and will be without Robert Tomaschek, Scott Severin and Lee Makel, with further doubts over Gary McSwegan, Steve Fulton and Gary Locke.

webTitle: Uefa Cup peview: St Gallen v Chelsea

fields.headline: Blues hope Ranieri is Italian for reliability
fields.trailText: Chelsea's outing in Europe may distract from Claudio Ranieri's main aim of winning the Premiership, but the trip to Switzerland will at least allow him to try out his ant-crushing plans with his new charges.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri is not one to waste a moment in his quest to take Chelsea to the top. While waiting for the team's flight at Heathrow yesterday morning the new Italian coach and his assistants could be seen practising English with the club's interpreter.

"Twentee, thirtee, fortee," the trio repeated parrot-fashion, though the significance of that particular numerical choice was unclear. Maybe this is the range of push-ups the reportedly disciplinarian Ranieri plans to introduce as punishment for players who flag on the training ground.

Two sessions a day now under the new regime; a necessary hardship, Ranieri believes, if Chelsea are to banish the inconsistency that has dogged them.

"A great team has to be able to play against any team," said the coach, pointing to Chelsea's problems beating the minnows in the footballing pond. "My philosophy is to have a lot of tactical solutions. And players have to adapt themselves to various solutions. To do this you need a lot of training sessions."

So although an excursion in the Worthington Cup of Europe appears to be a distraction from Ranieri's main assignment of winning the Premiership, it does offer him a chance to try out his ant-crushing plans with his new charges.

St Gallen are to Europe what Bradford are to the Premiership, a small-town visitor to the big city. But it is precisely Chelsea's habit of slipping up against the sort of teams they should be beating that has undermined Ken Bates's plans to win a trophy big enough to match his ego.

The little Swiss club have to play this match in Zurich because their own ground is too small, but they showed in the first leg at Stamford Bridge that they possess the ability to embarrass Chelsea.

Compact, well organised and dangerous on the break, they managed to restrict the home side to a one-goal win, though admittedly their task was made easier by the despondency of a Chelsea team in shock after the sacking of Gianluca Vialli two days earlier.

Yesterday Gianfranco Zola took the opportunity to deny reports that he played a part in Vialli's downfall. "My conscience is clear," he said. "I wish I had that power."

But already Ranieri has moved to restore unity. "I will accept any result if the players have played with their hearts," he said yesterday. And, of course, that is exactly what Chelsea did in his first game in charge, coming back from 3-1 down to draw at Manchester United. It is the sort of spirit that will be required tonight.

Tactically, Ranieri is expected to stick by the 4-3-3 formation that Chelsea have used of late, even though Marcel Desailly is out injured and Dennis Wise faces a late fitness check.

Chelsea (probable): Cudicini; Panucci, Bogarde, Leboeuf, Le Saux; Di Matteo, Melchiot, Morris or Wise; Zola, Flo, Hasselbaink.

webTitle: Uefa Cup preview: Red Star Belgrade v Leicester

fields.headline: Leicester are all smiles
fields.trailText: With Stan Collymore's brooding presence removed, there will be no lack of commitment from Leicester's players tonight as Peter Taylor's men take on Red Star Belgrade in Vienna.
fields.body:
With Stan Collymore's brooding presence removed, there will be no lack of commitment from Leicester City's players in tonight's Uefa Cup second leg against Red Star Belgrade in Vienna.

The Leicester manager Peter Taylor admits that Collymore was originally in his plan for the tie but pointed out: "We haven't lost a game this season - and Stan has started only one of them."

The tie has been moved from Belgrade because of fears of tension after the Yugoslav elections, and Taylor believes that this can only improve his side's chances, with several thousand Foxes fans expected to travel. "If we had been playing Red Star in front of 52,000 fans in their own stadium with no support, it would have been much harder," he said.

"The players are in a happier frame of mind. As soon as they realised they were not going to Belgrade you could hear them saying 'Thank God for that'."

The wing-back Andrew Impey is Taylor's biggest concern as he has been unable to train since injuring an ankle against Everton on Sunday. In addition the striker Ade Akinbiyi has received a kick on a hamstring and Gerry Taggart, who scored in the 1-1 first-leg draw at Filbert Street, has been suffering from a sore knee.

webTitle: Worthington Cup: Bignot leads Rovers return

fields.headline: Bignot leads Rovers return
fields.trailText:
Bristol Rovers 1 - 1 Everton (agg 2-2)
After extra time Bristol Rovers won 4-2 on penalties.
fields.byline: David Foot  at the Memorial Ground
fields.body:
Bristol Rovers won through to the next round of the Worthington Cup after extra-time had failed to yield an opening at the Memorial ground last night. In the end, it was Rovers' skill in the penalty shoot-out that settled the tie.

Marcus Bignot, wing-back and captain, had earlier rescued Rovers with a goal that was just reward for a zestful second-half recovery and prolonged the tie with Everton for an additional half an hour.

It took Everton only 15 minutes to move into the lead against a Bristol side that relies so much on its precocious enthusiasm. There were four teenagers in the home team, two 17-year-olds in midfield, and they seemed at times overwhelmed against a Premiership unit that remained mobile and skilful on the wet surface and in the swirling rain.

But despite shouts for offside from optimistic Bristol supporters, the goal came after a quarter of an hour of tense and competitive football. Francis Jeffers moved on to the perfect ball, provided by Steve Watson and Thomas Gravesen, then veered to his right and struck the perfect shot past Nick Culkin, the goalkeeper on loan from Manchester United.

It was a busy and then disappointing opening half for Jeffers. Eight minutes before the interval he was carried off after being injured in a goalmouth challenge. Alec Cleland took his place.

Rovers were typically zestful and covered well. Their best and most challenging effort had come from their Latvian captain Vitalijs Astafjevs, with a swirling 35-yard free-kick that gave Paul Gerrard some trouble.

The pairing of the unorthodox Nathan Ellington and Clinton Ellis, a former Chelsea trainee who had come in at the last minute for the injured Evans, was not particularly productive and their stray raids broke down against competent defending.

Everton always had a little to spare, though Mark Hughes received an early lecture and, not long after, a booking for his clumsy tackle on 17-year-old Simon Bryant. Right on half-time his powerful header was saved by Culkin just under the bar.

Rovers recovered some verve in the second half and extended their more experienced opponents for the first time. It still took a leaping save by Culkin to beat away a dangerous free-kick from Joe Max Moore, but Rovers delighted their full house of supporters with an equaliser after 58 minutes.

Scott Jones advanced down the left and Ellington saw his beefy drive parried by Gerrard. Bignot, up with his forwards, pounced to steer the rebound into an empty net.

webTitle: Digital TV seen as lifeline for poor

fields.headline: Digital TV seen as lifeline for poor
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Efforts to establish whether the internet and digital television can help to tackle social exclusion are to be announced today under a scheme run by parliamentary charity the Hansard Society.
fields.body:
Efforts to establish whether the internet and digital television can help to tackle social exclusion are to be announced today under a scheme run by parliamentary charity the Hansard Society.

As part of its research on how the internet could be used to improve communication between policymakers and people their decisions affect, the Hansard Society plans to use digital TV to harness the views of low income families.

Halifax's online bank is sponsoring the research which is attempting to establish whether digital TV can be used to foster debate between people on low incomes and politicians who make policies that are supposed to help them.

The new research, which will also test the internet as a tool to consult with elderly people, comes after surprise figures from the office for national statistics showed that 55% of Britons had never surfed the net. The statistics showed that low-income families and older people missed out, a potential worry for government which has cited the internet as one of its tools to enhance the country's role in the e-economy.

According to the ONS, a third of the people who access the internet have done so at work. This is expected to change once digital TV becomes more common and moves access to the internet to the living room.

Halifax Online said: "The project is designed to establish that technology is socially inclusive".

The Hansard Society said the research was the second stage in its "electronic democracy" programme, which earlier this year used the new e-technology to construct a dialogue between women victims of domestic violence and politicians.

webTitle: Savings rate drops in buoyant Britain

fields.headline: Savings rate drops in buoyant Britain
fields.trailText: British households, buoyed by the lowest unemployment rate for 20 years, are saving less of their income than at any time since the Lawson boom, according to official figures.
fields.body:
British households, buoyed by the lowest unemployment rate for 20 years, are saving less of their income than at any time since the Lawson boom, according to official figures.

In the second quarter of this year, the savings ratio - the proportion of income put aside for a rainy day - fell to 3%, the lowest since the third quarter of 1988 when it was also 3%. The fall was put down to low growth in salaries forcing people to draw on money they might otherwise have saved to maintain spending.

The figure has only once been lower, in the second quarter of 1963 during the Tories' pre-election boom which saw the ratio drop to 2.6%.

City analysts said the figures, published by the office for national statistics (ONS), pointed to signs of growing financial strain and that higher interest rates would be needed to persuade consumers to save more.

"With financial imbalances continuing to build, prevarication by the doves on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee is increasing the risks of a hard landing for the UK economy," said Richard Iley, of Dutch bank ABN AMRO.

Growth of household dividend income was also weak, reflecting heavy selling of share holdings in recent years.

There was a 0.8% jump in household expenditure, compared with 0.6% in the first quarter.

Separate balance of payments figures showed Britain in the red by £3.3bn, the same as in the first quarter.

webTitle: Murray Perahia's golden oldies

fields.headline: Murray Perahia's golden oldies
fields.standfirst:
Murray Perahia
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Murray Perahia
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.body:
Concert-goers in Manchester can easily feel patronised. When a major artist blows in from New York with only one work of his programme advertised in advance, we wonder. When the actual programme consists of Mozart's best-known piano piece, Schubert's best-known sonata, Chopin's best-known scherzo, probably his two best-known polonaises and his five best-known études (from Op 10, replacing the rarer Op 25 given in the printed programme), and then as an encore gives us Schubert's best-known impromptu, it really is time to feel uneasy.

Does Murray Perahia really think that Manchester audiences are not ready for anything else? At least his second encore was what probably counts as Chopin's least-known nocturne (Op 15, No 1, for the record).

There are, of course, good reasons why these works are so well known: they are among the finest and most fulfilling creations of western civilisation. And Perahia plays them like an angel. Particularly Schubert's last piano sonata, which grew and evolved with the most marvellous colours. It can so easily sound as though it were written against the instrument, but never for Perahia. Every detail was lovingly turned.

Schubert's often wayward formal designs flowed gracefully and gloriously, seeming perfectly logical. Nothing was overstated; in fact, Perahia never even opened his shoulders until the slow movement and did not actually play loudly until the final bars.

Naturally, things were different in the big Chopin pieces: the A-flat Polonaise was grand and stately, the Revolutionary Etude raised the rafters, and for the second Scherzo Perahia let it all hang out. But he is an artist who cannot do anything unmusical and ruthlessly resists making a fuss. He just sits there and the beauty flows out of his fingers. Which is why it is such a disappointment that he could not see his way to putting in even a few minutes of something unfamiliar.

Even in Manchester people are fast becoming aware of the enormous range of wonderful music that is rarely or never heard. Even in Manchester there is an impatience with the old repertory of a few dozen "masterpieces" handed down to us from the previous generation, and there is an awareness that there is something dangerously moribund in an art that trots out the same pieces without any aesthetic risks. Even with no advertised programme, Perahia can more or less fill the hall. But couldn't he offer something different?

When the actual programme consists of Mozart's best-known piano piece, Schubert's best-known sonata, Chopin's best-known scherzo, probably his two best-known polonaises and his five best-known études (from Op 10, replacing the rarer Op 25 given in the printed programme), and then as an encore gives us Schubert's best-known impromptu, it really is time to feel uneasy. webTitle: York gets ready to rumble

fields.headline: York gets ready to rumble
fields.standfirst:
Rumble Fish
Theatre Royal, York
***
fields.trailText:
Rumble Fish
Theatre Royal, York
***
fields.body:
The world premiere of the adaptation of SE Hinton's cult novel is something of a coup for Pilot Theatre Company. If it turns out to be less satisfactory than the company's last production, Lord of the Flies, it is not for want of theatrical daring - more to do with the fact that, for all its pseudo- Greek grandeur, Hinton's tale of brotherly love and hate in smalltown USA is big on teenage angst but small on more pressing world issues.

Adaptor and director Marcus Romer attempts some updating and there is a passing nod towards the connection between alienation, loneliness and the Columbine High School massacre. But there is little in the script that isn't conveyed more eloquently by his production, in which digital projection and live action are combined to quite brilliant and dislocating effect.

The overall impression is of something extraordinarily liquid, as if the entire performance is taking place in a giant goldfish bowl. A goldfish bowl which - as teenage tearaway Rusty James becomes increasingly obsessed with his brother, Motorcycle Boy - appears to fill with swirling patterns of blood. The sense of tension is added to by a continuous soundtrack that becomes a comment upon Rusty's increasingly agitated emotional internal world.

As in Francis Ford Coppola's movie version, the setting is almost timeless, maybe even futuristic, an impression added to by Ali Allen and Marise Rose's set, an urban concrete canyon complete with climbing wall. The actors use every inch of the space, both vertical and horizontal.

The increasing isolation of Rusty is cleverly done. This is a soul cut adrift: abandoned as a child by his mother, ignored by his drunken father, dumped by his girlfriend and rejected by his best friend. Romer's production places him in creasingly apart, bound only by an invisible umbilical cord to the brother who tolerates him but cannot embrace him.

Playing Rusty, Ari James is impressive on the boy's broken physicality, but vocally monotonous - particularly when conveying internal thought. These might work better as voiceovers. Most of the other characterisations are too skimpy to really make you care, although Ryan McClusky as Motorcycle Boy has a self-contained, detached glamour.

But for all its flaws, as with Lord of the Flies, there is a genuine sense of theatrical enquiry as it explores the relationship between theatre and digital technology, and triumphantly proves that they can be equal partners. And you can't complain about a show that gets 800 teenagers into the theatre on a wet Wednesday afternoon and generates the kind of rapt attention in which you could hear a pin drop.

 Until October 7. Box office: 01904 623568. Then tours.

webTitle: Alistair Beaton's top 10 New Labour bollocks

fields.headline: Alistair Beaton's top 10 New Labour bollocks
fields.trailText: Writer and broadcaster Alistair Beaton is the author of The Little Book of New Labour Bollocks: The Ultimate Antidote to Spin
fields.body:
Writer and broadcaster Alistair Beaton is the author of The Little Book of New Labour Bollocks: The Ultimate Antidote to Spin.
Buy The Little Book of New Labour Bollocks at Amazon.co.uk

1. What they said:
Many of Labour's improvements will not occur overnight.
(Labour Party policy document, January 2000)

What they meant:
Many of Labour's improvements will not occur.

2. What he said:
For better or for worse, we have a democratic system in this country.
(Lord Falconer, minister of state in the Cabinet Office, on Question Time, BBC TV, 11 May 2000)

What he meant:
I didn't get where I am today by being elected.

3. What he said:
You can always tell when an election is about to happen. The Tories head straight for the gutter and start playing the race card.
(Jack Straw, shadow home secretary, speech to Labour Party conference, October 1996)

What he meant:
That's a very nice gutter you've got there. May I join?

4. What he said:
It's a pity we can't have a more intelligent debate.
(John Prescott, Deputy Prime Minister, Speech to Labour Party Conference,September '99)

What he meant:
I wrote this speech myself.

5. What they said:
A fairer system of student grants.
(Lifelong Learning, Labour Party policy document, 1996)

What they meant:
No student grants.

6. What they said:
Labour aims to achieve a better qualtity of life for all by pursuing joined-up policies.
Labour Party policy document, January 2000

What they meant:
Tony Blair will be in charge in everything.

7. What they said:
Labour believes in the interdependence of town and country
Labour Party policy document, January 2000

What they meant:
We all have second homes.

8. What he said:
Responsibility is what I call the fourth R that is essential to successful schooling.
(Tony Blair, speech at the University of London, 23 June 1995)

What he meant:
The other three are:
Ranting at teachers
Rubbishing schools
Rogering LEA's

9. What he said:
A strong civic society takes seriously its obligations to our elderly.
(Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer, House of Commons, 21 March 2000)

What he meant:
75p.

10. What they said:
The country needs a transport system that is safe, efficient, clean and fair.
(Labour Party policy document, January 2000)

What they meant:
France.

webTitle: Calexico

fields.headline: Calexico
fields.standfirst:
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.body:
Concept music is silly by nature, but there's something especially absurd about Calexico. Like the town from which they take their name, their music sits plumb on the border between California and Mexico, or at least between the California and Mexico of old westerns, those expansive deserts populated by sly muchachos, scowling drifters, and beautiful women who lure the latter into their boudoirs only to steal their wallets and throw their pants to the hogs.

On Hot Rail, Calexico's recent third album, the accumulation of celluloid cliches is subtly executed: the brass breezes gently, the slide guitar lilts in the background, the mood is hazy, meditative, dark. The more accurately it's reproduced on stage, the less interesting it sounds. Joined on stage by a double bassist and a pair on trumpet and vibraphone, singer/guitarist Joey Burns and drummer John Convertino conjure images of clacking spurs, smoky saloons, men in ponchos fixing for a duel, even in one of London's plush former theatres. But they do so only when they play to the hilt, when the trumpets blare, when Burns bends his strings into extravagant Morricone-styled riffs.

Their first 10 songs, including a muted rendition of Service and Repair and a disappointingly flat version of the gorgeous Fade, are pleasant but lack verve. Calexico need their gimmicks: the more ridiculous their performance, the more engaging they are.

Just in time for the Hispanic trills of Tres Avisos, something happens. On troops a five-piece mariachi band: mischievous, brilliant musicians sporting bell-trimmed trousers and huge sombreros, whose aim is to chuck chilli powder over Burns and Convertino's songs. With their vibrant accompaniment, the brass-laden Stray has thrilling power, while the Hazlewood and Sinatra-inspired duet Ballad of Cable Hogue exhilarates, not least because Burns is also joined by a pistol-toting Frenchwoman who sings her role of murderous seducer with brio. Of course it's possible to go too far over the top: the encore closes with improvised party music more usually heard at tacky beach resorts. But it doesn't stop you looking for a horse and dusty cowboy to take you home when you leave.

webTitle: The Frustration of Figaro

fields.headline: The Frustration of Figaro
fields.standfirst:
The Marriage of Figaro
Grand Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
The Marriage of Figaro
Grand Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.body:
Some operas survive a sexless interpretation, but for Figaro the pheromones must fly. Caroline Gawn's playful staging for Opera North is steeped in sexual juices, while there's scarcely a whiff of the piece's revolutionary politics. And the fresh, young cast are lithe enough to make the palpitations palpable.

Figaro is an opera of anticipation, not fulfilment. Figaro does not get married; the Count does not get his hands on Susanna; Cherubino does not find a berth for his floating libido. As the events of the day unfold, Count Almaviva's delaying tactics appear not so much an attempt to put a seigneurial spanner in the works as a piece of masterly crafted titillation. Mozart transforms the basis of broad farce into an exquisite sequence of tension and release - the finest three hours of operatic foreplay ever written.

The credibility of many productions stalls at the sight of rather advanced young lovers panting for their wedding night. If anything, Gawn's suffers from the opposite problem. Michael John Pearson's show-stealingly virile Bartolo is far too well-preserved to be Figaro's father. But when even the oldies such as he and Marcellina (a comely Carole Wilson) are apparently in the first rather than the final flush of passion, the sexual charge of the Almaviva household crackles.

It helps that this generally upwardly-mobile cast seems excited by the business of working together. A production of Figaro more distinguished for its ensembles than its solo turns is no bad thing, and this is undoubtedly influenced by conductor Roderick Brydon's taut, intelligible approach. It's a good night for words, and hence for laughs, which are packed in by Amanda Holden's feisty translation.

Perhaps the lack of one truly outstanding vocal performance holds the show back, but characterisation has been well attended to. James Rutherford's amiable, slightly bumbling Figaro always seems a mental pace or two behind Colette Delahunt's Susanna. Majella Cullagh makes a fine job of maintaining the Countess's dignity, while Roderick Williams, as her husband, haplessly sabotages his own.

Best of all, however, is Emer McGilloway's Cherubino, a hopeless streak of hormones who seems to have lurched in from some adolescent bedroom to wreak havoc on an already overheated household. Alice Purcell's cartoon-rococo sets have a certain infantile charm, and if they lack a degree of substantiality, then so does Almaviva's authority. Figaro exposes the old social order as unstable. It could all blow away in a gust of laughter.

In rep until February 8. Box office: 0113-222 6222.

webTitle: Scottish bank bemoans its lack of partners

fields.headline: Scottish bank bemoans its lack of partners
fields.standfirst: Bank of Scotland says its appetite for growth is as strong as ever despite losing a bid for NatWest earlier this year
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland disappointed investors by remaining single yesterday despite conceding it wanted a partner to replace NatWest which it lost earlier this year.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland disappointed investors by remaining single yesterday despite conceding it wanted a partner to replace NatWest which it lost earlier this year.

A year on from the launch of its ill-fated bid for NatWest, Sir John Straw, governor (chairman) of BoS, said: "Our appetite for growth by acquisition is a great as ever".

But, BoS, which has been the topic of frenzied bid speculation in recent days, highlighted its organic growth instead as it reported a 14% rise in first half pre-tax profits to a record £535m. Its shares fell 30p to 580p.

The bank, which faces doubts in the City that it will be able to keep growing quickly, is cutting costs by reducing its workforce by 5% either by out-sourcing services, such as IT, or through voluntary redundancies.

Peter Burt, the chief executive of BoS, insisted that the bank's credibility had not been tarnished since losing NatWest to Royal Bank of Scotland. "It's very clear our momentum carries on undiminished," he said.

But, John-Paul Crutchley, analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "The growth story is faltering."

BoS, which has reorganised its business during the year at a cost of £66m, described its corporate banking business as the "jewel in the crown" after benefiting from a move to take public companies private.

In its personal banking business, Mr Burt pointed to demands from customers for better value for money and better service as putting pressure on profit margins. Its mortgage business, increasing by 17%, outpaced the broader market.

BoS runs Sainsbury's Bank and is looking for other partnerships with retailers and internet sites to selling more products to consumers.

The bank is considering changing the way it makes its provisions against bad and doubtful debts, which it believes is more conservative than some of its rivals.

Its charge against specific bad debts rose to £163m but its general provision fell in comparison with last year when it was hurt by car leasing and a loan to a Germany company hit by fraud.

It is also planning to securitise, essentially repackage as bonds, more of its loans in attempt to improve its potential returns to investors. It will pay a 5.3p dividend, up 15%.

webTitle: BBCSO/ Mackerras

fields.headline: BBCSO/ Mackerras
fields.standfirst:
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.body:
There are few better pieces than Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra to show off technical and musical virtuosity. The BBC Symphony Orchestra's performance of the work marked the opening of their 70th season, and the start of their new association with the Barbican. But with Janacek's Sinfonietta on the same programme - a work that tops even the Bartok for celebratory splendour - it was clear that this was no ordinary curtain-raiser. We were also marking the 75th birthday of the orchestra's conductor, Sir Charles Mackerras.

Mackerras's infectious energy creates a distinctive sound in any orchestra. The combination of airy brightness and superbly polished ensemble he produces was ideally suited to Bartok's extrovert concerto. The first movement grew in lyrical, brooding momentum, while Mackerras's fleet-footed tempo emphasised the rustic jocularity of the second movement. The third movement's eruptive nocturne, and the faltering intermezzo of the fourth movement, were also memorably characterised. But the tempestuous momentum of Mackerras's finale left all the preceding movements in its wake.

Mackerras is most closely associated with Janacek, however, and his interpretation of the Czech's Sinfonietta underlined his understanding of one of the composer's most demanding scores. Mackerras allowed the phalanx of extra trumpets required by Janacek to generate a suitable sonic superabundance. Yet this spectacular fanfare was only one dimension of his performance. He delineated the sometimes bizarre juxtapositions of mood, texture and melody with unerring conviction. The result was a riotous musical pageant, which encompassed everything from heraldic splendour to bawdy abandon.

The concert began with a more recent fanfare: the first UK performance of Harrison Birtwistle's Sonance Severance 2000, written for the reopening of the Cleveland Orchestra's Severance Hall. Although this is barely three minutes long, Birtwistle works out a fully fledged musical process in a series of cumulative, volcanic gestures. Finally, its energy spent after an enormous crescendo, a lone trumpet quietly intones a bare dotted rhythm: a bleak question to conclude this most uncompromising of musical christenings.

Mackerras demonstrated his versatility with a performance of Dvorak's Violin Concerto with soloist Pamela Frank. The conductor's rhythmic vitality and Frank's full-toned lyricism provided the most eloquent advocacy for one of Dvorak's more verbose compositions.

Leadership defeat: Darling fails to head off rebels demanding restoration of earnings link

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The grande dame of the Labour party, Barbara Castle, made an impassioned plea at the Labour conference in Brighton yesterday for restoration of the earnings link in the basic state pension yesterday when she questioned why the world's fourth richest country could not afford pensioners "that dignity".
fields.body:
The grande dame of the Labour party, Barbara Castle, made an impassioned plea at the Labour conference in Brighton yesterday for restoration of the earnings link in the basic state pension yesterday when she questioned why the world's fourth richest country could not afford pensioners "that dignity".

In an rapturously received speech on the week's most controversial subject, the veteran politician, 90 next month, warned delegates: "Unless this conference declares 'Yes', we won't see the restoration of the earnings link, not in my lifetime anyway." To cheers, and after a standing ovation, she said the "precious" basic state pension scheme would "to all intents and purposes be dead by the middle of the century" under the government's proposals, and suggested that the "very clever" social security secretary, Alistair Darling, had been less than honest.

"What he failed to tell you was that if Margaret Thatcher had not abolished the earnings link the moment she got into power in 1979, the single state pension today would have been worth £97 a week to everybody. It would have built up gradually and would have been a bearable cost." She continued: "This country can afford it because the cost of the earnings link only rises if earnings are rising too. Is a wealthy country not going to afford that dignity to our pensioners?"

Lady Castle's rallying cry came during a fevered debate in which the government failed to head off a revolt, despite 11th hour negotiations between the unions, the prime minister and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who flew back to the conference from a meeting of international finance directors in Prague. After intense pressure to restore the link, Mr Darling urged delegates to remit a union motion calling for an "immediate and substantial increase" in the basic pension, plus a restoration of the link to earnings, and to accept the government's proposals, which would mean "more, much more" for the poorest pensioners instead.

Stressing the party's commitment to the basic state pension and determination to "abolish" pensioner poverty, he confirmed that the government would raise the minimum income guarantee to £90 a week from next April, before concentrating on helping "millions of lower and middle income pensioners" with additional pensions of up to £30 a week through the pension credit scheme.

"If the choice is giving a little bit to everyone or giving more to the poorest and more to the people in the middle incomes, giving more to the people who require it most must be the priority for any party of social justice," he said time and again.

But his arguments held little sway with an audience that jeered one delegate who called on the party to "trust Gordon Brown, trust Tony Blair".

A Welsh pensioner, Monica Walsh, drew loud cheers when she told Mr Darling she still had to work because her two pensions only came to £480 a month and her mortgage to over £200.

"We can't wait until 2003," she said, referring to year when the pension credit will be introduced, "because we might be dead by then".

Rodney Bickerstaffe, general secretary of Unison, said supporting the earnings link was not a rant from the extreme left, and the elderly deserved better from the government: "The pensioners have not blocked the oil refineries, they have not threatened public services."

webTitle: Elton and Lloyd Webber's game of two halves

fields.headline: Elton and Lloyd Webber's game of two halves
fields.standfirst:
The Beautiful Game
Cambridge Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Beautiful Game
Cambridge Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
After years of hyperinflated, through-composed musicals, we at last seem to be returning to stories. And even if The Beautiful Game, which teams the abrasive Ben Elton and the romantic Andrew Lloyd Webber, isn't the greatest musical you'll ever see, it has the signal virtue of telling its story through words as well as song.

Elton brings the same narrative propulsion you find in his fiction. And his theme is the way the sectarian divide in Northern Ireland destroys promise. In the first half we see the triumphant progress of a Catholic boys' soccer club against the lengthening shadows of the 1969 troubles. But in the second we see lives fall apart. John, the newly married star striker, is interned and turned from potential professional into IRA hitman. His old mate, Thomas, becomes a manipulative Republican boss. Other team members, whose only previous sins were professional fouls, end up dead, exiled or crippled.

The big question is whether a musical is capable of measuring up to the subject of Northern Ireland at the time of the exploding troubles. For large parts of the show, the answer is yes. Elton is careful to condemn bigotry on both sides but there is a scene in the second half that conveys an uncomfortable truth about Northern Ireland. As the devious Thomas confronts the recently interned John he announces: "We aren't trying to win - we're trying to stop the other side winning." And that extremist belief that it is the struggle itself that matters, rather than any possible victory, is still sadly with us.

Where the musical doesn't always measure up is in trying to dovetail private lives and public attitudes. In the first half the joins are seamless: Lloyd Webber comes up with one particularly poignant song, God's Own Country, where a Protestant and Catholic girl both lay claim to national pride. But in the rebarbative second half, with its killing, and knee-capping, it becomes hard to swallow the climactic romanticism. Lyrics and music turn to mush as we're told: "There's only one love in the end."

But, even if the musical falls at the last hurdle, it as at least trying something boldly different, and Lloyd Webber's score, with its echoes of Irish folk and ballad music, is his best since Aspects of Love. Robert Carsen's stripped-down production is also free of that embalming detail you so often find in Lloyd Webber shows.

Meryl Tankard's choreography is excellent at conveying the aerial motions of footballing action. And there are good performances from Josie Walker, who has a raw-boned intensity as the deserted bride, David Shannon as the budding soccer star who swaps goals for guns, and Michael Shaeffer as the bespectacled Republican hardliner. Not a great musical, but at least it returns an inflated form to its storytelling origins.

Booking until March. Box office: 020-7494 5080. This review appeared in some editions yesterday.

webTitle: The Country Wife

fields.headline: The Country Wife
fields.standfirst:
Crucible, Sheffield
***
fields.trailText:
Crucible, Sheffield
***
fields.body:
William Wycherley wrote this satire about a man-about-town who gets unlimited access to his friends' wives by pretending to be a eunuch in 1675. Four years later he made his first disastrous marriage, to the Countess of Drogheda, which left him in financial difficulties for the rest of his life.

If he had written the play after his marriage, he might have penned an even more jaundiced account of male-female relationships. The situation in The Country Wife is summed up by one man thus: "If we do not cheat, the women will try to cheat us." Ironically, Wycherley ended up duped like one of his own characters: on his deathbed he married a woman who was, unbeknown to him, his cousin's mistress. She inherited his estate and promptly married the cousin.

That such scenarios were not just the figment of a playwright's imagination gives Wycherley's play the sourest of edges. But that aspect is not brought out in Michael Grandage's production. It is stylish and impeccably acted but treats this iciest of plays with cheery good nature. It is a while since I've seen the Alithea/Harcourt subplot played straight, with this duplicitously achieved union held up as a model of potential happiness.

If Grandage's production makes you leave the theatre feeling jolly, that's probably good news for the box office. It is less so for the drama, which is reduced to the level of romp. Even so, there are some nice touches: everyone rushes on and off the stage at high speed as if they're in a hurry to get into bed as quickly as possible.

Grandage's emphasis on the comic is pointed up in Victoria Hamilton's performance as Margery Pinchwife, the locked-up, country-innocent wife who becomes the object of the "eunuch" Horner's lust. She has the body of a 20-year-old and the mind of a foot-stamping toddler. It is in many ways an intensely irritating performance, although you have to admire its spirit and technical virtuosity. Dominic West, meanwhile, captures all of Horner's rumpled appeal and David Ross almost makes you feel sorry for the puffed-up Pinchwife.

This is a watchable, polished production. It is just a pity that it is so cosy.

Until October 14. Box office: 0114-249 6000.

webTitle: Game over for Collymore

fields.headline: Game over for Collymore
fields.standfirst: 'Unacceptable' attitude means Leicester show the troubled striker the door
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore found the last chance saloon at Leicester City shut last night when he was put on the transfer list by the manager Peter Taylor and told he was overweight, lacked application and had an inflated opinion of his worth.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore found the last chance saloon at Leicester City shut last night when he was put on the transfer list by the manager Peter Taylor and told he was overweight, lacked application and had an inflated opinion of his worth.

Taylor chose his words more carefully but his message was clear in describing how the errant striker had failed to put his career back on track at Filbert Street after the former City manager Martin O'Neill gave him the chance.

O'Neill took a risk when he signed Collymore who, out of favour with the Aston Villa manager John Gregory, was training with Villa's youth team. Now the 29-year-old is unlikely to be allowed to do even that with City after Taylor confirmed that putting him on the transfer list was tantamount to exiling him.

"He won't be training with the first-team squad and we'll be talking to his advisers about the whole training situation," Taylor said. "You never say never, especially in football, but I would be surprised if I played him again."

This latest trough in Collymore's trouble-strewn career follows his bright start at Filbert Street when he scored a hat-trick on his home debut to earn forgiveness from O'Neill for the infamous Fireman Stan escapade in Spain.

His current reversal of fortune began with City refusing his demands for a new contract six weeks ago and culminated in a woeful display against Everton on Sunday.

"His performance when he came on as a substitute on Sunday was the last straw," Taylor said. "I felt he could have worked a lot harder and it was totally unacceptable for a professional footballer. I told him that and he agreed. The performance was also out of character for a Leicester City player and meant it was time for me to step in."

Initially Taylor and Collymore, who had submitted a written transfer request on Monday, agreed to tear up his contract. But after Collymore talked with his advisers, who Taylor believes pointed out that the player would continue to be paid if he stayed put, he changed his mind.

Now he will remain at Filbert Street until another club comes in for him or until his contract expires in June.

It was after a previous meeting involving Collymore and his advisers, Taylor and the City chairman John Elsom that things started to go awry.

"They [his advisers] came in nine days before the start of the season and asked for very, very high wage demands and a new contract," Taylor said.

"I thought their timing was poor and the demands were totally unacceptable. They were far in excess of what any player earns here. Leicester City have given some good contracts this year to some good players who have played well for the club. And they haven't just played well over 6 matches, they've done it over a number of years and nearly 200 matches.

"Disappointingly for me, ever since then Stan's application has not been as positive as it had been in pre-season when he worked extremely hard to recover from a broken leg."

After a low-key display in the season's curtain-raiser against Villa, Collymore has not been in the starting line-up again because, Taylor says, "he has not recovered his fitness after suffering an achilles injury in training. He's put on a stone since the start of the season".

Taylor also questioned Collymore's attitude in advance of tomorrow's Uefa Cup tie against Red Star Belgrade in Vienna, adding: "He's not going on the trip because he says he's injured, but my physios don't seem to think so."

Collymore nevertheless appears anxious to resolve the issue. "I don't want to leave Leicester," he confirmed. "I'd like to tie down my future at Leicester and ever since [the pre-season contract talks] I've given my best.

"All I want to do, having come back from a broken leg, is to play regular first-team football. My aim is to get back into the England squad and I don't think I am going to do that by coming on for 20 or 30 minutes in a game."

Meanwhile, the FA has confirmed that its video advisory panel will meet this week to review Collymore's tangle with Paul Gascoigne on Sunday.

Stan Collymore fact file

1971

Born Stone, Staffordshire, January 22.

1993

After spells with Crystal Palace and Southend, joins Nottingham Forest for £2.2m rising to £2.75m.

1995

Acquitted of assault charge for alleged fight outside nightclub. First England cap against Japan. Joins Liverpool for British-record £8.5m.

1996

Fined £20,000 for missing training but Liverpool manager Roy Evans says Collymore will be staying even though he fails to play a reserve-team fixture.

1997

Joins Aston Villa for £7m.

October: Sent off and given a three-match ban after exchanging blows with Bolton defender Andy Todd. Todd undergoes nose operation to cure a breathing problem.

1998 March : Accuses Liverpool's Steve Harkness of racist abuse during and after Villa's 2-1 home victory.

June : Involved in an altercation with girlfriend and television presenter Ulrika Jonsson in a bar in Paris. He "deeply regrets everything that occurred" and "is beside himself with remorse".

1999

January : Announces he is seeking counselling and spends two weeks in a clinic to undergo treatment for depression.

February Returns to Villa side against Leeds. After 3-0 home defeat by Chelsea Gregory says he will not pick Collymore again this season as he needs full-time treatment for his depression.

August Moves to Fulham on a three-month loan .

December Collymore talks over a move to French club Montpellier but the deal is off when he refuses to play in a practice match.

February 10 Leicester sign Collymore on a pay-as-you-play deal.

February 16 Leicester are thrown out of their La Manga training base after Collymore is accused of letting off a fire extinguisher in a bar. Fined two weeks' wages and ordered to do community service by the club and warned as to his future conduct.

April Breaks left leg in the 3-0 defeat at Derby.

September FA video advisory panel to review incident in which Collymore appeared to stamp on and later elbow Paul Gascoigne. Collymore put on transfer list at his own request.

webTitle: Worthington Cup: Tottenham 2 - 0 Brentford (agg 2- 0)

fields.headline: Norse raid saves Spurs blushes
fields.trailText: Tottenham 2 - 0 Brentford (agg 2- 0)
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham's season is in danger of turning into a slow dirge. Last night they struggled to hit the high notes against a team two divisions below them.

Victory over a tiring Brentford was secured by second half goals from the Norwegian Oyvind Leonhardsen and a late tap-in from his fellow countryman Steffen Iversen. But it could not disguise the off-key nature of progression into the third round.

After the first leg Spurs had been upset by a comment from the Brentford manager Ron Noades that "when Ramon Vega comes on, you've always got a chance".

Last night the big defender made a rare start to a game, but still did his best to prove the accuracy of Noades' assessment when, on 51 minutes, he miskicked a clearance straight to Scott Partridge. Unfortunately for Brentford, the striker could only sky an inviting chance over the bar from 16 yards.

Two minutes later Leonhardsen gave Partridge an instant lesson in how to score from that range. Sherwood's forward header was helped on by a Brentford defender and the ball fell to the feet of the Norwegian, who tucked it past the visiting keeper. At last the home side had shown they were better than Brentford at something.

There was no devaluing of the Worthington Cup at White Hart Lane. After only managing a 0-0 draw in the first leg of this tie, George Graham reinforced against the possibility of an overall upset by fielding a full-strength side from those players available.

Tottenham were, however, without Sol Campbell (who picked up an injury in the first leg of this tie), Mauricio Taricco and Darren Anderton. Brentford were missing three players - Andy Scott, Mark McCammon and Simon Marsh.

Spurs began the evening expecting to repeat the victory they achieved over their poor relations from the other side of London at the same stage of this competition two years ago.

They went on to win the cup that season and are eager to repeat that feat in their quest for a place in Europe.

Not for the first time this season, lack of attacking creativity undermined Tottenham's ambitions. After a sparky first 15 minutes their play in the first half degenerated from the predictable to the disjointed.

They created chances: Tim Sherwood saw a header cleared off the line and Olafur Gottskalksson made smart saves from Iversen and Sergei Rebrov. Until the intervention of Leonhardsen, however, it was a poor return for a supposedly superior team.

They created chances: Tim Sherwood saw a header cleared off the line and Olafur Gottskalksson made smart saves from Iversen and Sergei Rebrov. Until the intervention of Leonhardsen, however, it was a poor return for a supposedly superior team.

webTitle: Champions League preview: Arsenal v Lazio

fields.headline: Lazio's firepower will test Gunners
fields.trailText: If ever Arsenal needed the home fires of their Champions League ambitions to burn bright it will be tonight when Lazio, the Italian champions and one of the tournament favourites, visit Highbury.
fields.body:
If ever Arsenal needed the home fires of their Champions League ambitions to burn bright it will be tonight when Lazio, the Italian champions and one of the tournament favourites, visit Highbury.

Lazio are not unbeatable; Valencia proved as much in last season's quarter-finals when they won the opening leg 5-2. But Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Rome club's Swedish coach, now enjoys an even more formidable set of options after spending £52m on two Argentine strikers, Hernan Crespo from Parma and Claudio Lopez from Valencia.

Crespo is unfit, but an Arsenal defence heavily dependent on the match fitness of Tony Adams will still have to cope with Claudio Lopez and Simone Inzaghi.

The importance of Adams's authority at the back was re-emphasised when Arsène Wenger rested him at Ipswich on Saturday. Arsenal cannot risk a repetition of the bizarre first half they experienced against Shakhtar Donetsk at Highbury a week ago when the Ukrainians scored twice in four minutes. Against Lazio it would take more than the heroics of Martin Keown to turn a similar situation around tonight.

No doubt the passions of the crowd spurred Arsenal on last Wednesday, something which was not quite working for them when they were playing their home legs at Wembley. "In our minds we will be playing at home tomorrow and our opponents will be away," Wenger explained. "At Wembley we didn't really play at home while our opponents didn't really play away."

Wenger will decide today who is to partner Thierry Henry up front, with Nwankwo Kanu a better bet than Dennis Bergkamp or Sylvain Wiltord after the Nigerian's important contribution to the recovery against Shakhtar. Provided Henry gets the service, his pace should test even Alessandro Nesta, who defended so well for Italy in Euro 2000.

First, however, Arsenal will look to Patrick Vieira to help them gain control of midfield, where Lazio are especially strong with two Argentines, Diego Simeone and Juan Veron, flanked by a Yugoslav, Dejan Stankovic, and the shrewd Czech Pavel Nedved.

With Manchester United at Highbury on Sunday, tonight marks the start of an important five days for Arsenal. Although the outcome of neither match will decide anything, the results will give an early indication of Arsenal's true potential this season.

Arsenal (probable): Seaman; Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour, Grimandi, Vieira, Ljungberg; Kanu, Henry.

Lazio (probable): Marchegiani; Negro, Nesta, Mihajlovic, Pancaro; Stankovic, Simeone, Veron, Nedved; Claudio Lopez, Inzaghi.

webTitle: Champions League preview: Galatasaray v Rangers

fields.headline: Advocaat hints at return for Negri
fields.trailText: No easy task for Rangers tonight. Galatasaray are struggling on both European and domestic fronts, but their supporters in this city have hearts of granite in the face of adversity.
fields.body:
Rangers are hoping that the earth does not literally move for them here tonight when they meet Galatasaray.

Having lost 3-0 to Sturm Graz last week, Galatasaray are struggling on both European and domestic fronts, but their supporters in this city have hearts of granite in the face of adversity.

Only last year the region containing Istanbul suffered an earthquake in which at least 20,000 people died. Galatasaray and their fans are conditioned to live for the moment, which is why Rangers, like Leeds and Manchester United before them, will enter a passionate atmosphere in the Ali Sami Yen stadium.

This match is also spiced with a hotpot of random fates. Gheorghe Hagi, Galatasaray's irascible Romanian, is suspended. Mario Jardel, the Brazilian who came within a whisker of signing for Rangers four years ago, will play for the Turks. And playing for Rangers should be Tugay Kerimoglu, a Galatasaray favourite of 14 years.

Though tactical tricks and selection surprises are habitual for Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager may be bluffing with the inclusion of Marco Negri - the so-called Huff of Italy - in his squad of 19 players. In 30 months Negri has played a total of 19 competitive minutes for Rangers. If he appears tonight it will be a big surprise.

"Negri is unlike any other striker we have," said Advocaat, though refusing to say whether the Italian would be part of the plot. "He is an out-and-out striker, someone who plays differently from either Billy Dodds or Michael Mols. He's here because we need to scare Galatasaray inside their own box."

Advocaat confirmed that Mols is an injury worry and the goalkeeper Stefan Klos is carrying an ankle strain.

webTitle: Champions League: PSV Eindhoven 3 - 1 Manchester United

fields.headline: Kezman cracks United wide open
fields.standfirst:
Ferguson pays for under-rating the Dutch champions
Bouma 17, Van Bommel 38, Kezman 64 | Scholes 2 pen
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson paid the price for under-rating his oppenents, when he took a wild selection gamble and saw it misfire badly.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Philips stadium
fields.body:
Battered and beleaguered, Manchester United emerged from an extraordinary night with their noses bloodied and their armoury beginning to rust. Sir Alex Ferguson took a wild gamble here and it misfired badly.

How serious the ramifications will be remains to be seen, but United's Champions League group is becoming too tight for comfort. For all their powers of endurance, this defeat and its comprehensive manner means it cannot be taken as a foregone conclusion that they will progress to the next stages.

For that, a certain amount of criticism must be levelled at Ferguson. The United manager fielded the sort of team he usually reserves for Worthington Cup duty and, if he was culpable of underestimating PSV, it was a crass error. United were a goal to the good courtesy of Paul Scholes's penalty after only two minutes, but were then completely overwhelmed by the irrepressible Dutch champions.

While United have found goals easy to come by on domestic duty, they had failed to score in four of their previous five away games in Europe. Not quite a drought but, by their heady standards, a dry spell all the same.

The onus here fell on Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Dwight Yorke, although if the latter was hoping his stand-off with Ferguson could be eased by one performance he was mistaken. For long spells of a pulsating night in the Philips stadium, Yorke was a peripheral figure.

Solskjaer has a few hard luck stories of his own, of course, having remained on the fringes of United's first team despite an extraordinary scoring record, and the talismanic Norwegian made his first contribution of the evening within 90 seconds of the kick-off.

A suicidal crossfield ball by Jan Heintze sold his team-mates short and Solskjaer, predatory as ever, was on the loose ball and away at goal. His first touch was too strong but the second nudged the ball away from Ronald Waterreus, and as the goalkeeper rushed off his line his momentum carried him into Solskjaer for a clear penalty. Yorke, somewhat intriguingly, handed the responsibility to Scholes, whose finish from 12 yards was emphatic.

The early breakthrough clearly rattled PSV and Yorke should have doubled United's lead a few minutes later, screwing his shot wide from six yards after Nicky Butt's cross had been laid off by Jonathan Greening.

At this stage United were beginning to take command, and the first whistles had already started to emanate from PSV's boisterous Oost Side by the time a classic counterattack saw the Dutch champions draw level on 17 minutes.

This time it was United's defence that was caught flat-footed, Yuri Nikiforov's measured through ball dissecting the Neville brothers for Wilfred Bouma to run clear and angle an exquisite shot past Raimond van der Gouw with the outside of his left foot.

For the remainder of a frenetic opening period PSV's lively brand of swift, attack-minded football managed to encroach United's defence time and again. Phil Neville, in particular, was having a jittery time at right-back, although the artist formerly known as England's scapegoat partially redeemed himself with a magnificent saving tackle to deny Arnold Bruggink from putting PSV ahead in the 34th minute.

United looked sluggish in comparison and their hesitancy in defence was punished five minutes later. Mickael Silvestre's poor positional sense was exposed by Mateja Kezman's angled pass, allowing Mark van Bommel to cut into the right-hand side of the penalty area and drive a daisycutter under Van der Gouw's legs. United's jitters were turning into the shakes.

Ferguson's line-up was so watered down - David Beckham, Andy Cole, Teddy Sheringham and Ryan Giggs all started on the bench - that it was tempting to assume he considers Sunday's trip to Arsenal to be United's immediate priority.

Certainly, in Bruggink and Kezman, PSV were not lacking potency in the absence of Ruud van Nistelrooy, and the front two combined again two minutes after the restart for what should have been PSV's third goal. Instead, Kezman let United off the hook, steering his shot narrowly wide of Van der Gouw's left-hand post with only the keeper to beat.

The reprieve was eagerly accepted but Kezman, a Dutch record signing at £8m from Partizan Belgrade, made amends in the 64th minute with the game's pièce de résistance , skinning Silvestre on the right and, from a tight angle, rifling a devilish shot into the roof of Van der Gouw's net.

United needed to find their powers of recovery from somewhere, but they were not being only out-thought but out-fought. They were in disarray. Against a side that has not lost to English opposition since 1984, however, it could also be construed that Ferguson was a little too blasé for his own good.

PSV Eindhoven (4-4-2): Waterreus; Van der Weerden, Nikiforov, Hofland, Heintze; Van der Doelen (Luceus, 77min), Vogel, Van Bommel, Bouma (Rommedahl, 80); Bruggink, Kezman (Kolkka, 83).

Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; P Neville, Brown, G Neville, Silvestre (Beckham, 70); Greening (Giggs, 70), Keane, Butt, Scholes (Wallwork, 70); Solskjaer, Yorke.

Referee: M Merk (Germany).

webTitle: Mind the childcare gap

fields.headline: Mind the childcare gap
fields.standfirst: Report warns 'family friendly' policies miss working poor
fields.trailText: Report warns 'family friendly' policies miss working poor
fields.body:
A continuing shortfall in affordable childcare risks limiting the benefit of the government's "family friendly" policies to the middle classes, the author of a new research study is warning.

Ministers must move further on developing parental rights at work even if it means subsidising employers to pay for it, according to Hartley Dean, professor of social policy at Luton University, whose study involved questioning almost 50 low-income working families and a number of leading companies.

His warning comes as the charity Daycare Trust this week also cautions that while the "childcare gap" is narrowing, it remains considerable. There is now one registered childcare place for every 6.9 children under age eight, compared with one for every 7.5 last year.

Colette Kelleher, the charity's director who is shortly leaving to work for the government, says the national childcare strategy is starting to deliver results. "But time is running out for many parents and children. There has been a lot of talk and some action, but more still needs to be done," she says.

Dean's research, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, found that family friendly policies were most likely to help "valued" - and therefore higher paid - employees. There was a danger of a growing divide between middle-class families enjoying assisted childcare, career breaks and parental leave, and poorer working families dependent on unassisted childcare from other family members or friends. Referring to a ministerial review group that is considering development of parental rights at work, Dean says: "It is to be hoped that when this group reports this autumn, it does not lose sight of the government's declared aim of abolishing child poverty in 20 years. They need to be aware of just how vulnerable low-income working families can be."

The Daycare Trust's annual review also shows that there remains only one after or before school place for every 13.9 children aged five to seven, while the number of registered childminders has slumped 8% in a year.

 Daycare Trust's annual review is available from the trust at Shoreditch Town Hall Annexe, 380 Old Street, London EC1V 9LT.

webTitle: Merging social services with other local government departments

fields.headline: What a mesh
fields.standfirst: Do social services operate effectively if merged with other local government departments?
fields.trailText: Do social services operate effectively if merged with other local government departments?
fields.body:
The search for a seamless service, the holy grail of social care, has led local authorities to merge social services departments with housing, education and even arts and leisure. Experts have had doubts about how well social work would survive some of the unions and fresh questions will be thrown up by publication later today of what is forecast to be the most damning joint review of a social services department so far.

The report of the review by the Social Services Inspectorate and the Audit Commission of services in the Vale of Glamorgan is expected to lay some of the blame for the department's problems on its merged stucture, with social services and education coming under the same strategic director. It will be sharply critical of neglect of services for vulnerable children.

The changing shape of social services departments was recognised by Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, in her most recent annual report. Over one third of councils had reconfigured their social services departments, she said, linking social services with housing, or social services for adults with housing and for children with education. Outside the town hall, councils are also seeking to mesh services with NHS bodies for older people or for people with mental health problems.

Successive governments have been searching for the most efficient and cost-effective way to deliver social services since generic departments were formed almost 30 years ago following the Seebohm report. The present administration is no exception. A raft of measures has encouraged inter-agency work - most recently the Health Act 1999 which created new opportunities for health and social care partnerships by allowing one or other agencies to commission services on behalf of both, the pooling of budgets and merged services. Care trusts, outlined in the NHS plan, will take integration further by assuming responsibility for health and social services.

In the days leading up to his retirement, Ian White, outgoing director of social services in Hertfordshire, has been working on an ambitious reorganisation plan for his department. By April next year, the authority hopes to have created a children, schools and families' department, focusing on "the needs of the child, not on the council's present structures", says the council. Four multi-professional local teams will bring together staff from social services and education. Services for vulnerable children such as adoption and fostering and residential care will be managed centrally rather than in local teams.

White is a keen advocate of merging local authority functions. Over the past 20 years health and social services have struggled to deliver a seamless service, he says. "Older people have to go to as many as eight different professionals at different sites with different priorities and separate budgets, to get what they need."

Children with problems are also bounced around between education welfare and mental health professionals, he says. Hertfordshire's plans will change that. "The parent of a 13-year-old who has started to abscond from school who can no longer cope with his or her behaviour - that parent will be able to go to a single team where psychologists, social workers - all the necessary professionals work together. They will be able to sit down with them and work out a plan. If you put the user at the centre you can cluster the services around them."

White points out that integrating staff into one-stop teams is very different from appointing a "super director" who is in charge of two separate arms such as housing and social services. "I think you need to drive integration all the way down to organisational level."

Anthony Douglas, executive director of community services in Havering, east London, is one such super director with responsibility for social services, housing, leisure and benefits and twice as many staff as he would have had as a director of social services. His assistant directors are also responsible for a range of services including homelessness, asylum seekers, leisure and call centres. Children's services has its own assistant director.

Douglas believes that authorities which are struggling to deliver the core social services should stay away from complicated structures. "Where things aren't working it is advisable to stick with a dedicated director of social services," he says. " You have to focus on the basics of the service first." People using the service benefit when bosses with social services expertise have got a foot in other camps. "We can influence functions such as planning so that officers take greater account of the needs of vulnerable people."

There are drawbacks to controlling several departments, admits one such director, who prefers anonymity. "There is an issue about how far you are stretched and inevitably you don't have the capacity to stay closely in touch with all the subjects you cover if it includes everything from elderly people to environmental health". He adds: "Sometimes the public is confused by the titles. I'm in charge of housing and social services and staff tell me that some users expect social workers to be able to get them another house too."

Another anonymous director is concerned about the expertise being pushed further and further down the hierarchy. "I worry when the most senior person who knows anything about child protection is just a principal officer," he says.

Some authorities have come unstuck with reorganisation. At the end of last year a joint review of Rhondda Cynon Taff, a new unitary authority like Vale of Glamorgan, found its structure was confusing. There was also concern about the level of social services expertise among councillors. Inspectors reported that there were many former district councillors in the present administration, but few former county councillors. As a result, the council was focused on the areas previously the responsibility of the district council rather than functions like social services that were under the county's wing.

Critics fear that the status within an authority of social services will be eroded following the merger of local authority functions. But White disputes the fact that only those who have done the job can run the service. "I was never a social worker and I am the longest serving social services director in the country," he says.

Whichever way the cake is sliced, the government is concerned to preserve clear lines of accountability. According to the quality consultation paper published in August, wherever social care staff are based, it must be clear who is responsible for the quality of their work and their professional development.

And while social services departments may grow into organisations that commission everything from home helps to play equipment, councils must still have a designated director of social services who is accountable to the local authority's chief executive.

"The director of social services must have authority and credibility within a local authority and its partners, and, where activities and functions are dispersed, clear and demonstrably effective lines of accountability must be in place," the paper says. Guidance is promised on the role of directors following consultation about what it should cover.

The Vale of Glamorgan's review suggests that seamless services do not automatically flow from merged departments. Social work professionals will have to work harder to ensure that internal reorganisations lead to improved services for the public.
