Services for vulnerable children such as adoption and fostering and residential care will be managed centrally rather than in local teams. White is a keen advocate of merging local authority functions. Over the past 20 years health and social services have struggled to deliver a seamless service, he says. "Older people have to go to as many as eight different professionals at different sites with different priorities and separate budgets, to get what they need." Children with problems are also bounced around between education welfare and mental health professionals, he says. Hertfordshire's plans will change that. "The parent of a 13-year-old who has started to abscond from school who can no longer cope with his or her behaviour - that parent will be able to go to a single team where psychologists, social workers - all the necessary professionals work together. They will be able to sit down with them and work out a plan. If you put the user at the centre you can cluster the services around them." White points out that integrating staff into one-stop teams is very different from appointing a "super director" who is in charge of two separate arms such as housing and social services. "I think you need to drive integration all the way down to organisational level." Anthony Douglas, executive director of community services in Havering, east London, is one such super director with responsibility for social services, housing, leisure and benefits and twice as many staff as he would have had as a director of social services. His assistant directors are also responsible for a range of services including homelessness, asylum seekers, leisure and call centres. Children's services has its own assistant director. Douglas believes that authorities which are struggling to deliver the core social services should stay away from complicated structures. "Where things aren't working it is advisable to stick with a dedicated director of social services," he says. " You have to focus on the basics of the service first." People using the service benefit when bosses with social services expertise have got a foot in other camps. "We can influence functions such as planning so that officers take greater account of the needs of vulnerable people." There are drawbacks to controlling several departments, admits one such director, who prefers anonymity. "There is an issue about how far you are stretched and inevitably you don't have the capacity to stay closely in touch with all the subjects you cover if it includes everything from elderly people to environmental health". He adds: "Sometimes the public is confused by the titles. I'm in charge of housing and social services and staff tell me that some users expect social workers to be able to get them another house too." Another anonymous director is concerned about the expertise being pushed further and further down the hierarchy. "I worry when the most senior person who knows anything about child protection is just a principal officer," he says. Some authorities have come unstuck with reorganisation. At the end of last year a joint review of Rhondda Cynon Taff, a new unitary authority like Vale of Glamorgan, found its structure was confusing. There was also concern about the level of social services expertise among councillors. Inspectors reported that there were many former district councillors in the present administration, but few former county councillors. As a result, the council was focused on the areas previously the responsibility of the district council rather than functions like social services that were under the county's wing. Critics fear that the status within an authority of social services will be eroded following the merger of local authority functions. But White disputes the fact that only those who have done the job can run the service. "I was never a social worker and I am the longest serving social services director in the country," he says. Whichever way the cake is sliced, the government is concerned to preserve clear lines of accountability. According to the quality consultation paper published in August, wherever social care staff are based, it must be clear who is responsible for the quality of their work and their professional development. And while social services departments may grow into organisations that commission everything from home helps to play equipment, councils must still have a designated director of social services who is accountable to the local authority's chief executive. "The director of social services must have authority and credibility within a local authority and its partners, and, where activities and functions are dispersed, clear and demonstrably effective lines of accountability must be in place," the paper says. Guidance is promised on the role of directors following consultation about what it should cover. The Vale of Glamorgan's review suggests that seamless services do not automatically flow from merged departments. Social work professionals will have to work harder to ensure that internal reorganisations lead to improved services for the public.

webTitle: Shelter for black and African ex-prisoners

fields.headline: Turning inside out
fields.standfirst: Ensuring that black and Asian prisoners receive support and shelter once they leave jail is the work of a pioneering housing scheme.
fields.trailText: Ensuring that black and Asian prisoners receive support and shelter once they leave jail is the work of a pioneering housing scheme.
fields.body:
When the doors of Armley jail clang shut behind a new black or Asian inmate, followed by that other prison sound, the rattle of keys, one of the surprises inside is an almost immediate visit from Shaqil Murtaza or Jason Khan. The two men provide a unique inside welcome, aimed at a worrying mismatch in prison statistics.

Blacks and Asians are over-represented in British jails and under-represented in the take-up of social care and housing after release - programmes with a proven record of cutting second crimes, keeping families together and saving the country a lot of public money.

Niggling away at the problem prompted Khan, 33 and an instinctive doer, to do something; he invented a pioneer scheme called Habap - Housing action for black and Asian prisoners - which has just won its second national award.

One of a series of odd acronyms (others include Lypht, Lilt and Thync) which appeal to the punsters of Leeds-based Foundation Housing, the project sounds to Asian ears like the Arabic word for "lovely" - habib or habab. In an unlovely world, it produces some upbeat images: here is Khan prompting a group of Rasta visitors to Armley to gasp: "Cool, it's a Paki with keys." Here is Murtaza startling a new and large Afro-Caribbean arrival by being, firstly black, and secondly, starting the conversation by asking where the man would like to live when he gets out.

Bringing that sort of hope is in the great tradition of British prison reformers and one of the reasons for Habap landing a Margery Fry award from the Howard League for Penal Reform, now followed by top prize in this year's Race and Diversity Awards, presented by the National Housing Federation and the Federation of Black Housing Organisations.

Like Fry, Khan and Murtaza have also earned the respect of most traditionally-minded prison officers at Armley who initially had doubts about an ethnically targeted project.

Khan won them over with his obvious eagerness, a folio of statistics on the prison/care mismatch for blacks and a sympathy with the old dilemma between wanting to punish and needing to reform.

In Habap's lair, Khan says: "It's hard, if you've been a victim of crime, if you've woken up to find someone standing over your bed, to think of them as a victim of circumstances. But there's no question that that person can change, if you set out to be open-minded and non-judgmental."

The ethnic targeting has a downside; the tension between the dangers of singling out the black and Asian minority and the benefits of meeting their specific needs. The problem has been eased by the arrival of Ian Summerskill, a Foundation Housing colleague, to tune up Harp (Housing Advice and Resettlement Project) another acronym aimed at Armley's white majority. But Khan and Murtaza don't want to dodge the issue.

"Our project is still virtually unique because so many prisons say: 'We haven't got a problem; we can deal with this sort of thing ourselves', but then don't," says Khan. "Time and again, you come up against the popular myths like 'they'll look after their own' or 'blacks always get somewhere to live'".

Out of 1,400 prisoners who have seen Khan and Murtaza since 1998, only two have refused their help - one who was completely out of it on drugs and the other because his after-prison plans were well fixed.

The problems facing the others have been satisfyingly technical; rather than offering tea and sympathy, Khan and Murtaza have helped to inform local councils of legal provisions like the right to housing benefit for 52 weeks for prisoners on remand.

They have also raised issues like the lack of knowledge among local magistrates about housing grant small print; the fact that benefits last for 13 weeks in prison, but not beyond, does not figure in sentencing policy as much as it should.

Khan is dispirited about a similar example of over-arthritic justice which is threatening to undo nearly two years of patient work with a young Habap contact. Delays in the legal system mean that the man has only just been sentenced to more than a year in Armley for crimes committed, more than two years ago.

"The punishment fits the crime, I'm not arguing about that," says Khan. "But the effect of a year inside is that he faces losing a college course he's organised and the flat we helped him get. This is someone who has tried to change his ways and make a go of it. Now it looks as if it's all kicked out from under him and of course he's bitter with 'the system'. Back to square one."

Except it won't be; thanks to Habap, the man's housing association landlord is likely to hold the flat - partly because of the group's record in playing fair in the opposite direction. When Khan or Murtaza find that inmates are going to be in prison for so long that their tenancies are bound to be forfeit, they inform councils promptly and return the keys.

"Quite often," says Khan, "it can take them weeks to discover that a tenant's inside, just as they're sometimes not up to speed with the details of housing benefit law."

Habap was recently visited by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, who joined a long line of dignitaries in praising the group's work. Unfortunately, praise alone cannot keep them afloat and the state of Habap's finances is perilous; the group is deep into a National Lottery Charities Board application - sure sign of severe problems - and needs £30,000 to avoid a deficit in its current financial year ending next month.

Ramsbotham wasn't optimistic but the great hope is that the Home Office will help, encouraged by the £18,000 put in by Armley itself, where the last governor, Rannoch Daly, and his successor, Stacey Tasker, the first woman to head the jail in its 150 years, are Habap fans.

Post Macpherson report, the awards and the setting up of Harp also point to a wider pilot. "When black or Asian prisoners transfer here from other jails," says Khan (who also visits three smaller Yorkshire prisons, including a women's unit) "they can be even more surprised to find us than the new inmates."

 Habap can be contacted on 0113 234 1693 or at www.foundationhsg.demon.co.uk

Prison figures in black and white

Prisoners from minority ethnic groups make up 18% of all men in jail in England and Wales and 25% of all women. This compares to minority ethnic strength of 6.5% in the population as a whole.

Of 61,000 male prisoners classified last year, 12% were black, 3% south Asian and 3% "Chinese and other". Of 3,000 women, the proportions were 19% black, 1% south Asian and 5% Chinese and other.

In all, more than 12,000 prisoners are from minority ethnic groups. Their representation appears to be growing: in 1998-99, the prison population shrank 2%, but numbers of minority ethnic prisoners rose 1%.

Contrary to popular prejudice, black male prisoners are less likely than white to be serving terms for violent or sexual offences. But they are more likely to be in jail for robbery or drug crimes. Of sentenced black prisoners, 65% are serving terms of four years or more, compared to 50% of whites.

webTitle: Milburn speech targets cancer and elderly patients

fields.headline: Milburn speech targets cancer and elderly patients
fields.standfirst: 10 year plan to make UK cancer services "the best in Europe"
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn sought to regain the support of disaffected voters by placing improvements to NHS cancer services and care for elderly people at the heart of his speech to Labour conference.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn sought to regain the support of disaffected voters by placing improvements to NHS cancer services and care for elderly people at the heart of his speech to Labour conference.

He also curried favour with the Labour faithful with promises to improve nurses pay, end the privatisation of hospital cleaning services, and enforce a ban on recently qualified NHS consultants carrying out private work.

The NHS will grow by a third by 2004, with more beds, more hospitals, more medical students and 20,000 more nurses, the health secretary said.

He admitted NHS improvements would take time and would not be easy, saying that not every problem had been solved: "But steadily and surely, people will see the NHS growing bigger, getting better, becoming the best."

Announcing the publication of a national cancer plan, he promised more cancer specialists, more cancer equipment, shorter waiting times for cancer treatment and extra cash for hospices.

"Our aim is the fastest improvement in cancer services anywhere in Europe. By 2010, our cancer survival rates will be amongst the best in Europe," he told delegates.

Mr Milburn also moved to placate elderly voters, admitting that the elderly do not always get the standards of NHS care they deserve.

He announced that standards would be published soon to end age discrimination against elderly people. Support for carers would be doubled to £100m a year within three years.

Nursing care would be free in nursing homes from next year, mixed sex wards would be abolished, health and social services would work together more closely, and £900m would be invested in rehabilitation services.

Mr Milburn promised to recruit 20,000 more nurses for the NHS, give them more responsibility on the wards and improve their pay. "More nurses more power, more pay. That is what this Labour government will deliver."

Perhaps the loudest cheer of his speech accompanied his promise to abolish the privatisation of NHS cleaning, portering and other support services.

"All too often Compulsory Competitive Tendering (CCT) lowered standards of cleanliness in our hospitals CCT has not improved care for patients. It has damaged the NHS for far too long. It will now go."

The health secretary also pleased delegates by reaffirming his commitment, made in the NHS plan early this year, to prevent newly qualified consultants from carrying out private practice for seven years.

"For too long the issue of consultants' private practice has been left unresolved. Today we have the courage to make this change."

He reaffirmed the government's commitment to the NHS, calling it the "fairest and most efficient way of providing healthcare for all." He vowed "never to go down the route" of private healthcare.

"Our investment in cancer services symbolises our ambition for the whole health service; an NHS no longer behind the best in Europe - but a health service, growing bigger, getting better - aiming to be the best."

The Tories came under predictable fire as "the political wing of the private healthcare movement," who would introduce private health insurance - a "Tory tax on old age".

webTitle: 'I am listening I hear And I will act'

fields.headline: 'I am listening I hear And I will act'
fields.standfirst: PM admits errors but challenges Tories to battle over taxes
fields.trailText: Tony Blair bounced back yesterday with an impassioned appeal to the "basic decent instincts" of the British people to give him a second chance - and a second term in power - to complete Labour's ambitious modernisation programme.
fields.body:
Tony Blair bounced back yesterday with an impassioned appeal to the "basic decent instincts" of the British people to give him a second chance - and a second term in power - to complete Labour's ambitious modernisation programme.

In one of the most important speeches of his career the embattled prime minister told Labour's pre-election conference in Brighton that his government represented the marriage of "realism and idealism", in contrast to tax-cutting Tory cynicism.

Beset by Conservative gains in the opinion polls, Mr Blair coupled hard-headed electoral calculation with an emotional claim to be a pragmatic and healing leader but also one with an "irreducible core" of moral values. It would prevent him getting into a populist auction with William Hague, he promised.

There were admissions of error and contrition - on the Millennium Dome and pensions. "As Gordon [Brown] said yesterday, we get the message," Mr Blair said as delegates roared their approval for generous pension rises before polling day - probably next May.

To the dismay of fuel protesters he was much less conciliatory towards calls for lower taxes. "I am listening to people's anger over fuel duties. But I have also had to listen over underfunding in the NHS, over extra investment in schools, over more police on the beat, over public transport," Mr Blair explained.

And in the passage on which his whole argument turned the prime minister stressed: "The real world is full of competing causes, most of them good ... it's not an arrogant government that chooses priorities, it's an irresponsible government that fails to choose."

The speech was punctuated with announcements of new or nearly new plans to improve schools - and school sport, to beat cancer and to give the police the power to "do as much damage to organised crime as organised crime does to our communities". It was the speech's one concession to rightwing populism.

Mr Blair, who looked relaxed but sweated profusely in the hot hall, said he relished the fight ahead. But he was equally anxious to persuade disaffected voters that he was listening to them.

He used the word nine times. At one point he said: "I am listening, I hear and I will act." At another he bemoaned "the fog that descends on the very dialogue between government and people necessary" to see the ambitious reforms through to completion.

As the rest of his speech made brutally clear, Labour's election campaign will hinge on the kind of choices which voters will be asked to make: between investment in public services and £16bn worth of tax cuts un der Mr Hague, between what he called "confidence or cynicism".

To drive home the choice, he itemised the schools, hospitals, teachers and nurses' jobs which would have to be cut to fulfil the Tory tax pledges. Mr Hague was "leaping aboard every passing bandwagon".

Mr Blair said Labour would fulfil its 1997 manifesto pledges by polling day and promised delegates "a second term more radical than the first" as his cabinet's multi-billion investment plans gradually produced better public services.

It was as eloquent a case as he has ever made for New Labour's view of active government, always at hand both to protect the individual and to provide opportunities for fulfilment.

But the emotional high point of the 60-minute address was his renewed plea to the wider television audience which has turned against him in the polls to trust him as a consensus-building "unifier" - happy to work with anyone for the common good.

In a late improvisation to the text Mr Blair also insisted that he had an "irreducible core" of principles - and listed the sort of things he would never stoop to in order to win votes.

Couched to contrast his own high-minded sense of social solidarity with Mr Hague's appeal to "narrow self-interest" and xenophobia, Mr Blair said he would never "stick two fingers up to horrible foreigners", exploit the asylum issue, or cut aid to the world's poor.

"I cannot do it," he repeatedly asserted. Though he would work with big business and even with Tories to bring about change, the self-styled "man with a mission" would not put tax cuts before economic stability or education either.

Eager for reassurance that the government was back on track, the conference loved it. After weeks when Labour had been battered by the fuel crisis and punished by falling poll ratings the Blair fightback won him a convincing five- minute standing ovation.

Mr Hague called the speech "the usual New Labour cocktail" of meaningless statistics, policy failure, unscripted promises and "apologies that never amount to saying you are sorry".

Today the conference will face both ways on pensions when it backs both Treasury policy and a union-led call to restore the link between the basic pension and earnings.

The government will swallow the result by saying the motion calling for restoration of the link proposes this only as one way of increasing pensioners' earnings. The deal was hammered out at a meeting between the leadership and the unions last night.

Union sources also said they had been told Mr Brown's pre-budget report would now be published at the end of October. The timing suggests he is planning to make concessions on the fuel tax before the 60 day deadline set by protesters.

Today the conference will face both ways on pensions when it backs both Treasury policy and a union-led call to restore the link between the basic pension and earnings. The government will swallow the result by saying the motion calling for restoration of the link proposes this only as one way of increasing pensioners' earnings. The deal was hammered out at a meeting between the leadership and the unions last night. Union sources also said they had been told Mr Brown's pre-budget report would now be published at the end of October. The timing suggests he is planning to make concessions on the fuel tax before the 60 day deadline set by protesters.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk.
fields.trailText:
1. Clubs on celluloid
"In This is Spinal Tap, the bassist Derek Smalls can be seen to be wearing an early 80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Have there been other incidences of silver screen glory for the lower league clubs?" asks James Mckie. "And I'm not interested in the thousands of times Man U-bloody-United have managed to foist their brand onto celluloid."

1. Clubs on celluloid
"In This is Spinal Tap, the bassist Derek Smalls can be seen to be wearing an early 80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Have there been other incidences of silver screen glory for the lower league clubs?" asks James Mckie. "And I'm not interested in the thousands of times Man U-bloody-United have managed to foist their brand onto celluloid."

"I think, but can't be sure, that "Gregory's Girl" involved at the very least a Partick Thistle scarf, if not actual top," says Paul Gorman. Simon Blackstone also points out that the father in Twentyfourseven was an obsessive Notts County fan.

Meanwhile Martin Edmondson remembers Bradford City appearing in the film I.D, "that one about hooliganism." Apparently, "The crowd scene where the guy gets carted along the touchline was filmed during a home match at Valley Parade in our days as a second division club. Although obviously now we're in the Premiership we only do Hollywood stuff."

2 Footballing firsts
"Can anyone tell me who were the first British team 1) with floodlights; 2) with shirt sponsors; and 3) to play in European competition?" asks Richard Falconer.

Arsenal were the first British club to play under floodlights - sixteen lamps were used to illuminate a friendly against Hapoel Tel Aviv at Highbury in September 1951. But QPR were the first club to hold a floodlit event - a rugby league exhibition match at White City in 1932.

Liverpool were the first British club to carry a sponsor's name on their shirts when, in 1979, they agreed a deal with electronics giant Hitachi.

Hibernian were the first British club to play in Europe. They defeated German champions Rot-Weiss Essen 4-0 in their first game in the 1955-56 European Cup and went on to reach the semi-finals, where they were defeated by eventual runners-up Reims. Chelsea, the English champions that year, had declined to participate in the tournament after caving in to pressure from the Football League, who opposed European competition at that time.

3. Sheep-stealing centre-forwards?
"Is it true that a winner of a Cup Final medal was hung for sheep stealing in Australia in the early 1900s?" James Carlin inquired a few weeks ago. Here's the latest.

"I suspect the story is what is known here as a furphy," says David Benjamin from the Archives Office of Tasmania. "Sheep-stealing, even in industrial quantities, had ceased to be a capital offence long before 1900. The former player would have to have killed someone in the course of the theft to be a candidate for hanging. With regard to the list of names I can only speak for Tasmania. Only three men were hanged here between 1900 and 1946, all for murder, and none had the name of any of the four players."

4. Tough-tackling toffs
"Does anyone know of any footballers that went to public school? I know Frank Lampard Jnr was one (he went to Brentwood). But are there any others?" wonders Joel Davison.

"I read recently that Quinton Fortune was a public school boy - albeit a special case as he came over here to play football," says Stuart Saunders.

5. Pyramid schemes
"The Nationwide Conference is a national league, but the leagues that feed into it are regional (north, south and midlands). Presumably the winners of these leagues (Unibond, Dr Martens and Ryman) are promoted to the Conference, with the bottom three in the Conference going down. But what happens if, for example, the bottom three are all northern clubs. Do they all go back into the Unibond league (or whatever) or would some of them have to play in the 'wrong' league, geographically speaking. How is it all sorted out?" asks Andrew Tracey.

"Basically, out of the three leagues (Ryman, Unibond, Dr Martens) there should be one club going up into the Conference out of each league and one club coming down into each," says Ally Farmer. "If it so happens that the three relegated teams in the Conference are all northern or southern then some shifting of teams has to take place."

However this isn't as complicated as it seems. "More often than not, there will be teams in the three divisions who have gone bankrupt during the season and are pulling out, which creates space for possibly two teams to go down into the same division. Similarly, there are often teams in one league who want to switch over into another league - for example Gravesend switched from the Dr Martens to the Ryman league because they thought the travelling was too much."

5 Artur new man
"How is Artur Antunes Cimbra more widely known?" asks Gerald Key

Gerald, you're referring to the brilliant Brazilian Zico, who played in an astonishing 1047 senior games (including 71 for Brazil) and was voted South American Player Of The Year in 1977, 1981 and 1982.

Any questions?

"Who was the first British player convicted of feigning injury to get an opponent sent off?" asks Jim Rowbotham.

"I know that players can't be loaned to a club in the same division as the loaning club but are there any cases of loaned players scoring against their 'club' in a cup game," asks Tobias Best.

"Following on from Simon Beresfords question about TSV 1860 Munich (see here), why have Schalke got the "04"? And are there any others with numbers in their names?" asks William Smith

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

webTitle: Adams: I am over my injury problems

fields.headline: Adams: I am over my injury problems
fields.trailText: Tony Adams insists he is over his injury problems - and says he plans to play at least 50 games this season.
fields.body:
Tony Adams insists he is over his injury problems - and says he plans to play at least 50 games this season.

Despite facing a demanding schedule of four games in the next two weeks and criticism that he rarely plays matches back-to-back, Adams claims he is now back to his full fitness and is ready to play a full part in the season's campaign - both for Arsenal and England.

"The time is right to put the record straight about my fitness," Adams declares in the programme notes for tonight's game against Lazio. "There have been a lot of rumours and a lot of talk from people who don't know."

"My target is clear. I plan to play between 45 and 50 games this season for Arsenal and I hope to add another half-dozen to that with England. I am confident that I will reach those targets. Quite simply, I jarred my back. Nothing more and nothing less."

webTitle: News Corp buys Liberty Media's Gemstar stake

fields.headline: News Corp buys Liberty Media's Gemstar stake
fields.standfirst: News Corp in Liberty Media talks
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has confirmed it is to become the biggest shareholder in Gemstar-TV Guide International, buying out the stake owned by Liberty Media.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has confirmed it is to become the biggest shareholder in Gemstar-TV Guide International, buying out the stake owned by Liberty Media.

News Corp said in a statement this afternoon that, in exchange for Liberty Medi'a's Gemstar stake, Liberty Media would become News Corp's top non-voting shareholder, as well as acquiring a stake in the firm's pay-TV subsidiary, Sky Global Networks.

Liberty will sell its 21% stake in Gemstar-TV Guide, which provides interactive programming guides and publishes TV Guide magazine.

The purchase will boost News Corp's stake to 43% and make it Gemstar-TV Guide's biggest single shareholder.

webTitle: Small companies ignorant of disabled workplace support

fields.headline: Enlarged opportunities
fields.standfirst: Small companies ignorant of disabled workplace support
fields.trailText: Small companies ignorant of disabled workplace support
fields.body:
More than 95% of smaller companies are unaware of the support available to meet disability needs in the workplace, according to a survey published today. Almost 80% have no idea where to go for information and advice.

The findings, based on questioning of 1,200 employers, suggest an urgent need to review the schemes under which help is available to employ disabled people - and especially to review the means by which they are publicised.

"Many disabled people are being denied access to employment opportunities in small businesses because employers do not know where to get information and support on meeting disability-related needs of employees," says Nick Goss, employment officer at disability charity Radar.

"As a result, many disabled people are unable to enter the world of work and the UK's competitiveness, in a market increasingly driven by diversity, is being damaged."

With more than nine in 10 employers classified as small to medium-sized, the survey has wide relevance. It was carried out by Radar, with support from the Disability Rights Commission (DRC) and the Federation of Small Businesses, to test awareness of schemes such as Access to Work under which employers can obtain financial help to pay for adaptations or special equipment to assist disabled staff to do their jobs.

The survey report, Jobs Worth: Disability in Small Business, is to be launched by Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, at a reception today at the Labour Party conference in Brighton.

According to the report, small businesses need to undergo a cultural change in terms of disability awareness if they are to have the confidence to employ disabled workers. As well as greater promotion of government support schemes, there needs to be aware ness training, peer support and use of case studies to demonstrate effective practice.

Larger employers, some of which have become regular and enthusiastic recruiters of disabled people, could play a valuable role in building the knowledge and confidence of smaller companies, the report says. Strategic bodies such as the Small Business Service could also weigh in.

Bert Massie, who chairs the DRC, says: "Greater publicity of government support schemes is needed alongside tailored advice and information through local employment and business agencies. We need to turn the commercial needs and goodwill of small employers into job opportunities for disabled people."

Jobs Worth is available from Radar at 12 City Forum, 250 City Road, London EC1V 8AF or at www.radar.org.uk

webTitle: Taylor: Stan 'didn't give a monkey's about Leicester'

fields.headline: Taylor: Stan 'didn't give a monkey's about Leicester'
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor has made another scathing attack on Stan Collymore, claiming the former England striker "didn't give a monkey's about Leicester City Football Club."
fields.body:
Peter Taylor has made another scathing attack on Stan Collymore, claiming the former England striker "didn't give a monkey's about Leicester City Football Club."

Taylor also revealed that he had planned to play Collymore during tomorrow's Uefa Cup clash with Red Star Belgrade - until he produced his "unacceptable" performance against Everton at the weekend.

"I will be totally honest and tell you that the plan I had was for Stan Collymore to start on Thursday," he said. "I think he would have been a handy player for the way I wanted to approach the game.

"But with the way things went on Sunday I wasn't prepared to [play Collymore against Belgrade] because I don't think it would have been right.

"My thoughts were that if he played like that in a live television game against Everton, when he could have been a hero and taken us to the top of the table, then he could play exactly the same way in Vienna. I was not prepared to take that chance. I am better having 19 players out here who are 100% committed than a big name who is not - and Stan was not committed on Sunday."

Taylor admitted: "I am fully aware of how popular Stan is with certain sections of Leicester fans and this is the last thing I wanted to do. They might think that we will lose because he is not playing on Thursday.

"I would say to the supporters there is nothing more important than your football club and there was a person out there on Sunday who didn't give a monkey's about Leicester City Football Club.

"I would also say to people that if they think I'm not speaking the truth then go and get a video of the game and judge Stan's performance for yourself. It is also worth pointing out that we haven't lost a game this season - and Stan has started only one of them."

webTitle: The Word: The New Puritans

fields.headline: The Word: The New Puritans
fields.trailText: Contributors to the controversial anthology All Hail the New Puritans defend their austere manifesto
fields.body:
One-third of the New Puritans sit inside Shakespeare's Globe theatre on a wet Sunday afternoon talking rather earnestly about their new anthology to an audience of around 20 people. They are young, attractive and middle class, and the audience is similar. The more well-known collaborators - Alex Garland (author of the bestseller The Beach), Paris Trance author Geoff Dyer and crime writer and Guardian First Book Award judge Toby Litt - are not present. Instead we have the editors of the anthology, Nicholas Blincoe and Matt Thorne, and two lesser-known contributors, Rebecca Ray and Daren King.

The New Puritans are a group of writers who recently published an anthology of short stories (All Hail the New Puritans), in which they stick to a predetermined 10-point manifesto. Inspired by the Danish film-makers Dogma 95, they believe that literature should be "simple" and "real".

Blincoe and Thorne begin the event by going through each point of the manifesto. They admit that out of the 10 points only six embrace the 'puritan' code of writing - including pledges to "shun poetry and poetic licence in all its forms", to enforce "textual simplicity and avoid all devices of voice", while keeping a moral voice and a "recognisable ethical reality". The other four were put in "to make things difficult". These include the much-mocked pledge to "avoid elaborate punctuation" and the decision to "eschew flashbacks" and "recognise that published works are also historical documents, so all texts are dated and set in the present day".

Rebecca Ray described the manifesto as "a test to write to a specific set of rules", while Blincoe complained that "too much has been made of each individual point of the manifesto, and what's more important is the spirit behind it".

This 'spirit' is the belief that the distinction between 'commercial' and 'literary' fiction' should be broken down. 'Page-turning' fiction is often dismissed by the literary establishment whereas, to these writers, plot is paramount. They seek to be the antithesis of the previous generation of writers. Although much too polite to say so, the implication is that it is the Amises and the Rushdies of this world who the New Puritans are reacting against. They believe that the last generation of writers (the Puritans refer to them only as the 'show-off' writers) write predominately for other writers and for the publishing industry. They also believe that London is far too often the focus of recent fiction, and have made a deliberate attempt to provincialise the tales. Hence we have stories set in places as diverse as Bedford, Preston and Cirencester.

Rebecca Ray and Daren King read their contributions to the anthology and demonstrated the diversity of styles that can exist within such rules. Ray's "Lovers" is a moving tale of a daughter leaving home for the first time, while King's surreal "Better than Well" is a journey into a mind altered by anti-depressants.

During the discussion with the audience afterwards, the Puritans emphasise that the anthology was a one-off experiment and they have no plans to continue writing strictly within the limits of the manifesto. All the stories were written between November 1999 and February 2000, making the anthology a "snapshot" of that time, and despite the restrictions, all the authors enjoyed the experience and felt very supported by their fellow writers. It was refreshing, they said, to have that kind of support in an industry that is often competitive.

On leaving the theatre, you wish them luck. Despite accusations of gimmickry the New Puritans seem genuinely excited by their project, and while the likes of Alex Garland and Geoff Dyer gain little professionally from appearing in such an anthology, the book successfully highlights some emerging British talent.

webTitle: Badger, Monkey, and Pony

fields.headline: Badger, Monkey, and Pony
fields.trailText: HEY, REFER(EE)! LEAVE OUR DAVE ALONE!
fields.body:
HEY, REFER(EE)! LEAVE OUR DAVE ALONE!

The Fiver has dubbed it "Koogan's first law" - and nobody who values our national game can afford to ignore it. Simply put, it states that whatever comes out of Kelvin Koogan's mouth always has an equal and opposite reaction. So when Koog recently claimed that David Beckham was now more mature, less petulant and would make a great England captain one day, you didn't need a PhD in reading the tea-leaves to forecast that trouble was around the corner, and just waiting to pounce.

Last night trouble finally struck. United were losing 3-1 and the game was drifting into injury time when the supposedly reformed Beckham got himself booked for dissent. But worse still, instead of shaking German referee's Markus Merk's hand and wishing him the best of bully, he then turned and spat on the ground in his general direction! Luckily for Beckham, Uefa aren't going to slap a punitive fine and a long suspension on him for his behaviour. But just in case they were thinking about it, the Imperial Lord Ferg has sprung to the petulant one's defence.

The second rule of football - just behind Koogan's first law - is that the Lord Ferg will always, always stick up for his players in public. Well, until he needs to shift a few more units of his autobiography. And today was no different. "It's understandable," said the United boss, talking about Beckham's reaction and not the wild celebrations that took place after United got beat. "They get frustrated with the referee. The referee is supposed to be at the top of his job - that's the reputation he's got. But we didn't get a lot of help from the referee in protecting the players." Considering United's reputation with manhandling referees over the years, can you blame him?

As Mrs Collymore gets on with baking her son's favourite meatloaf in anticipation of his return home, more interesting details emerge of Stanley Victor's tragically short career with Leicester City. "There is nothing more important than your football club and there was a person out there on Sunday who didn't give a monkey's about Leicester City Football Club," Mr Taylor said today, gloriously resurrecting a phrase that hasn't been heard since, well, since Burnside got the chop. webTitle: Archer takes refuge on stage from a real life drama

fields.headline: Archer takes refuge on stage from a real life drama
fields.standfirst:
Life imitates art as the peer charged with perjury prepares to play accused in his new production

Special report: the fall of Archer
fields.trailText: The twist could not have been plotted better by the man himself. On the very day Lord Archer was preparing to add the title "actor" to a CV that already runs from novelist to disgraced politician, Scotland Yard, demonstrating an unexpected knack for comic timing, charged the former Tory deputy chairman with perjury and perverting the course of justice.
fields.body:
The twist could not have been plotted better by the man himself. On the very day Lord Archer was preparing to add the title "actor" to a CV that already runs from novelist to disgraced politician, Scotland Yard, demonstrating an unexpected knack for comic timing, charged the former Tory deputy chairman with perjury and perverting the course of justice.

That Lord Archer should be about to make his stage debut in his own play The Accused, in which he stars as a doctor charged with the murder of his wife, only added to the irony.

News of the charges emerged just three hours before he was due on stage in Windsor for the final dress rehearsal of the courtroom drama, which opened last night to a full house.

Following the meeting with detectives, Lord Archer shunned publicity for this new venture.

He looked uncharacteristically subdued when he arrived at the Theatre Royal, which stands in the shadow of the castle walls. But this was nothing compared to the frustration of the box office, which was suddenly besieged with requests for seats despite being sold out.

Lord Archer's bashfulness came on suddenly. At the weekend he joked with reporters at a photo call to publicise the play in which he plays the lead, Dr Patrick Sherwood, a surgeon whose innocence or guilt hangs on the testimony of a woman claiming to be his mistress.

His fate will be decided on a nightly basis by the audience, who deliver their verdict by means of electronic keypads.

In a nod to Archer's doomed bid for election as London mayor, Ken Livingstone will pronounce the result by means of a pre-recorded tape.

Describing the play's typically labyrinthine plot, Lord Archer said: "At the end of the first act they [the audience] should think my character is innocent, at the end of the second they should think he's guilty, and at the end of act three you should be clueless. And then there's a triple twist at the end.

"It's not a very big role and of course I'm nervous, but I have appeared before 5,000 people; I've addressed party conferences," he said.

Prostitute

He denied that his experience in the dock during his successful libel action against the Daily Star in 1987 had influenced the play, but conceded that some parallels could be drawn.

For instance, the prostitute Monica Coghlan attempted to prove she had slept with the peer by making reference to spots on his back. In The Accused Dr Sherwood's mistress demonstrates her intimate knowledge by correctly claiming he has a lesion on his right arm.

After a short run in Windsor the play will tour the provinces before moving to the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, in London's West End next month.

The morning visit to Wimbledon did not seem to distract Lord Archer from performing to high standards in the afternoon's dress rehearsal.

"He was a consummate professional, very focused on the job in hand," said a spokeswoman.

"What happened this morning was part of his personal life and what happened this afternoon was part of his artistic life."

The millionaire author will hope for similar poise when he appears at Bow Street magistrates court next Tuesday, to stand in the dock with Ted Francis, someone he used to consider a close friend, and face charges which suggest fact really is stranger than fiction.

It was Mr Francis's revelations in the News of the World last November that sparked a Scotland Yard investigation and led to Lord Archer's immediate decision to stand down as the Conservative candidate in the London mayoral race.

Mr Francis, a former television presenter, claimed the two men had "cooked up" a story to help Lord Archer in his 1987 libel battle with the Daily Star, which had accused him of sleeping with Ms Coghlan.

According to Mr Francis, Lord Archer asked him to write a letter to his solicitors saying they had dined in a London restaurant on September 9 1986 - the night the tabloid accused him of being with Ms Coghlan. However, Mr Francis's alibi was never used because the paper later changed its evidence to say Lord Archer had been with her on September 8.

Last year Lord Archer admitted asking Mr Francis to cover for him, saying he wanted to protect a woman he had been with. "I realise I should not have asked him to write to my solicitors to that effect," Lord Archer said in a statement.

"But the matter ceased to be of any relevance whatsoever when the date alleged by the Daily Star of my being with Monica Coghlan was changed ... a date I was conclusively able to prove that I could not have been with her as they alleged."

However, further allegations emerged in the following weeks.

Misled

First Michael Stacpoole, a former confidant and PR adviser to the peer, claimed Lord Archer misled the high court over the state of his "happy" marriage.

In his summing up to the libel jury Justice Caulfield had described Lord Archer's wife Mary as elegant and fragrant.

"Is he [Archer] in need of cold, unloving, rubber insulated sex in a seedy hotel?" he asked.

Mr Stacpoole also described how Lord Archer gave him £2,000 to give to Ms Coghlan at Victoria station in London, and he claimed the peer paid him £40,000 to leave the country before the trial to prevent him giving evidence.

In a further twist, there were claims Lord Archer asked the late theatrical agent, Terence Baker, to provide him with an alibi for his whereabouts on September 8 1986 - the crucial date.

Lord Archer strenuously denied the allegation. "I reiterate that I did not have sexual relations with Monica Coghlan or any other prostitute," he said.

Scotland Yard began its investigation when the Daily Star made a formal complaint about Lord Archer's alleged behaviour.

It was led by Detective Superintendent Geoff Hunt, who was in charge of the 10-month criminal investigation into Jonathan Aitken after the collapse of the disgraced cabinet minister's libel trial against the Guardian and Granada television.

"The timing of the charges was purely coincidental," said one Scotland Yard source.

webTitle: Lord Archer charged with perjury

fields.headline: Lord Archer charged with perjury
fields.standfirst: Special report: the fall of Archer
fields.trailText: Lord Archer was facing the possibility of a lengthy term in jail yesterday when detectives charged him with lying under oath and alleged interference with important witnesses before his libel trial victory over the Daily Star newspaper 13 years ago.
fields.body:
Lord Archer was facing the possibility of a lengthy term in jail yesterday when detectives charged him with lying under oath and alleged interference with important witnesses before his libel trial victory over the Daily Star newspaper 13 years ago.

During a 75-minute interview at Wimbledon police station in south-west London, Lord Archer was told a nine-month investigation had uncovered enough evidence to charge him with two counts of perverting the course of justice, two of perjury, and one of using a "false instrument" - probably a forged or counterfeited document.

Attempting to pervert the course of justice is, in theory, punishable by a life sentence.

But if Lord Archer is convicted, a judge would probably be guided by the laws governing perjury, which has a maximum sentence of seven years.

The decision to charge the 60-year-old peer delighted Peter Hill, editor of the Daily Star.

The tabloid accused Lord Archer of sleeping with the prostitute Monica Coghlan in a hotel in 1986.

When Lord Archer won a three-week libel trial, it was forced to pay £1.2m damages and costs.

The paper is planning to sue Lord Archer for the return of the money, plus interest of up to £1m.

"We have cooperated fully with the police inquiry and will continue to do so," said Mr Hill. "Whatever the outcome of the criminal case, we will continue to press for the return of damages and costs ... with interest."

Lord Archer refused to comment as he was driven away from the police station and he ignored reporters when he arrived at the Theatre Royal in Windsor, Berkshire, where he was taking part in a dress rehearsal of his play, The Accused, which opened last night.

Lord Archer's lawyers, the London firm Mischon de Reya, also declined to comment yesterday. The peer has indicated he will fight to clear his name, and has retained the eminent barrister, Sir Sydney Kentridge QC.

Lord Archer was bailed to appear before Bow Street magistrates court next Tuesday, along with an alleged co-conspirator, Ted Francis, 67, of Cranleigh, Surrey, who was charged with perverting the course of justice.

"Whatever the outcome of the criminal case, we will continue to press for the return of damages and costs ... with interest." Lord Archer refused to comment as he was driven away from the police station and he ignored reporters when he arrived at the Theatre Royal in Windsor, Berkshire, where he was taking part in a dress rehearsal of his play, The Accused, which opened last night. Lord Archer's lawyers, the London firm Mischon de Reya, also declined to comment yesterday. The peer has indicated he will fight to clear his name, and has retained the eminent barrister, Sir Sydney Kentridge QC. Lord Archer was bailed to appear before Bow Street magistrates court next Tuesday, along with an alleged co-conspirator, Ted Francis, 67, of Cranleigh, Surrey, who was charged with perverting the course of justice.

webTitle: Falconer admits Dome reservations

fields.headline: Falconer admits Dome reservations
fields.trailText: Millennium Dome minister Lord Falconer has admitted the blighted Greenwich project was too ambitious but vowed to see it through.
fields.body:
Millennium Dome minister Lord Falconer has admitted the blighted Greenwich project was too ambitious but vowed to see it through.

In an address to the House of Lords he said there were lessons to be learned but it was impossible to put the clock back and he would not be resigning.

He said: "I am determined to see this project through to the end. The enhanced management team is committed to making this project work until the end of the year and ensuring an orderly wind down. This is our objective, and one I remain committed to seeing through."

Repeating prime minister Tony Blair's comments yesterday, he also said he agreed that the public sector should not try to run a visitor attraction.

Lord Falconer said the events of this summer, including Japanese bank Nomura's withdrawal of a £105m bid to buy the Greenwich site, were "disappointing".

Nomura backed out of the proposed deal on September 11, causing more embarrassment for the government, which was already feeling the force of sustained public fury over spending figures.

Lord Falconer said the government is now in discussion with the second shortlisted company Legacy PLC. He said it was also looking at other options but was not in serious discussions with anyone else.

Lord Falconer promised to make the dome's budget details public and said they were now based on visitor figures of around 4.5m a year.

He said: "The Millennium experience has not been as successful as we had hoped and the impact of the drop of visitor numbers and the resulting downturn in revenue has been by far the most significant pressure."

The original projected visitor figure was 12m, but Lord Falconer admitted that was "far too optimistic".

He said there had been 1,100 parliamentary questions about the controversial Millennium project, plus five select committee enquiries. The national audit office also has an investigation underway. The Government response to the select committee report published in July will be published on October 23.

Lord Falconer has faced repeated calls for his resignation, most recently when the dome was given another £47m because it was on the verge of bankruptcy.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrats' dome spokesman, said: "Lord Falconer really has to go, and it is clear he is simply staying put to provide a shield for Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson."

Earlier this week Lord Falconer made a muted confession during a Guardian debate entitled, Has Labour Forgotten its Roots?

Speaking after a new report suggested accountants cast doubt on the dome's viability three years ago, he said: "I also accept that there have been real concerns about the way it [the decision to build it] was reached in the first place and whether the money was handled in the right way."

But he insisted: "We did it with the best possible motives and we did it in a way which has brought jobs and regeneration."

webTitle: LibertySurf losses deepen

fields.headline: Losses mount at LibertySurf
fields.trailText: September 27: French ISP LibertySurf has posted deepened first-half losses amid reports that UK shareholder Kingfisher is seeking to pull out.
fields.body:
LibertySurf, the French internet service provider, has posted deepened first-half losses amid reports that UK shareholder Kingfisher is seeking to pull out.

The company reported a pre-tax loss of E85.3m (£51m) in the six months to June, against a loss of E25.6m (£15.5m) for the last eight months of 1999. Revenue figures gave some respite, rising from E6.1m (£3.7m) to E23.2m (£14m).

It is rumoured that Kingfisher, owner of the Woolworths and B&Q retail chains, will sell its 36% stake in LibertySurf for £600m. A similar holding is owned by Europweb, the investment company of Bernard Arnault, owner of the LVMH luxury goods company.

LibertySurf chairman Pierre Besnainou recently denied the company is in advanced talks with French media giant Vivendi about a possible takeover.

webTitle: Atlantis returns to Earth in pre-dawn darkness

fields.headline: Atlantis returns to Earth in pre-dawn darkness
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Gliding through a moonlit sky, space shuttle Atlantis returned from the newly furnished international space station, soon to be home to a permanent crew.
fields.body:
Gliding through a moonlit sky, space shuttle Atlantis returned from the newly furnished international space station, soon to be home to a permanent crew.

Within moments of Atlantis' touchdown, the clocks in Mission Control began counting backward toward the next launch. In one of the faster turnarounds at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Discovery is scheduled to blast off October 5 with new space station parts.

The space agency prefers a minimum of 21 days between shuttle launches. If Discovery soars on time, the gap will be 27 days.

"They did an amazing job this mission," flight director Jeff Bantle said. "This moved us, I would say, a significant step closer to getting a crew on board this vehicle."

The first full-time residents of the space station - Nasa astronaut Bill Shepherd and two Russian cosmonauts - are scheduled to blast off aboard a Russian rocket from Kazakhstan on October 30, following a delay of more than two years.

They were in Russia, training for their four-month mission, when Atlantis touched down after 12 days aloft. At that moment, their space station was soaring 240 miles above the North Atlantic.

Powerful xenon lights illuminated the 3-mile-long runway as Atlantis emerged from the gloom like a ghost ship, with a half-moon as a backdrop. Touchdown was right on time, at 3:56am, just as the launch was back on September 8.

It was only the 15th night-time landing in space shuttle history. Night-time landings are becoming more common, though, now that Nasa has a space station in orbit. All three previous shuttle flights to the space station also ended in darkness.

The freshly stocked space station was soaring 240 miles above the Atlantic when Atlantis touched down. It will be visited by shuttle astronauts again in just two weeks; its first full-time residents will move in at the beginning of November.

"We had a great time," commander Terrence Wilcutt said after inspecting his ship. "We're all glad to be back."

Wilcutt and his crew spent eight days at the space station, five of them inside. By the time they left Sunday night, they had hauled in and tucked away 3 tons of equipment. Among the supplies: shampoo, cream, shaving gel, moist towels and napkins, Russian and American meals, ear plugs, medical kits, labels, printer parts, clamps, brackets, camera equipment and small bags for the first permanent crew to use to relieve themselves in case the toilet jams.

The shuttle astronauts also installed the toilet, oxygen generator and treadmill in the new living quarters, and ran power and TV cables up the outside.

Getting an extra day helped. Nasa stretched the mission to 12 days to give the astronauts and cosmonauts more time inside. The only disappointment was with one of five new batteries that were plugged into the Russian modules. It would not charge properly and was disconnected; the first residents will deal with the problem when they arrive.

Another shuttle crew is scheduled to depart for the space station on October 5 aboard Discovery, making Nasa's 100th shuttle flight. Unlike this mission, most of the work will be outside next time. Four spacewalks are planned to wire up the first piece of station truss, or girder, and a new shuttle docking port, and to install tool boxes and power converters.

Nasa plans to use spacesuit parts from this mission on Discovery's flight. Workers will remove the spacewalking suits from Atlantis so the emergency oxygen packs can be installed in Discovery's suits, Nasa engineer Phil West said.

The regulators in all of Nasa's emergency oxygen packs were found in June to be contaminated with potentially flammable oil. The packs in the suits aboard Atlantis were cleaned. Nasa does not have enough time to scrub more packs, however, and therefore will use at least two of the ones that flew on Atlantis, West said.

Discovery's mission will clear the way for the launch of space station commander Bill Shepherd and his two-cosmonaut crew aboard a Russian rocket on October 30. They will arrive at the orbiting complex two days later and stay four months.

As for Atlantis, it will return to the space station in January, carrying the first lab module named Destiny. Space station assembly is expected to last until 2006.

webTitle: Parents: Self-esteem in children

fields.headline: Confidence tricks
fields.standfirst: New research shows high self-esteem in children leads to success. But,  Terri Apter asks, how to instil it?
fields.trailText: New research shows high self-esteem in children leads to success. But, Terri Apter asks, how to instil it?
fields.body:
Ask any parent what he or she wants for their child and they will say something about "being happy" or "fulfilling potential". Ask what is necessary to achieve these goals and you'll probably hear words like "self-confidence" and "self-esteem". Neither term is as popular in Britain as in the US. Yet new research confirms what has repeatedly been found to be true: self-esteem is a key to successful development and has a far greater impact on future success (and happiness) than intelligence or talent.

The research comes from Leon Feinstein's team at the Centre for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics, who have published results of studies on children born in April 1970 which showed a close correlation between childhood self-esteem and adult success.

The crucial years seem to be between five and 15, when children learn to assess their abilities and form expectations of success or failure which continue to frame their adult self-image. Parents school them in the importance of coming out "on top", while simultaneously they may try to support self-esteem by "talking them up". But the combination of pressure to perform and indiscriminate praise may confuse children.

It is often difficult to gauge confidence because self-esteem is not simply high or low. In childhood, it undergoes daily shifts in shape and intensity, varying with the familiarity of the setting, the task at hand, the attitudes of the people around.

Until about 10, children's daily lives are chock-a-block with discoveries about their abilities, their powers and limitations. They feel confident in one situation, but not in another. They are in control when the school bell rings, but lose confidence when someone is late to pick them up at the school gate. Adults usually only suffer such swings at times of social upheaval.

There is no sure method of assessing self-esteem, or measuring the extent to which it is lacking. In the abstract, a child may declare herself confident, say, in maths, but freeze when the teacher invites her to work on a new type of question. Some children boast of being the next David Beckham, yet they don't feel sufficiently confident to join in a game. Dreams aren't any use, unless they give day-to-day support.

If asked directly whether they think they can do something, or whether they "like themselves", children may speak with a confidence that is not really felt: they learn quickly that they shouldn't be down on themselves.

So how can parents judge a child's self-esteem? Some of the danger signals are obvious enough: a child who constantly makes derogatory comments about herself, expresses a wish to die, or speaks pessimistically about her future, is voicing despair over her own self-image.

But there are less obvious danger signals too, and these often involve lack of energy or interest in the world. A child with high self-esteem is curious, eager to know, and confident of her ability to understand. One who gives away little personal information may just be reserved - but may feel she has nothing of interest to say.

A child who cries frequently when faced with new or difficult tasks is likely to anticipate her own failure and be anxious about her own abilities. One who acts impulsively, or behaves inconsistently, may believe she has no control over the outcome of her actions. Nothing is more important in building self-esteem than a sense of being effective; nothing tears it down as much as a sense of powerlessness.

Parents can help. First, they can listen, key into what the child says, and accept her own statements about how she feels and what she thinks. They can help her find (acceptable) ways of expressing her emotions, whether of joy or sadness. Acceptance of her own emotions, and awareness of her parents' genuine wish to understand are important foundations of self-esteem.

Secondly, parents can ease anxiety about performance by showing the child that she does have power to extend her skills and knowledge. The important message is that one's abilities and behaviour can improve with effort. If a child does badly in an exam, what reasons does she give? Does she say, "I'm stupid/ I'm no good at this?" or does she say, "I didn't prepare enough/ pace myself"? The first replies show a belief in failure as permanent and inevitable. The second show that she sees some way of improving her performance.

Parents should also be on the lookout for what she says when she does well. If she says, "It was easy/ I was lucky", then even experience of success does not build confidence because she does not link it to her own efforts. Children with high self-esteem do not necessarily experience fewer failures than those with low self-esteem, but unlike the latter, they see how they can improve.

Third, parents can foster confidence by moderating their own anxiety about performance. The intense involvement parents often have with a child's "success" can lead to anger and frustration at "failure" to shine. Sometimes, too, a parent's own unhappiness or stress blocks interest in a child's complex inner world. Being ignored can make a child feel she has nothing to offer.

While self-esteem can be bolstered in a number of ways - by friends, siblings, teachers, even pets - parents are usually the quickest to respond to need, and so are the first to receive the instructions of pundits. But parents don't have to have perfect control of their own lives to help their children maintain self-esteem.

Even if their own self-esteem suffers in the ups and downs of adult life, they retain the capacity to support a child's, for self-esteem involves learning how to survive in the midst of problems. After all, we are aiming at skills that help children to thrive in an imperfect world.

 Terri Apter's The Confident Child: Raising Children to Believe in Themselves, is published by Bantam in New York and available at any internet bookshop.

webTitle: Parents: The dangers of sugar

fields.headline: Be a tooth fairy: keep sugar off their diet
fields.standfirst: Joanna Blythman on the food menace that must be fought
fields.trailText: Joanna Blythman on the food menace that must be fought.
fields.body:
It's a kneejerk British reaction. As soon as children squirm in their pushchairs, raising a querulous voice or complaining of thirst, we thrust something sweet into their sticky little hands. Sweets, biscuits, cakes, fizzy drinks - all are props to modern parenting. We trade sugar for peace and complicity. But it doesn't last: the short-term saviour becomes a sugary trap.

The toddler initially silenced by sweets becomes a monster once the sugar fix has worn off. They grow into children who say they don't like the taste of water because it's "plain" or an orange because it's too sour. Sugar can wreck a child's health. Excess sugar is converted to fat and leads to obesity. Obesity leads to more disease, such as diabetes.

Sugar also helps make foods loaded with fat and carbohydrate more tasty and these supplant more nutritious foods in a child's diet. No wonder that by 16, one in four British children is overweight. Then there's dental caries. It costs the taxpayer twice as much as heart disease and children are uniquely vulnerable because their teeth are still soft. Half the children in the UK aged 7-10 have tooth decay. This is not news to health-conscious parents, some of whom now favour low-calorie, artificial sweeteners as a solution.

Unfortunately sweeteners are a minefield too. OK, they don't rot teeth, but some scientists believe they act as appetite stimulants. In other words, a "diet" drink can make your child feel like eating a bar of chocolate. And the high phosphorous level in such drinks is implicated in weakening bones and causing osteoporosis. Not even honey, molasses, syrup and fruit juices are safe - damage teeth too.

So how much sugar can a child eat and stay healthy? The latest EU proposal is that children should eat sugary foods no more than four times a day, reflecting dentists' thinking that frequency of sugar consumption matters more than quantity. Nutritionists say sugar should account for no more than 10% of an adult's energy needs and probably less for children. The government's long-awaited survey of British children's diets recently revealed that sugar accounts for 16-17% of the average child's energy, with some clocking in at 30%.

That is no surprise given the confusion that reigns, in part thanks to advertisers. The health coalition, action and information on sugars, complained to the advertising standards authority that the claim that Ribena was "tooth-kind" was misleading. Last month the complaint was upheld. Ribena are to appeal. But can you blame a parent for thinking it was good for teeth when packs carry the endorsement of the British dental association?

Sugar turns up in some bizarre places. "Canned vegetables and sauces such as brown sauce and ketchup are the two most hidden sources," says Lord Rodgers, chairman of the advertising standards authority, "then come soft drinks, biscuits and baked goods, ice cream and dairy foods like yogurt, canned fruit, jams, sauces and confectionery."

Too many British children have become accustomed to foods with very high levels of sugar and parents do need to try to curb that sweet palate if they want to safeguard health. Parents are probably more of a problem than children themselves, many thinking the natural flavours of good food cannot be enjoyed unless they are very sweet or have added sugar. This is nonsense. It is perfectly possible to raise a child who prefers a clementine to a cola chew, or even to convert a child with a developed taste for sweet junk food.

If you really want your children to give up sugar, they will, but you need to believe you can do it."We have forgotten that water is the number one fluid for thirst quenching," says Dr Wendy Doyle of the British dietetic association.

Do not buy high-sugar foods or routinely keep them in the house: score sweet drinks, biscuits and sweets off your shopping list. Buy as little processed food and as much fresh food as you can and feed children from the same store of food as the adults. Children who raid the fridge for fizzy drinks or empty the biscuit tin are not satisfied nutritionally. In no time they will want more to eat and it's likely to be more junk. Soup, a decent sandwich, leftovers and fruit will make them much more biddable and contented, and in the long-term, infinitely more healthy.

The Food Our Children Eat, by Joanna Blythman, is published by Fourth Estate at £7.99.

Unfortunately sweeteners are a minefield too. OK, they don't rot teeth, but some scientists believe they act as appetite stimulants. In other words, a "diet" drink can make your child feel like eating a bar of chocolate. And the high phosphorous level in such drinks is implicated in weakening bones and causing osteoporosis. Not even honey, molasses, syrup and fruit juices are safe - damage teeth too. So how much sugar can a child eat and stay healthy? The latest EU proposal is that children should eat sugary foods no more than four times a day, reflecting dentists' thinking that frequency of sugar consumption matters more than quantity. Nutritionists say sugar should account for no more than 10% of an adult's energy needs and probably less for children. The government's long-awaited survey of British children's diets recently revealed that sugar accounts for 16-17% of the average child's energy, with some clocking in at 30%. That is no surprise given the confusion that reigns, in part thanks to advertisers. The health coalition, action and information on sugars, complained to the advertising standards authority that the claim that Ribena was "tooth-kind" was misleading. Last month the complaint was upheld. Ribena are to appeal. But can you blame a parent for thinking it was good for teeth when packs carry the endorsement of the British dental association? Sugar turns up in some bizarre places. "Canned vegetables and sauces such as brown sauce and ketchup are the two most hidden sources," says Lord Rodgers, chairman of the advertising standards authority, "then come soft drinks, biscuits and baked goods, ice cream and dairy foods like yogurt, canned fruit, jams, sauces and confectionery." Too many British children have become accustomed to foods with very high levels of sugar and parents do need to try to curb that sweet palate if they want to safeguard health. Parents are probably more of a problem than children themselves, many thinking the natural flavours of good food cannot be enjoyed unless they are very sweet or have added sugar. This is nonsense. It is perfectly possible to raise a child who prefers a clementine to a cola chew, or even to convert a child with a developed taste for sweet junk food. If you really want your children to give up sugar, they will, but you need to believe you can do it."We have forgotten that water is the number one fluid for thirst quenching," says Dr Wendy Doyle of the British dietetic association. Do not buy high-sugar foods or routinely keep them in the house: score sweet drinks, biscuits and sweets off your shopping list. Buy as little processed food and as much fresh food as you can and feed children from the same store of food as the adults. Children who raid the fridge for fizzy drinks or empty the biscuit tin are not satisfied nutritionally. In no time they will want more to eat and it's likely to be more junk. Soup, a decent sandwich, leftovers and fruit will make them much more biddable and contented, and in the long-term, infinitely more healthy. The Food Our Children Eat, by Joanna Blythman, is published by Fourth Estate at £7.99.

webTitle: Parents: The Panel

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Can computers damage children's creativity, as a new study warns?
fields.trailText: The Question: Can computers damage children's creativity, as a new study warns?
fields.body:
John Coe National Association for Primary Education

It is a possible danger. A number of colleagues and I are very concerned about the over-use of computers by younger children in primary school. They should be learning in their own way. They need learn to read and learn about the world by practical enquiry and interaction with other people. Computers encourage passivity and that can damage creativity. Their value does increase as a source of information for older children, but I'm concerned that young children should be using and developing their language skills, rather than viewing symbols on a screen.
Verdict: Yes

Christian Kerr Meditation teacher

Children's creativity is unlimited when inspired by their own imagination. But computers do very little to stimulate creativity in the very young, whereas a dressing-up box would. For older children computer games - and the internet - provide a powerful starting point to develop their own ideas. Limited and supervised use could be beneficial, but parents should know computers are only one source of stimulation: what about a walk in the park or a visit to the theatre? Not every moment of a child's day need be structured - a good dose of boredom can do wonders for creative urges.
Verdict: Yes

Greg Hadfield Founder schoolsnet.com

Computers are tools and should only be regarded as a part of the formative experience. They can't replace all the things children need to be creative, and no-one would think they should spend all day in front of a computer. But used wisely they can enhance creativity, providing parents make sure they get the other things they need. Think of a product that enables a child to do all sorts of artwork on a computer - that's hugely creative isn't it? Computers can't substitute parents or human interaction, but they are hugely valuable in what they can add to a child's experiences.
Verdict: No

Fiona Davis Early Learning Centre

Computers are an integral part of modern life and will be an increasingly important part of the lives of our children. Early learning in technology is as important as early learning in other spheres. However, it's also vital that children are given the right mix of toys to play with: technology-based toys should feature in the toy box along with those that stimulate imaginative play or encourage physical activity. Information technology is now part of the national curriculum for the youngest children, so the government clearly recognises its importance.
Verdict: No

Liz Sich Mother of four

Computers can be useful, but they have to be regulated. We have one computer and four sons - and yes, they play games - though some are logic and memory games which are marvellous for learning. Apart from visiting the Beano and Harry Potter websites, they mainly use the computer for course-work: to find all sorts of information that simply couldn't have been got in the local library or from an encyclopaedia. It's not creative writing, perhaps, but my kids are totally uninterested in poetry anyway. The great thing is that the computer has taught them to be better writers.
Verdict: No
