webTitle: Parents: Leah Wild's IVF diary

fields.headline: First the binge, then the guilt
fields.standfirst: Trying:  Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
Six rats have sealed my offspring's fate. It has been proved that the level of protein in the diet immediately following fertilisation of half a dozen female laboratory-bred vermin severely affects the birth weight of their babies.

Until I heard this, I was having a good week. I had strangely welcomed my morning sickness; it was further confirmation of actually being pregnant. I was learning to be a little bit lazy. At the time the news broke I was lying in bed listening to the Today programme. The ways in which maternal diet in the first five days of pregnancy can affect the long-term prospects of the child-to-be were terrifying. These future people would be more prone to diabetes, high blood pressure, strokes and "a number of adult chronic diseases". Before you even know you're pregnant, you've damaged your child.

I felt smug. Our eight embryos spent the first five days of their life in a dish. Over that long weekend, my boyfriend and I binged. I could eat and drink whatever I wanted, go out and party, while all the genetic material for our hoped-for progeny was several miles away in a hospital lab. It was our last weekend of debauchery. I was awash with red wine.

But there was a coda to the University of Southampton report. The research suggested that, in the case of IVF, there were particular problems. No one knows what the best medium is for the pinprick-sized embryos to develop in; God knows what mistakes might be made. There is a condition called "large offspring syndrome" which is found in in vitro -manipulated sheep and cattle, which leads to abnormally large lambs and calves, and is blamed on their time in the petri dishes. It was suggested that there should be a more thorough follow-up of children born through IVF. And, as my embryos spent two days longer than regular IVF in the lab, being tested for my genetic chromosomal disorder, I was doubly guilty. I had abandoned them before they'd even been implanted in my womb.

I sank back into bed. So, yet again, IVF is not the best, but the worst option. Simply by agreeing to undergo the procedure, I might have caused irreversible harm to the small thing growing in my belly.

Women who are infertile often blame themselves. In response to this column, I've received a wealth of messages from other women undergoing fertility treatment. It is rare for one not to contain the word "guilt". Some women have talked about their commitment to organic vegetarian regimes, Bach Flower Remedies, and a determined abstinence even from aspirin. Foresight - the organisation which advocates a strict diet as an aid to conception - urged me to look into their programme, even though it is absurd to suggest that a chromosomal disorder is susceptible to a higher intake of spinach or a moratorium on Marlboro.

And I am lucky; the cause of my inability to carry a child to full term is clear. Couples who have what is officially termed "unexplained infertility" (which should more accurately be called undiagnosed infertility) - about 10% of the barren - are far more likely to seek an explanation within their own behaviour. Unfortunately, much research encourages them to do so.

For those who simply get pregnant and have a child without any problems, and then progress towards a pension, the afflictions with which we, the barren, live are as foreign as another country. I do not expect you even to imagine them. But your child is, and always will be, regarded differently to mine.

Among the piles of forms that a couple is asked to sign when they undergo fertility treatment, the one I felt most resistant to was an agreement that any child born through the procedure could be tested at regular intervals, presumably to ensure their "normality". I don't buy into the idea that any unacceptable difference in a child can be put down to a single cause, such as the culture in which they swam until they reached eight cells. While the nurse was out of the room, my boyfriend and I had a whispered argument. I didn't want to put my name to such invasive monitoring; he was worried about seeming obstructive. I signed the form. The list for infertility treatment is long, and we were near the top. Anything to please.

I resent the fact that my child is not seen as another member of the human race on the long journey to being born, but as the result of, and still subject to, experiment. My nascent child may have spent a few days in a dish, but - however conceived - she or he is just another kid.

Contact: leahwild@cswebmail.com.

webTitle: Parents: No time to waist

fields.headline: No time to waist
fields.standfirst: If models and pop stars can get back in shape as soon as they're out of the delivery room, why can't you?  Caroline Luce tries to get her body back
fields.trailText: If models and pop stars can get back in shape as soon as they're out of the delivery room, why can't you? Caroline Luce tries to get her body back.
fields.body:
I'm not proud of this, so I'd better get it out in the open right away. The first time I managed to fit into my jeans after my baby was born, I was so thrilled I wanted to phone someone. Obviously I couldn't think of anyone to call ("Hi! It's me. I just had to let you know I can do my jeans up!" "Oh. Well ... ") but I wore them all week to celebrate.

It's not that I had been particularly preoccupied about getting my old shape back after having a baby. I know enough women who are mothers to know it's largely a matter of luck: either everything goes back into place eventually, or it doesn't. No, the problem was boredom. During my pregnancy I wore just three items of clothing, two of them black. And one pair of shoes. I was so looking forward to wearing something different. When I emerged from my pyjamas two weeks after the birth, I realised I still couldn't fit into any of my clothes. I had to climb back into my black, loose-fitting maternity skirt.

I avoided the fashion pages of magazines. It's difficult to look at needle-thin women in slinky pedal pushers when you don't know what shape you are any more. Besides, I had no money to buy new clothes - babies are astonishingly expensive - so if I couldn't get into my old clothes I was doomed to flap about in shapeless black.

Every so often over the following months I sneaked upstairs and tried my jeans on; no luck. But it was my tummy that got me doing crunches on the bathroom floor - I just got sick of the sight of that bulge (I dreaded people asking me when the baby was due). I think I did 20 sit-ups every morning, and then increased to 30. I lasted for two, maybe three weeks, then gave up.

You cannot overstate the depressing feeling that your body's never going to be the same after a baby. Whether it's the debilitating effect of stitches, the huge, painful breasts or the big, loose tummy, sometimes you feel like you're trapped inside an alien. At the same time, you're presented with media images of women looking toned and thin just weeks - no, days - after giving birth.

"Only six weeks after giving birth for the second time... Madonna is already showing off her stunning figure in skin-tight clothes" drools the Daily Record. "Cindy Crawford shows off a perfect figure just days after giving birth ... looking her usual sensational self" trumpets the Sun. The Daily Mail adds insult to injury by praising Cindy for "spurning painkillers and sipping camomile tea throughout the 17-hour labour". Patsy Kensit was spotted in a "slinky size 10" dress six weeks after having her second baby. The tabloids give out the message loud and clear: glamorous women get back in shape as soon as they're out of the delivery room. So why can't you?

Supermodel Crawford puts it even more bluntly: "For women who may not feel comfortable in their bodies, pregnancy can be an excuse to become Mother Earth."

You let your body change shape with childbirth? You losers!

"Women are under tremendous pressure to get thin after giving birth," says Lynn, a mother of two. "If a famous person has had a baby, the papers will always mention her weight and shape in the first paragraph."

For women who tend to worry about their weight, having a baby can be quite traumatic. "I was worrying about my weight in the hospital ," says Lynn, who has battled with anorexia in the past. "I had a caesarean so I couldn't start exercising immediately. But six weeks later I was at the door of the gym first thing, and putting myself through a punishing schedule." She did three hours of aerobic workouts and swimming a week, despite having been very ill after the birth. She's not alone either. Another friend bought a Reebok step after her third child was born, and used it every day, whenever the baby was asleep.

Since Lynn's caesarian prevented her from exercising straight away, she tried to cut down on food. This is a major mistake: the consensus is that breastfeeding women should keep up their food intake and eat as much as they want to, which is probably as much as they need. But what use is that sort of advice when you're surrounded by images of Madonna in skin-tight trousers?

"I weighed myself constantly and always had a tape measure to hand," Lynn admits. And did the weight fall off? No. Like many women, her weight remained constant as long as she was breastfeeding. She was actually tempted to stop feeding her second baby early so she could shed some pounds. Cindy Crawford's Mother Earth remark struck home: "Being pregnant is the only time in my life I'm not obsessing about my weight. It's liberating. But you pay for it."

To minimise the "pay-back", Lynn got super-fit before her second pregnancy, and found her recovery time much quicker. "I was so ill when my first baby was born, I was on a campaign. I was determined to be as fit and muscular as I could."

Linda Hicks, an ante-and post-natal exercise teacher with the National Childbirth Trust, agrees that the fitter you are during pregnancy, the quicker you'll recover. She believes it's "very advisable" for women to start exercising within the first six weeks after the birth, but not so that they can get their trim figure back or squeeze into a slinky size 10. "They must work on the pelvic floor muscles, on the stomach muscles, and do very specific postural work. If you don't do pelvic floor exercises you'll have trouble holding water, and you'll get to 50 and have prolapses."

Far from letting it all hang out, according to Hicks, you must start strengthening the muscles you need to look after a baby, to avoid pain and injury. "Post-natal women are bent over by the weight of huge pendulous breasts. They need to restore strength to the hips."

The women Hicks sees are more concerned with regaining strength in their backs than flat stomachs, but she agrees that most people are unhappy - for whatever reason - with their post-natal bodies: "People are shocked not by the fat but by the tone of what's left - a saggy, flappy stomach. If you've got no tone it makes what you've got look worse." She advises a regime of "active and dynamic" aerobic work and posture exercise. "Exercise can give women confidence about their bodies."

Hicks finds many women in a hurry to get back in shape - not so they can look like Madonna or Melanie Blatt, but so they can fit into their trousers. "Professional women have a timebomb ticking. They have to get back to work, and when they do they will need to get back into their clothes. If it comes to it, it's cheaper to get a personal trainer than to buy a new wardrobe."

One person I know was swayed by Cindy Crawford's anti-Earth Mother message and actually bought her Get Back In Shape After Pregnancy video. Eliza bought the video two weeks after the birth of her second child, watched it once and never looked at it again.

"It's not that I feel any pressure from others, you just get fed up with being fat, that's all. You're feeling so tired you can't concentrate on losing weight, all you can think is 'My child's screaming and I'm going to eat chocolate to give me energy'."

Eliza had her second child quickly after her first, so she never had time to lose the weight she'd gained during her first pregnancy. But in spite of leaving Cindy's video in the box, she is getting fit. "My two-year-old is really heavy, and though I never used to be able to do press-ups, I'm sure I could now: I've got so strong from lifting him."

Women are liable to put pressure on themselves and feel they have to keep pace with other mothers, and that is when motherhood starts getting seriously stressful. "Whether it's getting your baby to sleep through the night or getting back in shape, everyone else seems to be doing it quicker," says London health visitor Sue Braid. "But the only way to enjoy the experience is to take it at your own pace."

My half-hearted attempts to get my stomach flat lasted about two weeks and failed. But about four months after the baby was born I noticed the muscles in my back and arms were beginning to tone up. By this time, of course, the baby weighed a lot, and I was carrying him around in various awkward positions, in his car seat or his chair, all day. Last week I realised I could get up from sitting on the floor, holding the baby, in one move. Now I could never have done that a year ago.

The flatpack: Celebrity mums and their tums

Cindy Crawford gave herself 12 weeks to get back into shape after the birth of her son. The supermodel-mom had used yoga to stay toned during her pregnancy but to restore her 34-24-35 figure her Romanian-born personal trainer of 10 years, Radu Teodorescu, devised a strenuous two-hour, six-day a week schedule of workouts. Inspired by envy after seeing a teenage girl in Malibu wearing tanktop and jeans, the 34-year-old Crawford turned her talents to making an exercise video for other new mothers.

Demi Moore, who posed nude while heavily pregnant for Tina Brown's Vanity Fair, also took on a personal trainer to get her figure back. A few months later the movie star was back on the cover wearing nothing but her well-tailored birthday suit.

Victoria Adams denied employing a personal trainer days after having baby Brooklyn by caesarean, but risked swapping monikers with Sporty Spice after reportedly doing hundreds of sit-ups with husband David Beckham.

Yasmin Le Bon was back on the catwalk minus any visible bump within 20 days of giving birth to her daughter Saffron.

Model Rachael Hunter was posing for a swimwear calendar 12 weeks after the birth of Renee, her daughter by now ex-husband Rod Stewart.

Pamela Anderson and her midriff were spotted on the beach (where else?) a bare seven days after the end of her first pregancy.

Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas reportedly put off their wedding plans (originally scheduled for the birthday they share, September 25), so that she would have time to get her figure back. The 30-year-old Zeta Jones also telephoned Cindy Crawford for advice on an exercise regime to rid herself of the dreaded post-partum tum.

Patsy Kensit stepped out to a film premiere in Rome last year wearing a slinky size 10 gown just six weeks after the birth of her son with Liam Gallagher, Lennon. Her secret weapon was said to be a high-tech weight-training system, the "Figurella" treatment - yours for £2,500.

All Saints singer Melanie Blatt got back into training six weeks after the birth of her daughter Lilyella, with a 90-minute daily programme that included aerobics, weights and power-walking.

She believes it's "very advisable" for women to start exercising within the first six weeks after the birth, but not so that they can get their trim figure back or squeeze into a slinky size 10. "They must work on the pelvic floor muscles, on the stomach muscles, and do very specific postural work. If you don't do pelvic floor exercises you'll have trouble holding water, and you'll get to 50 and have prolapses." Far from letting it all hang out, according to Hicks, you must start strengthening the muscles you need to look after a baby, to avoid pain and injury. "Post-natal women are bent over by the weight of huge pendulous breasts. They need to restore strength to the hips." The women Hicks sees are more concerned with regaining strength in their backs than flat stomachs, but she agrees that most people are unhappy - for whatever reason - with their post-natal bodies: "People are shocked not by the fat but by the tone of what's left - a saggy, flappy stomach. If you've got no tone it makes what you've got look worse." She advises a regime of "active and dynamic" aerobic work and posture exercise. "Exercise can give women confidence about their bodies." Hicks finds many women in a hurry to get back in shape - not so they can look like Madonna or Melanie Blatt, but so they can fit into their trousers. "Professional women have a timebomb ticking. They have to get back to work, and when they do they will need to get back into their clothes. If it comes to it, it's cheaper to get a personal trainer than to buy a new wardrobe." One person I know was swayed by Cindy Crawford's anti-Earth Mother message and actually bought her Get Back In Shape After Pregnancy video. Eliza bought the video two weeks after the birth of her second child, watched it once and never looked at it again. "It's not that I feel any pressure from others, you just get fed up with being fat, that's all. You're feeling so tired you can't concentrate on losing weight, all you can think is 'My child's screaming and I'm going to eat chocolate to give me energy'." Eliza had her second child quickly after her first, so she never had time to lose the weight she'd gained during her first pregnancy. But in spite of leaving Cindy's video in the box, she is getting fit. "My two-year-old is really heavy, and though I never used to be able to do press-ups, I'm sure I could now: I've got so strong from lifting him." Women are liable to put pressure on themselves and feel they have to keep pace with other mothers, and that is when motherhood starts getting seriously stressful. "Whether it's getting your baby to sleep through the night or getting back in shape, everyone else seems to be doing it quicker," says London health visitor Sue Braid. "But the only way to enjoy the experience is to take it at your own pace." My half-hearted attempts to get my stomach flat lasted about two weeks and failed. But about four months after the baby was born I noticed the muscles in my back and arms were beginning to tone up. By this time, of course, the baby weighed a lot, and I was carrying him around in various awkward positions, in his car seat or his chair, all day. Last week I realised I could get up from sitting on the floor, holding the baby, in one move. Now I could never have done that a year ago. The flatpack: Celebrity mums and their tums Cindy Crawford gave herself 12 weeks to get back into shape after the birth of her son. The supermodel-mom had used yoga to stay toned during her pregnancy but to restore her 34-24-35 figure her Romanian-born personal trainer of 10 years, Radu Teodorescu, devised a strenuous two-hour, six-day a week schedule of workouts. Inspired by envy after seeing a teenage girl in Malibu wearing tanktop and jeans, the 34-year-old Crawford turned her talents to making an exercise video for other new mothers. Demi Moore, who posed nude while heavily pregnant for Tina Brown's Vanity Fair, also took on a personal trainer to get her figure back. A few months later the movie star was back on the cover wearing nothing but her well-tailored birthday suit. Victoria Adams denied employing a personal trainer days after having baby Brooklyn by caesarean, but risked swapping monikers with Sporty Spice after reportedly doing hundreds of sit-ups with husband David Beckham. Yasmin Le Bon was back on the catwalk minus any visible bump within 20 days of giving birth to her daughter Saffron. Model Rachael Hunter was posing for a swimwear calendar 12 weeks after the birth of Renee, her daughter by now ex-husband Rod Stewart. Pamela Anderson and her midriff were spotted on the beach (where else?) a bare seven days after the end of her first pregancy. Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas reportedly put off their wedding plans (originally scheduled for the birthday they share, September 25), so that she would have time to get her figure back. The 30-year-old Zeta Jones also telephoned Cindy Crawford for advice on an exercise regime to rid herself of the dreaded post-partum tum. Patsy Kensit stepped out to a film premiere in Rome last year wearing a slinky size 10 gown just six weeks after the birth of her son with Liam Gallagher, Lennon. Her secret weapon was said to be a high-tech weight-training system, the "Figurella" treatment - yours for £2,500. All Saints singer Melanie Blatt got back into training six weeks after the birth of her daughter Lilyella, with a 90-minute daily programme that included aerobics, weights and power-walking.

webTitle: Air France sues Continental over Concorde crash

fields.headline: Air France sues Continental over Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Air France is suing Continental Airlines for the Concorde jet crash, which investigators suspect was caused by a stray piece of metal on the runway that fell from a Continental plane.
fields.body:
Air France is suing Continental Airlines for the Concorde jet crash, which investigators suspect was caused by a stray piece of metal on the runway that fell from a Continental plane.

The lawsuit was filed in France earlier this month, the Houston-based Continental said, while an Air France spokeswoman in Paris today confirmed the lawsuit was going ahead.

Continental spokeswoman Julie Gardner declined to release further details and referred all calls to its London office, where no one was available to comment.

The Concorde, bound for New York's John F Kennedy airport, crashed shortly after taking off from Charles de Gaulle airport near Paris on July 25. All of the 109 people on board were killed along with four on the ground.

A metal strip found later on the runway was believed to have fallen from a Continental DC-10 bound for the United States. The piece of metal was suspected of puncturing one of the Concorde's high-pressure tyres and possibly setting off a chain reaction that brought down the plane.

"At this stage of the investigation, there is however no conclusive evidence that Continental Airlines is involved in the Concorde crash," Continental said in the statement.

French investigators have said part of a metal wear strip that is part of an engine thrust reverser assembly was missing from the Continental plane and had characteristics that appeared identical to the metal piece. The strip is not needed to fly the plane safely.

Meanwhile, a German lawyer for the families of the crash victims said today he was planning to sue Continental Airlines.

The lawyer, Christof Wellens, who represents 20 of the victims, said his lawsuit was likely to be filed in a Texas court. He declined to name a figure for damages sought or say exactly when he would file the lawsuit.

webTitle: Marketing round-up

fields.headline: Marketing round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from the trade title Marketing.
fields.body:
Coca Cola is planning to shake up its £40m UK ad arrangements as part of a drive for more localised marketing. The review is separate form a European pitch called earlier this year which is now thought to have been put on hold. Sources say that everything from creative to PR is being placed under the scrutiny of Tom Long, president of Coca-Cola GB and Ireland.

SmithKline Beecham has linked up with Carlton's interactive arm, Carlton Active, to sponsor Baby Baby, its first interactive programme for an undisclosed sum. The sponsorship will feature the pharmaceutical giant's children's toothpaste brand Maclean's Milk Teeth, which has not previously been advertised on TV.

Ulster TV has awarded its airtime sales contract to Granada Enterprises in a deal that sees Granada strengthen its position within ITV. Ulster TV accounts for 2% of ITV's revenue.

Virgin Interactive, the games publishing arm of Virgin has lost its vice-president of marketing Europe, Sean Ratcliffe, after just six months. The company is left without a marketing chief ahead of the crucial Christmas period and an imminent raft of new ads by Wieden & Kennedy.

COI Communications has appointed The Leith Agency to create a new ad campaign designed to address the problem of homelessness. The win is the agency's first piece of business since winning a place on the COI roster. It beat WCRS, BMP DDB and M&C Saatchi for the account.

Marks & Spencer is launching a celebrity hairdresser-backed haircare range as part of an ongoing effort to draw customers back to its stores with designer names. The Martyn Maxey range will be positioned as a luxury brand.

fields.trailText: Latest news from the trade title Marketing Week.
fields.body:
Unilever is launching its first interactive online soap opera under its Surf brand, called Foam and Away. The move marks the brand debut on the net.

TBWA/London executives have resigned themselves to losing the whole of NatWest's TV advertising account to M&C Saatchi, worth an estimated £25m.

Mills & Boon, the romantic fiction publisher, is launching a brand of books for men in the UK.

IPC has appointed the man who launched Dennis Publishing's Maxim as publishing director for its lads' titles, Loaded, Later and Loaded Fashion.

webTitle: Government child health policy void

fields.headline: Young and invisible
fields.standfirst: Charity attacks government void over child health policy
fields.trailText: Charity attacks government void over child health policy
fields.body:
Concern at the government's attitude towards children's issues surfaced earlier this week in a manifesto backed by 50 pressure groups. Tonight, that concern will be underlined in outspoken terms by Gillian Pugh, chief executive of Coram Family, which claims to be Britain's oldest children's charity.

Giving the annual lecture at Great Ormond Street hospital for children in London, Pugh will attack the "shocking invisibility" of children in the government's NHS plan. Child health, she will say, is becoming neglected and fragmented.

There has been mounting disquiet at what is widely perceived as a low priority that Labour is giving children's issues in England. By contrast, the devolved administrations in Wales and particularly Scotland are seen as taking a series of positive, child-focused initiatives.

Coram Family aims to deliver cohesive, community-based children's services of a kind said by critics to be missing from the government's thinking. Most alarming to some is the relatively small role apparently planned for the Department of Health in the emerging, pan-Whitehall children's unit.

Pugh, in extracts released ahead of her lecture, says children and young people make up 25% of the population and face growing problems of chronic illness and mental health disorder. Yet health has not been "round the table" with education and social services as often as it should have been.

"I was shocked to realise that this timebomb in our society seems to be invisible to NHS policy-makers. The NHS plan's major contribution to child health seems to be a target to provide a free piece of fruit to four- to six-year-olds by the year 2004," she says.

Health services need to become more responsive to children's needs and better integrated with the work of other agencies, says Pugh. "The needs of children do not fall neatly into separate boxes called education, health, play or social care. So why, by and large, do families receive services in this way?"

Pugh's comments follow publication in the British Medical Journal in July of a joint paper by 10 leading child health experts, warning of a policy void on child and adolescent health. They warned of basic principles being ignored and of "widespread frustration" among health professionals.

webTitle: Lessons in revolt

fields.headline: Lessons in revolt
fields.standfirst: Kate Connolly on how the Czechs are learning about direct action against the World Bank and the IMF
fields.trailText: Kate Connolly on how the Czechs are learning about direct action against the World Bank and the IMF
fields.body:
Limbering up in preparation for a training session she's giving in "non-violent direct action" at a temporary camp of protesters outside Prague, Starhawk says: "I almost feel like you have to give people a course in economics before they can join in the protest."

The spiritualist and lifestyle expert from San Francisco has spent a large part of her summer in the Czech capital, working with members of Inpeg, the Initiative Against Economic Globalisation, an umbrella group of anti-globalisation protesters who are in town for the International Monetary Fund/World Bank annual meetings.

"The issues are complex and the media is mostly set up to deal with things in a very simple way," says Starhawk, a new age "witch". "We haven't wanted to reduce the complexity to a simple soundbite."

Then there is the added complication that post-communist countries are unused to direct action, or the concept of "civil society". A lot of people from the region are just not keen to get involved, having been scared off by media reports telling them to barricade their doors against barbarian protesters from the west.

Cue Juraj Zamkovsky. He's the chairman of the Centre for Environment and Public Advocacy (Cepa), whose office is tucked away in the unlikely location of the Polana mountains in Ponicka Huta, a village of 300 in central Slovakia. The NGO is a founding member of the group's Central and Eastern Europe Bankwatch (Ceeb) network and part of Friends of the Earth Slovakia. Ceeb was set up in 1993 to train people how to challenge international financial institutions.

Zamkovsky and a few co-workers monitored several projects in order to help the average Slovak fight against what Cepa see as unsustainable project loans. "We hope that through the example of Prague 2000, Czechs and Slovaks will realise that it's their right to protest," he adds.

Projects have included a successful campaign against a World Bank loan for logging in Slovakia - an activity which in the past few decades has caused Slovakia to lose much of its 300-year-old primary forest. After that came a project to challenge the World Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (Cas) which Cepa believed failed to encourage the fostering of a sustainable economy for the country. It also provided legal support for the village of Dubakova to overturn a ban on local development of a major dam.

webTitle: Legacy of millennium awards scheme

fields.headline: Unsung heroes
fields.standfirst: The millennium awards scheme, unlike the dome, is set to leave behind a legacy
fields.trailText: The millennium awards scheme, unlike the dome, is set to leave behind a legacy
fields.body:
Pip Youngman left school at 13 but taught himself science and became an inventor. Now aged 76, he is more interested in teaching but believes conventional education destroys childrens' natural inventiveness.

Last year, Youngman ran a weekly workshop in Taunton, Somerset for 16 young people, aged 13 to 24, giving them space, materials, tools and equipment to develop their own products or ideas. He was able to do so because of a grant from the millennium commission, making him one of 12,000 people who, since 1996, have each received more than £2,000 under the millennium awards scheme.

The winners range across a huge spectrum, producing innovative projects that show up gaps in official provision and demonstrate the energy and inventiveness of individuals and small groups.

Andy Shercliff ran a medieval fair at Oystermouth Castle, near Swansea, where children could build their own castles, coracles and musical instruments. Ethel Culling launched a successful campaign to get laryngectomy accepted by the Department of Social Security as an allowable disability. Robert Dellar published Mad Pride, an anthology of true stories by psychiatric patients (chosen as a Guardian book of the week), which he said portrayed "a proud, defiant image".

These people are at the other end of millennium largesse from the dome and its mounting, multi-million pound subsidies which have prompted so much anger. The awards scheme, by contrast, has aimed to capture the energy of individual "social entrepreneurs". Working through intermediaries such as the charities Mind and Help the Aged, the awards were made to individuals such as Youngman to carry out community projects by fulfilling a personal ambition.

Scepticism has been expressed as to whether such a grassroots approach could achieve much value. To some critics, handing out cash to people who often had no relevant experience or qualification was a nice gesture, but largely a waste of the £100m which will have been committed this year.

Such doubts now seem to have been substantially dispelled, however. An independent study of the social impact of the scheme, just published, describes it as "a notable success". "The vast majority of award recipients can demonstrate that their projects have achieved their personal aspirations and those of the community," the consultants' report concludes.

Speaking at the report's launch last Friday, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said: "These lottery grants provide a leg up, helping individuals become effective catalysts for local renewal."

Erica Roberts, director of the awards scheme, says the analysis confirms anecdotal evidence of its success. "Our mission was always to enable people to fulfil personal ambitions, as well as providing community benefit. It is very pleasing that we have achieved both of those aims."

She also underlines the broader message that "amateurs" are important in community development, not just professionals in formal organisations. "It is more risky investing in individuals. But the report shows it works. Taking those risks pays off."

The analysis, by Annabel Jackson Associates, points to the gaps in formal provision. "The energy that the programme has released indicates faultlines in British society: gaps in social services, education and the health service; lack of time for professional development and innovation across the public and voluntary sectors; alienation and isolation within communities."

The conclusions are based on almost 1,000 telephone interviews with award winners. The consultancy cautions that assessing social impact is an imprecise exercise. But 90% of those interviewed regarded their project as a success in its impact on them, and almost the same proportion said it was also successful in terms of community impact.

More than two-thirds said their projects had reduced isolation and strengthened links with the community, as well as creating a new service. Importantly, almost two-thirds said the benefits would not have been felt without the award - in other words the scheme did make a difference.

There is always room for improvement, of course, and Roberts accepts several criticisms. Some of the intermediary organisations did not provide satisfactory support to the individuals they sponsored, many of whom needed training in aspects such as finance and publicity. Some projects failed because there was inadequate demand for the service, something a little preliminary market research might have discovered.

The consultants also suggest that some cooperation among the partner organisations might be in order. Many projects shared common aspects, or objectives, and could benefit from the award winners sharing their experiences.

These lessons are not just academic: the awards scheme is to continue, under different management, thanks to a £100m endowment from the commission.

Alex MacGillivray, deputy director of the thinktank New Economics Foundation, is cautioning against over-ambition. The foundation has carried out a smaller, impressionistic analysis for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, to be published in November. The study is expected to share enthusiasm for the scheme's approach, but warns that there is a danger of expecting too much.

"Small, informal groups are a crucial missing piece in social provision. But dumping £2,000 on people is not necessarily the best route," he says. "There also seems to be an obsession with growth, expecting these people to grow into major charities. But most people won't become Oxfams."

webTitle: Profile:   Nurses' leader considers bowing out

fields.headline: Leaving behind a healthy prospect
fields.standfirst: Nurses' leader considers bowing out when the profession is on a high
fields.trailText: Profile: Nurses' leader considers bowing out when the profession is on a high
fields.body:
The two main nursing journals could not have treated it more differently. Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing (RCN), had been nominated for election as president of the International Council of Nurses and was the sole nominee, said a brief item in last week's Nursing Standard, the college's magazine. "Hancock looks set to quit RCN," ran the headline in the independent Nursing Times.

Hancock has been the college's general secretary for more than a decade and her departure would be no great surprise. But she, and the rest of the RCN's leadership, will not have welcomed the outbreak of speculation about her future at what is a critical juncture for the college itself and nursing as a whole.

On the national stage, nursing has its tail up. As the medical profession's stock has sunk ever lower, so nursing has been seized on and promoted by ministers as the patient and voter-friendly alternative. But nurses are waiting for Labour to deliver - on staff numbers, pay and, most importantly, power - and Hancock knows the pressure has to be kept up.

Within the RCN, meanwhile, decisions are about to be taken on key issues. Voting ends today in a three-way membership ballot on the college's presidency, with the incumbent Christine Watson facing challenges from Roswyn Hakesley-Brown and, for a second successive year, Ray Rowden, the high profile NHS commentator, who is promising to shake up "the closed and elitist culture of the nursing hierarchy". Next month, voting will close on two highly controversial issues. The college's 325,000 members are being asked to agree to a hefty 29% rise in subscriptions, and to make a change to the RCN constitution to allow some healthcare assistants into a special category of membership.

This is by no means the first time that the leadership has sought to win acceptance of those who are not qualified nurses or students. And resistance continues to be fierce: at the college's annual congress earlier this year, the move to reopen the issue was passed by a majority of just 5%. But the rise of the healthcare assistant, increasingly taking over less skilled nursing tasks and increasingly holding vocational qualifications, makes the membership question an urgent one.

If the leadership wins the vote, to be announced at the RCN's annual general meeting on October 18, it will be a considerable feather in Hancock's cap. And it will undoubtedly prove more significant for the college than another vote with which she is already inescapably associated: the decision, in 1995, to tear up its no-strike rule.

"Never the same again," said Nursing Times at the time. But it has, in fact, since been very much the same. The college has not taken any industrial action and there is no prospect of it doing so. Yet the scrapping of the no-strike rule was a stunning propaganda coup that had reverberations across the political landscape.

Hancock's use of that issue was much in the mould of her predecessor, Trevor Clay, who transformed what was the original twin-set-and-pearls organisation into the very model of new trade unionism. She came from an NHS management background, though she had of course been a nurse, and had to reign in some of the college's wilder entrepreneurial activity that an ailing Clay had let flourish.

The college has, however, always been highly centralised. And this is causing dissent over the running of the current ballots. Mike Hayward, a prominent RCN steward from Portsmouth, wrote in last week's Nursing Times that he had received nine "biased and misleading" pieces of propaganda on the membership and subscription votes, including a postcard that has gone from Hancock to each member. Describing this as a "scandalous abuse of power", Hayward called for a new general secretary who would "run democratic, open and well-informed ballots".

If the speculation is right, he may be getting a new general secretary soon. The college is playing down talk of Hancock going, but the international role she will formally get next June is not seen as compatible with leading the RCN. No obvious successor stands waiting, but there would be no shortage of candidates for the £90,000-plus a year job.

Hancock has always been coy about her age, but one profile five years ago put her then at 52. Nurses of her generation have the right to retire with full benefits at 55. All things considered, the timing would seem to be right.

webTitle: Campaigner midwives

fields.headline: Birth of the radicals
fields.standfirst: Midwives have a long history as campaigners  both in the NHS and in the wider political arena. Anne Gulland meets the women  whose work and politics are intimately connected
fields.trailText: Midwives have a long history as campaigners both in the NHS and in the wider political arena. Anne Gulland meets the women whose work and politics are intimately connected
fields.body:
Few people with any experience of health care would be surprised to hear that one of the last women to leave the peace camp at Greenham Common was a former midwife. Midwives have a long history as campaigners and radicals in the NHS, and in the wider political arena, and Sarah Hipperson embodies that tradition.

Hipperson arrived at Greenham in 1983  two years after the first group of women set up camp at the Berkshire base, demanding the removal of US cruise missiles from British soil. In the 60s, she had become more and more concerned about the proliferation of nuclear weapons. She became an anti-nuclear activist and visited Greenham when the womens protest began. After the original group was served a high court order, requiring them to leave, she made her home in a tent at the perimeter fence.

She was not the only midwife at Greenham and Hipperson wonders whether her career had anything to do with her decision to protest. Were all the sum total of our experience, she says. My nursing and midwifery experience impacted strongly on me and I went on to have five children.

Nuclear weapons were just not comparable with any laws of nature or God. I discovered that if a bomb exploded, all my knowledge would be completely useless. I would have expected in times of war that doctors, nurses and midwives would have a role to play, but if a nuclear weapon was dropped there would be absolutely nothing we could do to help anyone.

I have asked myself why there were so many midwives at Greenham. The whole process of bringing life into the world was part of my life, not just as a midwife but as a woman, whereas nuclear weapons were about the destruction of life. And I think thats why I went to Greenham.

Hipperson and two other women finally quit the base this month, 10 years after the last US missiles left and eight years after the common was made redundant for military purposes. The women achieved their aim  the 1,000-acre site is now being used for peaceful means and houses a business park and a nature reserve. The women at Greenham were strongly associated with feminism and many midwives believe their radicalism and their desire to change womens health services for the better are also rooted in this movement.

Ella Jackson, a midwife from Brighton, is an activist in the Association of Radical Midwives (Arm), an organisation formed in 1976 by student midwives who shared a frustration with the increasing medicalisation in maternity care. She says: The Arm does have its roots in feminism. Midwifery is a vocation and we genuinely care about what we are doing. I dont think you can get into womens issues without being vocal and committed. Being a midwife is about empowering women to have the kind of labour they want, its about giving birth back to women.

In 1993, almost 20 years after the Arm was established, the Tory government launched Changing Childbirth  a document which promised a root-and-branch transformation in maternity services. The term woman-centred care was born and for the first time a mother-to-be would get the same midwife throughout her pregnancy. Although some mothers and professionals would challenge whether this is the case now, midwives were instrumental in forcing a change  maternity services were to be run with the wishes of women at their centre.

Mary Cronk, an independent midwife based in London, and one of the original radical midwives, says that while it was mothers themselves who were the prime movers in forcing change, midwives quickly joined in. Changing Childbirth was the consumers and midwives working together to effect change. They said they were no longer going to tolerate things like being shaved and given enemas before going into labour.

Midwives have always been autonomous practitioners  a woman can go through an entire pregnancy and labour without ever seeing a doctor if she wants to  and their title is protected in law. Midwives are also fiercely protective of their professional status and woe betide anyone who confuses them with nurses. One American midwifery website equates the term nurse/midwife with that of carpenter/ballerina.

This pride in the distinctiveness of the profession may have something to do with the fact that they are referred to as madwives by some doctors and nurses. Jackson says: When I was a student, madwife was used by some people but people dont think of us like that anymore. I think were accepted and respected. Radical midwives even have dealings with the government as we have been consulted on some policies, such as changes to the UKCC [the nurses, midwives and health visitors regulatory body] and primary care.

But in these anti-radical days is there a future for politicised midwives? Gay Lee, a midwife from London and one of the original radicals, thinks it is time that the radicalism which spawned Changing Childbirth took hold again. Changing Childbirth changed peoples philosophy and woman-centred care became an accepted notion. The problem is we need to establish a service where this can be practised. The midwife is on call, she is providing one-to-one care, so it means that shes having to do long hours in an overstretched and underfunded service. Midwives are voting with their feet. People are worried about this, but theyre not organising anything collectively to oppose it. And its time they did.

 Hipperson is leading an appeal for a memorial to the Greenham women. A cheque to the Commemorative Fund Appeal should be sent to GWPC, 15 Sydney Road, London E11 2JW.

Health and safety

The Greenham protest may be over, but a Hull midwife and health visitor, Lindis Percy, is campaigning to put other US military bases under scrutiny.

A member of a group called the Campaign for the Accountability of American Bases, Percys main target is Menwith Hill, an American intelligence base in the Yorkshire Dales. The base has come under renewed scrutiny recently because of its reported role in the proposed US national missile defence system.

Percy became involved in peace campaigning after attending a public meeting in Souhampton about military activities on Salisbury Plain. I came out of that meeting thinking what absolute madness and I became totally committed to raising questions and opposing deadly weapons, she says. She has been arrested and even imprisoned many times, but has never been deterred from her mission. If being a health visitor is about preventing ill health, then this campaign against weapons of mass destruction goes hand in hand with that.

Ella Jackson, a midwife from Brighton, is an activist in the Association of Radical Midwives (Arm), an organisation formed in 1976 by student midwives who shared a frustration with the increasing medicalisation in maternity care. She says: The Arm does have its roots in feminism. Midwifery is a vocation and we genuinely care about what we are doing. I dont think you can get into womens issues without being vocal and committed. Being a midwife is about empowering women to have the kind of labour they want, its about giving birth back to women. In 1993, almost 20 years after the Arm was established, the Tory government launched Changing Childbirth  a document which promised a root-and-branch transformation in maternity services. The term woman-centred care was born and for the first time a mother-to-be would get the same midwife throughout her pregnancy. Although some mothers and professionals would challenge whether this is the case now, midwives were instrumental in forcing a change  maternity services were to be run with the wishes of women at their centre. Mary Cronk, an independent midwife based in London, and one of the original radical midwives, says that while it was mothers themselves who were the prime movers in forcing change, midwives quickly joined in. Changing Childbirth was the consumers and midwives working together to effect change. They said they were no longer going to tolerate things like being shaved and given enemas before going into labour. Midwives have always been autonomous practitioners  a woman can go through an entire pregnancy and labour without ever seeing a doctor if she wants to  and their title is protected in law. Midwives are also fiercely protective of their professional status and woe betide anyone who confuses them with nurses. One American midwifery website equates the term nurse/midwife with that of carpenter/ballerina. This pride in the distinctiveness of the profession may have something to do with the fact that they are referred to as madwives by some doctors and nurses. Jackson says: When I was a student, madwife was used by some people but people dont think of us like that anymore. I think were accepted and respected. Radical midwives even have dealings with the government as we have been consulted on some policies, such as changes to the UKCC [the nurses, midwives and health visitors regulatory body] and primary care. But in these anti-radical days is there a future for politicised midwives? Gay Lee, a midwife from London and one of the original radicals, thinks it is time that the radicalism which spawned Changing Childbirth took hold again. Changing Childbirth changed peoples philosophy and woman-centred care became an accepted notion. The problem is we need to establish a service where this can be practised. The midwife is on call, she is providing one-to-one care, so it means that shes having to do long hours in an overstretched and underfunded service. Midwives are voting with their feet. People are worried about this, but theyre not organising anything collectively to oppose it. And its time they did.  Hipperson is leading an appeal for a memorial to the Greenham women. A cheque to the Commemorative Fund Appeal should be sent to GWPC, 15 Sydney Road, London E11 2JW. Health and safety The Greenham protest may be over, but a Hull midwife and health visitor, Lindis Percy, is campaigning to put other US military bases under scrutiny. A member of a group called the Campaign for the Accountability of American Bases, Percys main target is Menwith Hill, an American intelligence base in the Yorkshire Dales. The base has come under renewed scrutiny recently because of its reported role in the proposed US national missile defence system. Percy became involved in peace campaigning after attending a public meeting in Souhampton about military activities on Salisbury Plain. I came out of that meeting thinking what absolute madness and I became totally committed to raising questions and opposing deadly weapons, she says. She has been arrested and even imprisoned many times, but has never been deterred from her mission. If being a health visitor is about preventing ill health, then this campaign against weapons of mass destruction goes hand in hand with that.

webTitle: Eco soundings

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Damage limitation | Low profile | Wildlife wisdom
fields.body:
Damage limitation

Amid tears and cheers at Norwich crown court, the Greenpeace 28 walked free last week, after a jury decided that they had "lawful excuse" for weighing into that field of GM maize. Where this leaves the crown prosecution service, which decides where court cases are heard, is debatable. After a string of high profile jury acquittals of "ethical" protesters, it now has a problem finding anyone willing to convict GM, anti-arms trade, human rights and nuclear protesters. The likelihood now is that this kind of case will henceforth be confined to magistrates courts - where a conviction is more likely. Witness last week, when seven GM demonstrators in Weymouth, Dorset, had criminal damage charges dropped and replaced with aggravated trespass following their attack on GM crops. Moreover, criminal damage charges can only go before a jury if more than £5,000 of damage is caused, a point not lost on solicitors acting for 11 GM protesters accused of damaging a crop in Essex who are trying to show that they caused at least that much damage.

Low profile

Still with dynamite court cases, November sees the fifth anniversary of the hanging of the Ogoni writer Ken Saro-Wiwa by Nigeria's Abacha regime and the publication of his son Ken Wiwa's book about the affair. Shell will be keeping its head down ahead of the massive court case being mounted in the US by young Ken and other Ogonis. They accuse Shell and its Nigerian subsidiary of aiding and abetting in the torture and murder of Saro-Wiwa senior and other Ogonis, of taking land for oil development without adequate compensation and polluting air and water in Ogoniland and of recruiting the Nigerian police and military to attack local villages. Shell denies the charges but last week a federal appeal court decided the case could go ahead in New York, rather than London where it was less likely to reach the courts.

Wildlife wisdom

The WWF started life 50 years ago wilfully ignoring people in its mission to save wildlife and was constantly bashed by environmentalists and others who argued that it could not conceivably succeed because animals were vulnerable as long as people were in poverty and environments were in decline. How far it has come in 50 years can be seen in its latest "campaign", called People and the planet. The WWF now spends 50% of its budget on human poverty alleviation, it says, and indeed is the only environment group to get a block grant from the Department for International Development.

webTitle: The evolution of the Centre for Alternative Technology

fields.headline: It's wonderland
fields.standfirst: The Centre for Alternative Technology has gone from cranky to mainstream in 25 years.  Walter Schwarz  reports on its evolution
fields.trailText: The Centre for Alternative Technology has gone from cranky to mainstream in 25 years. Walter Schwarz reports on its evolution
fields.body:
On day three of the petrol crisis, shops in the Welsh town of Machynlleth ran out of milk. Paul Allen looked out of his window at a dairy farm in the middle distance and wondered if the farmer could help. No luck. The farmer had nothing so old-fashioned as a milk churn.

Allen was understandably quick to draw conclusions: he is development director at the Centre for Alternative Technology (Cat). "We've lost our ability to handle local goods. The supermarket gets milk from 300 miles away; this crisis reminds us we must stop moving food around so much."

That day the Cat's staff were drinking more beer than milk - celebrating a 25-year history in which it grew from a tiny community of optimists trying to live sustainably in an abandoned slate quarry into one of the world's leading centres of information, research and demonstration of the technologies that can deliver us from the tyranny of fossil energy. And now there is a new proposal to make the centre into "an authoritative body with freedom to speak out on the misuse of power by multinationals and on the iniquities of globalisation, and to initiate processes of change".

The quarry near Machynlleth has been transformed into a wonderland where you can learn more and have more fun than in the Dome. You arrive in a vertiginous cliff railway powered by water; pee in a recycling loo; call home from a solar-powered telephone; generate your own wave-power; feed farm animals that live almost entirely on kitchen wastes; go down a "mole hole" for a worm's eye view of soil; learn how to build your own sustainable house or grow lots of organic food in a tiny space.

More than 70,000 adults and children a year visit this unpretentious adventure playground where technical stuff is explained in homely language. Entry for the whole day costs £6.90 - with 50% off if you come on foot or on a bike. Every day telephone inquiries come in from people trying to grow, build and generate power sustainably. Inquiries are processed in a new information centre with walls and supporting pillars made of rammed earth and insulation made of Welsh wool.

In the beginning "the quarry was like a jungle scattered with ruinous buildings from which birch trees grew in profusion. My search for such a site had brought me to this beautiful and private place", says Gerard Morgan-Grenville. He had the feeling that "here something new, some fresh and saner way of living might be demonstrated". Morgan-Grenville, an egregious Old Etonian businessman, then aged 45, had studied American hippies trying out sustainable technologies. "They were mostly muddled and disorganised, fragile. Most failed, but the important thing was that they had opted out of mainstream life in order to find a way of living which respected the environment in which they lived. They also rejected authority on principle. I found myself in sympathy with both aims."

The original settlers at the quarry found their project exciting for technological solutions but disastrous economically: they were soon broke. Worse, they were bothered by a stream of visitors endlessly asking the same questions. In their first exercise in turning a problem into a solution, they decided to create an exhibition with explanatory signs, and to charge an entry fee.

The following years were pragmatic and experimental. "First we had the string-and-sealing-wax phase when we put up a Cretan windmill made of bits of wood and recycled car parts," said Peter Harper, one of the early settlers who is now head of biology and Cat's best-known spokesperson. "Then came the craft phase - everything made by hand, even our shoes. Then the ferro cement phase - everything made of chicken wire and mortar. Then the heroic-bits-of-kit phase - a wood-gas generator wreathed in curling pipes with a huge silver retort. Now the economics have changed; there's more money to spend and we can look at costly things like photovoltaic roofs."

Cat has a turnover of £2m and is run by a co-operative of 40 members in which everyone is equal and on the same salary. Paul Allen says the demand for its services has evolved. "Now it's more of a public policy agenda with organisations like the Welsh National Assembly wanting our help on using sustainable resources. But there are still individuals asking how to re-cycle used chip-fat oil or compost dog poo."

Allen said the latest report of the royal commission on environmental pollution calling for a 60% reduction over the next 50 years in the UK's carbon dioxide emissions through burning fossil fuels had given fresh impetus to the search for sustainability, and now the petrol crisis "will set people thinking faster".

Meanwhile do-it-yourself environmentalists can telephone to access Cat's database, call up the website at www.cat.org.uk, or order publications ranging from a tip sheet on organic ways of combating slugs (40p) or a factsheet on environmental building and water power systems (£2), to a New Futures book on designing a compost toilet (£12). Cat can send you a consultant to build your own house, install solar, wind or water power or set up an environmental exhibition in your museum.

Morgan-Grenville, now 70, is still innovating. He is setting up a new network of sustainable communities in the West country. Guest of honour at Cat's 25th anniversary party earlier this month he said it was time to move on. "In the seventies we aimed to attract attention to the environmental crisis. Since then there's been a seismic shift in the reception of that message but now other problems have loomed and Cat should be at the heart of the solution."

He said most people still do not realise the extent of the looming global disaster. "They still assume free trade is a good thing. There's huge public education to be done. I want a centre within the centre - a substantial building with a spiral walkway with bays framing photos and videoclips proffering solutions. We need an authoritative body with freedom to speak out, to tackle the controversial issues and initiate process of change. We're the best qualified body to demonstrate how we could have a better quality of life without ripping off the poor and the planet itself."

Morgan-Grenville believes Cat could get funding for a new centre that would put pressure on corporations by appealing to shareholders. He feels the new Earth Centre near Doncaster is "a theme park lacking a coherent message" while neither Greenpeace nor Friends of the Earth offer a centre where anyone can go to learn. If Morgan-Grenville can sell his latest innovation to Paul Allen, Peter Harper and other members of the co-operative, the Cat saga will only have begun.

 Cat is at Machynlleth, Powys SY20 9AZ; tel: 01654-702400. Walter Schwarz is co-author with Dorothy Schwarz of Living Lightly - Travels in Post-Consumer Society (Jon Carpenter £15)

webTitle: Study says there's no social underclass

fields.headline: Welfare culture
fields.standfirst: Study says there's no social underclass
fields.trailText: Study says there's no social underclass
fields.body:
Party conference season brings the usual rash of promises by politicians to break the "dependency culture". But a book published today concludes that there is no such thing.

Robert Walker, the book's author and professor of social policy at Nottingham University, says there is no single explanation for the growth in numbers of people claiming social security benefits. "There is no real indication that a social underclass actually exists," he says.

The term "benefit dependency" is thought to have been introduced into British political discourse by John Moore, the social security secretary in the Thatcher government. It has been picked up by politicians of all parties, including Tony Blair who said in opposition: "The welfare state is encouraging dependency, lowering self-esteem and denying opportunity and responsibility in almost equal measure."

Walker and the book's other author, Marilyn Howard, a specialist in disability benefits, say that the majority of benefits provide vital help to people in genuine need. Disabled people and pensioners account for the greatest proportion of benefit recipients.

The book, The Making of a Welfare Class?, analyses the reasons for the rise in benefit take-up that has more than doubled social security spending in real terms since 1971. Key factors, the authors say, have been structural economic change, demographic trends, changes in family life and individual aspirations and the introduction of new benefit regimes.

The latter is shown to have been particularly significant in respect of disability, with benefits introduced in the 70s in recognition of disabled people's special financial needs, and also in respect of help for families - replacement of family allowances by child benefit having hugely increased numbers benefiting.

The evidence for increased benefit dependency is "slight", says Walker. "If the phenomenon exists at all, it is localised. Life on benefit is mean and harsh. Consequently, people are much more keen to avoid claiming benefits than to choose them as a way of life. Most claimants who are able to work are eager to do so and routinely look for jobs when they can."

The past 30 years have not bred a culture of hopelessness, nor created a generation of scroungers. "Instead, by providing a measure of financial protection to the individual casualties of social change, social security has fostered economic and social progress," says Walker. "It is better viewed as an agent of societal success than as a cause of economic failure."

 The Making of a Welfare Class? Benefit Receipt in Britain is published at £16.99 by The Policy Press

webTitle: Older people are finding a new assertiveness

fields.headline: Golden oldies
fields.standfirst: Ageism may still be a barrier, but older people are finding a new assertiveness, as Labour is learning
fields.trailText: Ageism may still be a barrier, but older people are finding a new assertiveness, as Labour is learning
fields.body:
Before our very eyes, politics is changing for older people. Policy-makers have finally awoken to the enormous importance of older voters, just as retailers now defer to the older shopper. When today's toddlers reach their prime, every third person in Britain will be over 60.

There is still the obstacle of ageism to contend with, and old age is associated with stigma, deprivation and loneliness, but there is also a new assertiveness among older people. More and more of them are declaring: "I can say what I like and I can do what I like."

After almost 40 years in journalism, half of it on the Guardian, I have spent much of the past 18 months editing a book of older people's views for the charity Help the Aged. I have found that they are not by any means sweet old things who ask for a seat on the bus; they are demanding a turn behind the driver's wheel.

In all, I approached about 50 individuals, from old trade unionists to university dons, from a dinner lady to peers of the realm. Their brief was that they should share something of their experience and attitudes of being an older person. They could be humorous if they wished, or deadly serious, or political, or not. It was up to the writer.

Some of those approached declined to contribute, but often on grounds that they were too busy or that they did not believe in ageing. In the end, 26 pieces are included in the book, Getting a Life: Older People Talking. A number of the contributors are approaching, or even are well into, their 10th decade, it is good to report, and were typically among the most busy. Baroness Castle of Blackburn, 90 next week, was charming throughout our transactions but at one point bemoaned her lack of a secretary and desk facilities when her workload was so considerable.

Lady Margaret Simey - "just plain Margaret, if you please" - is already a nonagenarian. I rang her one evening to discuss an unclear sentence and, once we had dealt with that, her voice suddenly changed. "What on earth has happened to outrage?" she demanded. "There is a hell of a lot in this life to be furious about - and not just things affecting older people - and yet everybody seems to be taking it all so easy. We want more outrage."

Overall, the reassuring theme that emerges from the book is that so long as one's economic situation is bearable, life in the so-called "third age" can be rich, sometimes very rich. Mike Banks, albeit an ex-commando, describes vividly how he climbed the Old Man of Hoy in the Orkneys at 67 - and again at 71. Peter Preston, a former Guardian editor, writes of the joy of teaching his three-year-old grandson to use a computer. Pushpa Chaudhary, who fled India after partition, tells of the strength of her Asian community and the richness of her Hindu faith.

Yet uncomfortable questions hover in the air. Just how charitable are we towards older people? Whether we give them 75p extra a week to live on, or £20, how much do we care about their often precarious, often ill-managed economic circumstances? When we wave somebody goodbye, as they leave full employment for the last time, how much thought do we give to the sense of loss they may well feel next morning?

Or, at a more personal level, just how near are we, in 21st century Britain, to those whom we once called our nearest and dearest? Beyond the dutiful Sunday afternoon cup of tea, how much attention do we willingly give the older members of our family?

 Michael Simmons was born in 1935. Getting a Life: Older People Talking will be published next month by Peter Owen in conjunction with Help the Aged

Margaret Simey

Having been recruited by the women's emancipation movement in the 20s, and been an active politician ever since, I was an ordinary member of society running from meeting to meeting just like anybody else. But then some kind but misguided persons laid on a surprise birthday party when I was 90.

Until then they had called me Old Indestructible, so I was told, but overnight their behaviour towards me changed. Do you need a chair, dear? Would you like a cup of tea, love? Most cruel of all, whatever would I do with myself now that I was retired? My life as an ordinary citizen came to an abrupt end.

As befits my new status as a dependent, I must keep my head down, stop clamouring for a better pension and be grateful for my free bus pass and for concessions when I go into a museum. The whole welfare system seems hellbent on keeping me in what "they" think is my proper place.

My recent hip replacement had brought home to me my lack of independence. I discovered that a weekly case conference was held to review the progress of myself and all patients on the ward; this would decide when I would be allowed to go home. But I was excluded.

When they suggested I should go to a convalescent home, I panicked. I felt that if I agreed that would be the end of my independence. I insisted on going home, and, with the admirable care of community services, I survive. What is so exasperating is that none of this is inevitable. Ageism is a European phenomenon, a comparatively recent by-product of the industrial society. In that context, as non-workers, older people are a drag on the market, of no value, a cost and a problem. Is there no alternative?

My answer came from Africa - as wisdom so often does, if only we had the humility to listen. On a visit to my son in Lesotho, I found myself greeted with enthusiasm by the villagers. Pleased but baffled by my reception, I was told on inquiry that what moved them was their pleasure that my son should enjoy the exceptional good fortune of having such an old mother. To them, my experience and wisdom were worth more than money in the bank.

 Lady Margaret Simey was born in 1906. She has lived and worked in the Toxteth district of Liverpool most of her life, including more than 20 years as a local Labour councillor, specialising in police matters.

Denis Healey

Personally, I did not notice much change until I was 75. From that age on, I have found my memory deteriorating and my senses getting less acute. I can mistake a reference to "Stena Sealink" on television for "Denis Healey". I can distinguish between different vowels, but all consonant sounds are the same to me. I can fail to see something I am looking at when it is staring me in the face.

There is a saying that when you are old, you either widen or wizen. I have done both. Physically I have wizened; I lost two stones in weight between the ages of 75 and 77. I can no longer run upstairs as I used to do. I find travel very tiring. Psychologically I have widened. I am much more interested in people as human beings and can imagine them at every age from childhood onwards when I see them.

Mary Stott

Now well into my 90s, I feel that my way of life differs very little from the life of a male nonagenarian. I live on my own, I have local social services help with washing and dressing, and I have a cooked lunch delivered to my door. I now have no "feminine" hobbies. It is quite a long while since I gave up knitting, and I never was much of a needlewoman or an embroiderer.

Music has been an important part of my life ever since I was quite a young child, especially singing. When I moved into my 80s, I felt my voice was giving out on me. But, suddenly, I thought: I have a very low speaking voice. Surely these tones must be in my singing voice?

So I went, a little nervously, to the conductor of a small local choir and asked him if I might join the basses. He said I was welcome and, though at first the basses thought it was rather comic having a female among them, they came to appreciate the fact that I am rather good at reading music, since I have been doing it most of my long life.

I have not the physical strength to do much in the garden now, but I can sow a row or two of broad beans and runner beans and seldom walk down the garden without pulling up a weed or two. As for my other hobby, painting, that is dwindling, alas, as I grow less mobile. But so far I have managed to go on a painting holiday every summer, and I have some wonderful souvenirs.

Good as it is to have such enjoyable hobbies, they can hardly fill up the whole of one's life. What we women have to accept, I think, is that far more of us than of our male friends and relations will survive into widowhood. I think we should take this on board from the time of our retirement and involve ourselves in organisations that can provide friends as well as useful occupations.

I think that our daughters, however, are less likely to survive into a lonely old age than we were. The pattern of society is changing. Far more women are now in full-time paid employment, and far more husbands and sons involve themselves willingly in family and home.

We have a female monarch, we have had a female prime minister and a female speaker of the House of Commons. So may we not be pretty confident that change will come? I do believe that in the 21st century, women will walk hand in hand with men, as level partners.

 Mary Stott was born in 1907. She was editor of the Guardian's women's page from 1957 to 1972.
fields.bodyText: Before our very eyes, politics is changing for older people. Policy-makers have finally awoken to the enormous importance of older voters, just as retailers now defer to the older shopper. When today's toddlers reach their prime, every third person in Britain will be over 60. There is still the obstacle of ageism to contend with, and old age is associated with stigma, deprivation and loneliness, but there is also a new assertiveness among older people. More and more of them are declaring: "I can say what I like and I can do what I like." After almost 40 years in journalism, half of it on the Guardian, I have spent much of the past 18 months editing a book of older people's views for the charity Help the Aged. I have found that they are not by any means sweet old things who ask for a seat on the bus; they are demanding a turn behind the driver's wheel. In all, I approached about 50 individuals, from old trade unionists to university dons, from a dinner lady to peers of the realm. Their brief was that they should share something of their experience and attitudes of being an older person. They could be humorous if they wished, or deadly serious, or political, or not. It was up to the writer. Some of those approached declined to contribute, but often on grounds that they were too busy or that they did not believe in ageing. In the end, 26 pieces are included in the book, Getting a Life: Older People Talking. A number of the contributors are approaching, or even are well into, their 10th decade, it is good to report, and were typically among the most busy. Baroness Castle of Blackburn, 90 next week, was charming throughout our transactions but at one point bemoaned her lack of a secretary and desk facilities when her workload was so considerable. Lady Margaret Simey - "just plain Margaret, if you please" - is already a nonagenarian. I rang her one evening to discuss an unclear sentence and, once we had dealt with that, her voice suddenly changed. "What on earth has happened to outrage?" she demanded. "There is a hell of a lot in this life to be furious about - and not just things affecting older people - and yet everybody seems to be taking it all so easy. We want more outrage." Overall, the reassuring theme that emerges from the book is that so long as one's economic situation is bearable, life in the so-called "third age" can be rich, sometimes very rich. Mike Banks, albeit an ex-commando, describes vividly how he climbed the Old Man of Hoy in the Orkneys at 67 - and again at 71. Peter Preston, a former Guardian editor, writes of the joy of teaching his three-year-old grandson to use a computer. Pushpa Chaudhary, who fled India after partition, tells of the strength of her Asian community and the richness of her Hindu faith. Yet uncomfortable questions hover in the air. Just how charitable are we towards older people? Whether we give them 75p extra a week to live on, or £20, how much do we care about their often precarious, often ill-managed economic circumstances? When we wave somebody goodbye, as they leave full employment for the last time, how much thought do we give to the sense of loss they may well feel next morning? Or, at a more personal level, just how near are we, in 21st century Britain, to those whom we once called our nearest and dearest? Beyond the dutiful Sunday afternoon cup of tea, how much attention do we willingly give the older members of our family?  Michael Simmons was born in 1935. But then some kind but misguided persons laid on a surprise birthday party when I was 90. Until then they had called me Old Indestructible, so I was told, but overnight their behaviour towards me changed. Do you need a chair, dear? Would you like a cup of tea, love? Most cruel of all, whatever would I do with myself now that I was retired? My life as an ordinary citizen came to an abrupt end. As befits my new status as a dependent, I must keep my head down, stop clamouring for a better pension and be grateful for my free bus pass and for concessions when I go into a museum. The whole welfare system seems hellbent on keeping me in what "they" think is my proper place. My recent hip replacement had brought home to me my lack of independence. I discovered that a weekly case conference was held to review the progress of myself and all patients on the ward; this would decide when I would be allowed to go home. But I was excluded. When they suggested I should go to a convalescent home, I panicked. I felt that if I agreed that would be the end of my independence.
