webTitle: Struggling Windies right to send for the A team

fields.headline: Struggling Windies right to send for the A team
fields.trailText: The Caribbean's domestic competition was so tough in the late 70s and 80s that if cricket had been an Olympic sport, the Barbados team would been definite gold-medal contenders. The batting was opened by Greenidge and Haynes, the bowling by Marshall and Garner, and the supporting cast included Sylvester Clarke, Wayne Daniel, Ezra Moseley, Franklyn Stephenson, Carlisle Best and David Murray. These days, you won't find that much excellence in the whole of the West Indies. And the inter-island competition, now known as the Busta Cup, has fallen on hard times. The West Indies cricket board is trying to give it a shot in the arm by allowing the England A team to take part.
fields.body:
The Caribbean's domestic competition was so tough in the late 70s and 80s that if cricket had been an Olympic sport, the Barbados team would been definite gold-medal contenders. The batting was opened by Greenidge and Haynes, the bowling by Marshall and Garner, and the supporting cast included Sylvester Clarke, Wayne Daniel, Ezra Moseley, Franklyn Stephenson, Carlisle Best and David Murray. These days, you won't find that much excellence in the whole of the West Indies. And the inter-island competition, now known as the Busta Cup, has fallen on hard times. The West Indies cricket board is trying to give it a shot in the arm by allowing the England A team to take part.

Is it good for Caribbean cricket? There are opposing views on this in the region. The first holds that the Busta Cup is too short a competition, and the more teams the better (there are usually six - Barbados, Jamaica, Trinidad & Tobago, Guyana, the Leewards and the Windwards). The opposite view is that they'll be getting English youngsters used to Caribbean conditions, only for them to turn that experience against the West Indies at some point. Another argument against it is that while every team entertains touring Test sides during their domestic competition, no touring team actually takes part in their competition. Will the West Indies A team join in the County Championship? I don't think so.

Some of those reservations are well founded, but the idea has more merits than minuses. First of all, give the Board credit for another bold decision. Pat Rousseau and co are much criticised but they were brave and imaginative in their corporate-style appointment of the current coach and manager, Roger Harper and Ricky Skerritt. The decision to include an A team in the Busta Cup - not just England's but a different A team every year - is similarly innovative. That radical thinking may be just what's required to revive West Indies cricket. Of course it can go wrong, in the way that the new management team's results did on the England tour. If England A win the tournament, the Caribbean will be even more embarrassed than it was after the two-day Test at Headingley.

It's fanciful to talk of England players learning trade secrets in the Caribbean. As one local commentator cuttingly put it, "we have nothing to teach anyone these days". In this era of free movement, cricketers not selected for winter tours routinely go off to Australia for a spot of grade cricket. Australia don't seem unduly bothered about Alec Stewart's experience Down Under when he makes a big score against them - in fact, despite that experience, Australia are the one team he has consistently struggled against. And England herself has been a finishing school to countless overseas players over the years, including all those Bajan giants. Nearly all of the experienced Caribbean cricket watchers I have spoken with say the presence of England A will make the Busta Cup much more interesting.

It also means a quality addition to the competition. They've tried to bolster the Red Stripe Bowl, the one-day competition, by bringing in teams like Canada and Bermuda, comprised essentially of Caribbean expats and former players. England A do start as the strongest team, but that's no bad thing. The Caribbean players would already know that John Crawley, Alex Tudor and Chris Silverwood have put in good performances in Test cricket. Playing against them would be another important measurement for the young players in the various island teams.

England's chairman of selectors, David Graveney, has said he really wants to win this one, no doubt to maintain a psychological advantage over the Windies. He thinks they have a real chance, but he's half right. He's got players who'll want to show him they haven't had a long enough run in the Test side (Aftab Habib, Chris Read, Chris Schofield, Silverwood, Tudor), uncapped players who'll do their best to impress (Steve Harmison, Jason Brown) and John Crawley, who at 29 will want to show that he is far from finished. They'll be competitive all right, but they won't necessarily find the going easy in the West Indies.

The standard of pitches has become poor. Low scores and low averages have been the norm in recent competitions, and for all the great fast bowlers who've emerged from the region lately, it's the spinners who have tended to be more successful. Mahendra Nagamootoo was picked for the England tour, after jointly taking the most wickets (31) with Courtney Walsh in the Cup last year. Nagamootoo has troubled batsmen when he's played on tour, and he and Trinidad's Dinanath Ramnarine could be a real handful.

Another good thing is that it'll be something of a homecoming for Alex Tudor and the England A captain Mark Alleyne. I've always believed that the rules should allow players like Mark Ramprakash and Chris Lewis (Guyana), and Dean Headley (Jamaica), to play for their "home" countries. This is the next best thing. Expect an improved competition, and expect England A to play a part in that.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous column, in which he reflects on West Indies' summer of despair, click here

webTitle: Ferguson defends Beckham after spitting incident

fields.headline: Ferguson defends Beckham after spitting incident
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson has defended David Beckham, who was seen spitting in frustration near the end of Manchester United's 3-1 defeat against PSV Eindhoven.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has defended David Beckham, who was seen spitting in frustration near the end of Manchester United's 3-1 defeat against PSV Eindhoven.

Beckham was booked for dissent by referee Markus Merk, and he then showed his anger by turning and spitting on the ground in the general direction of the German official.

Merk did not take any further action and Ferguson felt Beckham was justified in being annoyed with the referee. "It's understandable," said the United boss. "They get frustrated with the referee. The referee is supposed to be at the top of his job - that's the reputation he's got. But we didn't get a lot of help from the referee in protecting the players."

Merk would not discuss the incident after the game and it is highly unlikely that Uefa's disciplinary committee will pursue the matter. Beckham's spitting was a sour end to a bad night for United as they sank to their heaviest Champions League defeat since they lost by the same scoreline to Gothenburg in November 1994.

Ferguson, however stood by his weakened team - Beckham, Ronny Johnsen, Ryan Giggs, Andy Cole and Teddy Sheringham all started on the bench, while Denis Irwin was not even a substitute - despite the result, and says he is confident that if United can win their two remaining home games and secure the 10 points they will qualify for the second phase.

"The only thing that can be questioned is my team selection, but I was looking for a fresher team on Sunday and I have achieved that," he said. "It puts us in a better position to face Arsenal on Sunday.

"This was a game in which I felt 10 points will qualify us and we have two home games and I think we can achieve that."

webTitle: Well, Tony did the business

fields.headline: Well, Tony did the business
fields.standfirst: In the third instalment of his diary, Labour MP Ben Bradshaw gives an insider's insight into Conference 2000
fields.trailText: In the third instalment of his diary, Labour MP Ben Bradshaw gives an insider's insight into Conference 2000.
fields.body:
Well, Tony did the business.

While Gordon had addressed the movement, Tony talked to the country.

About what we'd achieved, about what still needed to be done and about mistakes. Also, crucially, about the Conservative alternatives. He laboured totting up the £16bn of proposed Conservative spending cuts. But as the Tories themselves haven't even begun to say where the axe will fall, why not?

Newspaper coverage of Gordon Brown's barnstormer the day before was worth taking a long coffee break over. Even the Tory Mail and Telegraph couldn't help a certain amount of grudging respect. Labour's critical friends at the Mirror were positively gushing, but for some reason they have got it in for John Prescott.

The blood sports brigade, otherwise known as the Countryside Alliance, do their best to drown out an interview I'm doing live with my local ITV station. The consolation is that their demonstration was a tiny fraction of last year's.

For some reason national newspaper editors were seated among Labour MPs and delegates for the prime minister's speech. Most joined in the applause out of politeness - whatever their political beliefs. Not so the editor of the Tory Sunday Times, who sat firmly in his seat, stony-faced. Pondering, perhaps, what stories his paper might make up this week.

I'm perplexed that Labour South West's evening consists of a competition to kick a football through a very small hole to win money for your local football club and charity. "Isn't this a bit sexist, macho?" I ask. Only to have my own prejudice thrown back at me as two members of Brighton women's football team come closer than any of the lads to achieving the impossible.

Pondering, perhaps, what stories his paper might make up this week. I'm perplexed that Labour South West's evening consists of a competition to kick a football through a very small hole to win money for your local football club and charity. "Isn't this a bit sexist, macho?" I ask. Only to have my own prejudice thrown back at me as two members of Brighton women's football team come closer than any of the lads to achieving the impossible.

webTitle: Tiger Aspect sells BBC1 hits to US

fields.headline: Tiger Aspect sells BBC1 hits to US
fields.trailText: September 27: UK indie Tiger Aspect Productions has sold the formats to BBC1 hits the Vicar of Dibley and Playing the Field to US production companies owned by Frasier stars Jane Leeves and Peri Gilpin, and Whoopi Goldberg respectively. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
UK indie Tiger Aspect Productions has scored a double success in the US, selling the formats to BBC1 hits the Vicar of Dibley and Playing the Field to production companies owned by Frasier stars Jane Leeves and Peri Gilpin, and Whoopi Goldberg respectively.

Bristol Cities, the company set up by Leeves (Frasier's Daphne) and Gilpin (who plays Ros in the sitcom), will develop a US TV version of the Vicar of Dibley for Hollywood studio Paramount.

The pair - who will not star in the show themselves - are talking to a major US star about taking the lead role played by Dawn French in the BBC1 version. The show is expected to be pitched to the US terrestrial networks.

Goldberg's company, One Ho Productions, has optioned the Kay Mellor-scripted Playing the Field for the US.

Tiger Aspect has sold a third format, entertainment show StreetMate, to veteran US production house Dick Clark Productions, whose credits include the Donny & Marie Show, American Bandstand and Bloopers. Playing the Field and StreetMate will be pitched to US cable networks.

The format deals, which potentially could net Tiger Aspect millions if the US versions become hits, have been brokered by the company's commercial director, Andy Zein.

webTitle: BBC2's web drama fails to net viewers

fields.headline: BBC2's web drama fails to net viewers
fields.trailText: September 27: Attachments, Tony Garnett's BBC2 drama about groovy new media types, failed to set old-fashioned TV audiences alight on its debut last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Attachments, Tony Garnett's BBC2 drama about groovy new media types, failed to set old-fashioned TV audiences alight on its debut last night.

The BBC2 show opened with a disappointing 1.4m (7% share) from 9pm, against strong competition from ITV's Peak Practice (7.5m, 34%), Terminator 2 (2.8m, 15%) on Channel 5 and Channel 4 makeover documentary Faking It (2.4m, 11%), according to unofficial overnights

Elsewhere last night, BBC1 sitcom My Family (7.3m, 33%) had a strong second outing at 8.30pm, after its impressive debut last Tuesday (8m, 35%).

Earlier, the second half-hour of BBC1's Olympic round-up, Day Down Under, nabbed Emmerdale's inheritance from under the nose of The Bill. Emmerdale averaged 9.5m (48%) from 7-7.30pm, but a large contingent of ITV viewers appear to have switched over for the second half of BBC1's Olympic highlights.

The Bill's audience dropped to 7.5m/36% in the next quarter hour, while Day Down Under leapt from 4.9m/24% to 7.8m/37%. The Bill also lost out to EastEnders (9.8m, 43%) from 8pm, and overall had 7.1m/32% over 60 minutes from 7.30pm,

Earlier yesterday, Tony Blair's troop-rallying speech at the Labour party conference proved a ratings winner for BBC2, but not Channel 4. BBC2's Conference Live averaged 1.2m/19% over nearly two hours from 2pm, while on Channel 4, The Leader's Speech took 0.4m/6% from 2.15-3.35pm.

webTitle: IPC to relaunch Country Homes & Interiors

fields.headline: IPC to relaunch Country Homes & Interiors
fields.trailText: IPC Southbank is to reposition monthly home interest glossy Country Homes & Interiors in an October 12 relaunch, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC Southbank is to reposition monthly home interest glossy Country Homes & Interiors in an October 12 relaunch.

The overhaul is designed to emphasise Country Homes' upmarket appeal to take on the National Magazine Company's home interest title, Country Living. It will have heavier paper and more "sophisticated" copy in order to appeal to the "young country professional", according to IPC.

Earlier this month, NatMags reorganised in order to incorporate the newly purchased Gruner+Jahr titles. The publisher recently created an "affluent" magazines division to go head to head with Conde Nast.

webTitle: BBC Warriors in Prix Italia triumph

fields.headline: BBC Warriors in Prix Italia triumph
fields.trailText: September 27:Peter Kosminsky's hard-hitting BBC1 Bosnian war drama, Warriors, has taken top prize at the prestigious Prix Italia international television awards, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Peter Kosminsky's hard-hitting BBC1 Bosnian war drama, Warriors, has taken top prize at the prestigious Prix Italia international television awards.

The Prix Italia jury said Warriors dealt with the changing role of the modern soldier in "an outstanding way, which goes one step further than the terrifying images of war, in showing the aftermath of conflict".

The BBC won a second award at the Prix Italia, with bbc.co.uk voted best broadcaster portal in the inaugural internet section of the awards, which were presented in Italy over the weekend.

Mr Kosminsky's next project, docu-drama Innocents - which deals with the Bristol Royal Infirmary baby heart surgery scandal - is due to go out on Channel 4 this Sunday.

webTitle: Letter: Why I left, by Rushdie

fields.headline: Why I left, by Rushdie
fields.standfirst:
Read John Sutherland's comment: Scalpel, razor and hatchet
Feature: Why Rushdie wasn't welcome in New York
fields.trailText: John Sutherland (Scalpel, razor and hatchet, September 25) is generous about my writing ability, but wrong to suspect that I am spending more time in New York because of London party gossip (most of which I never hear) or bad reviews (actually, I think I've had a pretty even break from most book pages over the years).
fields.body:
John Sutherland (Scalpel, razor and hatchet, September 25) is generous about my writing ability, but wrong to suspect that I am spending more time in New York because of London party gossip (most of which I never hear) or bad reviews (actually, I think I've had a pretty even break from most book pages over the years).

What got to me, in the end, was the belief - widespread in Britain, rare elsewhere except in fundamentalist circles - that I was to blame for the terrorist assault against my life and work; the constant attack on the cost of my protection; and the incessant attempts at character assassination.

When Professor Sutherland writes of the "body count racked up by The Satanic Verses" and says that "there are people dead who would still be living had Rushdie never put pen to paper," I therefore find it hard to forgive him, even if he does hastily add that "it's fanaticism, not literature, that pulls the trigger". Well, yes, exactly. But if even so sympathetic a commentator as Sutherland is prepared to cloud the issue, it's not surprising that so many people in Britain find it easier to blame the "arrogant" novelist than his would-be killers.

I had thought I was fighting for what I valued most - a great principle, an idea of freedom, and yes, a book - against what I most disliked - intolerance, bigotry and violence. I am so sorry that the British have, for the most part, not been prepared to see it that way.
Salman Rushdie

webTitle: 'Our Peaceful Protests have been aborted, by those we call Comrades'

fields.headline: 'Our Peaceful Protests have been aborted, by those we call Comrades'
fields.standfirst: Protestor Gideon Burrows reports on the second day of clashes in Prague
fields.trailText: Yesterday when we gathered to march through the centre of Prague, there were only a few police on the streets. Today, there are clusters of armed officers at every corner. People are being randomly stopped, searched and asked for ID. If they are unable to show a valid passport or visa they are arrested. The protest information centre is now being monitored by uniformed police officers. Protestors were arrested at a World Bank/IMF delegate hotel this morning.
fields.body:
Yesterday when we gathered to march through the centre of Prague, there were only a few police on the streets. Today, there are clusters of armed officers at every corner. People are being randomly stopped, searched and asked for ID. If they are unable to show a valid passport or visa they are arrested. The protest information centre is now being monitored by uniformed police officers. Protestors were arrested at a World Bank/IMF delegate hotel this morning.

This morning, as a small number of us gathered at a main square to discuss our plans for the day, two hundred riot police arrived in armoured vans. They had pepper spray, huge batons and shields. They piled out, and into the crowd, surrounding people sitting on the church steps. We were released only if we could show valid ID. Five people were arrested as protestors chanted "Let them go. Free political prisoners!."

Yesterday we had freedom of movement around Prague. Today, it seems, police will crack down on any large assembly.

It is because of yesterday's violence.

It began yesterday afternoon, as my group were locked into a peaceful standoff with police and tanks at the main bridge to the conference centre. We heard reports of violent flare-ups at other railway bridges to the conference centre. The "Blue Group" had decided to take the police head on. Mainly German anarchists, the group came armed with Molatov Cocktails, bricks and sticks. We heard that ten managed to reach the conference centre, but most were beaten back by riot police with CS gas and water canons. We read in the Czech papers this morning that many police were injured, many protesters are in hospital. In the square this morning, some protesters were wearing head bandages.

There was a statement today from INPEG, the Czech hosts of the protest: "If you threw a rock, firebomb, apple, bottle or anything else at a cop during yesterdays protest and you are NOT an employee of some bullshit law enforcement agency, then shame on you. You have betrayed INPEG's commitment to non-violence, the movement and yourselves."

As I write, protestors are gathering again in the main square. They are huddled into groups, discussing what to do now. Options include going to the hotels, trying to get to the conference centre, maintaining a protest at the square and waiting for the Opera tonight, where delegates will be entertained.

One thing is certain. Because of the Blue Group's violence, any moves we make will be quickly curtailed by riot police. Smaller groups are likely to be challenged by police at every corner. Our non-violent, legitimate protests have been aborted, not by police or authorities, but by the people we call Comrades.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Labour in Brighton

fields.headline: Now the core counts
fields.standfirst:
Labour in Brighton: Our commentators on how the party plans to fight back - and where it came from

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: There is an irreducible core, that was the message. Yes, he has been a unifier, yes he always wanted one-nation Tories in his tent but now with his back to the wall there is nothing to do but fight.
fields.body:
There is an irreducible core, that was the message. Yes, he has been a unifier, yes he always wanted one-nation Tories in his tent but now with his back to the wall there is nothing to do but fight.

With the ghost of elections lost beckoning for the first time, he cast a deep red sea between his party and William Hague. The choice is there - a stronger community or no such thing as society, confidence or cynicism, good public services or devastating tax cuts. "It's not an arrogant government that chooses priorities," he said echoing Bevan's "Socialism is the language of priorities." "Solidarity" was his one-word vision. He might almost have called them comrades.

How obliging of the Countryside Alliance to launch their own rowdy class war outside the gates. The enemy army bayed in Barbours along the sea front, Bicester Hunt and the Barrell Harriers yelling outrage that by some unnatural coup Labour is in power, an illegitimate government because it is not theirs.

The chancellor and prime minister delivered a brace of fine speeches, passionate and substantial. In this febrile conference both were greeted with anxious rapture by a party on the verge of a nervous breakdown. For all the tales of near fratricidal sibling rivalry, these two men are joined at the hip, bound together in political life and death, sinking or swimming in the same great project. Each has the virtues of the other's vices, complementary and opposite. Gordon greets the world as a proud Coriolanus who will not bend to please the whims of an irrational mob. (When he did bend to shower cash on the pensioners he could not bring himself to mouth the words: his acolytes had to tell the press afterwards.) Tony Blair by contrast plays Mark Antony, ear well-tuned to each ripple of public mood, daily taking the people's pulse, wooing, cajoling. Different styles, same message - this year the irreducible core of belief.

But fine speeches butter few parsnips these days. A clip or two on the news doesn't often catch the spirit that ignites an eager conference. It doesn't reverberate far outside the political cognoscenti (though a disastrous performance would). It's the people out there that count now - the fickle 85% who swung so sharply behind the farmers and hauliers. Howling for blood one minute, weeping the next, demanding less taxing and more spending in the same maniacal breath; how do you reach people who do not want to listen? What is going on out there?

No one knows, it makes no sense, though a thousand views flow through every Brighton bar and hallway. A leader who once commanded an astounding 93% approval - more popular than Jesus Christ as John Lennon might have said - plunged out of the sky to -35, his people-sensing altimeters all awry. Blame and regret are everywhere. If only this or that, why oh why? Everyone asks everyone else, no one knows. Twenty-twenty hindsight is everywhere. The same people on the same day veer between the two paths - extreme caution or unaccustomed bravery.

The cautious voices warn not to forget at our peril that this is a profoundly conservative country. Tiptoe gently in this tax-phobic, Sun-damaged land, where Labour governments are accidental and unwelcome interlopers. Be not deceived by the mammoth majority - mainly Tory collapse and statistical fluke (fewer voted Labour in 1997 than in 1992). Blair's doomy pollster and soothsayer Philip Gould kept warning for the last six months that wicked issues were bubbling to the top of his focus group cauldron. Asylum, asylum, asylum he said, shuddering at middle England seething wildly in places where the only black faces are golliwogs knitted by the WI. This panic scenario says appease the furies, soothe the savage Murdoch - and hope to do a little good by stealth.

The fight-back position says do the opposite - and that is what Blair and Brown have chosen. The T-word is no longer verboten. Tax is good, tax cuts bad. The great debate has begun - the one they never dared have before. Eighteen years of low-tax Tories devastated generations of undereducated children, left hospitals to rot, public squalor amid squalid wealth. Now voters can be told: they get what they pay for. At last it is the end of the politics of the impossible, the fantasy promises that everyone can have it all, all the time, at no cost. Failure to deliver the transparent nonsense of the proposition has helped create the cynicism Blair now sets out to fight - no longer the pristine parfit knight of 1997, but an older wiser man. No more walking on water but a tough ideological battle to win.

W here does this debate take place? How do you engage with a public so alienated from politics? Tony Blair always used to say the case for tax would have to wait until things got better. Once clear improvement is delivered the argument will be won by the good things people see done all around them. By their works the people will know New Labour and the value of paying their taxes.

But what if they don't? I talked to a delegate from the Aylesbury estate, the concrete desert in south London where Tony Blair stepped out one morning in June 1997 to proclaim his plans for social inclusion - "No one left out". All the early money went to the poor first, do they notice any difference? Some have £25 a week more from working families tax credit, poor pensioners have an extra £5.40.

Yes, he said, a previously bad local primary has soared up the league table with a lot of extra help. Yes, people on benefits are a bit better off, there are more jobs, the new deal works. But no, they don't thank politicians and they don't even think things are getting better. "They believe what they read in the Sun more than what they see around them." Reality is less powerful than print. Other delegates said the same: tabloid truth triumphs over the evidence of people's own eyes.

If even the main beneficiaries don't yet get it, who will? Few heard the news that all pensioners were in for a whacking great rise. The Mail headline said "In retreat", a Brown climbdown, and the Sun put it on page eight with no headline. The corrosive effect of a press that simply does not relay the most basic factual news is frightening. A press courted then lost leaves too much to be relayed through an enemy messenger.

Labour is turning to its roots. Once so despised by New Labour architects, suddenly the centre is rediscovering the party and the unions with a new warmth. Politics no longer works from the top down: the challenge is to find ways to talk to people where they are, talking to those who detest and despise the political culture of Westminster. In a hostile climate, it is all fight from now on.

Jonathan Freedland's column will appear tomorrow.

fields.headline: Heat turned on spinners as they try to explain PM's sweat-soaked shirt
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The first tell-tale signs appeared under the collar of the prime minister's pale blue shirt, seeping down his chest under his tie and then creeping across his midriff.
fields.body:
The first tell-tale signs appeared under the collar of the prime minister's pale blue shirt, seeping down his chest under his tie and then creeping across his midriff.

When Tony Blair's jacket opened as he raised his arms at the end of the 56 minute speech, his shirt looked as if someone had thrown a glass of water at it.

As wags suggested that his speech was more about perspiration than inspiration, Mr Blair gave his wife, Cherie, a damp hug. Last night the talk of Brighton was the issue of body temperature rather than the content of the leader's speech.

Downing Street and Labour party spin doctors went into action, aware that it was damaging for their man to look as if he was breaking out in a sweat under pressure.

"It proves he is a real man," said one spinner, while another added: "It showed that when the heat is on he gets going."

The public relations consultant Max Clifford said: "I have spoken to people who have been to the conference and they have all told me how incredibly hot the conference centre is.

"So it wasn't as if Mr Blair's advisers could not have anticipated this.

"In my opinion, they made a critical mistake.

"This will now give the Tories a green light to say Mr Blair was sweating because he was squirming and fighting for his political life.

"They certainly won't be mentioning the heat."

The prime minister is believed to have showered and changed his shirt in Brighton last night before going to a Labour fundraising dinner.

webTitle: Blair comes out fighting as he admits mistakes and says he is ready to listen

fields.headline: Blair comes out fighting as he admits mistakes and says he is ready to listen
fields.standfirst:
Leader's speech PM gives pledges on asylum and overseas aid and refuses to budge on core principles
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: These are edited extracts from Tony Blair's speech in Brighton yesterday:
fields.body:
These are edited extracts from Tony Blair's speech in Brighton yesterday:

No prime minister, no party leader, could have a better deputy than John Prescott.

You know why the Tories hate him: because he started out as a seaman, steward on a ship, rose to be deputy prime minister and has never hidden or been anything other than totally proud of where he came from.

And you know why I like him: because not once in the last two weeks has he reminded me that when he was in charge in August we were 20 points ahead in the polls.

For me, the large majority we won was never a reason to do the job quickly; but to do it properly. We knew: first base was getting the fundamentals in place.

We said we would sort the economy out. We have. The strongest British economy for decades, delivered by this New Labour government.

We said we'd get people off benefit and into work. We are. One million more jobs.

We said we'd invest in schools and hospitals. It is happening.

And because we chose to invest; because we have in this country tens of thousands of dedicated hard working teachers as determined as we are to give every child a chance to succeed, last week, Britain had the best primary school results it has ever seen.

I could go on and on. Because we should be proud of our record. But this is not a time for lists. But for setting out the big choices facing Britain and for dialogue.

Knock

I'm the prime minister that's supposed to be the great reader of public opinion. After the events of two weeks ago, it's no wonder the government has taken a knock. It happened on my watch and I take responsibility. So: what do we make of it?

Three years ago, Britain was desperate to get the Tories out. The people liked the look of us. We were a breath of fresh air. New faces, new ideas, new policies. In some areas we've exceeded expectations. Let us be honest, a few people doubted the economy would be stronger under Labour. But it is. They like the 1m new jobs. They believe we are trying to make progress on schools and hospitals.

But for many families life's still a struggle. It's tough, balancing work and family. Jobs can be insecure. There's the mortgage to pay; the holiday to save for. Inflation may be lower but the kid's trainers don't get any cheaper.

Then, people hear the 20 second clip on the news. They see the ding-dong at prime minister's questions. They try to make sense of the swirling mass of news and comment in the 24 hour media age.

And they think: you're not listening. What's it got to do with me? Where is this journey's end? And a fog descends on the very dialogue between government and people necessary to get there.

And, yes, there are things we have done that have made people angry and we should be open enough to admit it.

The dome. Hindsight is a wonderful thing, and if I had my time again, I would have listened to those who said governments shouldn't try to run big visitor attractions.

75p. I tell you now, as Gordon made crystal clear yesterday, we get the message.

But I believe that when people reflect, on the big fundamentals that determine our future - the economy, jobs, public services - we are doing the right thing, and we are on the right track for Britain; and the last thing this country needs is a return to Tory government.

Let me come direct to the fuel crisis. I am listening to people's anger over fuel duties. For hauliers and farmers to say nothing of ordinary motorists, there is real hardship.

But I have also had to listen over underfunding in the NHS. Over extra investment in schools. Over more police on the beat. Over public transport.

I am listening over mortgages, where low interest rates can only be maintained if disciplined public finances are kept.

I am also listening to pensioners who believe the government should give them a greater share of the country's prosperity.

Our first priority was to help the 2m pensioners, many of them elderly women, who depend on income support. I make no apology for helping the poorest first and neither should this party. Through the winter allowance, now £150, and free TV licences for over 75s, we helped people with their most pressing costs.

We rejected returning to the earnings link. For the next two or three years we could afford it; but 10, 15 years down the line, it would have imposed a huge financial burden on a future generation that would have been unfair to them.

But I know there are pensioners not on benefit, who have saved all their lives but are not by any stretch of the imagination wealthy, and for whom the basic state pension and other government help is essential. It is right they share in the nation's wealth.

Listening

I am listening. I hear. And I will act. The point I'm making is this. The real world is full of competing causes. Most of them good. Most of them deserving. Many of them heart-rending. And it's not an arrogant government that chooses priorities. It's an irresponsible government that fails to choose.

The test of leadership in politics is not how eloquently you say yes. It's how you explain why you're saying no.

And would it ever be right to choose a priority simply on the basis of a fuel blockade? What of those who can't protest; whose voice isn't supported by the media; who go neglected unless we speak for them?

So I am listening. But I was also elected to lead. And if we want to reach our journey's end - that strong, fair and prosperous Britain for all - there are choices to be made.

Today the Tories are back with exactly the plan of 10 years ago. You don't need me to predict it. We all experienced it.

Don't ever let them con us into boom and bust again. Never forget: in 18 Tory years, unemployment trebled. Families of three generations with nobody bringing in a wage. Record youth unemployment. And what did they say: it was a price worth paying. Unemployment is never a price worth paying.

The New Deal has helped nearly a million people with work or training, the largest ever jobs programme Britain has seen.

The Working Families' Tax Credit makes work pay for over a million families. Childcare and training has helped 150,000 women find work or get a better job. And at long last a national statutory minimum wage has given 11/2 million people the dignity of a decent living wage.

And we have introduced the democratic right, delivered after 100 years of trying, to be represented by a trade union should you want it.

That was our choice. Not to leave you at the mercy of markets. Not to walk by. Not to say: tough, sink or swim.

There's Mr Hague. Standing around waiting for a bandwagon. Then three come along at once.

Opportunism always knocks for William Hague. You want tax cuts? Have them. Spending rises? Have them too. It all makes sense after 14 pints. Everything makes sense after 14 pints.

John Redwood looks sane. Michael Portillo looks loyal. After 14 pints, even William Hague looks like a prime minister.

Our education, health and transport plans represent the most radical reform in public services over 10 years any government has produced since the war.

In our manifesto, line one of our contract with the people promised to increase the share of our national wealth spent on education during this parliament. A promise made. A promise kept. Today I make a further commitment. Line one of the contract in the next manifesto will be a promise to increase the share of our national wealth spent on education in the next parliament.

Again, on health, let me set out the scale of our plans, for now and for a second term.

The waiting list pledge has been met. There are 10,000 more nurses in the NHS. Every A&E that needs it is being modernised. The biggest ever hospital building programme is under way. But we all know. Eighteen years of neglect isn't put right in three years.

Today, as we set out the next steps, I want to focus on cancer. There will be nobody in this hall, or watching from their homes, who has not seen a friend or family member struck down by cancer.

Under the plan we publish tomorrow, there will be 1000 more cancer specialists over the next six years - up nearly a third. 295 new scanners and radio-therapy machines so that for the first time the NHS can meet proper equipment standards for diagnosing and treating cancer. By 2003 for the first time the government will be matching pound for pound charity funding for cancer research.

Cancer patients in all parts of the country will get the right drugs at the right time, regardless of where they live. The postcode lottery ended. Waiting times will be cut. Maximum two weeks from GP appointment to first hospital appointment for suspected urgent cases. And, as we increase the number of specialists, a maximum wait of one month from diagnosis to treatment starting.

And because breast cancer kills 11,000 women every year, because it causes so much pain and suffering among Britain's families, we will extend breast cancer screening to all women aged over 65, helping an extra 400,000 women by 2004.

By acknowledging the duty to care, we earn the right to be tough on crime. Four out of 10 violent crimes are alcohol related. Half of property crime drug-related.

It is time for zero tolerance of the yob culture.

Time to stand up for the pensioner afraid to go out. Time to stand up for the single moth ers scared to walk to the shops. Time to stand up to the thugs and the bullies.

Time to tighten bail to deal with the absurdity of people released in the morning committing offences in the afternoon. Time to give the police powers to close pubs where there is fighting. Time to give them powers to ban drink in public places.

These are our second term plans. A 10 year plan for a modern NHS. The transformation of secondary education. A cradle to grave poverty strategy. A plan to harness new technology to spread prosperity to all. A plan to make our streets safe and our society strong. A 10 year plan for modern transport. The next steps to full employment.

This is a programme worth fighting for. A second term more radical than the first. A quickening of the pace of reform. The next steps on our journey. All based on our enduring mission, to offer everyone, not just the privileged few, the chance to succeed.

Unifier

By nature I am a unifier. I am a builder of consensus. I don't believe in sloppy compromise. But I do believe in bringing people together.

There is no point in leading the Labour party or leading a country without having a mission and a purpose that's more important to you than anything else.

I will do whatever I can to bring people onside but there are certain things I cannot do.

If you ask me to put tax cuts before education spending, I can't do it.

If you ask me to take risks with stability in this country after all we've learned over the last 30, 40, 50 years - I can't do it. Many of you would agree with that, many of the British people would, but let me tell you some more difficult things I cannot do.

If, in order to get a vote, I have to go out and tell people that Europe is full of terrible foreigners, we want nothing to do with them, and we'll stick two fingers up to them, I cannot do that either because in my heart I know it is wrong.

I know asylum is a problem. We are trying to deal with it, but if people want me to go out and exploit the asylum issue for reasons of race which we all know about, then vote for the other man, because I will not do it.

If I am asked to take that overseas aid budget that helps millions of people who live in circumstances of poverty we cannot even contemplate, and I am asked as the Conservatives do, to cut that budget for tax cuts, I cannot do it.

I was not brought in by ideology or policy. I was brought in by that simple and old principle of solidarity, shoulder to shoulder we get more out of this life, and give more in this life, than we do fighting each other as isolated individuals.

We are in a fight and it's a fight I relish.

We do not lie down in the testing times. We hold firm. We listen and we lead.

We can be confident in our policies, confident in the record we will put before the British people. Confident that we will repay the trust the British people put in us. Confident that we share their basic decent instincts and values. Confident that we are winning the big arguments on the big issues.

Stability. Or boom and bust. Jobs. Or unemployment. Investment in schools and hospitals. Or cuts. Leadership and engagement in the world. Or weakness and sour isolation.

Our journey's end: a Britain where any child born in this millennium, whatever their background, race or creed, wherever they live, whoever their parents, is able to make the most of the God-given ability they bring into this world.

That journey, that better Britain of hope and opportunity for all, that better Britain that calls to our best instincts and transforms our nation, I tell you, that journey is a journey worth making.

webTitle: Gaudoin joins IVillage.co.uk as editorial director

fields.headline: Gaudoin takes the helm at new women's website
fields.trailText: 12.15am: IVillage.co.uk, the soon-to-launch women's website from Tesco and US website iVillage.com, has appointed the former editor of Frank, Tina Gaudoin, as editorial director. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
IVillage.co.uk, the planned women's website from Tesco and US website iVillage.com, has appointed the former editor of Frank and Times journalist Tina Gaudoin as editorial director.

Gaudoin has been charged with fashioning iVillage.co.uk into the leading women's website in the UK. The site is expected to launch by the end of the year.

The joint-venture, which was set up in July, is backed by a $18m (£12.4m) investment from Tesco to see the website through its first three years. IVillage.co.uk will be heavily promoted on Tesco.com and in stores, and Tesco and iVillage.com will channel a total of $70m in marketing, branding, cash and resources into the site.

The initial intention is to migrate the 160,000 UK-based users who already use the US site to the new version, and tap into the 5.2m women currently online in the UK. The site will be split into branded channels focusing on issues such as computers and the internet, diet and fitness, food, horoscopes and astrology, news and politics, pregnancy and babies, relationships, and work and career.

IVillage.co.uk this week also announced its senior management team, which is to include Hillary Graves and Tory Crimmins as co-managing directors and Janice Fernandes, formerly sales manager at TDI Advertising, as sales director. Gaudoin has previously worked for Tatler, Harpers Bazaar and American Vogue.

Gaudoin said: "IVillage's community model allows us to offer content to women in a unique way. By responding to women all over the country iVillage will become the voice of women in the UK."

webTitle: Sketch: Blair's conference speech

fields.headline: After the grovelling he became a man transformed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: I sat in the front row for Tony Blair's speech. It was like the monsoon in a Somerset Maugham short story.
fields.body:
I sat in the front row for Tony Blair's speech. It was like the monsoon in a Somerset Maugham short story. Hot steaming sweat flew all over the platform. His shirt was so damp you expected him to rip it off in midspeech and call for horse blankets.

His eyebrows were on fire, blazing with commitment. At times he was excitedly hopping from side to side like a lonely line dancer.

The cabinet (remember them? They used to have a minor constitutional role in government) were herded into one set of seats below the Leader and to his left, so that they were obliged to gaze adoringly up at him, with the exception of John Prescott, who sat on the platform alternately beaming at Tony Blair and glowering at the sketchwriters.

He began with a ringing battlecry. "We're crap!" he told the adoring delegates. "Yes, we're crap, but we're not as crappy as the other lot!" He didn't put it quite like that, of course, but that was what he meant. It was that rarest moment, an apology from a politician. The dome, the fuel crisis, pensions, even prime minister's question time. But he was sorry, God he was sorry. He'd never do it again. Would a bunch of flowers help?

Tony was feeling our pain. "There's the mortgage to pay ... inflation may be lower, but the kid's trainers don't get any cheaper." (Yes, there's the riding trainer, the personal fit ness trainer - do you know what they charge these days?) He set a new Olympic record of 163 verbless sentences, those phrases which, by omitting a doing word, appear to offer a promise without making a commitment.

webTitle: 'I am listening ... I hear ... And I will act'

fields.headline: 'I am listening ... I hear ... And I will act'
fields.standfirst:
PM admits errors but challenges Tories to battle over taxes

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Tony Blair bounced back yesterday with an impassioned appeal to the "basic decent instincts" of the British people to give him a second chance - and a second term in power - to complete Labour's ambitious modernisation programme.
fields.body:
Tony Blair bounced back yesterday with an impassioned appeal to the "basic decent instincts" of the British people to give him a second chance - and a second term in power - to complete Labour's ambitious modernisation programme.

In one of the most important speeches of his career the embattled prime minister told Labour's pre-election conference in Brighton that his government represented the marriage of "realism and idealism," in contrast to tax-cutting Tory cynicism.

Beset by Conservative gains in the opinion polls, Mr Blair coupled hard-headed electoral calculation with an emotional claim to be a pragmatic and healing leader but also one with an "irreducible core" of moral values. It would prevent him getting into a populist auction with William Hague, he promised.

There were admissions of error and contrition - on the Millennium Dome and pensions. "As Gordon [Brown] said yesterday, we get the message," Mr Blair said as delegates roared their approval for generous pension rises before polling day - probably next May.

To the dismay of fuel protesters he was much less conciliatory towards calls for lower taxes. "I am listening to people's anger over fuel duties. But I have also had to listen over underfunding in the NHS, over extra investment in schools, over more police on the beat, over public transport," Mr Blair explained.

And in the passage on which his whole argument turned the premier stressed: "The real world is full of competing causes, most of them good ... it's not an arrogant government that chooses priorities, it's an irresponsible government that fails to choose."

The speech was punctuated with announcements of new or nearly new plans to improve schools - and school sport, to beat cancer and to give the police the power to "do as much damage to organised crime as organised crime does to our communities".

It was the speech's one concession to rightwing populism. Mr Blair, who looked relaxed but sweated profusely in the hot hall, said he relished the fight ahead. But he was equally anxious to persuade disaffected voters that he was listening to them.

He used the word nine times. At one point he said: "I am listening, I hear and I will act." At another he bemoaned "the fog that descends on the very dialogue between government and people necessary" to see the ambitious reforms through to completion.

As the rest of his speech made brutally clear, Labour's election campaign next spring will hinge on the kind of choices which voters will be asked to make: between investment in public services and £16bn worth of tax cuts under Mr Hague, between what he called "confidence or cynicism".

To rub home the choice he itemised the schools, hospitals, teachers and nurses' jobs which would have to be cut to fulfil the Tory tax pledges. Mr Hague, he said, was "leaping aboard every passing bandwagon".

Mr Blair said Labour would fulfil its 1997 manifesto pledges by polling day and promised delegates "a second term more radical than the first" as his cabinet's multi-billion investment plans gradually produced better public services.

It was as eloquent a case as he has ever made for New Labour's view of active government, always at hand both to protect the individual and to provide opportunities for fulfilment.

But the emotional high point of the 60 minute address was his renewed plea to the wider television audience which has turned against him in the polls to trust him as a consensus-building "unifier" - happy to work with anyone for the common good.

In a last minute improvisation to the text Mr Blair also insisted that he had an "irreducible core" of principles - and listed the sort of things he would never stoop to in order to win votes.

Couched to contrast his own high-minded sense of social solidarity with Mr Hague's appeal to "narrow self-interest" and xenophobia, Mr Blair said he would never "stick two fingers up to horrible foreigners," exploit the asylum issue or cut aid to the world's poor.

"I cannot do it," he repeatedly asserted. Though he would work with big business and even with Tories to bring about change the self-styled "man with a mission" would not put tax cuts before economic stability or education either.

Eager for reassurance that the government was back on track, the conference loved it. After weeks when Labour had been battered by the fuel crisis and punished by falling poll ratings the Blair fight-back won him a convincing five minute standing ovation.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union which was last night still threatening to help defeat Mr Blair on pensions this afternoon, was delighted with its core message. "Tony Blair has clearly signalled that the days of buying power through tax cuts are over."

Mr Hague was caustic. He called the speech "the usual New Labour cocktail" of meaningless statistics, policy failure, unscripted promises and "apologies that never amount to saying you are sorry".

David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, complained: "He could have toned it down and offered us a glimmer of hope." Further protests when the 60-day pause was over were now "10 times" more likely, he warned. Charles Kennedy, the Lib Dem leader, said Mr Blair was still not listening.

webTitle: Blair finally takes on enemies of his project

fields.headline: Blair finally takes on enemies of his project
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Since Tony Blair became the Labour leader, he never had to argue with the country. He soothed it, smiled at it, won it. His opponents were so feeble, so divided, so exhausted, so abominated, that he wasn't in a serious fight.
fields.body:
Since Tony Blair became the Labour leader, he never had to argue with the country. He soothed it, smiled at it, won it. His opponents were so feeble, so divided, so exhausted, so abominated, that he wasn't in a serious fight.

So he was never forced to make his case. He was sel dom put to a difficult question. All he needed was to avoid frightening the horses, which he did successfully from 1994-97 and then for his first two years in power.

The merit of recent events is that they have changed all that. Yesterday, for the first time as prime minister, Mr Blair addressed the country with arguments it might not like to hear. He took on the enemies of his project because, for the first time, he had to. It brought out by far the best in him. He emerged for the first time not primarily as a likeable leader, fawning and blurring and charming. There was very little smiling. Here instead was a combative, abrasive, adversarial man only now beginning to deploy on the country the argumentative passions that modernised the Labour party.

Going for likeable always was an error. And it did not succeed. The country never did much like the first Mr Blair. When he got into trouble with the petrol blockade, the well of popular affection was found to be as dry as every Esso station. But likeable is not what proper leaders do, as he now seems to have acknowledged. Not before time, the trouble exposed by the opinion polls has summoned the Blairite style into a new and better era.

That is not to say the leader has abandoned the spirit of consensus. He knows a concession when he sees it needs to be made. His virtual admission that the Greenwich dome really was a failure makes it easier, despite the shocking scale of the wasted money, to move on. Much more seriously, the new promises to pensioners, in which prime minister and chancellor have finessed their differences, look like being a big advance - quite essential for the most basic reasons of justice and politics alike. "We get the message," he said, rueful contrition written on his face.

But otherwise, the speech was as unappeasing as it was uningratiating. It was addressed to a country whose apparent disbelief in him Mr Blair himself cannot believe has any basis in reason or argument. Rather than the party proving itself to the country, one had the sense it was time the country proved itself to the Labour party.

Notably unappeased, first, was the business world. For six conferences, Mr Blair has devoted at least a page of his speech to the reassurance of capitalism. Labour as the friend of business was a message he sent equally to the party and the City. In the seventh year, he implied, the mission has been accomplished. Barely a paragraph was directed to that quarter.

Instead, it was up to business, and the whole wide world outside New Labour, to understand that this was now the party of government, the party with a project it had only begun. The vibes could not be more different from the nervy hysteria conveyed in those April memos exchanged with the polling adviser Philip Gould. Whether this accurately conveys a solid new confidence inside the skulls of the inner cabal I rather doubt. But the choice has been made, correctly, to show Labour as the party of the famous, unruffled, undeviating long term.

Unappeased, too, were blockaders of every kind. Here Mr Blair finally acquired a proper gravitas towards the trouble at the pumps, bringing the country to its senses against people who think their own distress has the right to be expressed by throttling everyone else. He may have touched some easy populist law and order buttons, encouraging the police to break the rules if that is what it took to deal with drug crime. He never has been much of a civil libertarian. But he offered an argu ment and not a peace offering to the haulier heroes of the Daily Mail.

He did not concede either, it must be said, to another class of critic, those who accuse him of Napoleonism. Though he no longer seems obsessed with being liked, he has lost none of his appetite for personal power and responsibility.

There were mentions of selected colleagues, each with his own graded ranking. Gordon Brown was "inspired", David Blunkett was a great education secretary, John Prescott, with whom Mr Blair's personal axis may now be the most telling in the cabinet, the finest deputy a leader could have. Alan Milburn and Jack Straw were mentioned in dispatches. But mostly it was I. "I am listening. I hear. I will act _ I was elected to lead _ I have my irreducible core." Mr Blair remains unashamed as the quasi-presidential figure who once told me, when I asked him if Labour would win the 1997 election, that it certainly would - if only he alone, his uninterrupted voice, was what the electorate heard speaking for the party.

This tendency may be regrettable, and is certainly registering a new transitional phase in the history of cabinet government. It has got the leader into trouble, as a control-freak centraliser. One response to that might have been to deflect power and collectivise the project. He is probably incapable of doing that, and thereby still runs a considerable risk. Everything will rise or fall on his performance just about alone. He is meeting this chosen fate, on the other hand, by reverting to the quality that first put him where he is today, which is his appetite for the most direct and unflinching contest about ideas: his ideas, as against those of the Tory party.

The thing he got rid of yesterday was the pretence that there can any longer be the search for common ground. Under pressure, New Labour is forced to become a party of argument and battle over a choice about which almost all its members, in the end, have no doubt. The leader is not only the greatest non-doubter, he is also the most complete exponent of a philosophy which he, more than any other person, has raised to the level of religious conviction. Prosperity and social justice. Realism and idealism. Self-interest and common good. Circles and squares.

He really cannot see there is any flaw. All he suddenly sees is the terrible possibility that the second term, which is the first time the large rewards will become apparent, might elude him. So he has decided to make the choice on offer much more stark. This is conviction not contrivance. The speech was the least contrived I have heard him give. At the end, everyone saw his torso dripping with sweat. I thought I could see near-tears of fury at the faint chance of the country not agreeing with him.

So the battle is joined. The election campaign, on one side, is beginning. Mr Blair lays down a challenge to the Tories. Can they equal his organised conviction? Will they give him an argument? Or do they plan to continue wallowing in the single-issue mud they have been successful in slinging for the past six months? It is a good thing they did it. It gave Mr Blair a necessary fright. But he has set a high standard for the combat to come: one which there is absolutely no sign that William Hague, in his new eminence, is ready to match.

webTitle: Why the Blair-UK romance had to flounder

fields.headline: Why the Blair-UK romance had to flounder
fields.standfirst:
Diana died before she experienced it, but Blair now learns that where illusion takes hold, disillusionment is sure to follow, says Guardian columnist David McKie

Read more David McKie
fields.trailText: Diana died before she experienced it, but Blair now learns that where illusion takes hold, disillusionment is sure to follow, says Guardian columnist David McKie.
fields.body:
The government cannot understand what has hit it. One moment it is riding high in the polls, then suddenly it is lagging behind the discredited Tories, after a swing in opinion more violent even than that which followed Black Wednesday.

A once admired prime minister is hugely distrusted as out-of-touch, over-mighty, uncaring. They can see why they might have fallen from grace: but why so precipitately? And yet there is no mystery, only this simple principle: the greater the illusion, the greater the disillusion.

Once upon a time there was a beautiful and adored princess who met with a sudden, tragic and possibly sinister end. In life she had won the hearts of the nation by her openness, grace and compassion for the afflicted. She brought comfort to dying children and moved easily, even lovingly, among victims of Aids, whom many then thought untouchable.

Her death left the nation distraught. A field of flowers, each bunch with its tear-stained tribute, was assembled to honour her. People camped on the streets in their thousands to mark her funeral. Some found all this unreal, hysterical even, but they were merely a grudging minority.

The royal family into which she had married, who never knew what to make of her, who increasingly had come to regard her as a danger and a disturbance, dissimulated and prevaricated. But Britain's new young prime minister put into faultless words the tribute which the nation wanted to hear. Diana, said Tony Blair, had been "the people's princess".

And he was the people's prime minister, swept into office by a landslide so staggering that it even astonished him. Wimbledon had turned Labour, and Harrow, and Hove. And the victory was his victory: even his enemies in his own party could not deny it. True, the great triumph was never quite what it seemed. Fewer than one in three of the British electorate had voted for the new party he had designed and created. He had fewer votes behind him than John Major five years before.

But if there were reservations they attached themselves to Labour rather than to its leader. Soon his popularity was breaking all records: his approval ratings at one point topped 90%. What people thought about Labour no longer mattered, for Tony Blair transcended all that. Here was man who was set to take the politics out of politics.

The views of the party he led did not seem to concern him greatly. He would listen to the people - all the people - discern what they wanted, and see that they got it, regardless of party doctrine. Some found all this unreal, hysterical even, but they were merely a grudging minority.

But the princess herself was not what she seemed. Or more precisely, she was what she seemed, but was other things as well. One day her suffering private secretary would write what he had learned to his cost: that twinned with the generosity and the compassion there was fickleness and mean-spiritedness and malevolence. Persecuted herself, she increasingly turned to the persecution of others.

Much of that sprang from an overwhelming sense of rejection. But it made her impossible. A little of that was perceived at the time, but it never became the people's sense of her. Had she lived, had she grown more bitter with time, it could not have been disguised. Then there would have been disillusion.

But the people's prime minister too was not what he seemed; or to be more precise, events and the nature of politics made that impossible. To govern, said Pierre Mendès-France, another political icon who fell from grace, is to choose; and that sometimes means choosing hard and unpopular options.

The people wanted Ken Livingstone and Rhodri Morgan; Blair feared them and tried to stop them. The people wanted Mo Mowlam; Blair exiled her to the margins. The people wanted generous treatment for pensioners; Blair's chancellor gave them less than a pound. The people told themselves they had never wanted the Millennium Dome, but Blair had insisted.

The people's prime minister could see their demands were incompatible, but the people did not. When the hauliers and farmers rose in revolt, the people overwhelmingly backed them. They made it the people's protest. Some found all this unreal, hysterical even, but they were the grudging minority.

webTitle: Freeserve results

fields.headline: Freeserve awaits City verdict
fields.trailText: The spotlight will fall back onto Freeserve when it announces its results tomorrow morning, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The spotlight will fall back onto Freeserve when it announces its results tomorrow morning.

Analysts are expecting big things from the ISP/portal, particularly since the company needs to prove itself in order to find a buyer. Strong first quarter results are crucial to the mooted sale of Freeserve by parent company Dixons, and the City will be watching very closely to determine the price tag of the company and how much of it should be sold.

Analysts are expecting revenues for Q1 to reach around £13m, with the split likely to have moved back towards access revenues as opposed to portal ad revenues (60:40). Subscriber numbers are expected to reach 2.1m and are on target to reach 2.65m by May 2001.

Overall Q1 losses are expected to be around £9.5m. Page impressions on the portal need to convince analysts that Freeserve has managed to maintain that all-encompassing aspect of 'community' - a rise to 180m in August from 151.5m in May would be enough to convince doubters.

Ahead of the results, most analysts are maintaining their buy recommendations and still see Freeserve as a key acquisition target, even though they are looking for reassurances on the impact of the unmetered access offer. At its present value of 247.25p, Freeserve is seen as a veritable bargain compared with a high of 920.75p at the start of this year.

webTitle: Third T-Online board member leaves in Deutsche Telekom clash

fields.headline: Third T-Online board member leaves in Deutsche Telekom clash
fields.trailText: September 27: Europe's leading ISP, T-Online, has lost its third board member in a month. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
T-Online, Europe's leading internet service provider, has lost its third board member in a month following a damaging breakdown in relations with parent company Deutsche Telekom.

Chief financial officer Christian Hoenig followed chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje and marketing chief Ralf Eck out of the door on Tuesday night.

T-Online's management have repeatedly clashed with Deutsche Telekom head Ron Sommer over the company's expansion strategy, with the telecoms giant wanting to make quick acquisitions and the ISP's board preferring investment in start-up companies.

Mr Sommer has brought in staff from his own company to replace the outgoing management team, with acting chief executive Detlev Buchal promising that the company is committed to acquiring European rivals. T-Online recently bought Spanish portal Yacom, but a takeover bid for the UK's Freeserve fell through this summer.

The boardroom upheavals have unsettled T-Online's position as European market leader, allowing rival Lycos Europe to seize the initiative with the E674m (£404m) acquisition of Swedish portal Spray Network. Analysts say T-Online could lose out in the period of frenetic M&A activity expected in the sector over the next three months.

webTitle: Music Choice Europe to float

fields.headline: Music Choice Europe prepares for stock market flotation
fields.trailText: Music Choice Europe expects to raise £50m in October stock market flotation, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
Music Choice Europe, which provides music via Sky Digital and the internet, is expected to raise £50m by floating on the London Stock Exchange.

The company today set its flotation price at 162p, which will value the placing of around 31m shares at £196m.

Following the float, BSkyB's stake in Music Choice will be reduced to 36.4%, while Time Warner will hold 16.4% and Sony Digital Radio 8.2%.

Music Choice is planning to use the money raised to invest in broadband and mobile technology, as well as for marketing costs and paying off a £3.7m loan from its main shareholders.

The firm operates 47 genre-based digital audio that are available in 17 European and Middle Eastern countries. Its subscription base grew to 4.8 million homes at the end of July, from 2.8 million at the end of 1999.

Trading in Music Choice's shares will begin on October 4. The firm's broker is Investec Henderson Crosthwaite.

webTitle: CJD fear leads to controls on plasma

fields.headline: CJD fear leads to controls on plasma
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The government is considering more stringent controls on blood plasma used in surgical emergencies because of the theoretical risk that using transfusions from unwitting carriers of human BSE might infect patients with the disease.
fields.body:
The government is considering more stringent controls on blood plasma used in surgical emergencies because of the theoretical risk that using transfusions from unwitting carriers of human BSE might infect patients with the disease.

Between 20,000 and 30,000 people a year are still thought to receive plasma from British donors despite other measures to reduce the threat from accidental transfer of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease via blood.

The national blood service said yesterday that new anti-viral treatments of plasma and artificial alternatives were among the options following recent evidence that a sheep could transfer a BSE-like disease to another animal through blood transfusion long before displaying outward signs of the condition.

The admission comes less than two weeks after the service and the Department of Health attempted to allay concerns sparked by research by scientists at the Institute of Animal Health. They then pointed to the precautionary measures introduced over the last two years - the filtering out of white cells, thought most likely to carry the vCJD agent, from blood and the use of plasma in blood products imported from countries without vCJD.

These would minimise the risk of future cases through transfusion. Seven known vCJD victims among the 74 dead and eight probable cases are thought to have been blood donors and there is as yet no test that could screen donations for the presence of the vCJD agent.

But some British plasma is still used to help clot the blood of victims of trauma or patients in long operations needing large transfusions. The blood service said this was a blood component from a single donor and not a factory- made product made from plasma pooled from many donors.

"There is a subtle difference", said Tim Wallington, the service's medical spokesman. "I don't think we have been misleading the public. What we have done is what was considered practical at the time. The truth is the sheep stuff has made everybody think again. We are doing everything we possibly can about this threat."

The health department said plasma was in short supply and alternative commercial sources were collected from European countries, which though vCJD-free, were not BSE-free.

Plasma for other medical products was imported from the US. The plasma used from UK sources was filtered in the same way as other blood donations.

A drugs company, Octopharma, claimed it could offer less risky alternatives to the fresh plasma used in emergency cases, even though it conceded that no known treatments could remove the deformed prion protein thought responsible for spreading vCJD. It sourced plasma from countries where the only reported cases of BSE were from imported animals and there were no reported cases of vCJD.

Brian Stack, Octopharma's acting UK general manager, said: "The evidence about vCJD is mounting. Why are they sitting on the fence and putting at risk the British population?"

The company has complained to the European commission, alleging unfair charging policies by the national blood service which makes British plasma less than half the price of its own.

The row over blood coincides with a leaked cabinet memo which confirms the government's determination not to offer compensation to vCJD victims without fighting them through the courts first. The families have already formally started legal action.

webTitle: Granada share slide continues

fields.headline: Granada share slide continues
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Granada Media's headlong plunge down the FTSE 100 continued this morning after a trading statement warned that broadcasting revenue will fall over the next six months. By Dan Milmo.
Comment
fields.body:
Granada Media's headlong plunge down the FTSE 100 continued this morning after a trading statement warned that broadcasting revenue will fall over the next six months.

Shares in the company fell 12% in early trading to 442p, outstripping yesterday's 9% fall when the market took fright at a Merrill Lynch note that cut Granada's profits forecast for next year by 21%. The investment bank had revised its figures after examining the company's new media costs and the softness of the advertising market.

Today's trading statement said Granada had benefited from the Rugby World Cup and the Euro 2000 Championships, which drove up premium advertising sales, but the success was not likely to be repeated next year.

"There are no such major events in the coming financial year. As a consequence, we are not expecting to match last year's revenues from broadcasting in our first half to March," Granada said.

Meanwhile, analysts at ABN AMRO have cut 2001 advertising revenue forecasts for Granada and ITV rival Carlton Communications. They have reduced revenue growth forecasts for October 2000 to September 2001 from 6.2% growth to 2% growth.

Carlton Communications shares fell 45 to 557p in early trading.

webTitle: Vodafone to fund start-ups

fields.headline: Vodafone to fund start-ups
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Vodafone yesterday announced the creation of a £100m venture fund to invest in wireless and internet start-up companies.
fields.body:
Vodafone yesterday announced the creation of a £100m venture fund to invest in wireless and internet start-up companies.

The fund will be aimed primarily at first and second round funding opportunities with the average investment ranging between £2m and £10m.

The wholly owned fund will be called Vodafone Ventures and is part of an increasing trend for media and telecoms companies to trawl for new ideas and technologies among young businesses.

By taking a stake, Vodafone can take a share not only in the economic upside but also in the content, services or software being developed.

Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, said: "We view the creation of Vodafone Ventures as providing an important vehicle for investing in an area of great strategic significance for Vodafone.

"We are determined to lead the way in wireless internet service development and the creation of this fund is a critical step in that direction."

The company earlier this year established Vizzavi, a joint venture with French media and telecoms group Vivendi to build a wireless internet portal business.

In Britain, Vodafone has recently signed up Barclays Bank as a partner to deliver online banking services, breaking the near monopoly on the banks held by rival BT Cellnet.

Vodafone Ventures has hired Goldman Sachs to advise it on where to make investments.

Vodafone also announced the resignation of deputy chairman Klaus Esser, who will leave the company at the end of the month.

Mr Esser, the former chief executive of German telecoms and engineering group Mannesmann, fought bitterly but ultimately unsuccessfully to avoid the company being taken over by Vodafone earlier this year.

He capitulated in March and joined the Vodafone board as a non-executive director. Mr Esser will not receive a pay-off.
