webTitle: Safety Nets in Rapidly Reforming Transition Countries

fields.headline: Safety Nets in Rapidly Reforming Transition Countries
fields.standfirst: This is the last of a series of four reports examining the ongoing impact of World Bank policy on the welfare of children in transition countries.
fields.trailText: The transition countries of Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union and Mongolia arguably had the world's most comprehensive formal social safety nets - packages of goods, services and income support intended to guarantee basic needs. All citizens were, at least in principle, guaranteed employment and housing, water and fuel were either free or greatly subsidised, staple food prices were mostly controlled, and there were a range of benefits to support low income or "vulnerable" groups, such as children and elderly or disabled people. There were undoubtedly holes in this safety net, and it was clearly fiscally unsustainable . However, although it was widely recognised that a restructured state welfare system had an important role to play in preventing and alleviating poverty and cushioning the shock of transition, in many countries the safety net was in fact "unravelled" quite rapidly, ironically at a time when such support has been most needed. The social consequences of removing this support were underestimated, as it was assumed by many that the economy would rapidly be back on track, and the strengths as well as weaknesses of the pre-transition system overlooked by many policy makers and advisors.
fields.body:
The transition countries of Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union and Mongolia arguably had the world's most comprehensive formal social safety nets - packages of goods, services and income support intended to guarantee basic needs. All citizens were, at least in principle, guaranteed employment and housing, water and fuel were either free or greatly subsidised, staple food prices were mostly controlled, and there were a range of benefits to support low income or "vulnerable" groups, such as children and elderly or disabled people. There were undoubtedly holes in this safety net, and it was clearly fiscally unsustainable . However, although it was widely recognised that a restructured state welfare system had an important role to play in preventing and alleviating poverty and cushioning the shock of transition, in many countries the safety net was in fact "unravelled" quite rapidly, ironically at a time when such support has been most needed. The social consequences of removing this support were underestimated, as it was assumed by many that the economy would rapidly be back on track, and the strengths as well as weaknesses of the pre-transition system overlooked by many policy makers and advisors.

Today, formal safety nets still exist in most transition countries, but are much less comprehensive than ten years ago. Even where the majority of the population are now below the poverty line, as in Kyrgyzstan or Tajikistan (60 and 70 per cent respectively by conservative estimates) , most benefits are quite strictly targeted to very poor families and individuals. Food and fuel subsidies have been scaled down or eliminated. Benefit levels have been eroded due to inflation and are often very low - in Tajikistan in 1999, the monthly cash benefit for low income families was only sufficient to buy two loaves of bread . Furthermore, in some countries anybody with a plot of land over a certain size is ineligible for income support benefits - even where these plots are too small to make a living. Due to irregular state revenues, benefits are often paid late - and in Kyrgyzstan, sometimes in kind. These problems and complex application procedures put off many poor applicants. As a result, often only a relatively small proportion of the population take up the benefits for which they are eligible . Nonetheless, benefits appear an important source of support for those who do receive them.

Extended families and communities are often the principal source of support to poor or vulnerable individuals and have played a vital role in preventing destitution over the transition period. However, due to unemployment, and lack of assets, many families are under great stress and struggle to support one another. In the words of one Kyrgyz man "having relatives is expensive these days". In parts of Eastern Europe, pressure on families is so acute that the percentage of children living in institutional care has risen 45 per cent in Romania and Russia and 75 per cent in Latvia since 1991.

Recommendations:

The World Bank Asian Development Bank and other donors are putting increasing emphasis on social protection, including adequate safety nets. We believe that adequate social protection will require some significant changes to current approaches:

1: A more holistic approach. At present, poverty issues are often depoliticised and compartmentalised. Most aid has focused on technical assistance for restructuring parts of the safety net, often broadly in a Western model. This is often disconnected from wider debate on the role of donor-sponsored or mandated economic policies in creating poverty, how poverty should be tackled, and what might constitute an appropriate safety net. This tunnel vision may help explain how radical changes to almost all aspects of social and economic life could be implemented simultaneously, underestimating the social costs. For example in Kyrgyzstan, due to the devaluations, collapse of state-owned enterprises and inequitable privatisation, in the space of a few years, millions were plunged into poverty, formerly universal cash benefits were removed, or re-targeted to the very poor, food and fuel subsidies were cut and people were suddenly asked to pay for health care, pre-school and university education, to contribute to school running costs, and the pension fund, and to pay land and water taxes. In the words of one rural pre-school teacher, a mother of four, 'we have to pay for everything now - and everything is expensive'.

2: Greater emphasis on damage prevention. Much WB and donor involvement, particularly in the early 1990s when poverty was increasing fastest, focused on cost-containment, at the expense of social protection. Now social protection is back on the agenda, but for many poor people the damage has been done, as notable increases in child malnutrition and reductions in school enrolment in Central Asia make clear. Serious attention to social protection is needed to reverse these trends.

3: Social funds (SFs). The World Bank has introduced stand-alone SFs (anti poverty or community investment programmes) in Mongolia, South East Europe and the Caucasus. While many of the activities supported by SFs are useful, the funds are usually too small and their activities too patchy to have a significant impact.

4: A fundamental rethink of how to protect poor and vulnerable people is needed. This will necessitate debate on a range of models, rather than restructuring social protection everywhere in line with the very low state provision of the American model. How this can be financed in the medium to long-term must be discussed. Donors may need to provide budget support in the short to medium term, while sustainable long-term financing options are developed.

The social consequences of removing this support were underestimated, as it was assumed by many that the economy would rapidly be back on track, and the strengths as well as weaknesses of the pre-transition system overlooked by many policy makers and advisors. Today, formal safety nets still exist in most transition countries, but are much less comprehensive than ten years ago. Even where the majority of the population are now below the poverty line, as in Kyrgyzstan or Tajikistan (60 and 70 per cent respectively by conservative estimates) , most benefits are quite strictly targeted to very poor families and individuals. Food and fuel subsidies have been scaled down or eliminated. Benefit levels have been eroded due to inflation and are often very low - in Tajikistan in 1999, the monthly cash benefit for low income families was only sufficient to buy two loaves of bread . Furthermore, in some countries anybody with a plot of land over a certain size is ineligible for income support benefits - even where these plots are too small to make a living. Due to irregular state revenues, benefits are often paid late - and in Kyrgyzstan, sometimes in kind. These problems and complex application procedures put off many poor applicants. As a result, often only a relatively small proportion of the population take up the benefits for which they are eligible . Nonetheless, benefits appear an important source of support for those who do receive them. Extended families and communities are often the principal source of support to poor or vulnerable individuals and have played a vital role in preventing destitution over the transition period. However, due to unemployment, and lack of assets, many families are under great stress and struggle to support one another. In the words of one Kyrgyz man "having relatives is expensive these days". In parts of Eastern Europe, pressure on families is so acute that the percentage of children living in institutional care has risen 45 per cent in Romania and Russia and 75 per cent in Latvia since 1991. Recommendations: The World Bank Asian Development Bank and other donors are putting increasing emphasis on social protection, including adequate safety nets. We believe that adequate social protection will require some significant changes to current approaches: 1: A more holistic approach. At present, poverty issues are often depoliticised and compartmentalised. Most aid has focused on technical assistance for restructuring parts of the safety net, often broadly in a Western model. This is often disconnected from wider debate on the role of donor-sponsored or mandated economic policies in creating poverty, how poverty should be tackled, and what might constitute an appropriate safety net. This tunnel vision may help explain how radical changes to almost all aspects of social and economic life could be implemented simultaneously, underestimating the social costs. For example in Kyrgyzstan, due to the devaluations, collapse of state-owned enterprises and inequitable privatisation, in the space of a few years, millions were plunged into poverty, formerly universal cash benefits were removed, or re-targeted to the very poor, food and fuel subsidies were cut and people were suddenly asked to pay for health care, pre-school and university education, to contribute to school running costs, and the pension fund, and to pay land and water taxes. In the words of one rural pre-school teacher, a mother of four, 'we have to pay for everything now - and everything is expensive'. 2: Greater emphasis on damage prevention. Much WB and donor involvement, particularly in the early 1990s when poverty was increasing fastest, focused on cost-containment, at the expense of social protection. Now social protection is back on the agenda, but for many poor people the damage has been done, as notable increases in child malnutrition and reductions in school enrolment in Central Asia make clear. Serious attention to social protection is needed to reverse these trends. 3: Social funds (SFs). The World Bank has introduced stand-alone SFs (anti poverty or community investment programmes) in Mongolia, South East Europe and the Caucasus. While many of the activities supported by SFs are useful, the funds are usually too small and their activities too patchy to have a significant impact. 4: A fundamental rethink of how to protect poor and vulnerable people is needed. This will necessitate debate on a range of models, rather than restructuring social protection everywhere in line with the very low state provision of the American model. How this can be financed in the medium to long-term must be discussed. Donors may need to provide budget support in the short to medium term, while sustainable long-term financing options are developed. webTitle: Aura makes offer to creditors

fields.headline: Aura offers creditors less than half money owed
fields.trailText: Creditors of Aura, the magazine closed last month by Eve Pollard's Parkhill Publishing, are being offered just 45% of money owed to them, writes Ray Walters.
fields.body:
Creditors of Aura, the magazine launched in May and closed last month by Eve Pollard's insolvent company, Parkhill Publishing, are being offered just 45% of money owed to them.

Unpaid contributors to the magazine have been contacted this week by Carol North, a partner in the London accountancy firm Harrison North, in order to gauge reactions to the offer.

Ms North's assistant explained to one creditor today: "We have collected as much of the money from the company's debtors that we can, and we are now in a position to offer you 45% of the money outstanding on your invoice. If enough of the creditors agree to the deal by the end of the week, the money will be paid to you fairly quickly. This is being done in order to avoid liquidation."

Asked if Harrison North represented the liquidators, she replied: "We are being advised by the liquidators." When asked if more money might be available if the company was put into liquidation, she replied: "That is possible. But then you would have to wait 18 months, or possibly longer. This way, at least you get the money quicker."

When Aura was closed in early August, Pollard - former editor of the Sunday Mirror and Sunday Express - assured Media Guardian that, "everyone will be paid", adding that there was enough money in the Parkhill kitty to cover debts.

Managing editor Richard Burton said the company had "a large debt book" and creditors would receive payments once money was clawed back from advertisers and agencies who owed cash to Parkhill.

Some contributors are owed thousands of pounds following the magazine's collapse. Aura was well received at its launch in May, selling a reputed 100,000 copies and subscriptions were said to have been piling in. But on July 27, as the August issue hit the stands, Parkhill informed staff that the company was seeking a buyer. In the end, the search proved fruitless.

webTitle: Sir Elton keen to get his hands dirty

fields.headline: Sir Elton keen to get his hands dirty
fields.trailText: Pop icon Sir Elton John is to make a £30m animated film about garden gnomes, complete with backing from Disney
fields.body:
Pop icon Sir Elton John is all set to make a £30m animated film, according to the Daily Express today.

The singer, who says that the music industry has become a "boring grind" for him, is to base the story around garden gnomes - apparently a subject very close to his heart.

The multi-millionaire will make the film through his film production company, Rocket Pictures, which he owns with his boyfriend David Furnish. Disney has already agreed to give the film its backing due to the enormous Stateside success of the British animated film Chicken Run.

Sir Elton, who won an Oscar for providing the music to Disney's 1994 animated smash hit The Lion King, is reportedly keen to get involved in all aspects of the film-making process.

webTitle: Behind the bike sheds with Luella

fields.headline: Behind the bike sheds with Luella
fields.standfirst: Spray paint and canary hues on London catwalk
fields.trailText: Stella McCartney may have defected to Paris, but no matter, London fashion has another young, talented, achingly hip female designer to hand.
fields.body:
Stella McCartney may have defected to Paris, but no matter, London fashion has another young, talented, achingly hip female designer to hand.

Luella Bartley is the darling of the fashion scene, the thinking woman's It girl, gracing the cover of the first issue of the new style magazine Pop (along with McCartney) and being the only designer so far this week to have lured a supermodel - Kate Moss - to a London catwalk.

The fourth Luella collection saw international buyers, press and celebrity friends jostling for space in a tiny studio on a west London industrial estate, decorated by bouncing a football dipped in fluorescent orange paint around the interior walls.

Entitled Dial F for Fluro, the show opened with Moss in a white minidress adorned with detailed electric blue, yellow and pink scribbles, resembling Chinese graffiti. A white leather biker jacket was spritzed with fuchsia spray-paint, a pink string bikini had canary yellow piping, while handbags arrived in neon lime or toothpaste white, and a sky blue strapless leather dress was edged with yellow wool trim.

This was lighter, brighter stuff than last season's, although the mod touches were still there in the shiny silver jackets with upturned collars, the neckties and the graphic black and white "LB" prints.

The Luella look is a homage to teenage kicks, to behind-the-bike-sheds cool. Bartley's clothes have a deliberately trashy edge. The lime green plastic handbags looked more suited to a market stall than designer boutique. But there were also well-judged, quieter pieces for those beyond their spray-paint days: tight, sexy jeans and fitted shirt dresses.

With Tristan Webber, another young designer showing at London fashion week, Bartley has been signed up as a consultant for the high street store New Look. Bartley told the magazine Vogue, where she was a fashion writer, that her job for the store will be to "tell them what's cool New Look are all about being young and teenage, which is basically what I'm about, but I do it in more expensive fabrics."

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip sweating profusely for the benefit of the country
fields.trailText: Aston Villa defender Alpay has told website One Football that Villa Park is only a stepping stone for a move to a better Premiership club. The Turkish international, who scored an own goal in Saturday's 1-1 draw with Middlesbrough said: "I want to get better and better every day so that bigger clubs will pay attention to me. I want to play for a better Premiership club."
fields.body:
Aston Villa defender Alpay has told website One Football that Villa Park is only a stepping stone for a move to a better Premiership club. The Turkish international, who scored an own goal in Saturday's 1-1 draw with Middlesbrough said: "I want to get better and better every day so that bigger clubs will pay attention to me. I want to play for a better Premiership club."

The Daily Mail reports that Martin O'Neill will offer Stan Collymore another last chance to resurrect his career. The paper suggests that the Celtic boss has already approached Leicester with a view to signing the former England striker, who was put on the transfer list by the Foxes yesterday.

Chelsea are attempting to sign every left-sided midfielder in the Primera Liga, if Planet Football are to be believed. After the Blues were knocked back in their attempt to sign Celta Vigo's Gustavo Lopez last week, the website reports that they then approached Valencia's Kily Gonzalez. But the Champions League finalists quoted a price of £18m (Kily's buy-out clause) and so new coach Claudio Ranieri has turned his attentions back to Real Madrid's Savio, who could be up for grabs thanks to the continuing financial problems at the Bernabeu.

Gerard Houllier has admitted that Michael Owen will leave Liverpool at some point. "Michael has intimated that he may play abroad at some stage", the Daily Mail quote Houllier as saying. "I would not expect him to stay here for his entire career because that does not happen any more."

Former Liverpool full-back Steve Harkness is set to leave Blackburn Rovers for Sheffield Wednesday, according to the Mirror. The 29-year-old who only joined Rovers six months ago will initially join Wednesday on loan, allowing the Owls to offload high-earning Andy Hinchcliffe.

Walter Smith has denied he is to make a move for Macclesfield's 21-year-old Nigerian defender George Abbey.

webTitle: Chan considers Rambo baddie role

fields.headline: Chan considers Rambo baddie role
fields.trailText: Martial arts star Jackie Chan is rumoured to be close to signing to star alongside Sylvester Stallone in the latest Rambo movie
fields.body:
Jackie Chan is rumoured to be close to signing up to star alongside Sylvester Stallone in the forthcoming Rambo IV film.

According to Coming Attractions, Miramax has been trying to persuade Chan to participate in the project for a few years, but negotiations took longer than expected because there were a number issues Chan was not happy with.

The original script saw Chan as a drug dealer who Stallone initially combats and eventually teams up with to take on other drug dealers. Chan said at a Q&A session at an American college on Monday that he had expressed reservations about playing such a character as he believed it would set a bad example for children. He was apparently also unhappy because his character eventually dies in the film.

According to Chan, rewrites of the scripts are currently taking place and he will go ahead with it if he's happy with the changes. Rumours are that the plot involves John Rambo infiltrating a right-wing militia group planning to topple the American government through terrorist action.

The last Rambo film was released in 1988 and it had looked unlikely that Stallone would reprise his role - he claimed at the time that his action persona had made him feel "very hollow". However, the subsequent flops of Copland and Judge Dredd may have made him rethink that decision. The 56-year-old actor is currently working on a remake of the 1971 Michael Caine gangster classic, Get Carter.

webTitle: Real Lives: Cancer

fields.headline: Cancer? You've got to laugh
fields.trailText:
Tiredness crept in like a warm blanket
And suffocated me in sleep
My bones ached, my mind was tired
My will, my motivation, both weak.
fields.body:
Tiredness crept in like a warm blanket
And suffocated me in sleep
My bones ached, my mind was tired
My will, my motivation, both weak.

Tom Bidwell's eyes are shadowed in grey and he is still skinny. But not as skinny as he used to be. He is up to seven stone. It's progress; a couple of years ago he was half a foot smaller and a stone heavier.

Tom, now 16, is recovering from cancer of the lymph glands. He has been through chemotherapy, radiotherapy and a bone-marrow transplant, and he has popped more pills than most people will hope to see in a lifetime.

And alongside all the conventional medicines, he has discovered his own form of complementary therapy - writing. It would be an exaggeration to say that Tom has written his way back to good health, but his writing has certainly helped. There are poems of anger, poems of love and loss, poems of tears and fears, poems of entrapment.

I don't wanna die, Mum,
Don't wanna have to cry, Mum
Don't wanna ask why, Mum
But why?

I just feel so bad, Mum
It hurts to see you sad, Mum
Not strong enough to get mad, Mum
Not strong

We'll make it through the grey, Mum
Tomorrow's another day, Mum
I love you more than I can say, Mum
Love you

Tom's mum and dad meet me at Preston station. Jack is a big, brawny Lancastrian who you just know must have been a no-nonsense centre back in his day. Barbara is smart and petite, a dead ringer for Sheila Grant. They talk about Tom with pride and tenderness.

I get a strange deja vu when I meet Tom. When I was a child, I was also ill and watched the weeks in darkness turn into months, and the months turn into years. Like Tom, I had a serious illness (encephalitis), and like Tom, I turned to poetry. Both of us had a precocious sense of the darkness in life, and both of us ripped off the Beatles mercilessly.

When Tom first went to the doctor, aged 14, he was told he had a pulled muscle and that he should exercise more. "The next day I tried to shave my brother's head with a razor and the vibrations made me pass out." He went back to the doctor, who told him he had been standing on the streets for too long and had caught a cold. At which point Barbara called for a second opinion. Tom says it was January 5 1999 when he was diagnosed with cancer. You don't forget dates like that.

He shows off the contours of his illness. There are numerous scars, reminders of all those tubes and needles - lumbar punctures, biopsies, thoracotomies. Tom became bitter, resentful. He would ask a question to which there was no answer: what have I done to deserve such pain? Tom became estranged from his friends and lost his faith in God.

As well as his poetry he kept a diary. In February 1999 he wrote: "Woke up and thought of everyone at school. This made me cry. Mum came in and asked, 'Why are you crying?' and I gave five reasons. 1) Can't get comfy. 2) Going back for intense treatment soon. 3) I just want to be back to normal. 4) Why? 5) I smell. Mum said she could only solve number 5, so I had a bath. After my bath I smelled myself, realised I still smelled, and started crying again."

He says the writing has been liberating, but doesn't quite know how to put it into words. Not spoken ones, anyway. The poems are loaded with images of bars, of shadows of life lived in a bubble. In a way, he says, the best thing is that it has enabled people to understand something of what he has been feeling.

Some of the poems are very funny. I Am Bernadette, Can I Feel Your Testicles?, inspired by the Beatles song I Am the Walrus, is a tribute to a hospital nurse. Tom explains this was the way she introduced herself to him. "How to frighten someone in two sentences, hey?"

As with so many people, illness seems to have broken down his inhibitions. Tom has taken embarrassing, deeply personal experiences and somehow seen the funny side. Like when the doctors thought Tom's cancer may leave him impotent so they decided to store up some of his sperm for the future just in case. "They said to me, 'Now wash your hands and masturbate until you ejaculate into this little pot, and there's some pornography in the drawer. But you don't have to use it.' And this pornography is full of" - he looks as if he's about to be sick - "huge, big-breasted women. Awful, it was." He tsks with sly laughter.

At one point one of his poems was read out on Radio Lancashire and the disc jockey announced that unfortunately Tom had since died. Barbara says it is not the first time people have given up on him. A few months ago the family took Tom on holiday and the curtains were shut while they were away. "When we got back, a few neighbours came up and whispered their sympathies to me," says Barbara. Both Tom and Barbara are giggling away. They've got a black sense of humour, these Bidwells.

With the help of his mum, Tom has managed to get his poems published. What D'You Make Of It?, which has been on sale in the local Waterstone's in Preston, has so far raised almost £5,000 for the Cancer Research Campaign.

He shows me a story from the local paper. "Just a sob story, really," he says sheepishly. His mum reads out the headline: "'Brave lad!' Oh, I hate that!" I know what she means. As if Tom had any choice in being ill. One of his favourite poems is called Cos Cowards Get Cancer Too. He makes no apologies for stealing the title from John Diamond's book.

"The reporter said, 'Why do you want to do the book for charity?' and I said I didn't really, I wanted to keep some of it for me 'cos I'd written the poems. But mum made me." I said to the reporter, 'Are you going to put that in?' and he said, 'No, I don't think we will.'"

Tom's immune system is still suspect - he is recovering from a bout of shingles - but the cancer has cleared up. Despite the illness, he managed to take, and pass, five GCSEs. Now he has started at sixth-form college to do A-levels and is beginning to return to normality. But, he says, in many ways he feels a different person to the Tom Bidwell of old. More serious, more mature. He has recovered his optimism, sorted things out with God, and says he sometimes feels older than his years. Many of the things he used to be interested in seem trivial now. "When I go out with my friends they just talk about ... stuff. It doesn't mean anything to me. They just, like, get drunk. Everyone does that, but I'm not bothered."

The best thing about the poetry, he says, is not the writing, it's the response he has had from people. "It's amazing some of the letters I've got. The poems seem to have given people comfort. One woman wrote to me saying I had changed her life."

For a second, he looks so happy, so chuffed, but he quickly brings himself down to earth. "Do you want to see a poem I wrote about enemas? It didn't quite make it into the book."

fields.bodyText: Tiredness crept in like a warm blanket And suffocated me in sleep My bones ached, my mind was tired My will, my motivation, both weak. Tom Bidwell's eyes are shadowed in grey and he is still skinny. But not as skinny as he used to be. He is up to seven stone. It's progress; a couple of years ago he was half a foot smaller and a stone heavier. Tom, now 16, is recovering from cancer of the lymph glands. He has been through chemotherapy, radiotherapy and a bone-marrow transplant, and he has popped more pills than most people will hope to see in a lifetime. And alongside all the conventional medicines, he has discovered his own form of complementary therapy - writing. It would be an exaggeration to say that Tom has written his way back to good health, but his writing has certainly helped. There are poems of anger, poems of love and loss, poems of tears and fears, poems of entrapment. I don't wanna die, Mum, Don't wanna have to cry, Mum Don't wanna ask why, Mum But why? I just feel so bad, Mum It hurts to see you sad, Mum Not strong enough to get mad, Mum Not strong We'll make it through the grey, Mum Tomorrow's another day, Mum I love you more than I can say, Mum Love you Tom's mum and dad meet me at Preston station. Jack is a big, brawny Lancastrian who you just know must have been a no-nonsense centre back in his day. Barbara is smart and petite, a dead ringer for Sheila Grant. They talk about Tom with pride and tenderness. I get a strange deja vu when I meet Tom. When I was a child, I was also ill and watched the weeks in darkness turn into months, and the months turn into years. Like Tom, I had a serious illness (encephalitis), and like Tom, I turned to poetry. Both of us had a precocious sense of the darkness in life, and both of us ripped off the Beatles mercilessly. When Tom first went to the doctor, aged 14, he was told he had a pulled muscle and that he should exercise more. "The next day I tried to shave my brother's head with a razor and the vibrations made me pass out." He went back to the doctor, who told him he had been standing on the streets for too long and had caught a cold. At which point Barbara called for a second opinion. Tom says it was January 5 1999 when he was diagnosed with cancer. You don't forget dates like that. He shows off the contours of his illness. There are numerous scars, reminders of all those tubes and needles - lumbar punctures, biopsies, thoracotomies. Tom became bitter, resentful. He would ask a question to which there was no answer: what have I done to deserve such pain? Tom became estranged from his friends and lost his faith in God. As well as his poetry he kept a diary. In February 1999 he wrote: "Woke up and thought of everyone at school. This made me cry. Mum came in and asked, 'Why are you crying?' and I gave five reasons. 1) Can't get comfy. 2) Going back for intense treatment soon. 3) I just want to be back to normal. 4) Why? 5) I smell. Mum said she could only solve number 5, so I had a bath. After my bath I smelled myself, realised I still smelled, and started crying again." He says the writing has been liberating, but doesn't quite know how to put it into words. Not spoken ones, anyway. The poems are loaded with images of bars, of shadows of life lived in a bubble. In a way, he says, the best thing is that it has enabled people to understand something of what he has been feeling. Some of the poems are very funny. I Am Bernadette, Can I Feel Your Testicles?, inspired by the Beatles song I Am the Walrus, is a tribute to a hospital nurse. Tom explains this was the way she introduced herself to him. "How to frighten someone in two sentences, hey?" As with so many people, illness seems to have broken down his inhibitions. Tom has taken embarrassing, deeply personal experiences and somehow seen the funny side. Like when the doctors thought Tom's cancer may leave him impotent so they decided to store up some of his sperm for the future just in case. "They said to me, 'Now wash your hands and masturbate until you ejaculate into this little pot, and there's some pornography in the drawer. But you don't have to use it.' And this pornography is full of" - he looks as if he's about to be sick - "huge, big-breasted women. Awful, it was." He tsks with sly laughter. At one point one of his poems was read out on Radio Lancashire and the disc jockey announced that unfortunately Tom had since died. Barbara says it is not the first time people have given up on him. A few months ago the family took Tom on holiday and the curtains were shut while they were away. "When we got back, a few neighbours came up and whispered their sympathies to me," says Barbara. Both Tom and Barbara are giggling away. They've got a black sense of humour, these Bidwells. With the help of his mum, Tom has managed to get his poems published. "Just a sob story, really," he says sheepishly. His mum reads out the headline: "'Brave lad!' Oh, I hate that!" I know what she means. As if Tom had any choice in being ill. One of his favourite poems is called Cos Cowards Get Cancer Too. He makes no apologies for stealing the title from John Diamond's book. "The reporter said, 'Why do you want to do the book for charity?' and I said I didn't really, I wanted to keep some of it for me 'cos I'd written the poems. But mum made me." More serious, more mature. He has recovered his optimism, sorted things out with God, and says he sometimes feels older than his years. Many of the things he used to be interested in seem trivial now. "When I go out with my friends they just talk about ... stuff. It doesn't mean anything to me. They just, like, get drunk. Everyone does that, but I'm not bothered." The best thing about the poetry, he says, is not the writing, it's the response he has had from people. "It's amazing some of the letters I've got. webTitle: Wales loses its most sustained lyric voice

fields.headline: Wales loses its most sustained lyric voice
fields.standfirst: Hermit-like poet RS Thomas dies aged 87
fields.trailText: Though he berated his Welsh homeland for its "cultural suicide", its "wanton" men and "sweaty females", the poet RS Thomas was embraced by the admiration of Wales and a wider world when his death was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Though he berated his Welsh homeland for its "cultural suicide", its "wanton" men and "sweaty females", the poet RS Thomas was embraced by the admiration of Wales and a wider world when his death was announced yesterday.

Thomas, one of the most uncompromising, purest and most sustained lyric voices of his century, died at his virtual hermit's home at Pentrefelin, near Criccieth. He was 87 and had been ill with heart trouble. He was being treated at Gwynnedd hospital until two weeks ago.

The unchanging themes of his poetry were God and the sparse natural world of the north Wales parishes which he served for 40 years as a Church in Wales priest.

He was still railing like a prophet against "the technological smugness, the awful atheism, the political sleaze" of the contemporary world in one of his last interviews late last year.

But his views were felt modern enough for a line from one of his poems to be quoted two years ago on the cover of the Manic Street Preachers album This is My Truth, Tell Me Yours.

In another poem, he wrote that he hated the Welsh "for your irreverence, your scorn even/of the refinements of art and the mysteries of the church". He accused them of committing their own cultural suicide, as "an impotent people/sick with inbreeding/worrying the carcass of an old song".

But in the principality yesterday he was hailed as a greater poet than Dylan Thomas. For the Welsh Language Society, Dafydd Lewis said, "He was probably Wales's most outstanding poet of the 20th century. He was a very good friend of ours.

"He was quite a character and did not mind supporting unpopular causes if he thought they were correct. Even if you didn't agree with his views they were interesting and thought provoking."

But the society disagreed with him over his support for the campaign of arson attacks on holiday homes in Wales.

Praising those who were fire-bombing English-owned property, Thomas asked in 1998, "What is one death against the death of the whole Welsh nation?"

Yesterday Rhodri Morgan, first secretary of the Welsh national assembly, said the country had lost a grand man of letters, a fierce and passionate man who had a unique knowledge of Wales and Welshness. "He leaves behind a rich legacy; a fascinating vision of an idyllic Welsh rural past and of spirituality which will be read with admiration for generations."

The Plaid Cymru president, Ieuan Wyn Jones, called Thomas one of Wales's greatest literary voices. He had helped to put it on the cultural map of the world.

"His profound spirituality and unashamed patriotism made his poetry unique and gained him an international audience," Mr Jones said yesterday.

"His work will remain with us as a testament to the flowering of Welsh writing in English and the emerging Welsh identity in the latter part of the 20th century."

M Wynn Thomas, a professor at the University of Wales, Swansea, said: "He was the Solzhenitsyn of Wales because he was such a troubler of the Welsh conscience. He was one of the major English language and European poets of the 20th century."

Al Alvarez, the English poetry critic, poet and author who first promoted Thomas's work in the late 1950s - along with that of Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath - said last night: "He was wonderful, very pure, very bitter but the bitterness was beautifully and very sparely rendered. He was completely authoritative, a very, very fine poet, completely off on his own, out of the loop but a real individual. It's not about being a major or minor poet. It's about getting a work absolutely right by your own standards and he did that wonderfully well."

Mr Alvarez said Thomas's work would survive as securely as that of Henry Vaughan, the 17th-century metaphysical poet who wrote: "I saw Eter nity the other night/like a great ring of pure and endless light".

Thomas, however, said in last year's interview that he was disqualified from major status by his "lack of love for human beings", adding: "There is a kind of narrowness in my work which a good critic would condemn."

The Other

Thomas's poem The Other stands inscribed on slate in the gaunt village church of St Hywyn, Aberdaron, where he was parish priest for 11 years:

There are nights that are so still

that I can hear the small owl

calling

far off and a fox barking

miles away. It is then that I lie

in the lean hours awake listening

to the swell born somewhere in

the Atlantic

rising and falling, rising and

falling

wave on wave on the long shore

by the village that is without

light

and companionless. And the

thought comes

of that other being who is

awake, too,

letting our prayers break on him,

not like this for a few hours,

but for days, years, for eternity.

webTitle: A giant of poetry

fields.headline: A giant of poetry
fields.standfirst: RS Thomas possessed huge moral courage, yet his austerity was full of unexpected tenderness
fields.trailText: Yesterday morning my husband told me that RS Thomas had died. I was thinking of RS the night before, when we saw a collage of one of his most famous poems, Welsh Landscape, stuck on the wall of a school where we had been for an evening class in navigation. The children had made a Welsh landscape out of tissue paper, with 3D hedges and suitably brooding mountains. Today, I feel lost because one of the peaks by which I orient myself has suddenly disappeared.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning my husband told me that RS Thomas had died. I was thinking of RS the night before, when we saw a collage of one of his most famous poems, Welsh Landscape, stuck on the wall of a school where we had been for an evening class in navigation. The children had made a Welsh landscape out of tissue paper, with 3D hedges and suitably brooding mountains. Today, I feel lost because one of the peaks by which I orient myself has suddenly disappeared.

RS Thomas was a giant in the poetry world and his passing cuts our contact with the generation which included what he referred to as "the other Thomases" - Edward and Dylan.

Born in 1913, RS Thomas, the son of a ship's captain from Anglesey, became a clergyman in the Church in Wales. He chose rural parishes to allow him time to write in the mornings and because of his love of nature, birds in particular.

His early poems such as A Peasant and Evans celebrated the bare, heroic lives of Welsh hill farmers; his portraits of their physical and spiritual poverty were shockingly unromantic, a savage rebellion against the sentimentality of romantic lyricism. Thomas's religious poetry was unrelenting in its search for a fickle and sometimes cruel God. His subject was himself:

"on the margin

of eternity, dissolution,

nothing but the self

looking up at the self

looking down ...

from bottomless fathoms

I dredge up the truth."

RS Thomas could be a forbidding figure. The first time I met him, to interview him for a Cambridge student magazine, I was so frightened that I asked a friend to come with me. We were astonished to find him a surprisingly humorous interviewee, though he did correct my spelling of something to do with feathers when I sent him a copy of the interview.

He didn't suffer fools gladly and was likely to rebuff any approach which he considered disrespectful of Wales or poetry. There is a story about one over-eager arts administrator deciding to take a Welsh Arts Council prize, which RS had won, to the poet in person. The officer made the pilgrimage to the remote manse where RS lived, expecting to be thanked profusely for the cheque. When RS answered the door, the story goes, the man explained his mission and smiled graciously. "Thank you," said RS, and shut the door in his face.

RS's total lack of interest in cultivating favour or in ingratiating himself with anybody may have contributed to the serious underestimation of him as a poet in the UK. It was certainly a direct result of his huge moral courage as a poet. He refused to be distracted from the great questions of existence. His stare at the blankness of eternity was unrelenting.

Over a career spanning most of a century, he was able to breathe thinner air than most of us but then, he had travelled further up the mountain and commanded a rarer view. His poetry was not written for entertain ment, but to be of use to people as they lived and died. And yet, his austerity was full of unexpected tenderness and sensuality; he was a magnificent love poet.

I got to know RS better at the end of his life, after we read together in Barcelona at about the time of the last football World Cup.

I had always addressed him as Mr Thomas, but ventured to ask what I should call him, as we had known each other for 20 years. "Ronaldo," he said, deadpan. I never dared call him that, but every visit to him and his second wife Betty was filled with laughter and irreverence. This was a side of him which was seldom seen in public.

He was a generous friend, answering requests by return of post. I once saw him drive through a whole day and half the night in order to honour an engagement with a group of local schoolchildren. His favourite shop-bought cake was the chocolate one made by Cadbury.

On the face of it it is hard to see what a minor Welsh cleric could have to say to young people at the start of the 21st century. Great poetry, whatever the circumstances in which it is written, has everything to do with everywhere.

Looking at that collage stuck up on the wall of the school, RS had already become the glue, sticky on the pupils' fingers, the tongues moving along their lips as they concentrated, as well as the poem the class had copied out.

And, reading one of my favourite poems of his again, after struggling with symbols on a shipping chart, I'm comforted that he saw himself as one who had

"been made free

by the tide's pendulum truth

that the heart that is low

now

will be at the full tomorrow."

 Gwyneth Lewis is a Welsh poet.

webTitle: Poor book sales fail to deter HMV

fields.headline: Poor book sales fail to deter HMV
fields.trailText: HMV Media yesterday said it remained committed to the group's ailing book retail chain Waterstone's despite reporting another slide in sales at the business.
fields.body:
HMV Media yesterday said it remained committed to the group's ailing book retail chain Waterstone's despite reporting another slide in sales at the business.

Alan Giles, HMV chief executive, described several bids for the book retailer over the summer as unsolicited and suggested he would stand firm in the face of an anticipated offer from the chain's founder Tim Waterstone. Mr Waterstone has beencritical of HMV Media's stewardship of the business and has secured financial backing from PPM Ventures to make an offer.

"Our view is that although the recent performance has been disappointing, Waterstone's is fundamentally a very good business in a good market," Mr Giles said. "We did receive some unsolicited offers but we are very committed to keeping it within the HMV Media Group."

Waterstone's suffered a 3.8% decline in sales during the three months to the end of July which the company blamed on a fall in sales to schools.

Insiders said Mr Waterstone's putative bid was not helped by the continued drop in sales at the book chain which made it difficult to shape an offer. The companies which made an approach to HMV earlier this year included Germany's Bertelsmann and Barnes & Noble of the US.

The flotation of HMV Media has been put on ice for the "foreseeable future" although Mr Giles said the performance of Waterstone's was not the prime reason. "There is little or no appetite from equity investors to support flotations in the retail sector so the performance of Waterstone's is academic," he said.

"The froth has gone from many of the internet plays which had been a perceived threat to retailers and damaged the sector. But the two seem to have become disconnected because there hasn't been a re-rating of the retailers."

Mr Giles denied coming under pressure from shareholders EMI and US venture capital fund Advent International to dispose of Waterstone's.

webTitle: NTL loses two chiefs in same week

fields.headline: NTL loses two chiefs in same week
fields.trailText: 10am: NTL is losing its head of corporate affairs and head of public policy in the same week, says Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
NTL is losing its head of corporate affairs and head of public policy in the same week, in a move described by insiders as "pure coincidence".

Will Robson is standing down to join Cambridge Positioning Systems, a mobile telecoms provider specialising in "positioning" technology (detailed mapping and local information services provided by WAP and GPRS technology). Venture capital-backed CPS is planning an initial public offering next year.

Meanwhile, head of public policy Alison Ryan is joining Manchester United football club as director of communications.

webTitle: Report claims half of UK adults now online

fields.headline: Half of UK adults now online
fields.trailText: Almost half of British adults - some 20.4m people - in the UK now use the internet, according to research from the National Statistics Office. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Almost half of British adults - some 20.4m people - in the UK now use the internet, according to research from the National Statistics Office.

Of the 55% of British adults who have never accessed the internet, half said they weren't interested in doing so. A quarter said they didn't have a computer and 15% said they lacked the confidence and the necessary skills to go online.

Men are still the more dominant sex online, with 52% of men having used the internet compared with 39% of women. The proportion of adults that have used the internet decreases with age, with 69% of those aged 16-24 and 6% of those aged 75 and over.

Social class is still a determining factor with the proportion of adults who had used the internet varied according to occupation - 66% of households that were headed by someone from a professional occupation used the internet, compared to 20% of individuals living in a household headed by an unskilled worker.

The research was the second in a series of reports on internet access, with the next to be published in December.

Men are still the more dominant sex online, with 52% of men having used the internet compared with 39% of women. The proportion of adults that have used the internet decreases with age, with 69% of those aged 16-24 and 6% of those aged 75 and over. Social class is still a determining factor with the proportion of adults who had used the internet varied according to occupation - 66% of households that were headed by someone from a professional occupation used the internet, compared to 20% of individuals living in a household headed by an unskilled worker. The research was the second in a series of reports on internet access, with the next to be published in December.

webTitle: News Corp set to buy Liberty's stake in GemStar TV Guide

fields.headline: News Corp set to buy Liberty's stake in GemStar TV Guide
fields.trailText: 9.45am: News Corporation is in talks with Liberty Media to buy its $6bn (£4.1bn) holding in electronic programming guide maker GemStar TV Guide.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is in talks with US cable operator Liberty Media to buy its $6bn (£4.1bn) holding in electronic programming guide maker GemStar TV Guide.

"The company confirms that it is in negotiations with Liberty Media Corporation for the acquisition of its stake in GemStar TV Guide, but that the negotiations have yet to be finalised," said a News Corp statement to the Australian Stock Exchange.

The link with Liberty will go a long way to building a US satellite platform for News Corps, which is planning to bid for satellite broadcaster DirecTV. The company is part of Hughes Electronics, owned by US car maker General Motors, and could be put up for sale in the next few months.

In exchange, Liberty could nearly triple its 8% stake in Murdoch's company. Such an arrangement would further dilute the Murdoch family's grip on News Corp, although having a respected cable company as a key shareholder is reassuring to share holders.

Liberty Media's parent company is At&T, the largest telecoms and cable TV company in the US, and analysts continue to tout the possibility of a strategic investment in News Corp.

Today's news is the latest attempt by News Corp to strengthen its satellite TV arm, Sky Global Networks, before launching it on the stock exchange.

webTitle: ONdigital may shelve flotation plans

fields.headline: ONdigital may shelve flotation plans
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Digital broadcaster ONdigital could shelve its planned £2bn flotation if a telecoms company takes a stake in it, according to industry sources. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ONdigital, the digital broadcaster co-owned by Carlton Communications and Granada Media, could shelve its planned £2bn flotation if a telecoms company takes a stake in it, according to industry sources.

Speculation is increasing over the fledgling broadcaster's strategy, following reports that it has entered preliminary discussions with several telecoms and cable companies about making a strategic investment in the company. BT, Telewest and Orange are rumoured to have been involved in the talks, but refused to comment.

A senior industry source told MediaGuardian that an investment from a telecoms company would be attractive to ONdigital, since it would provide access to broadband networks, and give a telecoms operator a foothold in the pay-TV market. ONdigital has 775,000 subscribers and aims to sign up 1m by the end of the year.

"If a telecoms company takes a significant percentage of the company, then it may negate the need to float. This is either a pre-float deal, or it is to replace a float. The ONdigital target is 2m subscribers, and it would be risky to launch on the market with that aim," said the source.

An ONdigital spokesperson refused to comment on the reports, adding that any decision on the company's future would be a matter for shareholders. Charles Allen, ONdigital chairman and head of Granada Media, said in August that a decision on floating the company would be made sooner rather than later.

On Digital has yet to secure a significant strategic alliance with ITV, despite the influence of Carlton and Granada, the major powers in the network.

webTitle: Videonet to commission original programming

fields.headline: Videonet to commission original programming
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Videonet's Simon Hochauser says it will move towards commissioning original programmes "in the next one to two years", reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Simon Hochauser, chief executive of Videonet, which yesterday launched its ADSL-based HomeChoice video-on-demand service, has told MediaGuardian it will move towards commissioning original programmes "in the next one to two years".

Hochauser said that in the initial stages of the launch newly commissioned programmes on a new platform would not attract the volume of viewers necessary to create "volume".

But he added: "Once we get past the hundreds of thousands of subscribers, we will start to increase significantly the proportion of our budget that we spend on commissioned programmes."

Hochauser said video-on-demand services like HomeChoice offer the opportunity to open up platforms for programming, "which, frankly, won't get commissioned by the broadcasters".

He continued: "There's an audience threshold below which niche and specialist programmes won't get commissioned."

Hochauser said the take-up of video-on-demand would be driven initially by film and music video.

Video-on-demand, he said, would lead to a radical shift in the way content is financed, moving from broadcaster-funding towards funding by finance houses, individual programme-makers, and through e-commerce partnerships.

He was unwilling to reveal details of the kind of budget Videonet would make available to programme-makers, but said it will be "an initially small, but growing, proportion of a tens of millions budget".

HomeChoice, which launched yesterday, will offer a library of 800 film titles, more than 1,000 chart music videos, sports programming, and home shopping and banking services.

webTitle: Telefonica to float mobile operations

fields.headline: Telefonica to float mobile operations
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Spanish telecoms group Telefonica is planning to float up to 15% of its mobile arm, Telefonica Moviles, according to a newspaper report. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Spanish telecoms group Telefonica is planning to float up to 15% of its mobile arm, Telefonica Moviles, according to a Spanish newspaper report today.

Financial daily Cinco Dias said Telefonica hoped to raise more than one trillion pesetas ($5.29bn) through the flotation of a minority stake, which is expected to take place in November.

Quoting sources close to the company, the paper reported Telefonica's board was due to discuss the flotation plan at a meeting today.

Telefonica, which owns Dutch TV producer Endemol, is seeking cash for its expensive European mobile expansion plans and had been expected to float around 30% of its wireless subsidiary.

The company was not available to comment.

United News & Media shareholders have approved the sale of United's ITV assets to Granada Media, as expected.

At an extraordinary general meeting held this morning, United shareholders voted almost unanimously in favour of the move.

As part of the deal, shareholders will receive around £1.25bn-worth of Granada Media shares in exchange for their United holdings.

United has retained stakes in Channel 5 (35%), ITN (20%), digital multiplex SDN (33%) and horseracing channel SIS (20%).

webTitle: Blair faces demand for pension increase

fields.headline: Blair faces demand for pension increase
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair is to face calls for an immediate substantial increase in pensions after promising to listen to campaigners' concerns.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair is to face calls for an immediate substantial increase in pensions after promising to listen to campaigners' concerns.

An emergency motion being debated today at Labour's annual conference in Brighton will call for the big increase in the state benefit.

But negotiations last night between unions and activists have headed off any possible demand for the restoration of the link between pensions and earnings.

A three-hour meeting between union leaders and officials from several constituency Labour parties agreed the wording of the motion to be put to delegates in Brighton.

Officials from public sector union Unison, the GMB general union and CLPs agreed simply to call for an immediate and substantial increase in the state pension, but stressing the need for an uprating mechanism such as linking the benefit to average earnings or inflation, without actually putting the Government on the spot.

A Unison official says the union has argued that the state pension should not be eroded and a GMB official says the motion is designed to be constructive, leaving the Government a number of options.

GMB general secretary John Edmonds has made it clear that the unions will press the Labour leadership on the issue of the pensions-earnings link.

His union wants to see the annual increase in pensions linked to the increase in earnings, he said, adding that the Government had made a big mistake by setting itself against restoration of the link.

He has welcomed indications that the Government is planning a significant increase in the basic state pension the coming year but add that that is not enough.

webTitle: Labour tries to placate pension revolt

fields.headline: Labour tries to placate pension revolt
fields.trailText: Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling today tried to head off a damaging party conference revolt over pensions policy and avoid defeat in a   vote on pensions.
fields.body:
Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling today tried to head off a damaging party conference revolt over pensions policy and avoid defeat in a vote on pensions.

After intense pressure from union bosses and delegates to restore the earnings link, Mr Darling promised more help for all pensioners from next April.

With arm-twisting going on behind closed doors right up to the start of the debate, he urged delegates to remit a union motion calling for an "immediate and substantial increase" in the basic state pension.

Mr Darling said the government's own proposals would mean "more, much more" than restoring the earnings link for Britain's poorest pensioners.

He pledged that funds would be made available for "transitional arrangements" in the pre-Budget report and assured delegates that there would be party-wide consultation examining all the issues on pensions before the end of the year.

The move followed a day of negotiations involving both the prime minister and Chancellor Gordon Brown, who flew back from a meeting of international finance ministers in Prague.

Mr Darling said the party's pensions policy marked a "major advance" for Labour. "It reaffirms our commitment to the basic state pension as the foundation for everything we do."

He confirmed that the government would raise the minimum income guarantee for pensioners to £90 a week. "It must be right to give more than an earnings link to those in greatest need," he said.

"An across-the-board earnings increase will not diminish growing inequalities. Nor does an earnings link do enough to help millions of people, who have saved a little, got a few thousand in the bank, got a modest works pension, who are not well off and feel they've lost out."

With the Chancellor sitting alongside, Mr Darling said the new pensioner credit would help lower and middle income pensioners with savings. "The proposals before you today will mean that we can give more than the earnings link to the poorest pensioners, more to those millions on modest incomes, as well as making sure that every single pensioner shares fairly in the country's prosperity."

webTitle: Labour conference 2000: Caught in the pensions mire

fields.headline: Caught in the pensions mire
fields.standfirst: The thorny issue of pensions is pitting New Labour's Alistair Darling against Old Labour's Barbara Castle, says Julian Glover in Brighton
fields.trailText: Comment: The thorny issue of pensions is pitting New Labour's Alistair Darling against Old Labour's Barbara Castle, says Julian Glover in Brighton.
fields.body:
This conference has seen pensions policy become a ticking parcel no minister wants to be left holding least it explode in their hands. On Monday, Gordon Brown cleverly passed the issue on to the prime minister by promising a complex (yet inexpensive) fudge, to be unveiled in full later this year.

Yesterday, Tony Blair told his party he had heard their complaints at the 75p increase in the basic state pension and would do better next time. He then landed the problem in the lap of the secretary of state for social security, Alistair Darling.

And this afternoon Mr Darling kicked off a conference debate on the subject with a speech which managed to be both a robust defence of government policy and an apparent climbdown. He was opposed by one of the great figures of Labour history, Barbara Castle, who gave a short but powerful speech which delighted even those who opposed her.

So has Mr Darling stopped the pensions bomb ticking? Perhaps - but we will only know for sure when we get the result of a knife-edge vote on an emergency motion on the issue later tonight.

Losing the vote would be embarrassing for the prime minister. Such things are not supposed to happen in New Labour. But it would hardly be a crisis and would not force the government to change its position, though it would add weight to calls to do so.

Part of the problem for the government is that its case can appear frighteningly complex. This week, ministers have made it more so by announcing all sorts of clever schemes which they say will ease the plight of poor pensioners without passing more government money to those who don't really need it.

Why give cash to rich retirees such as Margaret Thatcher, spin doctors have been asking? They claim (like Mr Darling today) that the government's own proposals mean "more, much more" than restoring the earnings link.

In fact, the dispute is a simple one. At its heart is the question of whether the social security budget should be used as a last resort for the poorest in society, as the government wants, or whether it should be expanded to provide a reasonable retirement income for everyone, which many in Labour would like but which would be expensive.

No one thinks much of the current position, which leaves the poor without adequate resources. Even the government has given up defending this year's 75p rise in the basic state pension.

Certainly in their hearts, delegates would like to see a restoration of the link between the rise in average earnings and pension payments. Barbara Castle, the former minister who looks like a sweet old granny but can act like the most ruthless politician at times, is doing her best to bring this about by defeating the government in today's vote.

Speaking in the debate (to cheers and a standing ovation), she said she could not "understand" why the government would not restore the earnings link. It would mean the state pension was "dead".

"Comrades, pass this resolution today. This country can afford it," she said to loud support. Barbara Castle, who is 90 this week, was applauded by the chancellor and the social security mininster as she left the platform.

And she may get her way today. That would keep the issue as a running sore for the government just at a time which it would like the wound to heal. So ministers will be hoping they win.

Even if they lose, though, Gordon Brown, the iron chancellor whose reputation has been half-restored this week, is unlikely to change course.

webTitle: St Luke's chief slams marketing industry

fields.headline: St Luke's chief slams marketing industry
fields.trailText: St Luke's Mark Earls says the marketing industry "in principle and in practice, it is not of any help", reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
St Luke's joint planning director Mark Earls has spoken out against the marketing industry, saying that "in principle and in practice, it is not of any help" and actually "gets in the way".

You could argue, he says, that marketing is no longer any use because everyone is doing it.

In a paper presented to the US Account Planning Group's annual conference in Miami, Earls said the marketing industry is the reason why many businesses are so unconducive to invention and innovative thinking, because its principles were developed for an earlier business age.

He says one of the main problems is the industry's reliance on consumer research. "In a world changing as fast as ours, the consumer is a very poor guide to tomorrow. When you're designing a new automotive vehicle, you may be five years ahead of the market. How can the consumer help you then?

"The European automotive industry has listened to them very well, which is why European cars all looked the same until recently."

Earls describes market research as "money down the pan" and adds that the problem with most businesses is that "marketing has pointed their heads at the customer and their arses at the future".

He uses Levi-Strauss, which through the 1980s Original Rebel campaign had a clearly defined brand, to illustrate his point. By not responding to changes in fashion and the impact of the product's success (parents caught on to the 501 look), the company failed to invent a future, he says.

While Earls conceedes that recent efforts may bring the brand back from the brink, but says that was not before Levi's was forced to close 22 US factories.

He adds that some of the leading advertising and marketing companies, including McKinsey and WPP, are finding it difficult to hold on to the best talent - to the extent that some London ad agencies have suffered staff turnover rates of up to 30 per cent.

"Unless you chain the talented [individuals] to their desks with the kind of obscene multi-million dollar golden handcuffs that the senior executives of Young & Rubicam or Saatchi & Saatchi have recently benefited from, they seem ready to walk.

"Talent does not want to breath the dull, stifling air of the kind of business that currently exists."

webTitle: No coronation for Granada

fields.headline: No coronation for Granada
fields.standfirst: Media sector takes a pasting
fields.trailText: Media sector takes a pasting.
fields.body:
Neil Blackley is considered by many people (including himself) to be the doyen of media analysts. Over the past 10 years or so, he has waltzed from one top City brokerage to another on ever-spiralling packages. He is at present using the firepower of Merrill Lynch to distribute his aggressive views.

He is hot property for one simple reason: the man can create trading volume and move share prices.

Witness Granada Media. On Monday Merrill published a "significant profits downgrade" for the broadcasting group, slashing Mr Blackley's forecast for next year by 21%. The shares fell 20p on the day and then another 50p to 503p yesterday as the rest of the stock market got its hands on the analyst's words.

These state, quite solemnly, that profits during 2001 are expected to be around £256m at the pre-tax level against Mr Blackley's earlier guess of £321m. This reflects the "softness" of ITV advertising and the fact that Granada plans to use a more conservative accounting approach to the TV assets owned by the newly acquired United News & Media than that favoured by the previous management (Lord Hollick).

On the surface, there is nothing too surprising in this. The entire media sector has taken a pasting in London over recent weeks as investors cottoned on to the fact that while the past 12 months have witnessed such extraordi nary growth in advertising revenues, there has to be a good chance that the coming year might only prove "exceptional" or may be even as bad as "good".

In particular, the sector has been bonged by the New at Ten about-turn, which has given commentators a peg on which to hang musings about ITV's shrinking market share. In the case of Granada, the company's value has fallen by a quarter in the space of a month.

Yet there is something grotesque about an investment culture where this is accepted as normal. Granada is a freshly quoted entity, worth more than £8bn, and a member of the FTSE 100 index. It should be, and is, analysed to death - to the point where the City knows precisely where it is going in the short, medium and long term.

Instead, it is being thrown in and out of fashion with such violence that the only way the management can possibly get on and run the business is by ignoring what the Square Mile is saying in terms of its share price.

The stock exchange's trading systems may be partly to blame, creating liquidity problems and increasing price volatility. It might be Mr Blackley's over-enthusiastic colleagues on Merrill's equity sales desk, hungry for commission. Or blame may simply rest with our gormless fund management community, who act like lemmings in order to avoid the risk of falling out of step with this or that performance benchmark.

On a longer-term view, Mr Blackley and his colleagues are devaluing their currency.

webTitle: Murdoch plays hardball in broadcast deal

fields.headline: Murdoch plays hardball in broadcast deal
fields.trailText: The increasing value of broadcast rights to the world's leading sporting events was underlined yesterday when Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation reportedly made a $2.5bn (£1.7bn) bid for exclusive rights to major league baseball, including the World Series.
fields.body:
The increasing value of broadcast rights to the world's leading sporting events was underlined yesterday when Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation reportedly made a $2.5bn (£1.7bn) bid for exclusive rights to major league baseball, including the World Series.

The bid is for a six-year deal that would run until 2006. Fox now shares the rights with NBC and Walt Disney's ESPN.

It also emerged yesterday that Mr Murdoch is in talks with GM to acquire Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV broadcasting unit for more than $5bn in stock and cash - filling a gap in News Corp's plan to reinvent itself as a satellite company.

webTitle: Beeb.com launches Top of the Pops shopping guide

fields.headline: Beeb.com launches Top of the Pops shopping guide
fields.trailText: 8.15am: BBC Worldwide's internet portal, Beeb.com, has launched a Top of the Pops shopping guide. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide's internet portal, Beeb.com, has launched a Top of the Pops shopping guide.

The TOTP Shopping Guide will act as an e-commerce gateway for users wishing to buy music, books and information about bands and celebrities. Users can buy directly from the TOTP database of around 24,000 artists and 70,000 albums.

Broadcasters including the BBC are keen to develop trusted content brands before the uptake of personal video recorder systems like TiVo. Radio Times this week announced a deal with ONdigital's new TV internet service, Onnet, and is believed to be in talks with TiVo and Replay.

webTitle: IPC Media recruits Fuller

fields.headline: IPC Media recruits Fuller
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Former Maxim publisher Eric Fuller is joining IPC Media as publishing director of IPC Media & Spor, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Maxim publisher Eric Fuller is joining IPC Media as publishing director of IPC Media & Sport from the beginning of October.

Mr Fuller, who worked on music magazine Sounds and adult title Knave before joining Drapers Record, has been widely credited as the man behind the success of Dennis Publishing's lad-mag, Maxim.

Reporting to head of IPC Music & Sport's managing director, Mike Soutar, he will be given responsibility for developing Loaded, Loaded Fashion and Later. Mr Fuller said "Loaded is the most famous name in men's magazines and one of the best known brands in UK publishing, while Later is the first and most innovative assault on the older men's market."

The appointment frees up IPC Music's publisher, Robert Tame, to focus on developing IPC's music portfolio.

webTitle: Unilever launches Surf website to clean up on student market

fields.headline: Unilever launches Surf website to clean up on student market
fields.trailText: Unilever is launching its first website for detergent brand Surf, pitching it firmly at students.
fields.body:
Unilever is launching its first website for detergent brand Surf, pitching it firmly at students.

The site, Surf.co.uk, which goes live tomorrow, is designed specifically to build awareness of the washing powder among this new target market.

The thinking behind targeting students, as opposed to middle-aged housewives, is that when they leave home they have to buy detergents for the first time and Unilever wants Surf to be their first choice.

"We aim to increase awareness and encourage their loyalty by bringing the brand to life in a medium that is attractive and increasingly available to students," said Surf's consumer brand manager, Shahla Rushworth.

The core feature of the site is an interactive soap-opera called Foam & Away, which will encourage students to contribute editorial and pictures to the storyline. Students get the chance to win money if their episode is judged the "best".

The first episode is being written by Suzie Smith, who has written for Grange Hill and Casualty, and will appear on its own website at Foamandaway.com.

Surf is planning a promotional drive at universities and has plans sponsor university foam club nights. Online and offline activity is planned throughout the academic year.

The site was developed by web design agency Wax New Media.

webTitle: Danish press urges voters to say yes to the euro

fields.headline: Danish press urges voters to say yes to the euro
fields.standfirst:
Polls indicate a close result in tomorrow's referendum
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Huge adverts urging a yes or no vote in Denmark's euro referendum were plastered all over the press yesterday as the latest opinion polls predicted a result still too close to call.
fields.body:
Huge adverts urging a yes or no vote in Denmark's euro referendum were plastered all over the press yesterday as the latest opinion polls predicted a result still too close to call.

As tension mounted ahead of tomorrow's historic vote, the 4m-strong electorate was bombarded with last-minute appeals from the rival camps.

Gallup in the Berlingske Tidende gave supporters of the single currency 42%, and the nos 46%. Vilstrup for Politiken gave the yes camp 46% and 43% to the nos. But a Greens poll for Boersen produced 51% against and 44% for - a finding that ran contrary to a trend over the past few days suggesting that the yes camp has narrowed the gap.

"I am not sure the yes camp will win," the prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, admitted. "But I hope Danes will vote with their hearts and their heads, because this is decisive for the future of the country and its place in the European family."

One of Denmark's most famous brand names, the toy manufacturer Lego, said it backed joining euroland, along with a majority of businesses who claimed that being in would boost jobs, growth and national influence.

But Holger Nielsen, leader of the leftwing Socialist Peoples party, insisted that advocates of a no vote were not extremists. "It is possible to be a good European and to oppose EMU," he said, rejecting suggestions that collaboration with rightwing euro opponents meant all were xenophobes or nationalists.

Overall, the atmosphere remained muted, with Denmark's sixth referendum on a European issue since 1972 being reported more vigorously in the media than on the streets.

Both sides said coverage had been scrupulously fair, even though almost all newspapers back the yes camp. The only significant opposition comes from Exstra Bladet, a populist tabloid. Its rival, BT, favours a yes vote while running the sort of Brussels horror stories beloved of one of the most eurosceptic publics in the EU.

The main broadsheets are solidly behind the euro. Also supportive, but with a nod to a rural and more eurosceptic audience, is the Jyllands Posten, Denmark's biggest circulation daily.

The positive editorial line reflects the fact that the country's political and economic elites - including newspaper proprietors - favour joining the single currency. "Another reason is that our papers are not owned by Australians and Canadians, as they are in Britain," said Ole Bang Nielsen of the Berlingske Tidende.

"Denmark's elites support participation in Europe, so it seems logical to go all the way," argued Jakob Langvad, EU correspondent for the Information daily. "There's not much sense in not adopting the euro when the krone is already pegged to it." His newspaper is to follow its own example from the Maastricht treaty referendum of 1992 - when the Danish no vote stopped the EU in its tracks - and print two editorials, one for the euro and one against.

Some people are frankly fed up with the whole thing. "This campaign has got a broken-record, deja-vu feel to it, of here we go again," said a political scientist, Lykke Friis.

The Copenhagen News, an English language weekly, said: "One can't help wondering whether, if all the most important social developments of the last couple of centuries had also been decided by referendum - the motor-car, penicillin, open-heart surgery, TV and the internet, we would now all be under 30, riding around on penny-farthing bicycles and sending each other messages in semaphore."
