webTitle: Reaction at the conference

fields.headline: Reaction at the conference
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: "It was nice to hear him saying that the 75p on pensions was a mistake, and that he was going to act on pensions but unfortunately we haven't got enough information about that yet. But as far as the electorate's concerned I think this speech will have helped considerably."
fields.body:
John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB

"It was nice to hear him saying that the 75p on pensions was a mistake, and that he was going to act on pensions but unfortunately we haven't got enough information about that yet. But as far as the electorate's concerned I think this speech will have helped considerably."

Michael Jacobs, general secretary of Fabian Society

"Listing the government's achievements and saying what it's going to do in the second term is necessary because that is what the government is going to fight the election on. In that sense, this was the right speech for the right time."

Fiona MacTaggart, MP for Slough

"Little things like mentioning dirty hospitals showed he knew the shoe pinched - that things were difficult and painful. I think what he was saying was: I believe what I believe in, I do what I can, it's not always as much as I hope but I hope to do better. It was a very honest speech and I really think he did enough."

Rhodri Morgan, first secretary of the Welsh Assembly

"This was contrition with a mission. He was making it clear that the government had heard the wake up call. He was quite contrite about what it is that the public don't like about us and said, we're going to listen more."

Linda Guerin, 47, marketing manager, from Ilford, north-east London.

"It was an absolutely fantastic speech. I I found it quite emotional actually. I'm Old Labour and there are some things I haven't been happy about, but now I feel we're back on track with him doing what's best for the country."

Ted Harris, aged 70, a retired station assistant on the London underground and Labour party member of 50 years, from Hayes, Middlesex(?).

"I couldn't get into the hall so only heard some of the speech out here. I can't say I was disappointed but I've heard better and, over the years, I've heard paragraphs from it before. We'll have to wait and see if he delivers on it.

"I'm most annoyed - and sceptical - about health. He promised a lot but we've got such a problem with health, particularly waiting lists and I'm still waiting for previous promises to be implemented.

"He's convinced the conference he'll do something about pensions but I think the link with earnings should be restored and he hasn't said that.

"It's not that I think there should be a different government and I do think we'll win the election. But there's no point in coming to conference if you can't be critical of the party."

webTitle: Way ahead for key policies if Labour wins second term

fields.headline: Way ahead for key policies if Labour wins second term
fields.standfirst:
Analysis: Guardian writers consider implications of speech

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Analysis: Guardian writers consider implications of speech.
fields.byline: John Carvel, Will Woodward,  Alan Travis & Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Health

Tony Blair promised yesterday to slash waiting times for cancer patients as part of a six-year strategy to increase survival rates from among the worst to the best in Europe.

A national cancer plan to be published today will pledge "a step change in the quality of NHS cancer care".

Posts for more than 1,000 extra consultants in the cancer specialisms will be created by 2006 increasing the capacity of NHS cancer facilities by nearly a third. This will allow a progressive reduction in waiting times.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said: "By the end of this year all patients with suspected cancer, urgently referred by their GP, will be seen by a specialist within two weeks. As the number of cancer specialists rise, we can make progress towards a maximum wait of one month from diagnosis to treatment, with most people treated much more quickly."

Other parts of the programme will include an extra £23m for cancer research and a promise by the prime minister that "by 2003 for the first time the government will be matching pound for pound charity funding for cancer research".

The plan, drawn up by ministers and Mike Richards, the cancer tsar, will renew and upgrade cancer scanning and screening equipment that is used by about 400,000 patients a year.

Mr Milburn promised to spend £300m by 2004 on NHS cancer equipment including 50 new MRI scanners, 45 linear accelerators and 200 CT scanners.

The NHS plan, published in July, established cancer and coronary heart disease as top priorities for investment.

Cancer kills 100,000 in Britain each year and the government said it was unacceptable that unskilled workers were twice as likely to die from cancer as professionals. Survival rates were worse in Britain for several common cancers than in equivalent European countries.

Mr Blair warned yesterday: "As things stand one in every four people in this country will die of cancer." The plan will today explain how the government intends to address the problem with "substantial improvements to every aspect of cancer services - prevention, research, screening, diagnosis, treatment and palliative care."

Over the next six years numbers of cancer specialists will increase from 3,362 to 4,333. Over the same period posts will be created for 257 extra general surgeons, 123 urologists and 208 gastro-enterologists - the three specialties crucial to cutting waiting times for cancer treatment.

The Department of Health said: "In addition, the plan will also set out proposals for boosting the number of other staff who have vital special skills, such as radiographers, medical physicists and staff trained in endoscopy. There will also be proposals for improving the skills and flexibility of the NHS workforce involved in delivering cancer services."

Mr Blair also promised an end to the postcode lottery for cancer treatment."Cancer patients in all parts of the country will get the right drugs at the right time, regardless of where they live," he said.

The national institute for clinical excellence will make an assessment of recently licensed cancer drugs to ensure they are available for all patients if they are shown to be cost effective.

There will be an extension of screening for breast cancer which kills 11,000 women each year. "Because it causes so much pain and suffering among Britain's families we will extend breast cancer screening to all women over 65, helping an extra 400,000 women by 2004," the prime minister said.

The Cancer Research Campaign said it was a red letter day for patients, volunteers and charities. "We did not expect the prime minister's pledge to match charity funding pound for pound. That will mean about £200m extra each year to plough into research and treatments. It will give our volunteers an enormous boost to raise even more cash for cures," said Gordon McVie, the campaign's director general. John Carvel

Education

Tony Blair last night reasserted education as the government's number one priority for the next parliament and made a spending pledge potentially worth billions to Britain's schools.

He said the next Labour manifesto would repeat its 1997 pledge - "line one of our contract with the people" - to increase the share of national income spent on education.

"Education, education, education - then, now and in the future," the prime minister said.

Policy, "the next stage of our journey", would be directed at creating "first class secondary schools" to match the already "excellent primary schools", creating 1,000 specialist schools by 2004 - double the number now and 200 more than previously pledged.

Extra money will be attached to catch-up lessons for 11- and 12-year-olds who fell below expected literacy and numeracy standards and new targets for results at key stage three, at age 14, and at 16. By 2004, 54% of pupils will be expected to achieve five A*-C grades at GCSE.

Mr Blair unveiled plans for an extra £1bn spending on ICT - actually £710m in new money allocated from the July comprehensive spending review - to deliver one computer for every five children in secondary and one computer for every eight in primary schools.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, will today unveil a three-year, £8bn package to repair Britain's crumbling schools. All schools will get some money for repairs, funnelled directly to schools: 600 will be either rebuilt or completely transformed.

Mr Blunkett will also promise to deliver more direct funding to schools, cutting local authorities out of the loop, which will annoy them but please head teachers.

The government will just achieve its target on spending as a share of national income - on this measure, only this year will spending beat John Major's last year, and then only by 0.1% to 4.8%. But spending will start to rise from next year and is, on government estimates, set to increase education's share of national income to 5.3% by 2004.

But, assuming that the economy continues to growth, Mr Blair's promise will mean hefty extra sums beyond then. And it gives the education secretary considerable leverage with the chancellor.

Mr Blunkett came out reasonably well in the spending review, but argued hard in private with Gordon Brown and was upset not to have won more.

He last night summoned the spirit of Britain's Olympic success to promote the specialist schools which specialise in sports, arts, languages or technology. Mr Blair massaged the teachers - like our doctors and armed forces, they were the best in the world. "Education is the passion of this government," he said.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, welcomed Mr Blair's pledges, though he was anxious about the new targets. Extra money for ICT was essential because in five years' time existing school computers would be obsolete. Mr Blunkett is concerned to bridge the "digital divide".

But Mr Dunford noted the extra specialist schools, which the government believes is creating excellence and diversity, but which others in Labour ranks, including Lord Hattersley at a fringe meeting yesterday, regard as an extension of the two-tier state education system. Will Woodward

Crime

The police are to be given the power to issue £100 fixed penalty fines to anyone found drunk in public or indulging in loutish disorderly behaviour as the main plank of Tony Blair's promise yesterday that it was time for "zero tolerance of yob culture".

The new scheme has dropped all plans to "march drunken youths to the nearest cashpoint", as Mr Blair once suggested, and instead police will issue £100 tickets in the same way that parking fines are handed with the possibility of contesting the case before a magistrates' court.

A Home Office consultation document published after Mr Blair's speech indicates that ministers are proposing that 16- and 17-year-olds as well as adults should be liable for the new £100 fines and those who repeat the offence within six months will face even heavier penalties. Ministers also believe there is "a strong case for an automatic increase in the level of the penalty if the fine is not paid within a certain number of days."

Under the new power the police will be able to fine people for a wide range of disorderly behaviour offences, including drunkenness in public, abusive or insulting behaviour, buying alcohol by or on behalf of under 18s, drinking in public places and minor cases of criminal damage, including spray-painting graffiti.

Police will also be given power to arrest anyone who refuses to provide evidence of their name or address.

Mr Blair said the new fines were needed because he was determined to deal firmly with the type of loutish behaviour, often fuelled by alcohol, which, he said, had become commonplace in villages, towns and cities.

"Fixed penalty notices will enable the police to deal effectively and speedily with minor offences of public drunkeness and disorder, while reducing the the time they have to spend on paperwork," said the prime minister.

Mr Blair's tough words will echo in the corridors of his own home. Only in July his 16-year-old son, Euan, was arrested after being found drunk on the pavement in Leicester Square, London. At the time he received a police reprimand but under the new scheme he would be liable for a fine.

About 77% of the 3.4m fixed penalty fines issued for motoring offences are paid each year. The Home Office estimates that even if the amount was set at £50 rather than £100, the introduction of such fines for loutish and drunken behaviour could raise £24m a year.

Nearly all the crime measures mentioned by Mr Blair in his speech have already been well trailed, including the power to close violent pubs, compulsory drug treatment for those testing positive when arrested, a new attack on organised crime, and more rights for victims, including introduction of victim impact statements in court cases.

The prime minister hinted at further changes to come when he talked of tightening up bail conditions so that those released by the courts in the morning could not commit offences in the afternoon. Alan Travis

Sport

Up to £1bn is to be spent on new sports facilities at schools across the country as the government attempts to lift sporting standards throughout Britain.

Tony Blair announced yesterday that £750m of lottery money will go towards the facilities, which will include astroturf pitches, tennis courts and indoor and outdoor cricket pitches.

The prime minister told the conference: "Today we set out plans to invest £750m of lottery money in schools and commmunity sport as part of a £1bn investment over three years. This is not just a sports policy. It's a health policy, an education policy, an anti-crime policy, an anti-drugs policy."

The ambitious scheme, which will benefit 1,500 schools, was drawn up with the help of the chairman of Sport England, Trevor Brooking, who flew from the Olympics in Sydney to attend yesterday's conference.

The prime minister hopes to emulate the "mille piscines" policy adopted by France in the 1960s and 1970s, when huge sums were pumped into sports facilities. The improved facilities raised French sporting standards as well as improving the health of schoolchildren.

The British scheme will pay for new sports halls, synthetic pitches, athletic facilities, tennis courts, football and rugby pitches and indoor and outdoor cricket pitches. The investment will also fund improvements to existing sports halls and playing fields.

The New Opportunities fund, which helps to distribute lottery money said outdoor adventure and sporting facilities and equipment should no longer be a luxury that few can afford.

The chairwoman, Lady Pitkeathley, said: "Educational and sporting opportunities for schools with wider community use is an excellent means of ploughing lottery funding back into localities in a way that fosters community spirit in its widest sense and builds self confidence."

British sports stars, including successful Olympic athletes, welcomed the new funding for sports facilities in schools.

Steve Redgrave, the rowing gold medallist, said: "We must encourage youngsters to be keen about sport which has been neglected in schools for too long."

Jason Queally, cycling gold medallist said: "All successful sporting nations have the roots of their success in school sport and I hope there will now be an increase in the choice of sports."

A consultation paper will be published soon and proposals will be drawn up towards the end of the year. Nicholas Watt

webTitle: Milosevic buys time as wife decides next move

fields.headline: Milosevic buys time as wife decides next move
fields.standfirst:
First couple increasingly isolated as president heads off defeat with call for runoff
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: If the procession of visitors to the former residence of the king of Yugoslavia - now the home of President Slobodan Milosevic and his powerful wife, Mira Markovic - means anything, it paints a bleak picture of what is in store for the people of Serbia.
fields.body:
If the procession of visitors to the former residence of the king of Yugoslavia - now the home of President Slobodan Milosevic and his powerful wife, Mira Markovic - means anything, it paints a bleak picture of what is in store for the people of Serbia.

The couple have been at Beli Dvor, or White Court, since casting their votes in the elections on Sunday morning.

According to reliable sources, the guests since then have included Zoran Janackovic, a former secret police chief and now ambassador to Macedonia, followed by the current head of the Serbian police, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, and the head of state security, Rado Markovic. Yesterday afternoon they had a visit from General Nebojsa Pavkovic, who runs the army.

President Milosevic has enjoyed 13 years at the top after coming to power in September 1987.

But now his people have rejected him in favour of a 56-year-old lawyer, Vojislav Kostunica, who has united Serbia against Mr Milosevic and his wife. And the signs of what is to come are ominous.

"Initially they were in complete shock when the results came through and he especially was stunned by them. They never expected the opposition to get their act together so quickly," said the former information ministry head, Aleksandar Tijanic.

"He doesn't watch TV and his party people told him he was assured of victory. At first they could not believe it," he added.

"They were convinced that they were going to win. For the first 24 hours there was a real battle between Milosevic and his wife to choose between the soft option of letting go of power and the hard one that could eventually mean police on the streets."

Their strategy was decided after a three-hour meeting in the White Court on Tuesday morning with the leaders of both their parties, said Nebojsa Covic, the former leader of the Belgrade Socialist party and the ex-mayor of Belgrade. Ms Markovic leads the Yugoslav United Left party.

"The meeting began at 9am at their residence and ended at 12. After that they announced his victory at a press conference and said there would be another round."

"They are preparing to go for another round," said Mr Covic. "Some of his people told him that he should recognise the elections but the problem is his ego and his wife. They are both very sick people now."

"She sees herself a some sort of Rosa Luxemburg, or Karl Marx, with a mission to save Serbian communism at whatever price," Slavoljub Djukic, the author of four books on Slobodan Milosevic and Mira Markovic said.

"In a way he is the softer one. The one thing that Milosevic treasures above all else - even power - is his family and if they were under threat as they are now, I think he would consider other options. There are countries that could take them - China - but it will be she that decides."

Mr Covic, who also agreed that it would be Ms Markovic, not Mr Milosevic, who decides Serbia's fate, said he believed that they were buying time to discredit the elections before crushing the protests.

"It is true that the paramilitaries and parapolice are available to them. It is a sort of criminal police force that in cludes: the Legion, which has around 500 men; Frenki's Boys, about 1,400 of them [a vicious paramilitary force that fought in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo] and finally about 1,600 men in the 7th brigade who are loyal to him and based in Montenegro."

The presidential couple have been an extraordinary and devastating political unit for over 40 years since meeting at school.

"She chose him and she made him president," said Mr Covic, who for four years was part of the inner circle. "I was in the house regularly, for dinner, for talks. While I was mayor of Belgrade three years ago I was there every day."

Mr Covic believes that now, as then, Ms Markovic is insistent that her husband does not accept the election results.

"She is mad. It is as simple as that and she is very powerful," he said.

In a reference to demonstrations in Belgrade at the rigging of local elections, Mr Covic added: "During the protests in 1997 I tried to persuade him that he couldn't just null the elections and he would eventually have to give in.

"Then he would appear to soften and go home and then he would be back the next morning as hardline as ever. She cleaned his mind then and she is doing it again now," he said.

"Over the last two years even his speeches reflect her language. He has started using her words. Words for the opposition like 'lesbians', 'hyenas', 'rats'. That is Mira talking and now she is in charge."

Speaking before the election commission's announcement of the runoff, he added: "My prediction is that they will have a second round and then find some way to discredit the elections.

"Then they will bring the parapolice on to the streets and it will be a very dangerous time for everyone."

As if on cue, the phone in the former mayor's office rang. His workers told him that the gov ernment was declaring that the results from 26 out of 70 polling stations in one area of Belgrade would be declared invalid.

The reasons given included the stations staying open late, the fact that they had more ballots than they were supposed to have, and the distance of party posters from the entrance to the polling station, which was said to be less than the required 50 metres.

"It's starting," he said.

webTitle: Yesterday

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

For Observer chief political commentator Andrew Rawnsley whose barnstorming book has taken conference by storm. Politicos book shop reports Servants of the People is the week's bestseller with 130 copies walking out the door and an extra 100 ordered for a personal signing today. But some delegates are not too keen to advertise their newly acquired tomes. They are insisting the books are wrapped in a brown paper bag before leaving the shop.

Bad day

For Mo Mowlam, still suffering from having lost her glasses on Monday. At a Charter 88 fringe meeting she was forced to borrow a pair to read her speech.. But the new pair made her so out of focus that she insisted on speaking while sitting down."These are very very strong and I get a bit kind of woozy," she said. " I might fall over and then the press would have a field day and say I was pissed - but I'm not."

Debates

 Mo Mowlam again. The former secretary of state for Northern Ireland painted an astonishing picture of the informality she brought to the peace process when she told of how she refused to treat extreme loyalists and republicans with kid gloves and made tea for Bill Clinton to "take the piss out of him". She said: "One of the ways in the peace talks that you get people to break down their egos and neuroses is to deal them as human beings. "In that context, I used to do weird things. I used to take tea. I used to wander around with chips and get in Chinese takeaways Making tea for Clinton was just to take the piss out of him really."

 The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will announce tomorrowthat the government is to publish a draft bill to crack down on the arms trade.

The bill will for the first time license the hundreds of brokers dealing in arms in Britain. At present, anyone can set up as an arms dealer.

 Clare Short, the international development secretary, announced an extra £63m in aid to Rwanda targeted on universal primary education, including a teacher training programme using the latest access to information technology. An extra £61m will support primary education in Malawi.

 Defence secretary Geoff Hoon said the government was committed to spending £5bn in new orders for missiles and transport planes for the RAF, as well as new destroyers, amphibious landing ships and air craft carriers for the navy.

Today

11am : Debate on education, with David Blunkett speech

2.15pm onwards: Alan Milburn speech and debate on health

Paul Murphy, speech on Wales

Allistair Darling speech on welfare including vote on pensions

The Family Planning Association's condom demonstrator was stolen overnight from its stand in the hotel Tony Blair is staying in. The rigid piece of red rubber, about 12 inches long, was discovered missing by assocation staff at 8.30am yesterday. Given the tight security on the mini-state's borders, officers suspect it was an inside job.

 The tranquillity of Tonytown has also been broken by the mysterious case of the missing ministerial speech. A porter in Blair's hotel was frantically knocking on doors, asking residents if they had taken delivery of a suprise package. The bigger surprise was saved for the minister left waiting for his speech.

Sitting in the hall hoping to be called, she showed how far has been her fall from grace since hubby Ken took a swipe at the prime minster. The speech started with a very old Labour "Good morning, comrades." As time ticked by and the chair turned a Nelsonian eye, she updated it to "Good afternoon, comrades". Touchingly for one not called, the next line said she had come to conference for 20 years and never succeeded in being called.

 After grabbing a volume on Nelson Mandela to produce a photo pass, security chiefs have now made one for Michael Foot by using a picture of the former Labour leader in his biography of Nye Bevan. Fortunately, Footie looked 87 back in the 1960s when he wrote the book.

 Gordon Brown delayed his return to the Czech Republic and IMF cashfest until yesterday morning, overnighting in Tonytown to sort out his pension problems. "I'm off back to Prague," huffed the chancellor, "because there are fewer protesters."

webTitle: £38,000 for woman who came back from the dead

fields.headline: £38,000 for woman who came back from the dead
fields.trailText: A grandmother who came back from the dead has won a four-year legal battle for compensation after a GP's misdiagnosis brought a hearse and coffin to her cottage door.
fields.body:
A grandmother who came back from the dead has won a four-year legal battle for compensation after a GP's misdiagnosis brought a hearse and coffin to her cottage door.

Maureen Jones, 63, who suffers recurrent nightmares about being buried alive, accepted an out-of-court settlement of £38,000 yesterday from insurers acting on behalf of Marion Meeson, who mistook Mrs Jones's diabetic collapse for a fatal stroke.

Mrs Jones said she was relieved but still severely traumatised by the fact that only an observant policeman, who spotted her leg twitching, had prevented funeral arrangements from going ahead. She said that she and her four children had "been to hell and back" since the near-tragedy in April 1996.

The Medical Defence Union confirmed the payout, only days before a final hearing to settle compensation for the negligence claim which has dragged on since shortly after the incident.

Mrs Jones was found face-down on the bedroom floor of her cottage in Thwing, east Yorkshire, by her son Neil, a shepherd, who called Dr Meeson.

A court hearing in Hull earlier this year was told that Dr Meeson, 46, senior partner in a rural health centre where she is still practising, had been reprimanded after an independent inquiry.

Investigators from Durham health authority found that she had failed to comply with her NHS terms of service and recommended she undergo a period of assessment and support to ensure that she met the standards of best medical practice.

Mrs Jones's three other children were on their way to Thwing, and a hearse had pulled up outside, when PC Kevin Smith, called to the scene with local coroner's officer PC Philip Shrimpton, saw the slight leg movement. He said later that he was "frightened out of his wits", but the two officers cleared Mrs Jones's airways and carried out heart massage.

Mrs Jones, a widow, had opened her eyes by the time a paramedic team arrived to take her to Scarborough hospital, where she later made a full recovery. She has been unable to recall the details of what happened before and during her collapse, and learned about the drama only when her daughter Vicky, a university student, took her through newspaper reports.

Dr Meeson has never spoken about the case, but Mrs Jones's solicitor, Nigel Walshe, said that psychological evidence bore out the likelihood of continuing trauma and continuing difficulties for his client over living with the thought about what might have been. Mrs Jones had moved from Thwing to Bridlington, to escape constant gossip about the incident.

webTitle: Threatened great apes 'will vanish in 10 years'

fields.headline: Threatened great apes 'will vanish in 10 years'
fields.trailText: The great apes, including chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans, face extinction in the wild within a decade unless action is taken on their behalf, an alliance of the world's leading primate experts warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The great apes, including chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans, face extinction in the wild within a decade unless action is taken on their behalf, an alliance of the world's leading primate experts warned yesterday.

Multiple threats are now a fact of life for these members of the anthropoid apes. Their habitats are being destroyed by human encroachment, wars are creating barriers preventing their protection by zoologists, and their carcasses, as highly prized "bushmeat", are ending up on dinner tables, sometimes in Britain.

Jane Goodall, the primatologist and conservationist, warned: "The bushmeat trade, particularly in the great Congo basin, is the worst conservation dilemma Africa has faced in a century. It is no longer stable hunting [practised] by pygmies but hunters from towns going in on trucks and shooting everything, from elephants and chimpanzees to birds and rats."

The meat is not to feed starving people. It is often sold at far higher prices than beef or goat meat and is destined for the plates of the rich.

Dr Goodall called on the west to help African nations enforce conservation laws. She said there was so much corruption, just a small amount of money - but enough to represent a year's salary for some locals - paved the way for bushmeat's passage across international borders.

Chimpanzee carcasses have been found in the kitchens of a Congolese restaurant in Antwerp, and a London butcher was raided by customs and excise last year after he sold investigators a young, endangered red-eared guenon monkey from Nigeria for £350.

Primate meat is often smoked and exported from Africa packed into suitcases. Yesterday, a conservationist accompanied by the Guardian, found bushmeat - in this case a cane rat, a type of large rodent commonly known as a "grasscutter" - for sale at a food shop in Brixton, London.

The shop's staff denied selling monkey meat, but one said: "Chimpanzee are big animals like cattle. If somebody has it in abundance in his country - you eat cows, what is the difference?"

Stephen Brend, UK representative for the International Primate Protection League, said that while the cane rat was not endangered, its availability demonstrated the ease with which meat from wild African animals could be exported and sold in British shops. "Grasscutters are caught in snares which can catch anything. If the avenues exist to get this into the country, I'm sure they can get in other forms of bushmeat."

A coalition of 34 wildlife charities, the Ape Alliance, launched a campaign at the House of Commons yesterday aimed at galvanising public support for primates.

Dr Goodall, who has been studying chimpanzees at Tanzania's Gombe national park for 40 years, told a Commons press conference that chimp numbers had declined dramatically: "There were between one and two million chimpanzees 100 years ago across what was then the equatorial forest belt. There is not a forest belt any more, only shrinking patches of forest. There are at most 200,000 chimpanzees today, probably less, and diminishing all the time."

The press conference heard from an Indonesian representative of an NGO, who spoke of his "shame" at the large scale illegal logging in one of the country's national parks, which involved a timber baron who is also a member of Indonesia's parliament.

Invasion of the jungle by illegal loggers and goldminers threatens the orangutan, which depends on the trees for its survival, getting 90% of its food from the forest.

Another primate, the bonobo, faces extinction in the sole country in which it lives. Jo Thompson, a bonobo specialist, said: "This is the species we are likely to lose first. It only exists in one country, the Democratic Republic of Congo, which has been invaded and occupied by seven nations in the last few years. We can't get any researchers into the field while the war is going on and researchers are the best protection."

The Ape Alliance is urging governments to increase funding for conservation and ensure environmental impact assessments are carried out before Britain allocates aid or loans for development projects.

Sir David Attenborough hosts a public lecture on the future of the great apes, at Westminster Central Hall, Storey's Gate, London SW1, at 7pm tonight.

 Undi, a 10-year-old western lowland gorilla at Bristol zoo, who gave birth two months ago, died yesterday after a short illness. Her baby, Djengi, is being looked after by the zoo's keepers.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Behaviour order on boy, 10
fields.body:
Behaviour order on boy, 10

A 10-year-old boy who terrorised other children on an estate has received a two-year anti-social behaviour order from Walsall magistrates, West Midlands. Walsall council said the child had also used foul and abusive language and interfered with residents' cars.

Professor in jokes row quits

Professor Laurence Goldstein has resigned as head of Wales University's philosophy department following a row over risque jokes he told at a staff Christmas party. A tribunal at the university in Swansea into allegations of inappropriate behaviour and sexual harassment has now been dropped.

Flood warnings for rivers

Flood warnings were issued yesterday by the environment agency as heavy rain continued across much of Britain. Warnings were in place for stretches of the rivers Vyrnwy, Severn, Avon, and Sow.

Court backs extradition

William Beggs, 36, accused of murdering supermarket worker Barry Wallace, 18, whose severed limbs were found at Loch Lomond, yesterday lost his appeal in the Netherlands against extradition back to Scotland.

Guardian names websites chief

Guardian Unlimited has appointed Benjamin Wegg-Prosser as publisher of two websites covering UK politics and the environment, due to launch early next year. Mr Wegg-Prosser, who will oversee the commercial development of the ventures, was formerly a special adviser to Peter Mandelson at the Department of Trade.

webTitle: Melvyn Bragg on the NHS

fields.headline: The best PM we never had
fields.standfirst:
He was a true working class hero, rising from the pits to parliament where he dazzled politicians and public alike with his oratory. The one great pity about Nye Bevan, writes Melvyn Bragg, was that the founding father of the NHS never led the country

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: He was a true working class hero, rising from the pits to parliament where he dazzled politicians and public alike with his oratory. The one great pity about Nye Bevan, writes Melvyn Bragg, was that the founding father of the NHS never led the country.
fields.body:
In the middle of the last century, Nye Bevan was the people's champion. Into the lists he rode, out of the valleys of death, lancing the opposition with his scorn, his wit, his marvellous eloquence. The only one of ours able to take on Churchill who had won the war but brought out the troops against the Welsh miners. Bevan had been a miner and his revenge could get the better of him. "Lower than vermin," he called the Tories and their press lynched him. Boys adopt heroes easily but it is very rare for a politician to qualify. Nye Bevan did.

We relished his melodious oratory, we swallowed whole tall tales of his innate aristocracy (unaware of irony) - he would starve himself for days on end, we told each other, to save up for one really fine meal. He could recite volumes of poetry by heart, understand science and when he spoke in the House of Commons the assembly looked on with awe as at the young Jesus.

But above all he was one of us. He had risen from the pits to the dispatch box and many of us wished that he had gained the leadership. I still think of it as a crucially missed opportunity not only for the Labour party but for the country. He would have brought so much that was new and fresh to leadership. The middle-class socialists who had taken over the parliamentary party (which Bevan rightly saw as the real engine of power) had brought much to the table. Bevan, however, provided what will certainly be the last real chance for a true working-class hero to become a national leader.

The personal qualities he would have brought to it came from a sensibility in the majority but never in the ascendance in this country - what, not too inaccurately, could be called educated working class: but the education bedded in the working.

Nye Bevan knew about the hard unpleasant labour which was the lot of most men and many women at the time he had done it. He knew the value of learning - he had struggled for it in the few leisure hours above ground. He knew about the richness and potential buried in the massed neglect of working-class life. He had seen it all around him. And he knew about the collective will, the strength of communality, the essential importance of democracy and the absolute necessity for change.

Strong leaders make governments and influence the tone and sometimes the character of the country, I believe, and the personality of Bevan would have inspired that major part of our society which still appears to lack the confidence and high ambition found in comparable countries. He would, I think, in his policies and by his example have elevated the condition and the motivation of those thought well below the salt. He would have brought the best of working-class qualities and culture to this country at a time particularly ripe for it.

Just as Churchill represented and helped to release one sort of Britishness in 1940 and Thatcher another in the 80s, so Bevan could have given political expression to that movement of enfranchisement of the many, which characterised the culture of the late 50s and 60s. We have never had a man of the people to lead the people. His death prevented what could have been a very un-British triumph.

His critics will cite against him his belief in the state occupying the commanding the heights of the economy as proof that he would have led the country into the hopeless prison of socialism. But at that time politicians across the parties went along with nationalisation. Even now it could be argued that had some of those heights of the British economy been given the intelligence and the investment afforded them by their counterparts elsewhere - France for instance - then they would be rather more commanding than what has replaced them.

The chief point I would make though is that Bevan was perpetually aware that things must change. Had he seen poverty threatening because wealth producing was being denied he would certainly have reshaped his policies as so many others did.

It is the National Health Service which is his monument, and an intriguing one. It is regularly portrayed now as run down, terminally gone to seed, probably irrelevant to modern demands. In short, Bevan's monument is falling down. Some of its faults have been there since the 40s. The power and masonic arrogance of some of the senior medical men is continuing proof of that deep strain of resistance to the whole enterprise which grew up in the 40s and has never gone away. There were those who said, and were reported and applauded for saying it, that we had fought the Nazis to stop the sort of thing Bevan was doing with the nation's health.

There is also the matter of those 18 years of Conservative neglect which just cannot be reversed in two or three years.

But there are other ways in which Bevan's NHS seems to be at bay. People are living longer, and need more care. Science provides cures which can be hugely expensive and, so it goes, the system of half a century ago built for less healthy days is rapidly becoming insupportable. There is more. The rise of the insecure job-changing individual crossed with an increasingly global economy is at odds with the ethos and delivery of a system built in less demanding, better drilled times. In fact, so this argument goes, socialism will inevitably go the way of Soviet communism, and this marxist NHS, "to each according to his needs", is increasingly marooned in a world view and context far away from the insatiable society of today.

But the oddest thing of all is that despite all this, all the evidence, all the portents, all the complaints, we as a country want Nye Bevan's NHS. We believe in it and cry out most loudly to make it as good as Bevan wanted it to be. In building the NHS, he did what the greatest politicians do: he met the deepest needs of the people he served.

Another conclusion I draw from this is that Bevan found a brilliant way to smuggle his own version of Welsh Labour party socialism through the capitalist triumphalism of the 20th century. The British do indeed want their health service to take care of them "from the cradle to the grave" and they have a faith in the system's potential to do so which defies the often crumbling reality.

Bevan's health service is still called upon to be democratically available to all and equally. To pay no regard to status, income or class but only to need. To engage the whole of society in a true collective. It is high idealism in action.

It may be that as well as the NHS surviving and, who knows, eventually thriving, another factor will be at work. Bevan's credo showing its social effectiveness. Something perhaps to be bred from when called on and the present rush blows its fuse. In every ward and surgery and clinic the man's socialism marches on. That could be an even more powerful legacy.

Another conclusion I draw from this is that Bevan found a brilliant way to smuggle his own version of Welsh Labour party socialism through the capitalist triumphalism of the 20th century. The British do indeed want their health service to take care of them "from the cradle to the grave" and they have a faith in the system's potential to do so which defies the often crumbling reality. Bevan's health service is still called upon to be democratically available to all and equally. To pay no regard to status, income or class but only to need. To engage the whole of society in a true collective. It is high idealism in action. It may be that as well as the NHS surviving and, who knows, eventually thriving, another factor will be at work. Bevan's credo showing its social effectiveness. Something perhaps to be bred from when called on and the present rush blows its fuse. In every ward and surgery and clinic the man's socialism marches on. That could be an even more powerful legacy. This is an edited extract from a speech given by Lord Bragg to the Nye Bevan Society at the Labour party conference last night.

webTitle: Letters; Is anyone listening?

fields.headline: Just listen
fields.body:
Has anyone noticed the alarming transformation of the word "listen" in current usage? It seems that "listening" now involves doing whatever has been asked of you. This has serious implications for democratic government, and for society as a whole. Have we become so selfish that we expect others to do exactly what we tell them? Whatever happened to dialogue?
Dr Anshuman Mondal

webTitle: Mother caught out in rape lie

fields.headline: Mother caught out in rape lie
fields.trailText: A woman who falsely claimed she had been raped and was paid £7,500 compensation was ordered yesterday to serve six months in a young offenders' institution.
fields.body:
A woman who falsely claimed she had been raped and was paid £7,500 compensation was ordered yesterday to serve six months in a young offenders' institution.

Natalie Knighting, 20, a mother of three young children from Newcastle upon Tyne, said she had been raped by a tramp on her way home from a funfair four years ago.

She gave police a detailed description of her purported attacker, but the investigation drew a blank.

By an extraordinary coincidence last year, a man whose DNA profile matched that of the alleged rapist was arrested on an unconnected matter. After Knighting was told, she admitted having made up the rape story, saying she had consented to sex with the man. She also pleaded guilty at Newcastle crown court yesterday to wasting police time.

Judge David Hodson told her that he had thought long and hard about the appropriate grounds for dealing with her. "It is quite clear that you have three young children to bring up, and the consequences of you losing your liberty would be substantial for them.

"You must receive a custodial sentence for these serious offences, but what I do is to substantially reduce the sentence I would otherwise have passed."

Tim Parkin, prosecuting, told the court that Knighting had reported the rape in June 1996 and police had appealed for witnesses. DNA samples had been taken from a number of suspects, but tests had proved negative.

"In December 1998 the defendant made a claim to the criminal injuries compensation board in relation to the rape," he said. An offer of £7,500 was made to her, which she accepted in July 1999.

In August last year a male was arrested on a wholly irrelevant and minor matter. His arrest led to a DNA sample, which was forwarded for analysis in the national DNA database in October.

The sample "matched that which was held in relation to the allegation of rape made by this defendant." She had admitted to officers that her statement had been false.

Mr Parkin said about 140 hours of police time had been wasted, and attempts to recover the £7,500 compensation money had proved fruitless.

Martina Connolly, defending, said Knighting had given birth to her first child three months before the alleged rape and had been suffering from post-natal depression.

"The reason why she did what she did was the care and attention that she got," she said. "She was the centre of attention."

webTitle: Letters; countryside quiet

fields.headline: On the wind
fields.trailText: Much as we have admired Harry Griffin's Country Diary over the years, we must take issue over his latest (Tilting at windmills, September 25). As we stood on Lambrigg Fell at Friday's inauguration we had a very different view. The turbines barely utter a whisper. The roaring traffic from the M6 is clearly visible and audible. It is the road and the traffic, together with other notable blots on the landscape, that are the real monstrosities.
fields.body:
Much as we have admired Harry Griffin's Country Diary over the years, we must take issue over his latest (Tilting at windmills, September 25). As we stood on Lambrigg Fell at Friday's inauguration we had a very different view. The turbines barely utter a whisper. The roaring traffic from the M6 is clearly visible and audible. It is the road and the traffic, together with other notable blots on the landscape, that are the real monstrosities.

The turbines are not "the largest in England": they are efficient, reliable and cost effective. They will provide Kendal with a third of its domestic requirements and will pay for themselves in a few months. Climate change is forecast to cause erosion of the fells, as well as loss of many species of wildlife.

Harry should have a go at the real despoilers of his, and our, wonderful Lake District.
Margaret and Hans Sanders
Kendal
margaret@goosander.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Short's protester comments

fields.headline: A Luddite, and proud of it
fields.trailText: So Clare Short thinks the Prague protesters are Luddites (Finance, September 26). In the same edition you report that German investors plan further takeovers of UK utilities, companies which have been involved in takeovers of Bolivian water companies.
fields.body:
So Clare Short thinks the Prague protesters are Luddites (Finance, September 26). In the same edition you report that German investors plan further takeovers of UK utilities, companies which have been involved in takeovers of Bolivian water companies.

Not all that long ago, domestic water rates in Manchester were equal to about 10% of the general rate. Now water charges are about 30% of the council tax. Globalisation sounds more like burglarisation to me. If that makes me a Luddite in Clare Short's eyes, fine. I'd rather be a Luddite than a Dullite.

Kevin Donnelly
Manchester kevin@kevdon.demon.co.uk

 Clare Short's relentless attempts to divide the protest ers by branding all anti-globalists "Luddites" plays into the hands of that unholy trinity, the World Bank, the IMF and the WTO. She knows that the protesters are angry at a system that allows 19,000 children to die every day from malnutrition, while medicines and foodstuffs are stockpiled by transnational corporations to keep their profits high.

Most of the protesters are in favour of technology and development when it empowers and sustains. But globalisation has created a vacuum of responsibility. The protesters are taking on the responsibility that diplomats, fat cats and many (non-fair trade) consumers are not.

Aaron Payne
Leeds
aaronpeace@hotmail.com

webTitle: Letter: rail safety

fields.headline: Better route to rail safety
fields.trailText: Ian MacKellar from the Association of Train Operating Companies claims (Letters, September 26) that European automatic train protection (ATP) is not yet ready to be installed. So how come commercial contracts have been let or are close to letting for it throughout Europe.
fields.body:
 Ian MacKellar from the Association of Train Operating Companies claims (Letters, September 26) that European automatic train protection (ATP) is not yet ready to be installed. So how come commercial contracts have been let or are close to letting for it in Germany, Italy, Switzerland, Holland and Spain, and that it is under trial in Hungary, Austria and France?

The European technical standards for interoperability (TSIs) are all but finalised and other countries, apparently more concerned about railway safety than we are, have no difficulty in following them. No other European country is wasting half a billion pounds installing an inferior system. The train protection and warning system (TPWS), currently being fitted in Britain, does not work on trains going faster than 74mph and is not computerised. European ATP has many well-known engineering suppliers in competition, whereas we in Britain will be at the mercy of one supplier for TPWS.

My clients, the bereaved and injured of Southall and Ladbroke Grove, know that TPWS would not have prevented Southall and will not prevent more high-speed crashes in the future, which are precisely those that cause the most casualties. For this reason they want the government and the railway industry to abandon TPWS and install European ATP as quickly as possible.
Louise Christian
Southall and Ladbroke Grove Solicitors' Group

webTitle: Letters: Islington is unmoved

fields.headline: Islington is unmoved
fields.trailText: Simon Hoggart (Diary, Saturday Review, September 23) suggests that "the entire population of Islington" might prefer to go to Scotland rather than their regular French haunts. This illustrates a view which for us, the umbrella organisation of Islington's voluntary sector, is all too frequently printed, but is entirely inaccurate.
fields.body:
Simon Hoggart (Diary, Saturday Review, September 23) suggests that "the entire population of Islington" might prefer to go to Scotland rather than their regular French haunts. This illustrates a view which for us, the umbrella organisation of Islington's voluntary sector, is all too frequently printed, but is entirely inaccurate.

The national index of deprivation shows that Islington is the eighth most deprived borough in Britain and the second most deprived in London. Aside from a small bunch of cappuccino-swilling New Labourites, the rest of the borough is not a picture of rosy health, with high levels of poverty, homelessness and ill health. And while the press continues to portray the borough as some wealthy island, it makes it harder for voluntary-sector groups to raise the funds they need to work with Islington's deprived communities.

To cap it all, Simon Hoggart then goes on to report and endorse a taxi-driver's description of the Liberal Democrats as "nice prats". Having recently suffered massive cuts in services, including £2.1m of funding to the voluntary sector, under the local Liberal Democrat council, I don't think many people around here think of the Liberal Democrats as "nice".

David Abse
Islington Voluntary Action Council (IVAC)
ivac@bluebirds.net

 Simon Hoggart's story about his taxi-driver in Bournemouth reminds me of a conversation I had, also with a taxi-driver in Bournemouth. I asked him whether he noticed much difference between Labour and Conservative conference delegates. He said that both tended to ask for receipts for their fare, but the Conservatives usually asked for the amount to be left blank.

Susanna Pressel
Oxford
spressel@lmc.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: PE teachers doing a good job

fields.headline: Gold reserve
fields.trailText: Tony Bayliss (Letters, September 26) says that, as we are on course for a record number of Olympic medals, we should all stop rubbishing schools and recognise the good job being done by school PE teachers.
fields.body:
Tony Bayliss (Letters, September 26) says that, as we are on course for a record number of Olympic medals, we should all stop rubbishing schools and recognise the good job being done by school PE teachers.

I have never heard of cycling, target shooting, sailing, equestrianism being taught at schools. Granted, there are a few that teach rowing, and many more used to teach hockey, swimming and athletics, but that was in the days when sport and PE were part of the school syllabus.

We should be applauding the sports clubs and the dedication of the club coaches and trainers for the part they have played.
Laurie Kerr
Pinner, Middlesex
kerr@lakergate.demon.co.uk

 Sorry, Tony Bayliss, Britain's PE teachers will not get the credit. Chris Woodhead is about to declare that the Olympics are getting easier.
Tony Purcell
Chelmsford, Essex

webTitle: Letters: Art and cooking

fields.headline: The art of criticism
fields.trailText: I don't know much about art but I don't think much of what those young artists are up to.
fields.body:
 I don't know much about art but I don't think much of what those young artists are up to.

And don't talk to me about writing. It's not writing, it's typing. Except on computers. I have had to give up taking the Telegraph because it gave a rave review to a book called All Hail the New Puritans. I tried the Times but they said everyone who cares about literature must go out and buy it. Thank God for Charlotte Raven (Don't mention the A word, September 26), if it wasn't for her, I do not know where I would read the kind of reactionary tripe I love.
Nicholas Blincoe
London

 Three cheers for Delia Smith (Knives out as Delia the bitch bites back, September 26). She has said what I and many others feel about Anthony Worrall Thompson.
SK Dey
Dousland, Devon

 Has Delia Smith been out drinking with William Hague?
Alan Maycock

webTitle: Letters: verdict on Labour

fields.headline: Labour's lost conscience
fields.trailText: • "Bugger all" says Steve Bell's cartoon on Gordon Brown's conference speech. Oh yeah? The Working Families Tax credit has given my family £80 extra per week.
fields.body:
 "Bugger all" says Steve Bell's cartoon on Gordon Brown's conference speech. Oh yeah? The Working Families Tax credit has given my family £80 extra per week.

This tax credit alone symbolises the vast difference between New Labour and the Tories. Bugger all to rich lefties, perhaps, but sticking £10 and £20 notes in the pockets of working-class families has made a real difference. Millions of people like us are in desperate need of another Labour government. More bugger all, please!
Jesse Smith
Penarth, South Glamorgan
jesse@frjesse.freeserve.co.uk

 Now that Gordon Brown has accepted the principle that single pensioners need a minimum income of £90 a week to live on (Brown's pension promise, September 26), where does that leave those living in an unemployment blackspot, forced to go on his New Deal scheme?

An extra £15 on top of Job Seekers Allowance still means you have to cope on less than £65 per week, despite having to put in 30 hours work. I can't help thinking that we're back to the days of the "deserving" and "undeserving" poor, with the jobless being firmly included in the latter category.
Tim Mickleburgh
Grimsby

 I pass the book store above Birmingham New Street Station several times a week (Letters, September 25), and even at the knockdown price of £2, Paul Routledge's biography of the chancellor doesn't seem to be selling. Things can only get better?
Alun Severn
Oldbury, West Mids
alun@ukiah.demon.co.uk

 Your picture of the farmers' protest at the Labour party conference shows them carrying placards with the words "British farmers - use them or lose them". Can we be told if this is a serious offer?
Jeremy Biggs
Kidlington, Oxford
jbiggs@brookes.ac.uk

 It's very dispiriting, within a month of the death of MP Audrey Wise, for your correspondent to suggest (Rattled minister beats retreat, September 26) that Lady Castle alone introduced the link between pensions and earnings in the 70s. It was Audrey Wise and Jeff Rooker who forced this measure through a reluctant Labour cabinet.

Don't you recall the Guardian's many glowing subsequent references to the Rooker-Wise amendment? Evidently someone in Labour does, and that probably accounts for Jeff being despatched to "handle" those unruly pensioners.
Bern Geelan
Bolton
bgeelan@salford-col.ac.uk

 Trying to explain the large number of police in Brighton, I told my four-year old that "the government are here to have a conference", explaining all the terms. To check I'd been clear, I asked her what I'd said. She sighed and replied, "the government are here to get a conscience". If only.
Hannah Richards
Brighton

webTitle: The odd couple

fields.headline: The odd couple
fields.standfirst: Chirac and Jospin fall out of bed
fields.trailText: Given that they are likely rivals for the presidency in 2002, it is a wonder their power-sharing double act lasted as long as it did. But now it is rapidly, very publicly falling apart and the outcome could be immensely damaging to both.
fields.body:
He says it is all untrue. His partner does not believe him. As the couple's friends take sides and third parties are sucked in, each blames the other. Accusations fly; trust is lost; and the relationship begins to crumble. Cohabitation is never easy. It often ends in tears. And after three years in a polite but loveless relationship, French president Jacques Chirac and prime minister Lionel Jospin appear to be no exception. With hindsight, as therapists say, it is plain the two men never had much in common: one a Gaullist, the other a Socialist; one a back-slapping, party-machine patrician, the other a cerebral, rather strait-laced professor. Given that they are likely rivals for the presidency in 2002, it is a wonder their power-sharing double act lasted as long as it did. But now it is rapidly, very publicly falling apart and the outcome could be immensely damaging to both.

The catalyst for this rupture was the discovery last week of a videotape personally implicating Mr Chirac in illegal fundraising for his RPR party while mayor of Paris, prior to 1995. Although the president has frequently been accused of knowing about various Paris town hall slush-funds, voter registration fiddles, kickbacks and payroll frauds, and although investigations into the conduct of the current RPR mayor, Jean Tiberi, have long been in train, the tape appeared to provide the first evidence directly linking Mr Chirac to criminal wrongdoing. Since then, like an ink stain on a tablecloth, the scandal has rapidly spread. On Monday, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, Mr Jospin's finance minister and close associate until he resigned under a cloud last October, admitted he had possessed a copy of the tape in 1998 but had not handed it over to the police. This immediately sparked speculation that Mr Jospin himself knew more than he was admitting, or that his judgment was sadly awry, or that the Socialists were playing dirty tricks to embarrass the president. Mr Chirac, on the record, dismisses the allegations as lies. Mr Jospin, on the record, says his hands are clean.

For democracy's sake if nothing else, it is to be hoped that these rebuttals are entirely and wholly accurate. As so often in the past, it is not the crime itself but the subsequent cover-up that brings disaster. Mr Jospin has already suffered badly in the polls in the wake of the recent fuel protests. His interior minister's defection over his Corsica policy damaged him. Suddenly, despite his tax cuts, economic growth is slowing. Mr Chirac has had his setbacks, too, not least in last Sunday's risible referendum on presidential terms and his leading role in the EU's Austrian debacle. Now the shadows of Mitterrand and Kohl gather around his re-election hopes. Thus at the very moment of their estrangement, this odd couple actually need each other more than ever. And in a very French sort of way, it may be that they will yet succeed in reaching a mutually satisfactory accommodation.

This immediately sparked speculation that Mr Jospin himself knew more than he was admitting, or that his judgment was sadly awry, or that the Socialists were playing dirty tricks to embarrass the president. Mr Chirac, on the record, dismisses the allegations as lies. Mr Jospin, on the record, says his hands are clean. For democracy's sake if nothing else, it is to be hoped that these rebuttals are entirely and wholly accurate. As so often in the past, it is not the crime itself but the subsequent cover-up that brings disaster. Mr Jospin has already suffered badly in the polls in the wake of the recent fuel protests. His interior minister's defection over his Corsica policy damaged him. Suddenly, despite his tax cuts, economic growth is slowing. Mr Chirac has had his setbacks, too, not least in last Sunday's risible referendum on presidential terms and his leading role in the EU's Austrian debacle. Now the shadows of Mitterrand and Kohl gather around his re-election hopes. Thus at the very moment of their estrangement, this odd couple actually need each other more than ever. And in a very French sort of way, it may be that they will yet succeed in reaching a mutually satisfactory accommodation.

webTitle: Safety alert after boy killed in scooter accident

fields.headline: Safety alert after boy killed in scooter accident
fields.trailText: The micro-scooter craze sweeping Britain claimed its first life yesterday when a nine-year-old boy was hit by a taxi and killed in Liverpool, bringing calls to remove the trendy toys from the roads.
fields.body:
The micro-scooter craze sweeping Britain claimed its first life yesterday when a nine-year-old boy was hit by a taxi and killed in Liverpool, bringing calls to remove the trendy toys from the roads.

Aaron Jennings was riding his scooter down a busy road in Anfield in the rush hour when he was hit by a black cab. He died from his injuries in hospital.

Tony Hegarty, the boy's headteacher, said that he understood he had been in a group of seven or eight children playing on scooters after school. A witness said: "He obviously thought he could get across the road on the scooter. The taxi driver had no chance to stop."

Roger Vincent, of the Royal Society of the Prevention of Accidents, warned that unless micro-scooters were taken off the road, more deaths would follow. "This death is our worst fear come true. We have been warning parents for several weeks to make their children aware of the danger.

"Children and adults should not ride these scooters in the road, under any circumstance. They should not cross the road on them, as motorists do not expect to find them on the road and can be easily surprised. Children are not in full control on these scooters, most of which do not have brakes.

"In 1998, 2,200 people in the UK were involved in accidents involving children's scooters. If you consider this was before the craze started, we expect to have a problem on our hands this year.

"Micro-scooter incidents in the US have risen by 700% since May. Most involved children under 15 who had taken scooters on to the road. We have to learn a lesson from that." Carol Sherriff, director of the Child Accident Prevention Trust, warned parents not to let their children out on micro-scooters unless they were in a safe area, off the road.

Micro-scooters are similar in shape to normal push scooters, but are made of aircraft grade aluminium - making them foldable and easy to carry. Push-started, they can reach speeds of 20mph.

Designed by Wim Ouboter, a Swiss inventor, they appeared on the market in 1998. But demands for the Ouboter scooters outstripped production, and there are 20 imitation brands on the market. More than 8,000 a week are sold in the UK, at an average of £90 each; around 60% are sold in London.

A Department of Transport spokesman said that use of scooters on pavements and roads was probably illegal, but it was a grey area of the law.

"It would appear that these scooters are covered by the same 1835 Highways Act that prevents cycles being ridden on pavements. But it is a matter for police to consider in local circumstances. This needs to be tested in court. It is a very tricky area."

He said parents should make children aware of the dangers of micro-scooters. They should only be ridden on private land because they were not suitable for road use. "All protection helps, and cycle helmets are very important, but we also recommend that knee and elbow pads are worn when riding these machines."

A spokeswoman for the corporation of London said that the City of London was involved in legal efforts to ban micro-scooters from paved walkways because of the danger they caused. She said a ban would not be enforced until early next year.

Brian Croft, trading standards manager for Liverpool, said that trading standards officers all over Britain had received complaints about safety in the past fortnight.

Importers Olop Leisure Group and retailers Woolworths were banned from selling the 900TT model of scooter this month after it failed part of a toy safety standard test.

A 10-year-old girl from Slough had the top of her finger sliced off and a 15-year-old from Essex was injured when part of the folding mechanism trapped his finger. "Accidents can range from children falling off scooters to misuse, incorrect assembly, and design and safety defects," Mr Croft said.

"The problem with micro-scooters is that because they are a craze, new models imported from Taiwan and China are coming on to the market all the time.

"British law does not require manufacturers to tell us how they have been tested. So we are at the mercy of importers and manufacturers to conduct their own safety tests. "

webTitle: Young are a beacon of hope for new Serbia

fields.headline: Young are a beacon of hope for new Serbia
fields.standfirst:
The future: Optimism and uncertainty

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Few Serbs are more delighted with the opposition's apparent election victory than Natasha Kandic, founder and director of the Humanitarian Law Centre in Belgrade.
fields.body:
Few Serbs are more delighted with the opposition's apparent election victory than Natasha Kandic, founder and director of the Humanitarian Law Centre in Belgrade.

She is champing to get back to the frontline where she has been working for several months with the student-based resistance movement, Otpor, which sparked the first major protests against Slobodan Milosevic's rule this spring and summer.

"This victory is a victory for young people," she told the Guardian in London, where she picked up an international human rights award last night.

"For the first time we have young people without any nationalistic views. They represent something new, hopeful, innocent, and with no burden of responsibility for the last 10 years."

Several hundred members of Otpor have been questioned by Serbian police and briefly detained this year. Some have had to go into hiding. "Otpor young people voted for [the leader of the democratic opposition] Vojislav Kostunica of course, but they did it from a distance. No one in the opposition, except for one party - Civic Alliance - gave them support when they needed it," she said.

For all her optimism that the opposition's election victory has "created space for discussion and change", Ms Kandic has a sense of foreboding. "Ordinary people refuse to think about next week. They just want to keep up this atmosphere of celebration. Milosevic is trying to buy time and decide what to do. He is surprised, angry and scared, and he may use force."

Long before the Kosovo crisis reached a head with Nato's intervention, Ms Kandic and her small team of human rights workers regularly visited Kosovo to compile evidence of abuse by Serb police and Albanian freedom-fighters.

They were almost the only Serbs who took an interest in atrocities by Serb forces. Now she campaigns for Albanians held in Serbian prisons, as well as for Serbs from Kosovo who were abducted by Albanian revenge-seekers after Nato-led troops reached the province.

"Two days after the bombing started, I went to Pristina. I saw a city without people. I saw fear. Maybe there will soon be the same atmosphere in Belgrade. Perhaps we cannot reach peace in Serbia without going through the same things as the other peoples of former Yugoslavia," she says.

Some Albanians have called Ms Kandic a "Serbian Schindler". On one occasion, at the height of the ethnic cleansing in Kosovo last year, she drove to Prizren to rescue the wife and young son of Baton Haxhiu, the editor of the newspaper Koha Ditore, who had been reported missing.

Last month she had an astonishing exchange of letters in a Belgrade newspaper with the information officer of the general staff of the Yugoslav army, who accused her of supporting terrorism.

In her reply Ms Kandic wrote: "In Serbia today, the authorities put everyone, including children, under suspicion of being terrorists. When anyone dares to raise the question of the responsi bility of the Yugoslav army, you respond with secret trials. I am one of those people who refuses to remain silent, even at the cost of being brought to trial by you.

"I will not remain silent about the horrors your generals sent young recruits to witness in Kosovo. I can still see the anguish on the faces of 20-year-olds who gave their rations of milk, bread and cheese to Kosovo-Albanian mothers and children driven from their homes by the army and police.

"The road from Kosovoska Mitrovice to Pec and Djakovica on April 14 and 15 is engraved on my memory: a column of Albanian civilians, young soldiers going up to them with tears in their eyes, pleading with them to accept their food, to forgive them, saying it was not their fault, that their officers ordered them to Kosovo, that they did not know where they were being taken. Young soldiers were the bright light of humanity and life in other localities of Kosovo too.

"If you can find no one else to hold accountable for these events, you may count on me. I stand here and plead guilty because I did nothing to prevent these crimes from being committed. You rebuke me for not praising the Yugoslav army, the astuteness of its commanding generals, its high morale, good tactics and ingenious camouflaging. Do you really think the people of Serbia believe you fought against a flesh and blood enemy, those you label 'Nato criminals', and you won? Every casualty of the bombing is your casualty too.

She was the first recipient last night of a new $50,000 (£34,000) award offered by the Northcote Parkinson Fund of New York for "civil courage - resisting evil at great personal risk".

webTitle: Suspensions for two in drunken sailors case

fields.headline: Suspensions for two in drunken sailors case
fields.trailText: The captain of a 100,000-tonne oil tanker who sparked a sea rescue after attempting to sail back to his ship in force six gales after a four-hour drinking session, was declared fit to serve at sea by a tribunal yesterday.
fields.body:
The captain of a 100,000-tonne oil tanker who sparked a sea rescue after attempting to sail back to his ship in force six gales after a four-hour drinking session, was declared fit to serve at sea by a tribunal yesterday.

But the hearing ruled that Clive Mottram, of Southampton, had been negligent and incompetent in charge of his duties.

His captain's licence was suspended for 14 months, but he will be able to take up a captaincy at sea next year as he has already been suspended for six months.

His chief engineer John Blamires, from Buxton, Derbyshire, was also found guilty of negligence and misconduct and had his licence suspended for six months by the tribunal at Eastleigh magistrates court, Hampshire.

Coastguards had been forced to launch a hazardous rescue mission to save the group of four sailors who were attempting to sail 13 miles back to their ship, the Macro Clyde, in March.

After an afternoon of heavy drinking in the fishing village of Macduff, near Aberdeen, they received a call urging them to return to the tanker.

As they attempted to steer their 16ft craft Sea Rider from the harbour, they collided with a wall. Six miles out to sea, the craft was hit by a wave and started to take on water.

Lionel Persey QC, who chaired the inquiry, said both Mottram and Blamires had previously unblemished records. When they were rescued, their alcohol levels were below the drink drive limit.

webTitle: Duck gets the bird from West End show

fields.headline: Duck gets the bird from West End show
fields.trailText: A duck has been dropped from a West End show because it cost four times more to employ than an actor.
fields.body:
A duck has been dropped from a West End show because it cost four times more to employ than an actor.

The comedy review, Arthur Smith sings Leonard Cohen, which opens at the New Ambassadors theatre near Leicester Square, London, on Friday, was to feature a two minute appearance by a duck, wheeled in on a tea trolley to the song Like a Bird on a Wire.

After trial runs of the show in Bath, where a Muscovy duck called George took to the stage at the standard rate of £250 a day - replaced by another duck after he became tense backstage - Smith decided it was cheaper to hire an actor in a duck suit for the union minimum of £292.84 a week.

"I feel quite down about this," said Smith. "Keeping the duck would have bankrupted me, so I've decided to give the part to an unemployed actor.

"How far down the food chain are actors if their worth is a quarter of a bird's? I paid for the duck myself; I wouldn't have minded if it had got a laugh, but it got no laughs at all, so I thought sod it."

Liz Rutherford, a director of Janimals 2, the firm which provided George the duck, said the charges were reasonable because ducks required training, insurance and a handler at all times. "You cannot just go and haul any old duck off a pond to do this type of work," she said.

webTitle: Serbian opposition parties plan nightly demonstrations

fields.headline: Serbian opposition parties plan nightly demonstrations
fields.standfirst:
Celebrations: Cede power, Milosevic told

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Euphoric but apprehensive, Serbia's opposition parties have planned a victory concert in Belgrade tonight, despite the state election commis sion's call for a runoff in the presidential contest.
fields.body:
Euphoric but apprehensive, Serbia's opposition parties have planned a victory concert in Belgrade tonight, despite the state election commis sion's call for a runoff in the presidential contest.

Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition leader, has already said he will accept nothing less than a first-round victory.

With 97% of the votes counted, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia said yesterday that by its unofficial tally Mr Kostunica had 54.6% and Slobodan Milosevic 35%.

This result was supported by both the Belgrade-based Cen tre for Free Elections and Democracy and the far-right Serbian Radical party which ran its own candidate and is still nominally part of President Milosevic's coalition.

Cedomir Jovanovic, the opposition spokesman, said: "It is absolutely certain we have won, and so we request the federal election commission to erase all suspicion and not misuse this critical situation."

He called on Mr Milosevic's Socialist party of Serbia and the Yugoslav United Left party to respect the popular will and cede power. If this did not happen, he said the opposition would protest peacefully.

Meanwhile Miroslav Hristodulo, deputy president of the Social Democratic Union, said before yesterday's runoff announcement that if the election commission denied Mr Kostunica outright victory, nightly demonstrations would take place from tomorrow.

Asked about the future of Serbian hardliners who have been indicted by the international criminal tribunal in the Hague, he said Mr Kostunica's plan was retribution rather than revenge. There would be proper law and proper trials, he said.

Few observers believed that the opposition would come together so smoothly to give the country's disillusioned voters a respected figure to support.

Massive campaigns to mobilise voters were organised by non-governmental groups, women's organisations and the student resistance group Otpor.

Another opposition tactic - to provide an efficient and credible vote-reporting service - caught the Milosevic regime off guard.

Politika, a pro-government newspaper, published partial local election results yesterday that noted opposition victories in many towns.

A Socialist party spokesman, Ivica Dacic, also admitted at a press conference that the government had lost some towns, but declared its overwhelming victory in parliamentary elections. He made no mention of the presidential poll. Some saw this as a sign that the government would eventually back down.

"If they have already recognised such a crushing defeat in all the municipalities, there is no chance for them to tamper with other results now," said Mladjan Dinkic, coordinator of the G-17 Plus group of academics and professionals.

In another sign of the opposition leader's acceptance within the country, the head of the Serbian Orthodox church, Patriarch Pavle, received Mr Kostunica yesterday.
