webTitle: Five Britons deported in crackdown on Olympics ticket touts

fields.headline: Five Britons deported in crackdown on Olympics ticket touts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Australian officials are to deport five British ticket touts following a crackdown on the illegal selling of tickets for the Olympic Games.
fields.body:
Australian officials are to deport five British ticket touts following a crackdown on the illegal selling of tickets for the Olympic Games.

Police in Sydney have arrested 10 touts, five of them British, who have been asking for as much as 50% more than the face value of tickets, particularly for events involving Australia. Tickets for some athletics finals with a face value of £35 have been changing hands for almost £200. One British tout arrested in central Sydney was carrying almost £4,000 in cash.

Police have swooped on a number of ticket touts' rackets operating in the city's bars. In one raid, police found 400 tickets for Olympic events with a face value of £20,000.

Since the start of the games last week, scores of mainly British touts have been attempting to sell tickets in central Sydney and outside a number of games venues, prompting a cat and mouse game as police and Olympic officials tried to clamp down on them.

One British tout has already been handed over to immigration officials and is expected to be deported, with two others. Going back to the UK by the end of the week will be a number of other touts. Australian officials said that all the Britons had breached holiday visa restrictions barring them from commercial activity, and that special Olympic laws introduced in Sydney also made touting illegal.

In Australia, ticket touting is known as "scalping". A spokesman for Sydney police said: "Some of the scalpers [touts] have obviously been involved in well organised operations with huge turnovers. We will not tolerate touting of any sort." Olympic and local officials said that while they had acted against some touting operations, several others were still going on.

Many of the touts in Sydney said they usually worked outside Premier League grounds and other big sporting events in Britain and that they had enjoyed lucrative trade at the games. With thousands of people in the city, there are rich pickings to be had for touts, particularly from visitors from Japan and east Asia.

One tout from west London, said: "It's been a great chance to come over, have a holiday and make some money. I obtained these tickets legitimately from a travel company in England. We have not done anything wrong. Many of the tickets seized have just led to empty seats at events, stopping genuine fans getting in."

One British tout has already been handed over to immigration officials and is expected to be deported, with two others. Going back to the UK by the end of the week will be a number of other touts. Australian officials said that all the Britons had breached holiday visa restrictions barring them from commercial activity, and that special Olympic laws introduced in Sydney also made touting illegal. In Australia, ticket touting is known as "scalping". A spokesman for Sydney police said: "Some of the scalpers [touts] have obviously been involved in well organised operations with huge turnovers. We will not tolerate touting of any sort." Olympic and local officials said that while they had acted against some touting operations, several others were still going on. Many of the touts in Sydney said they usually worked outside Premier League grounds and other big sporting events in Britain and that they had enjoyed lucrative trade at the games. With thousands of people in the city, there are rich pickings to be had for touts, particularly from visitors from Japan and east Asia. One tout from west London, said: "It's been a great chance to come over, have a holiday and make some money. I obtained these tickets legitimately from a travel company in England. We have not done anything wrong. Many of the tickets seized have just led to empty seats at events, stopping genuine fans getting in."

webTitle: Who killed the Robin?  French blamed for death of cult three-wheeler

fields.headline: Who killed the Robin?  French blamed for death of cult three-wheeler
fields.trailText: Despite 65 years of ridicule, 44,000 drivers of three-wheeled cars and vans yesterday joined the actor David Jason in lamenting the decision to phase out their cherished Reliants - the last British three-wheelers on the road.
fields.body:
Despite 65 years of ridicule, 44,000 drivers of three-wheeled cars and vans yesterday joined the actor David Jason in lamenting the decision to phase out their cherished Reliants - the last British three-wheelers on the road.

The eccentric vehicles won popularity, despite their shaky looking singular front wheel, because, weighing in at 450kg, a motorcycle licence is all that is required to drive one.

With their rust-proof fibreglass body and low fuel consumption they also built a reputation as budget vehicles that would last.

"There goes a bit of British comic history," said Mr Jason, who brought the Reliant Regal three-wheeled van to global fame - in "New York, Paris and Peckham" - as Del Boy Trotter's "company car" in the 1980s BBC television series Only Fools and Horses.

The shabby yellow three-wheeler, painted with the logo "Trotters Independent Traders", took Del Boy, his brother, Rodney, and their grandad around the markets of south London.

Recently the three-wheelers have fared poorly against French-built four-wheeled microcars, which can also be driven without a full licence.

Noel Palmer, spokesman for Reliant Cars, said that after 65 years of almost continuous production, many three-wheeler owners were turning to the French- made, high economy Ligier Ambra, costing about half the price of the hand manufactured Robin which retails at almost £10,000.

"There will be a lot of disgruntled owners but we need to expand the Reliant cars in other areas," he said.

"We have been importing the Ligiers and have sold almost 700 through our Reliant dealership network in the last 12 months. The Ligier Ambra is a more modern car, it has four wheels and you can still drive it on a bike licence."

Jim O'Meara, who owns Reliant Services garage in Stirchley, Birmingham, said the news was not unexpected. "[Reliant] have shot themselves in the foot."

"They decided to bring in a four-wheel vehicle you can drive with a motorcycle licence. Two French firms have done the same and undercut them.

"It's not surprising. If they would cut the price in half, they would have been able to keep going."

Mr Palmer said he sympathised with the anger of some Robin dealers and owners but the marque "which has almost become a British institution" could not be sustained.

"Robins are bought by traditional and loyal buyers," he said. "A lot of them are on their 10th or 12th car; but they are an elderly and a very niche market."

Mr Palmer said the end of the Robin would not mean job losses at the Burntwood production line in Staffordshire. He said: "Because of our increase in the import business, all the existing staff have been redeployed.

"We will reorganise the factory for a new model, not a three-wheeler, to be announced at the Birmingham motor show in October."

Meanwhile, Mr Palmer tried to placate three-wheel enthusiasts by announcing a special edition Robin 65s to roll off the production line until the end of the year.

It will have chrome door handles, a walnut dashboard, a stainless steel exhaust, and, of course, three alloy wheels.

On the road to fame

 The Robin appeared in the 1977 film Star Wars. Luke Skywalker's hovering landspeeder was built around one.

 In 1989 a Cheshire firm was reported to be giving Robins to sales staff who failed to meet their targets.

 In 1992 traffic police in Kent were overtaken by a customised Robin, fitted with a 1000cc Nissan engine, at 102mph.

 In 1997 repair and delivery staff at the the US embassy in London introduced a fleet of Robins to get around quickly.

 A 20 stone Yorkshire trucker said this year he had two sacks of potatoes in the passenger seat to stop his tipping over.

webTitle: Pre-election sops are out, Brown tells World Bank

fields.headline: Pre-election sops are out, Brown tells World Bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown underlined his determination to resist calls for vote-winning concessions on fuel and pensions yesterday when he ruled out a pre-election upgrade in the economy's annual growth rate - a move which would add billions of pounds to his budget surplus.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown underlined his determination to resist calls for vote-winning concessions on fuel and pensions yesterday when he ruled out a pre-election upgrade in the economy's annual growth rate - a move which would add billions of pounds to his budget surplus.

Laying out his goal of beefing up Britain's growth rate over the next four years as part of a nationwide drive to increase productivity, Mr Brown said that - although the economy had consistently outperformed pessimistic Treasury assumptions - it was too soon to plan spending on a more generous trend growth rate.

"We will not fall into the trap of basing our approach to economic policy including fiscal policy on the potential for improvement in trend growth before this has been demonstrably achieved," Mr Brown told delegates at the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual meetings in Prague.

"So we will continue over the coming year with the same deliberately prudent approach to the public finances."

There had been speculation that, with an election likely next year, Mr Brown would increase the estimate of the sustainable growth rate for planning the public finances to 2.5%, the growth rate the Treasury considers to be consistent with non-inflationary long term growth.

But, in a reference to the "boom and bust" of the late 1980s which led to the largest ever peace time deficit, Mr Brown declared: "We will not make the old British mistake of assuming that a cyclical improvement in the public fi nances automatically means a structural improvement."

Shortly after the general election, Labour cut the estimate of the trend rate of growth from the 2.5% figure which the Conservatives used to plan public finances to 2.25%.

The Treasury's goal is to raise the sustainable growth rate to 2.75% over the next four years, an objective which Mr Brown said was achievable.

The Chancellor said Britain had much to learn from the American economy, which has enjoyed high growth, low inflation and rising productivity for most of the 1990s.

"It [the US] has shown how combining stability and fiscal prudence with high levels of investment, particularly in the new information technologies, can lead to sustained productivity improvements and more higher skilled employment.

"Our challenge is through a national productivity drive to bridge the 30% gap with our competitors which still exists."

An upward revision to the trend growth assumption would have the effect of swelling Treasury coffers because it would allow a lower forecast for unemployment and welfare spending and a higher forecast for tax receipts. Experts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies estimate that raising the assumption of the trend rate of growth would give the chancellor an extra £1.4bn to play with in next year's Budget and £2.8bn the following year.

But in reality the public coffers are awash with cash and the government has already pencilled in big rises in spending on health, education and transport in coming years so has no need to pull any book-keeping stunt to give itself any more money.

webTitle: International: new in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Eight people were killed and three injured when two helicopters carrying tourists collided over western Switzerland yesterday, police said.
fields.body:
Mid-air collision kills eight

Eight people were killed and three injured when two helicopters carrying tourists collided over western Switzerland yesterday, police said.

The two Air Glaciers helicopters crashed on to a football pitch near the town of Beuson. One Swiss pilot died and a number of Indians were among the victims, a spokesman said.

Reuters, Zurich.

French video claims denied

The former French finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, yesterday denied he had been given a videocassette detailing graft allegations against President Jacques Chirac in exchange for granting the fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld a tax break.

Mr Strauss-Kahn told French radio the claims were "a tremendous diversion" to draw attention from Mr Chirac.

Jon Henley, Paris

Arab numbers grow in holy city

Jerusalem's Arab population is growing at three times the pace of the Jewish population, according to a study released by the Jerusalem Institute for Israel Studies yesterday.

About two-thirds of the city's approximately 646,000 population are Jewish but the study found the Jewish portion was at a new low at the end of 1999.

Reuters, Jerusalem

£1,550 for Walesa pipe

A Polish man spent a quarter of his life savings on a tobacco pipe used by the former Solidarity trade union hero and ex-president of Poland, Lech Walesa, it was reported yesterday. The man, a tailor, paid £1,550 at an auction for a children's charity.

Reuters, Warsaw

webTitle: US sends ancient bones back to grave

fields.headline: US sends ancient bones back to grave
fields.trailText: A 9,000-year-old skeleton, one of the oldest and most complete sets of bones ever found in North America, will return to the grave after a ruling that elevated cultural claims over scientific research.
fields.body:
A 9,000-year-old skeleton, one of the oldest and most complete sets of bones ever found in North America, will return to the grave after a ruling that elevated cultural claims over scientific research.

The US government ruled that Kennewick Man, found four years ago in a mud bank of the Columbia river in Washington state, should be returned to five native American tribes for burial rather than subjected to further study.

But scientists who believe that Kennewick Man's features owe more to the ancient peoples who once populated Asia or Europe than to native Americans suggested that the decision was based on political correctness, and not on the evidence at hand.

Some say that the skeleton, whose age is put at between 9,320 and 9,510 years, gives credence to the idea that ancient Europeans or Asians lived in North America before the tribes, a concept seized upon by white supremacist groups.

Bruce Babbitt, the interior secretary, said he had arrived at his ruling on the basis of cultural affiliation, geographical data and oral history.

A group of scientists from the Smithsonian Institute and across the US are hoping to contest the ruling in court, as it appears to contradict a judgment in the case of the 10,000-year-old Spirit Cave Man, found 60 years ago in Nevada. Last month a judge ruled that the skeleton is of native American origin but cannot be affiliated to any contemporary tribe and can thus can be studied.

webTitle: Arts: Arthur Smith Sings Leonard Cohen

fields.headline: Has anyone here seen Leonard?
fields.standfirst: When  Arthur Smith  heard a rumour that Leonard Cohen was visiting New York, he immediately went on the trail of his hero
fields.trailText: When Arthur Smith heard a rumour that Leonard Cohen was visiting New York, he immediately went on the trail of his hero.
fields.body:
"Where are you going?" The man on reception looked at me suspiciously. "Er, I want to go in the lift - sorry, the elevator - and sing a song." "If you're not a resident, you can't go in the elevator." He noticed my disappointment and softened. "But you can sing as much as you like in the lobby."

The Chelsea Hotel in New York has had some distinguished guests. Brendan Behan, Arthur Miller, Dylan Thomas and Mark Twain are all commemorated on plaques outside the grubby entrance. I had come to seek out a wild man of rock'n'roll whose stay goes unrecorded. Not Sid Vicious (who murdered Nancy Spungeon in one of the rooms) but Leonard Cohen, whose strange, beautiful, lugubrious songs I have lately inhabited.

I wasn't expecting to find him in the lobby - he checked out 35 years ago - but I had reliable information that he was in town and might be found at one of the New York fashion shows. This sounded improbable until I remembered Cohen's great fascination with the calibrations of his lust for beautiful young women. I had wangled tickets to the show in question.

The show was the next day. In the meantime I had come to the hotel that gave its name to a song about his affair with Janice Joplin. In his introduction to Chelsea Hotel #2 he recalls meeting her in the elevator. "Are you looking for someone?" he ventured. "Sure, I'm looking for Kris Kristofferson." Cohen, who once wrote a song called Don't Go Home With Your Hard-on, was not one to pass up on an opportunity. "Little lady, you're in luck. I am Kris Kristofferson." However strung out on human growth hormone Joplin was, she could hardly have mistaken the small dark Jewish man for the tall muscular Aryan; but, as Cohen says, "They were generous times..."

My girlfriend was relieved that my failure to penetrate the elevator had saved her from having to play out this dialogue but listened dutifully as I started droning away. Her friend looked alarmed and then concerned. Two elderly French tourists scuttled out of the lobby, The bell boy, meanwhile, began to hum along. I was not surprised by this, as I have discovered ever since I became the world's only Leonard Cohen tribute band that there is a large mass of secret fans out there, not at all like the speccy Norwegians who live in his various websites.

Their perversion is clandestine because most people who have heard of Leonard think of his songs as painful dirges, and to confess a liking for them invites jokes about razorblades. He is seen, as he ruefully concedes, as "the captain of gloom".

This is partly why I chose to do a show called Arthur Smith Sings Leonard Cohen on the Edinburgh fringe this year. The title seems to suggest the grimmest evening of entertainment imaginable. If people complained that it wasn't funny, then I would say, "Well, what did you expect with a brief like that?" Having booked to do the show in London, I'd decided to try to find him to seek permission to do his songs and generally make him realise what a great guy I am. This was never going to be easy, given that in 1996 Cohen became an ordained monk in a zen monastery in California and took the name Jikan, which means "the silent one". I'd been told, however, that he was often away from the monastery at the moment, and he was eager to revisit New York.

I wangled my way into the fashion show through the auspices of Lucy Sykes, the fashion editor of Marie Claire. I had a number of stereotypical ideas about what a fashion show is like, and all of them turned out to be true. An ocean of cameras, bright lights and skinny girls. There were air-kissings, "darlings" and "sweeties" to shame a festival-load of actors. I was squinting across the catwalk looking for Leonard when I found myself in conversation with Ivana Trump, who is, I realised, Zsa Zsa Gabor by another name. I asked her what she thought of my outfit. She said, "My daughter often wears sandals like those. She has a black belt in shopping." This seemed like reasonable praise, but then there was a caveat. "She only wears them on the beach."

Lucy was networking with wild abandon. She introduced me to a famous fashion photographer (I forget his name), "America's leading dermatologist", the supermodel Giselle and then, most excitingly, Eva Herzigova, the prominent bra model. I was rather overpowered by her height and beauty but was determined not to wither before them. I tried to think of something to say that she hadn't heard before. The result was, "You're very ugly." She looked pained and I went red, but then she laughed. For about 24 minutes we got on very well. She suggested she might make her West End debut as one of my backing singers. But don't bank on it.

I never met Leonard Cohen, of course. If he was there, he was somewhere beyond the lights. I'm not quite sure what I would have said anyway. "Len, I'm doing a comedy show and I sing a bit of some of your songs. Is that OK?" It would have been much more intimidating than meeting my old mates Ivana and Eva. It was nearly enough to stand in the foyer of a seedy hotel at 222 West 23rd Street and commune with him in my silly, show-off way. Nearly, but not quite. I still want to find him. I doubt if he reads the Guardian, but if you do, Leonard, where are you? I'm waiting.

Arthur Smith Sings Leonard Cohen is at the New Ambassadors, London WC2 (020-7369 1761), on Fridays and Saturdays till October 27.

webTitle: Arts: The Crucible

fields.headline: 'You can't market rubbish. Well, you can - but the audience won't come back again'
fields.standfirst: Lyn Gardner  meets the double act who cracked the secret of regional theatre
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner meets the double act who cracked the secret of regional theatre.
fields.body:
The time has come to stop writing the obituary of regional theatre. The Arts Council's promise to inject £37m in additional funding, in-sufficient though it is, has helped to create a psychological transformation in an area that had suffered 20 years of underfunding. But even before the news came through, there were signs that plenty of regional theatres were no longer going to sit around waiting to be put out of their misery.

At Northern Stage at Newcastle Playhouse, Alan Lyddiard, inspired by the work of Peter Brook, Alain Platel and Lev Dodin of the Maly, has created an ensemble to match the National Theatre's. What's more, in his productions of A Clockwork Orange, a factory-style Romeo and Juliet and the current The Ballroom of Romance, he has created a body of work with wide appeal that speaks directly to its community. Audiences have risen by 20%.

At the Octagon in Bolton, where Lawrence Till had been doing such unsung work for so long, the local community suddenly woke up to the fact that if they didn't use it they'd lose it and mounted a fierce campaign to save the theatre as a producing venue.

Part of the new optimism is simply the result of musical chairs: Till's move to Watford and Giles Croft's to Nottingham Playhouse. At Sheffield, Michael Grandage, whose As You Like It topped anything the RSC could offer last season, is now spearheading the artistic vision, and Joseph Fiennes has committed to playing Edward II there in the spring.

But it is in Colchester, not renowned as a hotbed of theatrical innovation, that the greatest miracle has taken place. Two years ago the Mercury was teetering on the brink of closure, and hardly seemed worth saving. It's still not out of the woods, but it is held in respect by its local community and seen as a beacon of hope by other regional theatres. Its transformation is a lesson in how the survival of regional theatre is about not just money but also the will and the vision to reinvent yourself.

Two years ago I went to a press conference about the new plans for the Mercury. There was only me and a man from The Stage there. The Mercury's new chief executive, Dee Evans, talked about the theatre's "do or die", artistically led policy. There would be no more productions of Shirley Valentine put on simply because a one-woman show means only one cast member has to be paid.

Instead, the Mercury would create a small company of actors and stage plays that Evans and her artistic associate Gregory Floy had a passion for. I remember leaving the press conference admiring their guts but suspecting that nine months or so hence I'd be hearing of the theatre's demise.

I was wrong. That first season included What the Butler Saw, the British premiere of Eric Emanuel Schmidt's Don Juan on Trial, and an excellent Uncle Vanya. The next offered a well-reviewed Richard III and A Streetcar Named Desire; the one after, The Duchess of Malfi and a witty The Provok'd Wife. Audiences for classic drama have risen by 38%, proving that art and audiences are not mutually exclusive. This autumn they can see The Crucible and Waiting for Godot. "I think that we and our audience are just about ready for Beckett," says Floy, and indeed advance sales are looking good.

Recognition of the theatre's new lease of life has come with funding and support from the local council and, a year ago, £350,000 recovery funding from the Arts Council. It is the first theatre to receive such money.

Like Alan Lyddiard at Northern Stage, Evans and Floy realised that one of the problems with most regional theatres was that actors had become the least valued, least well- paid and least permanent members of the team. Years of crisis had seen the numbers of administrative and marketing staff increase, while less and less money was spent on production and performances. When Evans arrived at the Mercury, an actor playing a lead role could expect to be paid the same weekly wage as the wardrobe assistant. The lack of value theatre places on actors was also one of the things that Lyddiard set out to right when he founded the Northern Stage ensemble in 1997.

Evans is not against marketing; she simply points out that "you can't market rubbish. Well, you can, but the audience won't come back a second time." The Mercury's strategy has been to invest in productions and actors: each season now begins with a training week for the performers, a move that initially met with some resistance from the actors, who saw it as remedial work, but is now welcomed.

The ensemble this session consists of 18 actors: 12 who have previously been at Colchester - and six newcomers. "We didn't want to go back to the old rep company idea," explains Evans. "Having the same company from year to year can be stultifying." Instead the theatre through-casts a season as much as possible and involves everyone in education and community work. The actor who leads a school workshop will be the same one that plays Richard III.

Underlying all this is a belief in the role of the artist in society. One of the desperate things about regional theatre in recent years is that it has crushed the artistic vision out of those involved. For many, meeting performance targets, balancing the books and justifying the subsidy have become a raison d' tre rather than a by-product of a thriving theatre. Evans firmly believes that we need regional theatres such as the Mercury because they contribute to the desire, articulated by the philosopher RG Collingwood, "that most people want a better life". If that means making money by doing some canny co-productions with commercial managements, so be it, but it also means putting the theatre at the heart of the community.

The Mercury has 500 seats and Evans knows that if it had had 800 or 1,000 the task of keeping the theatre not just open but thriving as a producing house would have been far harder. The Mercury is not in the clear yet, but it is past the crises of the kind that occurred a month after Evans arrived. Then she was told that there was money left for two weeks of wages and then it would be curtains.

But if neither Evans or Floy are keen to have the Mercury held up as a model of how regional theatres should run, arguing that successful theatres depend on the dynamics of the particular group of people working there, they are encouraging evidence that the combination of an injection of energy, vision and cash can turn an ailing theatre around and make it worth saving. Evidence too, as Lyddiard has found at Northern Stage, that a company of actors can be as much of a draw as a star name.

How the £37m rescue package will be distributed has yet to be decided, but anyone reading between the lines of Arts Council talk about the need for significant changes in attitudes would conclude that not everyone will be saved. The difference between the situation now and a couple of years ago is that theatres no longer feel that there is a secret agenda to have a limited number of regional theatres survive while the rest go to the wall.

As Evans says, we need a network of regional theatres that support each other by creating a theatre-going culture, not just a few centres of excellence: "If one regional theatre thrives, so will others. If one closes, it threatens others. If you've got leprosy and your hand drops off, it doesn't benefit the rest of the body. It's still dying." But she has a word of warning for the funders: "They should get a grip. After all, they put a huge amount of money in. If we are not producing good work and audiences, then we shouldn't be doing the job and we should be fired. But if we are doing a good job, we should be left to get on with it."

The Crucible previews at the Colchester Mercury from tomorrow. Box office: 01206 573948.

webTitle: Arts: Jonathan Romney: Apocalyptic visions

fields.headline: Loving the alien
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney: Apocalyptic visions
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney: Apocalyptic visions
fields.body:
In Theodore Roszak's 1991 novel Flicker - a wonderfully mind-bending paranoid thriller about cinema history - the future, and the end, of film is discovered in the shape of a teenage auteur called Simon Dunkle. He is the nihilistic genius behind avant-garde horror works such as Insect Anxiety and the apocalyptic Sub Sub, a film said to initiate a new genre, "genocidal farce". Dunkle outdoes even these with The Lonesome Lovesong of the Sad Sewer Babies, a work so disturbing that the novel's narrator deems it not so much a movie as "a kind of optical acid that burns through from the eye straight down into the vital organs".

Flicker proposed the horrifying, yet strangely thrilling, possibility that cinema would soon belong to lawless infant-savants like Simon Dunkle. We haven't really seen one yet - even Harmony Korine seems too benignly cinephilic to qualify. However, I can think of one film-maker who has consistently been disturbing enough to come close to the Dunkle aesthetic, and that is Chris Cunningham, the British music video director whose work features in the Royal Academy's Apocalypse show.

The exhibition's subtitle is Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art, and Cunningham is familiar with both. He has done futuristic beauty in the video for Bjork's All Is Full of Love, with the star playing two auto-erotic porcelain robots. And he has done horror in his videos for Aphex Twin, in which swarms of delinquent brats and siliconed hip-hop molls all wear the distorted features of Aphex mastermind Richard James. These grotesquely comic vignettes are not only the antithesis of MTV-friendly, they are unfriendly, period. And they make you want to see - and shudder at the thought of seeing - a feature film made by this man.

Instead, Cunningham has taken a detour into the art world, and now exhibits at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery. But his 15-minute film, Flex, showing there and in Apocalypse, is surprisingly low-key. A naked man and woman, lit in bilious green, confront each other in darkness, exchange brutal volleys of blows, screw just as convulsively, and finally, coupling in mid-air, are struck by a ray of light that vaporises them. Who would have imagined Cunningham producing romantic abstraction of such a transcendentalist strain?

Flex is less disturbing than it seems on paper - a coupling of brutality and beauty. What makes it transcend the apparent banality of its topic is the execution, the meticulous sound design and machine-gun editing. It's a work to be heard and felt as much as seen.

Cunningham began as a teenage special-effects expert, working on Alien 3 and Stanley Kubrick's abortive AI project. He is not alone: sculptor Ron Mueck was a movie animatronics specialist (he also worked on Alien 3), and he too is currently at Anthony d'Offay with his waxily lifelike human figures.

Mueck and Cunningham have moved from what you could patronise as the merely "lifelike" to work that strives to address the human condition. But you shouldn't dismiss the visceral impetus of effects work. The purest example I ever saw was a stall at a Spanish horror film festival. It was laden with hundreds of latex horror models - all gouged eyes, severed limbs, ripped bellies disgorging rubbery entrails. You fairly retched to look at them, but you could hardly take your eyes away.

We usually expect art proper to demand a more complex reaction than that, but in fact one work in the Apocalypse exhibition made me react quite similarly to the Spanish atrocity exhibition - Hell, Jake and Dinos Chapman's Holocaust installation. However repelled I felt, I couldn't stop peering at it; yet that fascination stood in the way of any coherent critical reaction to it.

At Apocalypse, Chris Cunningham and Jake and Dinos have somehow reversed career paths. The former sci-fi robotics nerd has moved away from pure effect into a more contemplative, impressionistic realm. Meanwhile, the Chapmans have reverted to teenage special-effects artists with their meticulously constructed Airfix landscape of horror. Hell, their very own "genocidal farce", makes them the true Simon Dunkles.

Chris Cunningham and Ron Mueck are at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery, W1 (020-7499 4100) till October 17. Apocalypse is at the Royal Academy, W1 (020-7300 8000) till December 15.

webTitle: Arts: Blues legends 15-60-75

fields.headline: Prime numbers
fields.standfirst: Tonight  David Thomas of Pere Ubu shares the bill with blues legends 15-60-75. Here he explains why this is so thrilling
fields.trailText: Tonight David Thomas of Pere Ubu shares the bill with blues legends 15-60-75. Here he explains why this is so thrilling.
fields.body:
Robert Kidney lives in a cemetery. He rents a two-room bungalow. Over the years its porch got turned into a kitchen, but with a ceiling so low that tall people are forced to duck down to walk through it. On the worktop by the door is a wide, deep wooden bowl brimming over with sunglasses.

Inside, the biggest room is dedicated to yards of suits and stacks of paintings - Robert paints canvases and he paints houses, the latter to make a living. The last, and smallest, room in the bungalow contains everything else associated with having a house: a sofa-bed, a desk and one chair, a few records and tapes, some shelves of books - nearly all of them about the blues and their place in American culture. There's a guitar and a painting, and though both a man and a woman live here, there is nothing that is not hard and dedicated to the cold eye. Nothing is out of balance. Nothing serves as a distraction. Here lives a man who walks a narrow road with an utterly medieval sense of mortality. Which is as well, since one of Robert Kidney's kidneys failed 10 years ago, and now his other kidney barely copes, and when he speaks to you it's like the Icelanders do, up close, too close, with his eyes locked on to yours past the bounds of anything that might be called comfortable. There is no time to waste.

Robert Kidney is the guitarist/ singer/leader of a band called 15-60-75. It's a blues band. Of a sort. But where the guardians of the form have starved it of innovation, 15-60-75 nurtured abstract evolution. They play blues reimbued with meaning, purged and purified by flame, shorn of every superfluous moment, sound or word.

Because their songs are compiled across a series of markers - words, sounds, phrases and pauses - they don't count measures and can't outline the structure of their songs to an outsider. For the blues, a form routinely approached as a compendium of formulas, this is startling, and it means that any change of personnel necessitates months of not just relearning but rewriting every song. It is a methodology from another planet - Don Van Vliet and Sun Ra come to mind. It is form dedicated to vision.

The band are from Kent, Ohio, a small college town 40 miles south of Cleveland. In 1970, on the campus of Kent State University, four students were killed by National Guardsmen during a demonstration against the Vietnam war. Neil Young wrote a song about it. Robert Kidney started a band, and for its name chose a set of numbers with numerological significance, but he also chose numbers to suggest Orwellian political darkness. Later, somebody in the band noticed that those numbers described a 1-4-5 ratio which happens to be the progression on which the blues are based, and so the group are also called the Numbers.

Seeing 15-60-75 for the first time in a honky-tonk on Water Street, on the other side of the railroad tracks and next to the grain silos, where for most of the last three decades they have played four sets a night, four nights a week - seeing them there is like staring into a last chrome flash of that Old America of Thoreau and Kerouac, Harry Partch and John Coltrane, Mark Twain and Robert Johnson... and rock music.

"The first time I saw them my hair stood on end," says Chris Cutler, veteran of British progressive music. "You have to go to a small city in America to see a band with this much intensity."

It's an intensity, a fire from inside that they have sustained in obscurity, without regard to reward or praise or even appreciation.

Tales of their bad luck and misfortune are breathtaking, and watching them bleed their lives away some night, playing in front of an utterly uninterested lounge crowd at a Holiday Inn that some booking agent thought would be a good idea, cauterises any doubts. And yet the core of the group today is as it has been for 30 years - Robert, brother Jack Kidney (harp and sax) and Terry Hynde (sax). And it is a mark of the respect they engender in their fans and fellow musicians that Terry has a younger sister, Chrissie, who must, in northern Ohio at least, forever labour in his shadow.

15-60-75 are at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), tonight. Their first album, Jimmy Bell's Still in Town, has been reissued on Pere Ubu's Hearpen label.

webTitle: TV guide: Court circular

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Welcome to a special 80s has-been Court Circular this week, featuring two of the most desperate cases you could ever find in legalistic strife. Kicking off the action is 80s has-been TV actor Jan-Michael Vincent, the former Airwolf star whose life since the demise of said show has routinely made supermarket tabloid headlines. And now he's finally wound up inside, after being sentenced to 60 days in an Orange County, California lock-up for repeated probation violations, culminating in an argument with his wife which led to "pushing and hair-pulling". Regular readers of this column may already be aware of the hapless Vincent's troubled history, dating back - at least - to 1996, with an arrest for drunk-driving following a car crash that left him partially paralysed; since then, the erstwhile pin-up has been arrested three times this year alone, on one occasion being discovered by police rolling around in the grass in Santa Monica with over three times the legal blood-alcohol limit coursing through his veins. Currently in rehab, Vincent's jail sentence begins later this week, after which he's to return to the clinic on an indefinite basis.

And then there's 80s has-been rock star Rick Springfield, whose career after the global smash hit that was Jesse's Girl has followed a similar trajectory to our friend Jan-Michael, right down to his arrest in Malibu last week for spousal assault. Springfield's run-in with the law came after a heated domestic argument was overheard by his sister-in-law, who then called 911; although the ruckus later subsided, police nonetheless turned up at the singer's house and - upon noticing "minor injuries" to his wife's face - took him down for an evening in LA County Jail. After posting $50,000 bail, he was released pending the District Attorney's decision over whether to press charges...

And now he's finally wound up inside, after being sentenced to 60 days in an Orange County, California lock-up for repeated probation violations, culminating in an argument with his wife which led to "pushing and hair-pulling". Regular readers of this column may already be aware of the hapless Vincent's troubled history, dating back - at least - to 1996, with an arrest for drunk-driving following a car crash that left him partially paralysed; since then, the erstwhile pin-up has been arrested three times this year alone, on one occasion being discovered by police rolling around in the grass in Santa Monica with over three times the legal blood-alcohol limit coursing through his veins. Currently in rehab, Vincent's jail sentence begins later this week, after which he's to return to the clinic on an indefinite basis. And then there's 80s has-been rock star Rick Springfield, whose career after the global smash hit that was Jesse's Girl has followed a similar trajectory to our friend Jan-Michael, right down to his arrest in Malibu last week for spousal assault. Springfield's run-in with the law came after a heated domestic argument was overheard by his sister-in-law, who then called 911; although the ruckus later subsided, police nonetheless turned up at the singer's house and - upon noticing "minor injuries" to his wife's face - took him down for an evening in LA County Jail. After posting $50,000 bail, he was released pending the District Attorney's decision over whether to press charges...

webTitle: TV guide: Plug Me In

fields.headline: The best possible taste
fields.standfirst: In the 70s, cinema pornography seemed to be finding its way into the mainstream. Then the advent of video dragged it back underground. So why is the band Add N To (X) trying to rescue its reputation? By  Phelim O'Neill
fields.trailText: In the 70s, cinema pornography seemed to be finding its way into the mainstream. Then the advent of video dragged it back underground. So why is the band Add N To (X) trying to rescue its reputation?
fields.body:
Technology ruined hardcore pornography. Back in the 70s, with films like Deep Throat and The Devil In Miss Jones, porn almost became an art form, achieving unexpected acceptability in mainstream circles. These were "proper" films, shown in proper cinemas to chic young couples and doing proper business at the box office.

Then came the video revolution and adult films moved into the home - all well and good, but besides giving porn consumers the freedom to enjoy their wares in private, video also gave unscrupulous filmmakers a licence to print money. Gone were any pretensions to art, and plot - already rudimentary at best - went out the window when the industrious video pornographer discovered he could churn out up to 15 titles in three days. The cheaper the product, the nastier it became. To paraphrase Spinal Tap: it was sex, yes. Sexy, no.

Meanwhile, video had a similar impact on the music industry, quickly becoming the most important tool in every band's marketing campaign. But although the two genres have partially intertwined, with softcore imagery now saturating the screen, the supposed wilder elements of the rock'n'roll sector have been loathe to take it further. In America, chart-friendly rockers such as Blink 182 and The Bloodhound Gang regularly use well known faces (or bodies) from adult films in their videos and album sleeves to increase their fratboy kudos, while in the world of hip-hop, porn stars regularly outnumber the rappers. So far, so much affectation.

Their bluff has now been called by electronic band Add N To (X), the first band to put their money where their mouth is, with a no-holds-barred 50-minute adult opus called Plug Me In. But how does their product differ from the rest? "The idea was to make a porn film that we actually wanted to see", explains frontman Barry 7. "Hardcore pornography is incredibly boring. The music is boring, they're deathly dull and often quite disturbing to look at. On the other hand," he shudders, "there's 'artporn', which comes loaded with horrifically obvious metaphors - which we didn't like either. What we wanted was a pure sex film."

And Plug Me In certainly does look different from most adult films. The action - if that's the word - concerns two women exploring each other's bodies, employing a dizzying array of sex toys. "Having only women in the video gave us a broader scope", says 7. "Female sexuality is very lateral and male sexuality is very linear. Men don't need a lot of detail - they just want the action."

To get a suitably intimate look, the band used small surveillance cameras and attached them to the models. "It subverts their use", says 7. "This ties in with the whole Big Brother thing, which I think is just dishonest pornography. It simply shows people's misery without revealing anything true about them." Though the rest of the film is shot in a variety of styles and formats, it's the footage shot from the participants' point of view - fluid and detail-obsessed - that grabs the eye. And since porn is an intrinsically voyeuristic medium, the closed-circuit style successfully draws you closer.

Meanwhile, the problem of the porn soundtrack has been addressed too. The non-specific groaning and Bontempi sleaze has been replaced with what a typically cryptic 7 calls "sexual musique concrète ". But though the finished product certainly has its merits, aren't there certain moral questions to be answered? "The only time myself and co-director Jonathan Benton-Hughes had any doubts were at the casting stage", says 7. "We were presented with videos of quite young - though of legal age - girls being coaxed into doing things they obviously didn't want to do. Because porn has been pushed underground, it does attract a lot of unsavoury folk, and we were guilty of believing many of the publicly perceived prejudices. But when you get involved with the models you realise that these aren't damaged or exploited people. The women we used loved sex and were completely open about it. They knew exactly how far they were prepared to go, and your preconceptions fly out the window."

Currently in the final editing stages, the film should be available by December, when it will be released under the new and troublesome (at least to Jack Straw) Restricted 18 certificate, which allows adult material to be sold in licensed sex shops. Keeping out of the usual HMV/Virgin music outlets should create some distance from the argument that this is just some muso dilettante's publicity stunt.

"If you see the film, that much is obvious", says 7. "It's not meant to outrage anyone. We just wanted to make a no-bullshit sex film. Any intelligence is the result of having the cameras controlled by the women involved. To be honest, they were the directors." The video will be followed by adverts in the sex press and a hardcore trailer that 7 hopes will be shown on the Internet and on cable in Europe and America. "With discarded porn mags in the park providing sex education for most people in this country," says 7, "that can only be a good thing."

7 doesn't pretend to have all the answers to the questions raised by hardcore porn - but, as far as he's concerned, just posing those questions publicly is sometimes the point. "I'm not interested in debating it", he says. "The deal is, I'll make it so you can debate it for yourself."

webTitle: Today's radio

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play: The Good Samaritan/The Commission
fields.body:
The central figure in Stephen Wakelam's Afternoon Play: The Good Samaritan (2.15pm, Radio 4) is called Spencer, but is really based on a genuine fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge, Frederick Simpson. A historian and cleric, he was renowned for his intellect and notorious for his deep eccentricity. His old friend Canon Eric James helped Wakelam compile this not wholly flattering portrait. Alex McCowen gives a splendid performance as the dotty academic, whose bizarre behaviour always managed to advance his self-interest.

This week's task for The Commission (8.0pm, Radio 4) is to assess and possibly modify the Home Secretary's pro posal that fewer criminal cases should be decided by juries. According to Mr Straw, this could save £120 million a year. After the Dome experience and the reputed cost of the petrol blockade, that sum sounds like small change in the corners of Gordon Brown's coffers. Can it really justify the abandonment of a centuries-old legal safeguard?

webTitle: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean

fields.headline: Wired but tired
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Attachments
fields.body:
Never mind This Life, Attachments (BBC2) is oddly reminiscient of Big Brother. Of the team of bright-ish, young-ish things thrown into a precarious situation, one is a lesbian, one is a skateboarder (admittedly not the same one), one is a lech and one is even duplicitous - stealing another's CV to get a job. They sit around in east London smoking and swearing, they have a webcam in their toilet, and there is plenty of naturalistic camera work. There is even a not-very-good website. There is also some slightly dodgy acting going on. And the latter notwithstanding, the characters who populate the drama will perhaps become like dear friends in the weeks to come. The first episode, however, wasn't a good start.

Following the start-up of seethru.co.uk - which actually exists - it began, rather predictably, with some nudity. First, there's Brandon. He is a Louis Theroux-a-like who skateboards around the office with his bits out. From this, we can assume he is a geeky technical type who is slightly dysfunctional. Then there are Mike and Lucy, the brains behind the website. They lie on top of their duvet in their ersatz Elle Decoration room and are about to make sweet, sweet love when a phone call from the naked Brandon stops them. From this, we can assume they are passionate but businesslike. As the rest of the cast is introduced, we are laboriously spoonfed with little nuggets of their personalities, which could have been happily avoided if they had all worn t-shirts with their main characteristics on them ("lesbian, anti-establishment, crisp-eater", for Sophie, say). Instead, we got a procession as predictable as the nudity of the opening scenes. It's been called "attention-grabbing", but only if you have a very short attention span and don't get out much.

Of course, the nudity is supposed to be "true to life" and no big deal. And of course, it is both. To use it in the opening sequence is hardly cutting edge. The deployment of naked people (who, in a radical move, were all thin and toned and easy on the eye) is a patronising cliché, as if the producers couldn't think of anything else to grab viewers attention. "I know," they must have exclaimed. "Let's get a bit of cock on screen within the first five minutes. That'll catch the audience's eye." Unfortunately, it doesn't really capture the imagination. After all, the target audience for Attachments probably see naked people quite a lot, if only themselves and their partners (in their ersatz Elle Deco bedrooms).

Which isn't to say it all goes downhill after the naked skateboarding. In fact, Attachments shows potential, though it's hard to tell how good it will get. Lucy and Mike's relationship could be ripe for exploration, though only if they stop being quite so nice to each other. Equally, the arrival of the new sales manager, Yvonne, makes watching at least next week compulsory. The CV stealer, her presence is bound to up the ante in the oh-so-trendy office where Reece, the lech, Jake, the gay designer, Sophie and Brandon amble around. As for their relationship, there simply wasn't enough of it on display to make any judgements. For 50 minutes of drama, there wasn't an awful lot happening anywhere. Lucy might have been struggling with whether to join seethru.co.uk as planned or accept a promotion at her old job, Reece might have been anonymously sending Sophie nasty emails and Jake might have lost the entire site's contents, but even with all of that, Attachments still seemed a bit empty and undramatic. Even Joe, the scheming investor, having an embolism in the toilet didn't help matters, nor did the once new protean and naturalistic camerawork, which verged on self-parody.

The This Life comparisons abound; Attachments probably won't match up to the (slightly inflated) opinion of that as a genuinely exciting, groundbreaking series, but hopefully it will develop into a compelling spectacle instead of a rather conspicuous drama-by-numbers set in a groovy environment to appeal to da kids. As it is, it is not as mature or well-written as The Cops - and comparisons with that are inevitable too - nor as populated with genuinely multi-faceted, fleshy characters nor as muscular plots. It is so forced a contemporary drama, it could almost be on Channel 4. While leagues ahead of much of television's dramatic offerings, it is disappointingly underwhelming. Personally, I am hoping for an upgrade.

webTitle: Today's TV

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Man Who Changed His Mind/Shadowlands/Blue Velvet/Kids Return
fields.body:
The Man Who Changed His Mind
(Robert Stevenson, 1936) 1pm, Carlton Cinema

Boris Karloff is a disturbed genius who has invented a machine that can transplant people's minds into different bodies. An attractive young student joins the deranged idealist at his country mansion, where he lives with a bitter, crippled assistant, and when her boyfriend comes to rescue her he finds himself the victim of a body change. Soon, minds are flying and it becomes difficult to remember who's who. Not without a dated charm, though.

Shadowlands
(Richard Attenborough, 1993) 8.45am, Carlton Cinema

Anthony Hopkins does another pent-up middle-class Englishman, impersonating CS Lewis living monk-like at Magdalen College, Oxford, circa 1952. But in breezes the passionate flurry of Debra Winger's American poet Joy Gresham, and son Douglas (Joseph Mazzello), attracted by the don's Narnia tales.

Blue Velvet
(David Lynch, 1986) 10pm, FilmFour

Disturbing, voyeuristic peep at smalltown America, with a Buñuelian sense of the surreal. Kyle MacLachlan is the cherubic young chap whose discovery of a severed ear is an entree into a macabre underworld. The relationship between nightclub singer Isabella Rossellini and Dennis Hopper is gut-churning.

Kids Return
(Takeshi Kitano, 1996) 2.50am, FilmFour This partly autobiographical work of cinema's poetic hardman has two pals back in their old schoolyard, reminiscing about their past. An intriguing, affectionate, but unsentimental insight into the director's early years.

webTitle: What printers are watching on TV...

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What printers are watching on TV...
fields.trailText: What printers are watching on TV...
fields.body:
Len Furnish: "It's a very funny question, I must say. Aren't you going to ask what we log into on the internet? That's a bit more up to date, isn't it? I think TV will be outdone by the net. My children use it all the time, and they don't understand that it's so expensive. TV? Oh yeah. I saw that Martin Clunes programme last night, about him being a murderer. I watched that. What was it like? Rubbish. Insatiable wife person, if you know what I mean. Hmm."

Lloyd Furnish: "Well, you never really see printers on TV because it's not very thrills and spills, you know? The noise might get you. No, we don't print incendiary literature, we print wedding invites and headed notepaper. You can't make much out of that. Well, maybe Mike Leigh, but not telly. I watch Coronation Street because the missus likes it, I watch a bit of motorsport and that sort of thing, football obviously - big Leyton Orient fan. They're not very good!! Hahahaha! Well, they're not."

Derek Benson: "I listen to the radio more than the telly. I like Radio Two, it's very trendy now, well I think it is. It's got Jonathan Ross and Danny Baker on it. I think, or is that the old GLR? Well, it plays a lot of Northern Soul, and I'm a big fan. My dad says it's girls' music, but he doesn't know anything. A friend of mine does Northern Soul DJ nights and he was in Q magazine once. Do you want me to talk about telly? Well I might watch Top Of The Pops 2 but that's about it. Cricket. I don't know, I'm boring."

Julie Critcheley: "I like EastEnders - I think it's brilliant, the storylines are really good and the acting is just so amazing. These are very talented people. I once tried to be an extra and thought I could sit in the Queen Vic drinking, but I got hardly any work and it was all short notice. I got an ad for insurance then I lost interest. The TV programme I would most like to be on, though - Big Brother. Honestly! No, I wouldn't go mad. I'd win the money. I would. And I'd snog Craig (pictured), definitely."

Sin Pattenden spoke to JK Printers, Walthamstow.

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: It is Claire, not Clare, Rayner who is supporting the cause of pensioners, Rattled minister beats retreat etc, page 9, September 26. She has not been an "agony aunt" for a number of years now.
fields.body:
It is Claire, not Clare, Rayner who is supporting the cause of pensioners, Rattled minister beats retreat etc, page 9, September 26. She has not been an "agony aunt" for a number of years now.

In a column, page 20, September 23, we wrote, "Suggesting truth in rumours that one of the shadow cabinet shot an albatross during the summer holidays, the government's bad luck continues." The word "shadow" is an intruder. Shooting an albatross was thought to bring bad luck on the shooter not to the shooter's enemies or opponents (Coleridge: Rime of the Ancient Mariner etc).

The channel between Denmark and Norway is the Skagerrak, not the Skaggerat, as it appeared in a leader, page 17, September 25.

Homophone corner, from a piece headed Britannia is just so uncool etc, page 20, September 22: "...the owner-drivers are forced to cut corners on maintenance or abandon their spare tires so as to carry more freight" [an Americanism perhaps].

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. webTitle: Passnotes: Diane Louise Jordan

fields.headline: No: 1728
fields.standfirst: Diane Louise Jordan
fields.trailText: Diane Louise Jordan
fields.body:
Status: Former Blue Peter host turned Songs of Praise presenter.

Ah, yes, the Beeb's popular God slot. How has Ms Jordan been since she swapped sticky-backed plastic for psalms? Let's just say we're considering stripping her of her Blue Peter badge and privileges.

Praise be! How might she have wronged Auntie to deserve such ignominy? It seems she hasn't been entirely honest. "When I left Blue Peter to present Songs of Praise I thought I should appear to be a Christian, so I faked it," says Jordan. "I was worried that I would be found out."

And now she has. It must be time for BBC1's controller Lorraine Heggessey to come out from behind her executive chair and tell the Songs of Praise audience that she let herself down, she let the BBC down, and, most of all she let you, the viewers down. Not exactly. Since telling her little fib, Jordan has been suitably repentant. In a powerful admission of "here's one I told earlier", she confessed her sin in front of 800 members of the Christian group Alpha that her BBC producer had nagged her to attend.

What did they do? Turn the other cheek? Forgive and forget? They didn't need to. By the time she made her admission, she was a certified convert. "I thought it was a great opportunity to be a good fake Christian. I went along reluctantly but, to my surprise, it was great and I came out the other side a real Christian."

So now she's a firm believer, just like our most recent gold medallist Jonathan Edwards. Maybe she'll start limbering up for the triple jump soon. Not likely. She's too busy promoting courses for Alpha, launching Alpha 2000 in 10 cities across the country, or attending one of the 7,000 courses this month coming to a church near you.

Do say: "Sins of praise."

Don't say: "Thou shalt not tell porkies."

Not to be confused with: Michael Jordan, the model Jordan.

webTitle: BP's Gulf breakthrough

fields.headline: BP's Gulf breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Abu Dhabi stake signals return of Big Oil to the Middle East
fields.trailText: BP is to make a triumphant return to its Persian Gulf roots by buying a financial stake in an arm of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc) . A deal may be signed today.
fields.body:
BP is to make a triumphant return to its Persian Gulf roots by buying a financial stake in an arm of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc) . A deal may be signed today.

The British oil group has agreed to take 14.67% of the Zakhum Development Company from state-owned Adnoc which it established in 1977 to operate offshore oil fields in the Gulf. The stake, analysts say, could yield $700m a year in revenue.

A new company is to be set up early next month to take account of the new shareholding structure which will also see smaller stakes being controlled by TotalFinaElf (13.33%) and Japan Oil Development Company (12%). The remainder will continue to be owned by the Abu Dhabi government.

BP would make no comment but Middle East sources confirmed that a formal agreement was scheduled to be signed in the next couple of days.

It will give Sir John Browne, BP's chief executive, an important stepping stone to fully re-establishing the group as an important player in the oil-rich Middle East.

In the early part of the century BP dominated those parts of the region which were under the protection of the British empire but Big Oil has not been welcome there for a quarter of a century.

In recent years, however, the Abu Dhabi government, like other Gulf states, has been keen to find ways of squeezing more oil out of its assets and improving the industry's operating efficiency.

Adnoc restructured itself last year, splitting into six divisions, and is looking at amalgamating its two other subsidiaries, Abu Dhabi Operating Company and Abu Dhabi Marine Operating Company. BP has held small stakes in them since 1978 and 1977 respectively.

Other big oil producing nations such as Saudi Arabia, Iran and Kuwait have also been looking at ways of harnessing western technology and financial muscle to help them increase output.

The move to let one of the top three oil groups in the world take a holding in a company that produces 450,000 barrels of oil a day is not worth large amounts of money but it has considerable political significance and is the biggest sign yet that Middle East countries are not only willing to deal with western capital but also allow it to take ownership interests again.

Sir John and all his counterparts have been in Saudi Arabia recently at the government's invitation to look at ways of developing its gas fields, but the lifeblood of the Saudi economy - its oil exploration and production - will continue to remain off limits to foreign companies.

BP has also been shortlisted by Kuwait to bid for projects to operate northern fields along the border with Iraq. This move comes after it signed a technical services agreement following its liberation from Iraq in 1991.

BP said last month it was preparing a bid for Iran's huge Bangestan oil development in the Khuzestan province, hoping to take advantage of better relations between the US and Iran. Until now BP has concentrated its exploration and development efforts on areas such as the US Gulf and the Caspian sea, but the industry is aware the truly enormous reserves that can be exploited cheaply lie in the Gulf.

The British oil group has enormous financial fire power at present on the back of very strong crude prices. Last night BP shares ended up 5.5p at 600.5p.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone may have left the Labour party, but his legacy continues to cause all sorts of trouble. The tense battle for his old parliamentary seat in Brent East has reached boiling point.
fields.body:
 Ken Livingstone may have left the Labour party, but his legacy continues to cause all sorts of trouble. The tense battle for his old parliamentary seat in Brent East has reached boiling point between supporters of the two front-runners, GMB union president Mary Turner and the Blairite Brent council leader Paul Daisley (although the CWU's Gerry Ryan and NEC member Shahid Malik also have their hats in the ring). One issue is 100 applications for postal votes (out of 600 eligible voters) which have been thrown out by the local party executive. The whole matter was kicked upstairs to the Greater London party organisation, who have sat on it for two weeks. But the latest move is that the party is likely to take the dramatic step of suspending the entire selection process - which could lead to the national executive imposing its chosen candidate on the electorate.

 Some people already think the expanded Olympics in Sydney are a few events too far. I mean, synchronised diving? Not so in India, where a 2,780-member group is pushing to get a new event in the 2004 games - snake charming. The group, known as the Coalition for Inclusion of Reptilian Gymnastics in Olympic Competition, say the Olympics are biased towards sports in which US and European athletes excel. In India, they say, snake charming is seen as a sport and entrants are judged on "the grace and agility of the cobras as they sway to the music the competitors play". I'm not sure how the drugs testing would work, though.

 There are some people whose names mean they are born to do a certain job. Like James Whitehouse, the BBC Washington correspondent. But the best of these has to be Wolfgang Wolf, coach of the German premier league football team Wolfsburg. All that's needed to make it perfect is if the players nicknamed him "Wolfie", in the tradition of footballers going straight for the bleedin' obvious. But no, according to the club's PR officer, Miriam Herzberg, that's reserved for the club's mascot, which (unsurprisingly) is a wolf. So, do the fans call him the Wolfman? "No." Wolfmeister? "No. He really doesn't have a nickname." There's only one thing for it: a move to Wolverhampton Wanderers and the predictability of English football fans.

 This Diary's commitment to accuracy is legendary (and not, as some say, mythical), and so I'm delighted to be able to clear up some confusion surrounding Sir Michael Caine's visit to the Bilbao Guggenheim art gallery on Sunday. The gallery was open (it is only closed on Monday), but that self- proclaimed working-class icon Sir Michael was given a VIP tour around parts of the gallery which are normally closed to the public.

 Here's another correction, but one that should be in the Daily Express. On Monday its readers were warned (you may recall) not to eat poisonous yew berries, after being told on Saturday that yew berries were "sweet-tasting". But reader Myles Yorke calls to say he has eaten yew berries and lived. The poisonous bit is the cyanide-laden seed in the middle. Myles has even made yew berry jam (his top tip: be sure to use a fruit sugar with pectin or fructose when cooking the jam). "It probably shouldn't be tried though," says Myles. And if Express readers start dropping dead, we'll know why.

 Speaking of jam, another contender for most exciting press release of the year pops up, announcing that October 30 is the start of National Toast Week. According to the release, "noted psychologist and author" Dr Pam Spurr will provide "expert analysis on the art of toast making, scraping and spreading". Next week we hope to talk to Dr Pam about the psychology of toast making, especially Freud's famous Anchovy complex.

webTitle: Nuclear rivals to test fire missiles

fields.headline: Nuclear rivals to test fire missiles
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: The nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan took a dangerous twist last night after both sides pledged to test fire their latest intercontinental ballistic missiles "soon".
fields.byline: Luke Harding  in New Delhi and Rory McCarthy in Islamabad
fields.body:
The nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan took a dangerous twist last night after both sides pledged to test fire their latest intercontinental ballistic missiles "soon".

Pakistan's leading nuclear scientist, Abdul Khan, said his country was in a position to "hit almost all the major Indian cities" and had a "stockpile of missiles and atom bombs".

They include Shaheen-II, a missile with a 1,550-mile range, capable of striking deep into southern India. "It is ready for testing. We are waiting for orders only," he said.

His comments followed a claim by the Indian defence minister, George Fernandes, that New Delhi's newest intercontinental weapon, Agni III, would be test fired "sooner than expected".

The missile, which has a range of more than 1,860 miles, enough to reach targets in central China, had almost completed the development stage, he said.

The international community imposed sanctions on India and Pakistan after they carried out tit for tat nuclear tests in 1998.

During a visit to Washington last week, India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said that New Delhi would exercise nuclear restraint. But it has refused to sign up to the comprehensive test ban treaty.

India is about to sign a $3bn (£2bn) arms deal with Russia during a visit to New Delhi by President Vladimir Putin next week. It is poised to buy a Russian aircraft carrier, several squadrons of Su-30 MKI aircraft and 310 T-90 tanks.

The deal is part of a massive arms buying spree by India following last year's escalation of the Kashmir conflict with Pakistan. The Indian government is expected to confirm on October 8 the purchase of 60-80 Hawk jets from Britain.

"You are seeing a further escalation in the arms race between India and Pakistan. The race has acquired a particularly dangerous dimension because both countries have passed the nuclear threshold," an Indian nuclear analyst, Praful Bidwai, said last night.

"Naturally, there is a lot of grandstanding and extravagant claims. But the situation is very, very dangerous. We appear to be slipping into a new circle of rivalry."

Most defence experts believe Pakistan's nuclear programme is now more advanced than India's - though its conventional army is much smaller. According to US intelligence and military sources, Pakistan has stockpiled a "substantially larger" nuclear and missile arsenal because of help from China and North Korea.

India defended its nuclear tests two years ago by pointing to a Chinese nuclear threat.

Pakistan increased defence spending by 11% this year to £2bn. Defence expenditure in India rose by 28% to £8.4bn.

"This rhetoric and aggressive posturing probably has to do with the fact that the India-Pakistan relationship is really in very, very bad shape," said Rifaat Hussein, professor of political science at Islamabad's Quaid-I-Azam university.

webTitle: At this price?  London & Edinburgh

fields.headline: At this price?  London & Edinburgh
fields.trailText: Four years after floating, London & Edinburgh Publishing is to change its name. Publishing, after all, is a rather old fashioned word conjuring up images of dusty old men in a dusty old business.
fields.body:
Four years after floating, London & Edinburgh Publishing is to change its name. Publishing, after all, is a rather old fashioned word conjuring up images of dusty old men in a dusty old business.

Also, London and Edinburgh may be modern cities but they are more suggestive of the British Isles than the global interests of the new-media age.

London & Edinburgh's recent acquisition of Profile Pursuit Group has prompted the naming plans. It will become Profile Media Group, "to reflect more accurately the group's activities and its development into a broader-based media and communications group". The group said it would explore opportunities to enhance existing activities and investigate potential acquisitions.

Profile Pursuit Group was set up to exploit a niche market: bespoke publications for companies with large, dispersed networks of customers or staff. Revenue was raised from advertising the publications attracted.

The April acquisition gave London & Edinburgh a big US presence which, combined with strong organic growth, underlay its record first-half results, the firm said. It posted a pre-tax profit of £1.85m to the end of June, compared to £795,827 a year ago. It also reported a trading profit before tax and goodwill amortisation of £2.22m, up from £490,000. Turnover rose to £9.23m from £2.33m.

London & Edinburgh has grown since its flotation in 1996. Last year it bought the Good Ski Guide's title and assets and reaped instant rewards from buying PPG.

Deputy chairman David Ellingham said: "We are very much a niche publisher, but we have £5m in the bank and we are a cash-generative business, so we want to make sizeable acquisitions."

He declined to say whether they would be in the US, but the new nomenclature points to international growth.

The shares closed 1.75p down to 50.75p. Wait and see before investing.

webTitle: Business: news in brief

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Go Ahead wins 17% pay rise
fields.body:
Go Ahead wins 17% pay rise

Directors at transport group Go Ahead, operator of the Thames Trains franchise involved in the Paddington crash, have received salaries totalling £760,000 - a 17% rise on the previous year, it emerged yesterday.

The group's report and accounts show that eight directors of the firm took home £760,000 for the 12 months to July 1, up from £650,000 last time.

House prices falling fast

House prices are falling at their fastest rate for five years, with the south-east bearing the brunt of the slowdown, estate agents said yesterday.

In the north of England and Wales many areas are still seeing prices rising, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. The market was stabilising after the upheavals of past months, RICS chief economist Milan Khatri said.

£350,000 fine for Nomura

The City regulator yesterday handed out its second-largest fine, to Nomura, severely reprimanding the Japanese institution and prohibiting one of its former executives from working in the City.

Another former executive was fined £60,000, the second-largest penalty imposed on an individual. The securities and futures authority, the regulator which levied the £350,000 fine and £122,944 in costs on Nomura, said the penalty related to improper trading activities executed from London on the Australian stock market in 1996.

The regulator said it had expelled Robert Mapstone from its register of directors and representatives and required the former co-head of its equity division to pay £60,000 towards costs. Gary Channon, head of equity derivatives trading, was severely reprimanded, ordered to pay a fine of £60,000 and contribute £20,000 towards costs.

Regus listing to raise £320m

Regus, the world's largest serviced office group, said yesterday it would list on the London Stock Exchange and Nasdaq in an offering that would value it at up to £1.6bn.

It said it would raise £237-320m through an offer of 118.5m ordinary shares, including American depositary shares, at 200-270p each.

Regus abandoned plans to list a year ago after investors questioned its expansion plans and valuation, and asked to see another year of trading before giving approval.

webTitle: Tycoon mulls Sotheby's stake sale

fields.headline: Tycoon mulls Sotheby's stake sale
fields.trailText: Former Sotheby's boss Alfred Taubman is considering selling his entire controlling stake in the auction house to help fund his £130m contribution towards legal settlements with the scandal-hit company's customers and shareholders.
fields.body:
Former Sotheby's boss Alfred Taubman is considering selling his entire controlling stake in the auction house to help fund his £130m contribution towards legal settlements with the scandal-hit company's customers and shareholders.

He is footing much of the bill to compensate victims of the auction house's alleged price-fixing racket with rival group Christie's. He is awaiting the outcome of a US department of justice investigation into the affair, and he could yet face criminal charges.

However, the hefty payment is unlikely to bankrupt the 75-year-old American entrepreneur - Forbes magazine recently estimated his wealth at $720m (£493m).

A former construction contractor, Mr Taubman has made his fortune from building shopping centres throughout the US. He founded his property development business, the Taubman Company, with a $5,000 loan in 1950. It is now valued at nearly $600m on the New York Stock Exchange.

Based in Detroit, Mr Taubman has made a series of high-profile endowments in the US and been dubbed a "serial building namer". His name has been immortalised at organisations such as the Taubman Health Care Center, the Taubman Medical Library, the Taubman Center for Public Policy and the Taubman College of Architecture.

His recent $30m gift to one such institute was criticised by the writer Arianna Huffington, who said: "If Taubman likes his name so much, it would be helpful if he gave 3,000 homeless people $10,000 a piece to simply change their names to Taubman."

Mr Taubman's company has been credited with changing the way shopping centres are designed throughout America.
